column2: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that the Transit Authority had contracted to spend only 10 per cent of a 1967 bond issue authorization of $600-million for new construction and that project costs had doubled in the meantime.

OF all the strange paradoxes and perversities that dot France's cultural history, the phenomenon of Grand Opera as it developed in the mid-19th century is one of the most peculiar. Paris was the operatic center of the world at the time-a triumph at the Opera was the ultimate goal any composer could hope for.
Representative Mario Biaggi yesterday announced his opposition to the $315-billion transportation bond issue, and called an the other mayoral candidates to make a more intensive study of the issue.

KIT, 25, wearing blue jeans, a T-shirt and a panama hat, drives the big Buick sedan across the prairies towards Montana. Beside him on the front seat is Holly, 15, who is on the verge of being pretty though she still looks something like a cookie that hasn't yet been baked.
For nearly a quarter of a century Paul Robeson's name has been a great whisper and a greater silence in black America.

ITS always satisfying in the theater to find yourself a little bit outsmarted. Neat the end of "The Father," Strindberg's apostrophe to the female as praying mantis and the male as all too obliging victim, the generally fine company assembled at the Roundabout Theater strikes a tableau.
A rush-hour. subway train in Brooklyn still feels like "the sardine can special," yet the number of Brooklyn riders a week has declined by more than a million in the last decade.

Robert Jackson, lawyer and mining company officer, who served as secretary of the National Democratic Committee from 1932 to 1934, died Friday in New York Hospital. He was 93 years old and lived in Littleton, N. H.

It's almost as hard to find a dress for the daylight hours as it is to find a good cup of coffee. But there's one fashion that could fit into almost everybody's wardrobe-the tent dress. It's cut with a flare that lets you move (and conceals bulges) and it looks right all day long. The tent dress may be the "old faithful" of the winter season.

In the minds of many, the New York area is a land of apartment buildings. They seem to blanket Manhattan, loom over Queens and even march up the New Jersey Palisades. Yet population density within a 20mile radius of the Empire State Building is less than two-thirds that of Paris. Why? Because New York is not so much a mountain range of high-rises as it is a vast scrub forest of one- and two-family homes.

Angelo DeCarlo, a one-time powerful Mafia leader who was granted executive clemency by President Nixon last Christmas because he was suffering froth terminal cancer, died yesterday at his home in Mountainside, N. J. He was 71 years old.

METUCHEN -- Collectors bf railroad memorabilia will meet here next Saturday to buy, sell and trade their wares. The. ..Railroadiana Bourse, as 'it is known, will be held from 9. A.M. to 6 P.M. at the Holiday Inn, which is situated at the junction of U.S. 1 South and 1-287.

The United Mine Workers Welfare and Retirement Fund has reported that record benefits of nearly's quarter billion dollars are being paid to soft coal miners and their families.

Charles O. Finley insists he war right in trying to replace Mike Andrews on the Oakland Athletics baseball team.
On a day in which all the dramatic elements that make horse racing merged, Step Nicely yesterday won the Aqueduct race named for Winston Churchill's grandfather-the Jerome Handicap.

To the Editor: Prof. Milton Friedman's proposal ("The voucher idea," Sept. 23) to turn over the education of our children to private enterprise, which would sell schooling like groceries in return for Government-supplied money vouchers from each family, has, paradoxically, great appeal but little merit.

To the Financial Editor: Gerd Wilcke's article on the fertilizer shortage ("Pro. fit and Pinch in Fertilizers," Oct. 7) quotes key executives of several producing companies who foresee a longlasting world shortage of fertilizer and fertilizer raw materials,
National School Lunch Week has come and gone and for the third school year in a row there still are no lunches being served to this city's 20,000 pupils.

Unbeaten Alabama exploded for three touchdowns in the fourth quarter and beat Tennessee, 42-21, today in an impressive performance that could push the Crimson Tide into the No. 1 spot in college football.
It was a warm and bright picnic day in Old Greenwich, Conn., last Sunday for the ninth annual model sailboat regatta at Binney Pond.

The Black Theater Alliance Festival, designed to serve as a showcase for black theater talent, will get under way at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Oct. 31 with a performance by the Afro-American Studio Theater.

Two persons were killed and 10 others were injured late Friday night when gas fumes from a coal furnace rushed through an apartment building in the Bronx.
Princeton followed Coach Bob Casciola's pregame plan to the letter today and the Tiger football team upset Colgate. 37-21

The Chilean military authorities today ordered the expulsion of thee foreign priests. The priests-two Spaniards and a Frenchman-had been engaged in "extremist activities," according to official sources. They were also said to have resisted the military.
With all the imperturbability of an unchallenged monarch, George Meany blithely returned last week to the starting point of a 360-degree turn around the national political circuit.

Elliot L. Richardson resigned as Attorney General of the United States as President Nixon dismissed the special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, and Deputy Attorney General William D. Ruckelshaus for refusing to obey-his orders on the handling of the White House tapes.

Dr. Alfred Gellhorn, dean of the University of Pennsylvania School of Medicine and director of the Medical Center there, has been named the first director of City College's Center for Biomedical Education.
Miss Suominen and Charles E. Summerall, graduates of Syracuse University, were married here this morning in St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. T. Carleton Lee.

Mrs. H. H. Kung, sister-in-law of Chiang Kai-shek, the president of Nationalist China, died here last night after a lengthy stay at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital for an undisclosed illness. She was 85 years old.

The theft of 19 carved ivory figurines said to be worth $250,000 was reported to the police yesterday. The owner of the figurines was identifed as Mrs. Florence Rosenfeld of 785 Fifth Avenue, near 60th Street. According to the police, Mrs. Rosenfeld had packed a collection of 24 figurines Thursday for shipment to a bonded warehouse, but the warehouse said that only five figurines were received.

NUTLEY-A street-paving controversy between Nutley's Public Works Department and residents of The Enclosure, a former artists' colony, seems destined to end in a compromise.

A weekend trip to Montreal, complete with Gallic atmosphere and superb cuisine, is a cheap and convenient alternative to the rising prices of Paris.

DETROIT - In the office of Loren R. Papenguth in the executive headquarters of the Cadillac Division of The General Motors Corporation, little things hint at what kind of man the occupant is. A spare, oval table serves as a desk.

LITTLE Sammy is small, but ... oh, my! When 5-foot-3-inch Sammy Davis Jr. is at work, big men bow low. His talent makes him boss. He can treat people like punching bags, because if stars were nice guys how would you know they were stars?

" Rigoletto," in the form of the sometimes illogically designed but always theatrically vivid production of Frank Corsaro and Lloyd Evans, reentered the repertory of the New York City Opera Friday night.
Miss Laurie Enid-Polk Grenley, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Grenley, was married here this afternoon to John Hallen, a corporate bond trader with Weeden Co:, Inc., in New York.

WASHINGTON - Vitamins are potent, mysterious, necessary and easily provided in pill form. People have died from lack of one or another essential vitamin even though their diet was above the starvation level in other-respects.
A wealthy Princeton matron, a Democrat who was a leader in Senator George McGovern's campaign in New Jersey last year, is involved in another underdog race: her own campaign for the State Senate.

The Soviet Union disclosed today that the world's first nuclear reactor within the Arctic Circle was now supplying millions of kilowatt-hours of electricity each month to the under-developed polar regions around Murmansk.

The great showman Phineas Taylor Barnum (1810-91) mastered so well the art of deviousness that he might be known today as the high priest of radical chicanery, but to friend and enemy he was known as a charlatan, trickster, bamboozler and humbug.
The Oakland A's will try to win the championship of the baseball world today with a line-up that has not played in any of its previous 173 games this year.

WATER MILL, L. I.-"It's really just a novelty, but we thought the kids would enjoy it." And so, last October, the Raymond Halseys opened a field behind their Green Thumb farm stand here for people to pick their own pumpkins. Success prompted a repeat of the venture this year.
Pat Haden threw for two touchdowns and ran for another, guiding the u?? en Southern California Trojans over Oregon, 31-10, today in a Pacific-8 Conference football game.

The Bryn Mawr Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Shirley Brewster Davis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Newlin Fell Davis of Haverford, to Courtlandt Devereux Gross, who is with White, Weld Co., investment bankers in New York.

Was Booker T. Washington an asset or liability to black people? The role of Washington, founder and president of Tuskegee Institute in 1881, to some a "virtual dictator of Negro America," and to others a "super- efficient fund - raising machine," was. "reconsidered" yesterday during a workshop session of the Association for the Study of Afro-American Life and History.
The two chief commanders of the Israeli offensive in Egypt spoke with exuberant confidence .today of the progress of the campaign and predicted a speedy end to the war.
It took Dartmouth's football team 14 minutes 57 seconds to make a first down against Brown today. But once it discovered how it was done, the Big Green had no difficulty subduing the Bruins, 28-16.

AKRON, Ohio-After years of proven service in Europe, the radial tire is coming of age in America. More cars are rolling off factory assembly lines equipped with various types of radial tires, and the radials' share of the replacement tire market also is increasing.

MORRISTOWN-As every television watcher knows, most hospital lobbies are bleak pacing places in which nervous people derive what comfort they can from dogeared magazines, nondescript chairs and plastic plants.

Ed Powers, quarterback, connected on a 9-yard scoring pass to Richard Maake, a flanker, as C. W. Post College came from behind to defeat Kings Point, 24-23, in a Metropolitan Intercollegiate Football Conference game. The victory was Post's fifth in six games. Kings Point has a 3-3, won-lost record.

ARDENERS are aware of differences in cold hardiness among various plants.Tomatoes, squash and marigolds turn black after the first frost. Cabbage, carrots and snapdragon are not harmed by light frosts, but succumb to a hard freeze. Some plants Much as maple, fir and juniper colerate-50, or even colder.

The Capital Bullets, a team with a new name, a new home and a new coach, will play the Knicks at Madison Square Garden at 7:30 P. M. on Tuesday. The club, formerly the Baltime Bullets, is playing its home game at the University of Maryland until a new arena at Largo, Md., is completed. K. C. Jones, the former Boston Celtic star, became coach when Gene Shue resigned to go to Philadelphia.

Two goals by Larry Romanchych at right wing, led the Atlanta Flames to a 4-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight. The victory was the second National Hockey League upset in a row for the Flames. They beat the Boston Bruins, 4-3, Wednesday night.

Jack Benny, invited to throw out the first ball at today's World Series game, tried to keep it instead. The comedian, who made a fortune out of posing as a cheapskate, faked a toss to the A's catcher, Gene Tenace, then put the ball in his coat pocket and sat down.

Giuseppe Campora, the Italian tenor, has been singing in and around New York now and then for nearly 20 years. But it was not until Sunday night that he made his unscheduled debut with the New York City Opera, taking over the part of Des Grieux from an indisposed Jose Carreras in the season's first "Manon."

Kevin O'Sullivan, president of Worldvision Enterprises, a company engaged in television program syndication, has called a meeting on Oct. 31 with the heads of 11 other major distribution companies to consider taking action against what he termed "the blacklisting and graylisting of television series."

Both Iraq and the Palestinian resistance movement today rejected the cease-fire called for by the United Nations Security Council and accepted by Israel and Egypt. The rejections did not come as a surprise and they are not
Mrs. Helen Hicks Healy, who had helped her husband, Edward M. Healy, run Camp Androscoggin, Wayne, Me., where many New York boys went, died Sunday at her home in Wayne. Her age was 73.
Separate plans to shore up New York's sagging theater district were put forward yesterday by two of the mayoral candidates.

For the last five years, the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity has presented a series of Bach cantatas as part of its regular Sunday vesper service, closely duplicating the way Bach himself performed the cantatas, week by week, at Leipzig's St. Thomas Church.

Brendan T. Byrne, who has stressed "integrity in government" and his own experience in law enforcement in his campaign for election as New Jersey's Governor, called today for stronger criminal penalties for public officials convicted of bribery and extortion.

Three men were killed and a fourth was critically injured yesterday when their car skidded out of control and slammed into a tree, the state police said. The driver, George Killpatrick, 22 years old, of Fulton, was accused of driving while intoxicated and speeding.

Neither victory parades nor crocodile tears greeted the New York Mets early yesterday when they returned home from their long journey to the National League pennant and their final setback in the seventh game of the World Series.
Standing and cheering, delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention here voted today to ask President Nixon to resign and to demand his impeachment if he did not.

Administration officials said today that in the wake of the Middle East cease-fire resolution, they expected Washington and Moscow to take the lead in coming weeks in trying to prod the warring countries into negotiating a political settlement of the longstanding Israeli-Arab problem.
The Chrysler Corporation announced today a third-quarter loss of $17.4-million, or 34 cents a share. It blamed strikes and parts shortages, which cut sharply into production.

Eleven cars of a 52-car eastbound Erie-Lackawanna freight train were derailed here at 4:25 o'clock this morning. The damage was estimated in the hundreds of thousands of dollars and rail traffic was tied up for the better part of the day.
The metropolitan championship of the Greater New York Bridge Association concluded at the New York Hilton here yesterday with 52 teams contesting the board-amatch event.

Jacqueline Giat, who has been a flutist with several orchestras including the American Symphony and is now on the New York University faculty, can play a blue streak. But her program at Carnegie Recital Hall on Sunday night was a model of honest musicianship as well as a technical display.
The clanging bells and rhythmic clicking of trolley wheels so familiar in American cities in the early part of the century will be heard once again in Detroit next summer..

While Arab nations are cutting off oil supplies to the United States, the Soviet Union today moved a step closer toward cooperation with American companies in this field by formally opening the largest American exhibition ever held here to show oil and gas technology and equipment.

Officials of the State Department of Transportation said today that they would fight to preserve freight services on 436 miles of Penn Central branch line tracks in the state that the railroad said did not meet the tracksafety standards of the Federal Railroad Administration.
An Israeli soldier poked his head out of an Egyptian bunker on the western bank of the Suez Canal today and grinned. "Want some ice cream?" he asked, offering his visitor paper cup and spoon.
One of the former Greek military leaders has turned against President George Papadopoulos, accusing him of trying to consolidate his "dictatorship under a parliamentary cloak."
The American Insurance Association today endorsed Federal guidelines for nationwide nofault auto insurance as an alternative to slow and haphazard movement by the states individually.
The Ford Foundation yesterday announced the appropriation of $1-million to finance research into the growing role of economics in international relations.

Women who read Cosmopolitan are more affectionate then men who read Playboy's Oui but more affectionate still are the men who read Cosmo. At least that's the way they see themselves and that's what they communicated to the interviewers from Target Group Index.
Four airline hijackers freed their 11 hostages and gave themselves up to Bolivian authorities today after striking a bargain for safe conduct that ended a 48-hour holdout in southern Bolivia.
Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba said tonight that his Government had sent physicians and medical technicians to the Middle East "to give their collaboration to the brother Arabian peoples."
The Marathon Oil Company today confirmed reports that it had held preliminary discussions with the Republic of Ireland about the potential

The extraordinary beauty of the Shingon Buddhist Monks' Shomyo ceremony Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Academy of Music made one regret all the more the peculiarities attendant upon their brief New York visit.

An 18-year-old A.W.O.L. Marine, armed with a shotgun, held his teen-age girlfriend and three other persons hostage in a mobile home trailer park in a night-long siege during which he wounded three policemen and demanded a plane to fly him to Egypt.
The Dorchester High School Annex was "a total loss" after a fouralarm fire yesterday, according to a School Department spokesman.

An elderly man was killed tonight in a bomb explosion that wrecked an East Belfast bar. According to the police, the man died because he did not leave the tavern fast enough after the bomb was dumped in a corridor.

Judge John J. Sirica of Federal District Court in Washington, who made landmark rulings in the Watergate case, will be presented a special award at a meeting this Thursday of the American Judges Association a spokesman said today.

Middle-class organizations representing truckers, shopkeepers, doctors and others who played a major role in the overthrow of President Salvador Allende Gossens are emerging as a significant force in the political vacuum in Chile today.
So far as dance is concerned Philadelphia jokes should cease forthwith. Why only yesterday I spent a week in Philadelphla-no, seriously-and saw two excellent dance performances:

One defendant sits in Federal court bound and gagged. Another assails the court with a 'barnyard epithet." A schoolboy appears in court to challenge the principal who ordered him not to wear an earring in school.
The collapse of Spiro T. Agnew's career was a negotiated decline and fall. The dimensions of the bargaining were even broader than the public record suggested.

William G. Heep Jr., vice president and managing director of Lord Taylor's Westchester store, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived here. Mr. Heep joined Lord Taylor in 1928.

In the face of President Nixon's defiance of the law, the courts, the House and Senate, and the American people have to ponder and act upon their responsibilities in this grave time. United States District Judge John J. Sirica, who ordered the President to make tapes of nine Watergaterelated conversations available to him, has the most immediate duty.
A thin plurality of 44 per cent of Americans, questioned since Saturday night in a national poll say that they favor impeaching President Nixon, N.B.C. News said last night.

The operators of a vocational school that had its license revoked last month for fraudulent advertising are trying to reopen the same kind of operation under a new name, according the City Department of Consumer Affairs.

The New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority, hard-pressed for funds because of successive marketing delays on a proposed $280-million bond issue, is apparently in the process of trying to renegotiate contractsigning deadlines with five construction companies.

To the Editor: "Where Are the Volunteers?", a recent column by C. L. Sulzberger, culls an interesting conclusion from questionable reasoning. Despite the fact that the policy of voluntary enlistment in the military is too new to warrant drawing conclusions as to its effectiveness, the gap between anticipated and actual enlistments should not be surprising to anyone.
An Israeli general said tonight that his nation had won a "very big victory" in the Middle East war but "it could have been bigger."

PLAINFIELD, N. J. - It was a day much like any other day in the life of Mrs. Paula Grossman: A hormone shot at the doctor's. A lunch of three hot dogs at Opdyke's Charcoal Grill, her favorite roadside restaurant.
The Community Service Society of New York accused the Legislature yesterday of an "unwillingness to deal realistially with alarmingly increased rates of health disorder and disease."

Senator Robert P. Griffin, Republican of Michigan; the assistant minority leader, proposed today a constitutional amendment to abandon permanently the election of Vice Presidents and give Congress and the President joint power to select them.

Two gifts of the sea that we had always considered trash came to our table recently as savory surprises. First, a neighbor came from Fire Island with a dog shark and a recipe that his motherin law used back in Abruzzi for scapece (pickled) of shark or skate, which are quite similar.
Black students, after doubling their numbers in the city's public schools ever the last dozen years, are for the first time the largest group in the multiracial system.

Pro football's only unbeaten teams, the Los Angeles Rams and Minnesota Vikings, play at Bloomington, Minn., on Sunday and don't look for the game on your local television set. You are stuck with the Giants and Jets, and both have lost four of six games.

WASHINGTON-Richard Nixon has ordered his own whitewash. He has put an end to an investigation of his Administration's activities that he had promised would be independent, unhindered and complete, and he has reasserted his political direction of the Department of Justice.

Isabel Zubinic, an 83-yearold widow, waits every morning for a phone call to break the silence in her one-room apartment. She seldom speaks to anyone in person for she lives alone in a small room up five long flights of stairs.

ABRAMS--Fannie, devoted mother of Elaine, Lillian and Everett; dear sister, loving grandmother and great-grandmother. Services Tuesday, I P.M., at Gutterman's."Lincoin Square Chapels," Broadway at 66th St. ALEXANDER-Anna. Dearly loved mother. Survived by daughters Charlotte Amble, Gaby Bluestein, Lilly Salls and Claire Mock; 7 grandchilden, 10 great-grandchil.
Kurt Schmid, Latin-American general manager of the Swissair airline, was kidnapped today by unidentified armed men who intercepted his car, a company official reported.

" By the time I get through, the candidates will be chasing me." This was the comment of an ebullient Mayor Lindsay the other day to some of his closest advisers when he burst into City Hall after a well-staged celebration of the official opening of the $58-million Police Headquarters.
The manuscript, hidden since 1634, of an unknown play by the 17th-century dramatist Thomas Heywood will be auctioned by Sotheby's on Nov. 20.
The American Institute for Imported Steel noted yesterday that steelimports for the first
Two youths were buried alive and six others narrowly escaped death today as a mountain of sand collapsed on them in four closely spaced avalanches at the Huntington Town dump here.

The modern masterpiece "Monkeys in the Jungle" by Henri Rousseau, which the Metropolitan Museum sold secretly early last year, was purchased by Mitsui and Company, a 300-year-old Tokyo trading firm, which obtained it for about $1.7-million.

A major bank here reported today that a Japanese banking consortium was negotiating a loan of $30million to $50-million to the Government of Abu Dhabi, one of the Persian Gulf sheikdoms that have cut off oil shipments to the United States.
Lawrence Iason, who retired recently as chairman of the board of N. Erlanger, Blumgart Co., Inc., a textile 'concern, died yesterday at his home, 44 East 67th Street. His age was 80.

Democratic leaders of the house of Representatives tentively agreed today to have ??e House Judiciary Committee ??gin an inquiry into whether resident Nixon has committed ny offenses that could lead to ??neachment.
Black students, after doubling their numbers in the city's public schools over the last dozen years, are for the first time the largest group in the multiracial system.

Jet fans watching their favorite team on television this season-and that's the only way they've been able to see them-have seen the team crawl to a disappointing start for various reasons, including injuries, missed blocks, errant passes and faulty running.
Those who are working on or writing about the gubernatorial campaign of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., agree on one thing-it is unusual.
An Israeli soldier poked his head out of an Egyptian bunker on the western bank of the Suez Canal today and grinned. "Want some ice cream?" he asked, offering his visitor a paper cup and spoon.

The American Medical Association, in an editorial published in its journal yesterday, challenged the prevailing attitude that the migration of thousands of foreign physicians to the United States represented a "brain drain," seducing badly needed doctors away from developing countries.

Commodity futures trading, setting new records, jumped 51 per cent in the first nine months of 1973. From Jan. 1 through Sept. 30, 19.4 million contracts were traded, compared with 12.8 million in the same nine months of 1972, according to the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc.
An extraordinary, criminal trial of John N. Mitchell anti Maurice H. Stans is scheduled to start here today, but it may be postponed because of a disputed White House tape recording.

Richmond Memorial Hospital, the only nonprofit voluntary hospital serving Staten Island's south shore, was down to 50 remaining patients yesterday as administrators awaited a court ruling today to determine whether the hospital would close completely.

Eleven cars of a 52-car eastbound Erie-Lackawanna freight train were derailed here at 4:25 clock this morning. The damage was estimated in the hundreds of thousands of dollars and rail traffic was tied up for the better part of the day.

The Watergate break-in was only one of five broad areas under close examination by Archibald Cox before his dismissal Saturday as special prosecutor. Though all five areas overlap, Mr. Cox's investigators had set up separate task forces to handle them. The other areas were these:

A ceasefire in the fourth Middle East war since the creation of Israel went into effect today on the Egyptian front, about 12 hours after the United Nations Security Council called for an end to the hostilities.

Two youths were taken into custody yesterday shortly after two Molotov cocktails were thrown from a roof at an unoccupied police radio motor patrol car in front of 882 Beck Street in the southeast Bronx. No injuries or damage were reported.
Syria reported last night that her troops were fighting Israeli forces on the Golan heights well after the cease-fire agreed upon by Israel and Egypt went into effect on the Sinai front.
The General Telephone Electronics Corporation reported yesterday records in telephone revenues, manufacturing sales, net income and share earnings for both the three and nine months ended Sent. 30.

A. D. Emmart, retired associate editor of the Baltimore Sunpapers and editorial page editor of The Baltimore Evening Sun, died yesterday at the age of 70. Mr. Emmart, known as Dol, a contraction of his first name Adolphus, joined the staff of the Sunpapers as a copy editor in May, 1924.

The 1974 model United States cars are still new to the showroom, but in Montana, where winter comes early, a Chevrolet dealer said: "There are not too many [people] coming out to drink your coffee and eat your doughnuts.

Henry Steele Commager, the historian, called tonight for the impeachment of President. Nixon and said the President had violated the law 13 times. Mr. Commager told 700 students at Amherst College,. where he teaches, that Mr. Nixon should be impeached

Between the diplomatic ingenuities of the two superpowers and the workaday inclinations of Arabs and Israelis living side-by-side, the dream of peaceful co-existence in the Middle East is reaching toward the daylight of reality.

A ceasefire in the fourth Middle East war since the creation of Israel went into effect today on the Egyptian front, about 12 hours after the United Nations Security Council called for an end to the hostilities.

Federal District Judge John J. Sirica will meet tomorrow morning in his courtroom here with members of the two main grand juries that have been investigating the Watergate affair. He will read them a "pretty general" statement regarding the continuation of their work, a member of the judge's staff said today.
The East River between the Manhattan and Williamsburg Bridges was closed to shipping traffic for four and a half hours yesterday to permit the "maiden voyage" of the 226,200-ton tanker Brooklyn.

Jim Turner, who missed a pair of legnthy first half field goals, booted his third threepointed of the game from 35 yards out with three seconds remaining tonight to give the Denver Broncos a 23-23 tie with the Oakland Raiders.

Shocked and angered by what they consider to be an unprecedented attack on the nation's system of jutice, the leaders of America's legal profession began mobilizing today to rebuff President Nixon and, if need be, to urge his impeachment.

Wearing tattered clothing and burnt-out expressions, the derelicts of New York sprawl on the city's sidewalks, clutching bottle of cheap liquor wrapped in brown paper bags. They call the sidewalks home, and there seem to be more of them than ever.

Mrs. William D, Ruckelshaus said today that she expected to remain in her part time post at the White House even though her husband was dismissed as Deputy Attorney General Saturdya after he refused to obey President Nixon's order to dismiss Archibald Cox as the special Watergate prosecutor.

The latest Paris Biennale, which just closed at the Musde d'Art Moderne, presented nearly 100 artists under the age of 35 from all parts of the world. On the whole, this eighth. Biennale resembled closely other recent avant-garde jamborees.

The chairman of the largest Indian tribe in the United States charged today that the biggest barrier to economic development and selfsufficiency for Indians was Federal red tape and bureaucratic fumbling within the Bureau of Indian Affairs.

Several locally prominent radical activists, who attended the University of Wisconsin in the late nineteen-sixties, testified in an occasionally tearful hearing here today on behalf of Karleton Armstrong, an admitted saboteur.

The Chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board denied today that there was any impropriety in the approval of federal insurance' for a savings and loan association with close ties to Charles G. Rebozo, a close friend of President Nixon.
A driverless diesel engine rolled 80 miles yesterday from Rutland to Essex Junction at 5 to 10 miles an hour before it was detected.

George Steinbrenner, chief owner and president of the New York Yankees, said his team was interested in hiring Dick Williams, but that the former Oakland manager had not been approached about the job.
An Uruguyan national, described as the top supplier of cocaine in the United States, was arraigned yesterday in Federal Court in Manhattan and held in $500.000 bail.

Pablo Casals, the celebrated cellist and conductor, died today at Auxilio Mutuo Hospital of complications from a heart attack suffered three weeks ago. He was 96 years old and lived in nearby Santurce with his wife, Marta.
With the baseball season officially dead, it can be safely said that the technical coverage by the National Broadcasting Company was superb.

The Health Department has released the names of 37 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

A tcease-fire between Egypt and Israel went into effect about 12 hours after the United Nations Security Council called for an end to hostilities in the fourth Middle East war. But fighting continued in Syria. The Damascus radio said that Syrian leaders were "considering" the Security Council's resolution. Iraq, whose troops are fighting at the side of the Syrians, rejected the proposal.

The Communist party leader, Edward Gierek, said today that a purge of the party's 2.5 million members was near. He said the Politburo would conduct a review of membership cards before the seventh party congress in 1976.

Dr. Paul Dudley White, the Boston heart specialist who treated the late President Eisenhower several years ago, is this year's winner of the American Heart Association's James B. Herrick Award for "unprecedented achievements in the practice and advance of clinical cardiology here and around the world."

President Nixon's dismissal of Archibald Cox has elicited the strongest press criticism since his election nearly five years ago. The great majority of newspaper editorials in the last 48 hours deplore the President's action in discharging the special Watergate prosecutor

Patrick A. Robinson, an 18-year-old A.W.O.L. Marine, armed with a shotgun, held his teen-age girlfriend and three other persons hostage in a mobile home trailer park in Dover Township, N.J., in a night-long siege during which he wounded three policemen and demanded a plane to fly him to Egypt.
While Coach Alex Webster was busy trying to find out what was wrong with the Giants, Wellington Mara said yesterday that Webster was not to blame for the team's four-game losing streak.
Francis, the pregnant white whale at New York Aquarium, in Coney Island, regained her appetite yesterday and took her first food in eight days.

Following is the text of the resolution to be presented to Congress by deans of United States law schools throughout the nation: Whereas substantial evidence exists that close associates of the President of the United States, and possibly the President himself, have engaged in a deliberate effort to obstruct justice;

By collaborating through the United Nations cease-fire resolution to bring the Arab-Israeli fighting to a halt, the United States and the Soviet Union have succeeded in checking a tragic slaughter that threatened to become unbearably costly in lives and resources for both sides. They-have also narrowly averted a grave threat to their own detente, and thus to the peace of the world.
Three major airlines today announced agreement to reduce service between Chicago and sven other cities in efforts to conserve fuel.

Four of five Canadian International Paper Company mills have resumed full production following contract- ratification Votes by workers who have been on strike since August.
Standing and cheering, delegates to the A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention here voted today to ask President Nixon to resign and to demand his impeachment if he did not.
Government and industry officials are uncertain as to whether the Arabs also intend :o sheath their "oll weapon" if cease-fire is achieved in Syria and the Sinai.

Salom Rizk, who wrote and lectured widely on his life story of a vagabond orphan in Syria questing for education, freedom and economic security in America, died yesterday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 63 years old.
Some football coaches and players may feel Oklahoma inflicts cruel and unusual punishment when the Sooners pile up those 50 and 60 point victories.

The New York Philharmonic's management announced yesterday that it had agreed to accept the New York State Mediation Board's proposal of binding arbitration in the four-week Strike by the orchestra's musicians. Spokesmen for the players, however, immediately denounced the plan and said the musicians had not been consulted, and would not agree to it.

EXPOSURE SoHophoto started life in a SoHo walkup a year or so ago. Shortly after this plebeian beginning, the photo gallery, which is a cooperative of about 100 members, moved to 30 West 13th Street, (652-9721), where you take an elevator to its roomy open quarters on the fifth floor.

Arthur Ashe, the American tennis star, has applied to play in the South African open lawn tennis tournament here Nov. 14-27 "in a spirit of goodwill and cooperation." The South African Government has twice refused a visa to the black player on the ground of his "antagonistic attitude" toward South Africa and its racial policies.
The United Nations prepared contingency plans today in case it should be asked to police the cease-fire in the Middle East called for by the Security Council.

A 14-year-old boy died yesterday shortly after he tried to get "high" by hyperventilating, sheriff's deputies said. The boy Kelly Canlalosi, was found lying unconscious on the floor of his home by a friend whom he had telephoned. He was dead on arrival at Hillside Hospital.
Italy's strongest labor organization formally loosened its ties with the Soviet-dominated World Federation of Trade Unions at a congress that ended in Varna, Bulgaria, today.

The Union Oil Company of California reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose 61 per cent to $50.7-million. The nine-month profit was up 44 per cent to $129.1-million. The company said strong demand and higher prices had contributed to the gains.

The New York Times Company reported yesterday thirdquarter net income of $4.19million, or 37 cents a share, up 30.4 per cent from the yearearlier level. The 1972 quarterly net included an extraordinary credit of $1.2-million - 11 cents a share-from the sale of Family Circle magazine's 50 per cent interest in Standbrook Publications, Ltd., publishers of Family Circle (Great Britain).

From 4,000 to 6,000 high-school students, mostly seniors from metropolitan schools, conferred at the Americana Hotel in Manhattan with campus representatives from 125 Roman Catholic colleges and universities.

The outlook for men's sports wear next spring is higher prices, shortages of key items and more informal styling. That's the word from the trade show of the National Association of Men's Sportswear Buyers, being held here this week at the Statler-Hilton Hotel.
An Israeli general said tonight that his nation had won a "very big victory" in the Middle East war but "it could have been the bigger."

The Security Pacific National Bank, Los Angeles, the eighth largest commercial bank in the United States, yesterday followed the lead set last Friday by the First National City Bank and announced a reduction in its prime rate to 9 3/4 per cent.

Brooklyn homicide detectives reported yesterday they had no clues in the brutal killing of a 70-year-old man, whose body was discovered last Thursday in his apartment at 132 Bradford Street in the East New York section.

It's a chance to do good for others and to "open doors" for yourself, says Steven Russell. He's a school health aide at Public School 101 in East Har-. lem, giving eye tests and calling parents' attention to the fact that at least five out of each class of 25 or 30 youngsters needs care.
That rarest of masterpieces, the complete "Les Troyens" by Hector Berlioz, came to the Metropolitan Opera last night in its first staged production in this city. It was high time.

Dr. Robert F. Loeb, Bard Professor of Medicine Emeritus and former chairman of the department of medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, who was considered one of the nation's leading medical teachers, died Sunday at his home, 950 Park Avenue.

The Oakland A's got high on champagne, the traditional method World Series winners have long used to touch off clubhouse celebrations. The losing New York Mets also got high but without any feelings of exhilaration. It was done for them by the chartered airliner that returned them to New York early yesterday morning.
Three boys were charged with firstdegree murder today in the death of a homeless. derelict who was sprinkled with lighter fluid and set afire.

Democratic and Republican political activity on the campuses is at a virtual standstill. Many students, unaffiliated with college political groups, are blase about the Watergate scandals, regarding them as confirmation of their previously held belief that politics is synonymous with corruption.

Wheat, corn and soybean futures prices showed little change at the end of trading yesterday, despite some wide swings during the session. At one point December wheat futures had jumped the 20-cents-a-bushel daily limit, perhaps because of some euphoria about a cease-fire in the Middle East, but at the close the price was $4.32 a bushel, barely ahead of Friday's $4.30 1/2, on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The Knicks held a prolonged practice session yesterday at Madison Square Garden that included the showing of a horror movie filmed Saturday night. It was entitled, "New York 69, Chicago 85."
Kirk Kerkorian, the former flight instructor who in 1968 paid $67.5-million for control of Western Airlines, Inc., said yesterday it now was his "intention" to sell a "significant"
The principal speaker at the annual Veterans Day parade charged yesterday that "business interests" had diluted the significance of the holiday by recommending a change in the date.

For the second time in three years, a voluntary accord between this city's construction companies and building trades unions for hiring members of minority groups on federally subsidized building projects has collapsed because of poor performance.

The House Government Operations Committee says Agriculture Department attempts to get financial information from three million farm income tax returns for statistical purposes could be an invasion of privacy.

PANAMA CITY - Scattered across South America and the Caribbean are more than 170 graduates of the United States Army School of the Americas who are heads of governments, cabinet ministers, commanding generals, chiefs of staff and directors of intelligence.

Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany led his party's parliamentary delegation into the Reichstag building here today. It was the first time in more than three years that a meeting was held by the Social Democrats in West Berlin.

Diplomats here and in scattered capitals around the world worked today to construct the road to peace in the Middle East from a precarious point of departure: a costly war and a hastily arranged and fragile cease-fire.

A 26-year-old woman from Niagara Falls, N.Y., was beaten and shot by a hitchhiker after an argument and then tossed out of her car into a ditch along a deserted stretch of a Colorado highway, the authorities said today.

When Jose Rodriguez was still an infant, his parents abandoned him in a shabby Manhattan rooming house. Yesterday, before a crowd of 36,104 at Aqueduct, the orphan rode against millionaires like Laffit Pincay Jr. and Jorge Velasquez in his debut as a jockey.

He is 6 feet tall and weighs 220 pounds. He has earned a letter in four sports and has led Syosset's football team to four straight victories this season. He is Kevin Mannix, a fullback of big-time proportions and big-time ambitions and perhaps the best player on Long Island. Mannix, who scored four touchdowns last Saturday, now has 14 for the season. He also gained 151 yards as Syosset crushed Port Washington, 43-6.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market dropped sharply yesterday in lackadaisical trading.
The Symphony of the New World played a concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon, though it .had to cross a picket line of striking New York Philharmonic musicians to do so.

As a result of the national and international crises and an unusually dull mayoral campaign in New York City, the election of members of the City Council is being almost wholly ignored this year. Such lack of interest would be unfortunate in any year since the Council has an important governmental role to play as the local legislative and investigative 'body.

Col. Muammad el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, threatened today to cut off all oil deliveries to Western Europe because its representaties in the United Nations had voted for the cease-fire "imposed" on them by the United States and the Soviet Union.
Three children were burned to death and two adults injured when fire raged through a second-floor apartment today in the Beaver Brook City Housing Project on Eden Drive here.

Mrs. Barbara Blum, the city's Commissioner for Special Services for Children since 1971, was named yesterday to head a new 16-county metropolitan region for the State Board of Social Welfare, supervising public and private agencies for children and adults;
Le Duc The has rejected the Nobel Peace Prize awarded to him jointly with Secretary of State Kissinger for the Vietnam agreement they negotiated, Hanoi announced today.

The 23d German chemist to win the Nobel Prize . . . Born in Munich on Nov. 10, 1918, the day before World War I ended... The son of Karl Fischer, who was a professor of physics at the University of Munich...

A dispute over White House tape recordings delayed the scheduled trial yesterday of former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and former Commerce Secretary Maurice H. Stans on charges that they obstructed a major investigation and lied about it to a grand jury.

Administration officials said today that Secretary of State Kissinger and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Communist party leader, did not reach agreement in Moscow on much more than was included in the Middle East cease-fire resolution adopted by the Security Council yesterday morning.
Yesterday's indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco was the second time this tors. year in which a Federal crime was charged to a Brooklyn Congressman.
Dr. Daniel J. Ellsberg has called for an investigation into the possibility that the White House "plumbers" engineered the shooting of Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama.
The State Court of Appeals today reversed the conviction of two Bronx men sentenced to death for the 1968 slaying of a Westchester County deputy sheriff.

Ken Patton, head of the Economic Development Administration, says he has been offered the job of president of the New York Board of Real Estate and has asked the city's Board of Ethics to rule on whether his acceptance would create a conflict of interest.

New Yorkers may be faced with a $100-million rate increase for electrical service during the next year, the city and the Consolidated Edison Company said yesterday, because of spiraling costs and diminishing sources for oil stemming largely, from embargoes in the Middle East.

Archibald Cox bade farewell to his staff today. Dismissed by the President Saturday in an action that stirred a nationwide outcry, the former special Watergate prosecutor had no words of bitterness or revenge.
Two scientists with leading American companies and a Briton won the 1973 Nobel Physics Prize today for theories that have advanced and expanded the world of miniature electronics.

A New Jersey Supreme Court decision that struck down the state's traditional system of financing public-school education was allowed to stand today when the United States Supreme Court refused to hear an appeal in the case.
Theodore Shapiro, a cofounder of the Dutch Masters Paint and Varnish Company of Brooklyn in the nineteen-twenties, died yesterday at his home, 35 East 35th Street. He was 87 years old.
A major struggle over political control of France's state-owned television and radio monopoly led today to the dismissal of both antagonists.
Israel announced early today that she and Egypt had agreed on a new cease-fire to go into effect at 7 A.M. (1 A.M. Wednesday, New York time).

A Transit Authority patrolman shot and killed an unidentified man in a subway station in Jamaica, Queens last night, minutes after the man had allegedly robbed a neighborhood medical center, the police reported.

Officials of the Bureau of Indian Affairs told the United States Commission on Civil Rights here today that they had neither time nor manpower enough to enforce Federal nondiscrimination clauses in some $60-million worth of yearly contracts the bureau signs- to run the Navajo Indian reservation.

The Soviet Union accused Israel tonight of renewing Middle East hostilities in violation of the United Nations cease-fire resolution and warned of the "gravest consequences" if fighting persisted.

A man accused of murder last April 6 of Bruno Carnivale, a reputed mobster, pleaded guilty yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens to a lesser charge of manslaughter in the second degree.

North Vietnam today attacked "maneuvers" by President Nixon and Secretary of State Kissinger, and criticized what it called the blindness of those who tended to forget that "American imperialism remains the No. 1 enemy of all the peoples."
A Brazilian airliner, with passengers including the Lieutenant Governor of Indiana and 11 other members of a state trade mission, crashed into Guanabara Bay here today and sank.

The establishment of a new state college at which all of the students will be prison inmates is expected to be approved this morning by the trustees of the State University of New York.

Dr. Abraham W. Schenker, a physician who had been active in rehabilitation therapy for the Veterans Administration died, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, at Roosevelt Hospital on Oct. 12. He was 78 years old and lived at 303 East 66th Street.
J. Edward Smith, a partner in the New York law firm of Turk, Marsh, Kelly Hoare, died here, apparently of a heart attack, yesterday. He was 67 years old and lived in Hastings-on-Hudson.
The French Cabinet named a new director of the state-owned radio and television monopoly today.

An angry and bitter Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. told Republican audiences today that his gubernatorial campaign was in trouble for lack of funds and he urged a "people's" crusade to turn the tide by Election Day.

Randy Johnson will start at quarterback for the New York Giants Sunday against the St. Louis Cardinals. "I think he deserves a shot," Coach Alex Webster said today on his decision to replace Norm Snead for the first time in the regular season with the 29-year-old Johnson.

C. Arnholt Smith agreed late today to surrender active control of the Westgate- California Corporation, the keystone of the financier's business empire, in order to escape trial on multimillion-dollar fraud charges brought by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

The president of the University of Michigan, Robben W. Fleming, was named today president of the Association of American Universities. He succeeds Herbert E. Longenecker of Tulane University and will serve for one year.

Recurrent calls for corrective action to avert the kind of accidents that occurred on the New Jersey Turnpike yesterday have produced little progress in solving the national traffic-safety problem created by dense fog on superhighways.
Charles O. Finley, the owner of the world champion Oakland A's, started a new controversy today by refusing to release Manager Dick Williams to the New York Yankees without compensation.
Max Dunn, who retired from the New York City school system last year after 35 years as a librarian, died yesterday at his home in Scottsdale. His age was 64.

The Soviet Union has quietly launched its second nuclearpowered icebreaker in a bid to keep a growing volume of shipping moving along the nation's icebound coasts at a time of expanding foreign trade.

Democrats in control of the House Judiciary Committee decided today to pursue and broaden an inquiry into the impeachment of. President Nixon.
The Lebanese public was warned today to be prepared for some form of Israeli attack in reprisal for the activities of Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon.
President Nixon, in another sudden turn in the Watergate crisis, canceled his scheduled television address to the na. tion tonight and planned in stead a news conference al 9 P.M. tomorrow.

John Lennon, the former Beatle's singer, sued the United States Government yesterday, demanding that it admit or deny whether Mr.. Lennon or his lawyer, Leon Wildes, had been the subjects of illegal wiretaps or surveillance.

President Nixon, in a further confrontation with Congress, vetoed a bill today that would limit the powers of the President to commit the armed forces to foreign hostilities without Congressional approval.

College enrollment is up about 2.5 per cent from last year, it was reported today by Dr. Garland G. Parker, a national authority on college enrollments. Dr. Parker, who is vice provost for admissions and records at the University of Cincinnati,

At least nine persons were killed and more than 40 injured in a series of collisions that sent 65 vehicles crashing and careening into each other in a heavy fog that swathed a large stretch of the New Jersey Turnpike late last night and early this morn. ing.
The Nixon Administration's budget cutbacks in kidney research threaten an exorbitant future cost in money and human suffering, two Senate Democratic leaders charged today.

Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today that Israel regarded the Suez Canal cease-fire as still in effect despite repeated violations in the first 48 hours.

Wendell Ladner of the Kentucky Colonels, considered the wild man in the American Basketball Association because of his fierce temper, boasted before tonight's game that he could stop Julius Erving of the New York Nets, the No. I scorer in the A.B.A,
Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork made clear today his intention to take any necessary steps, including judicial action,

It has long been clear that snowmobiles-at last count there were two million of them in North America-are here to stay. The problem then is how to regulate their use so that they will do a minimum of harm to the natural environment and its denizens, including man.

Nine men died last night in an outbreak between coal miners near this town in the northwest area of Natal Province. The fights, between members of the Basotho and Xhosa tribes, began over the weekend and the police had announced that one man died on
Rudy Tomjanovich and Mike Newlin led Houston in a second-period outburst and the. Rockets went on to a 132-117 National Basketball Association victory over the Boston Celtics tonight.
The Pentagon announced yesterday that it planned to add a burial place for an unidentified Vietnam war casualty at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier at Arlington National Cemetery, Arlington, Va.
Under the whitewashed battlements of the local police post, the guard was yawning today, and no passing warplanes, Arab or Israeli, disturbed Kafrein's heat-drugged calm.

Archibald Cox said today that, at the time he was dismissed as the special Watergate prosecutor, his staff was looking into large political contributions, "chiefly in cash," raised by the White House staff in 1970.

For those who feel themselves trapped or get a little hysterical after starting needlepoint, crewel embroidery or just plain embroidery ("This thing has taken over my life," or "I'll never get it finishedl")-Blooming. dale's stands ready to spring to the rescue.
Corporate bond prices edged up yesterday in relatively quiet trading. Intermediate and long-term Government bonds were up in price from 1/32d to as much as 8/32ds.
The Swiss Government indicated today that it was prepared to have aMiddle East peace conference in Switzerland.
Three of the City Center Joffrey Ballet's six original cast members of "Weewis" have since defected to other companies, perhaps because they were obliged to dance in ballets like "Weewis."
One of the huge maps displayed last night in the Hiram Halle Library, where 60 Pound Ridge townspeople had gathered to hear a new concept in town planning, looked like an invasion chart.
The Vermont Yankee nuclear power station at Vernon is expected to be shutdown for an additional two or three weeks because of the latest technical problem of the facility, the company said.
The Ford Motor Company announced today a third-quarter profit of $95-million, only $1million above the $94-million in the same period a year ago.
Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Senate Watergate committee, canceled today the committee meeting that was scheduled for tomorrow.
It is a time unlike any in our experience. Events crowd in so fast, one upon another, that our emotions cannot catch upmuch less our understanding.

The Chinese press today issued its first direct comment on the American-Soviet resolution calling for a cease-fire in the Middle East, accusing the two superpowers of trying to "put out the blazing fire of this just war.
The most' ambitious negotiations yet undertaken for freeing the flow of world commerce, were launched here today under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.
President Nixon, in another sudden turn in the Watergate crisis, canceled his scheduled television address to the nation tonight and planned instead a news conference at 9 P.M. tomorrow.
Rescue workers dug tons of dirt and mud away from, the entrance to an old gold mine late last night to free two men who had been trapped 33 1/2 hours by a landslide.

Shortly after the United Nations Security Council issued its second call in less than 48 hours for a ceasefire in the Middle East, the Egyptian Foreign Minister declared that observance of the new order would serve as "a test of faith." Within hours, heavy fighting had broken out anew on the Suez front.
Four members of SANE, the national peace organization, have been refused Soviet visas to attend the World Peace Congress opening in Moscow today. Sanford Gottlieb, SANE's director,

The Dowdle Oil Corpothree-well drilling program on a 160-acre lease in Okmmulgee County, Okla. A second well will be drilled in Ofkuskie County and the third in Osage County All will seek to tap oil at depths of 3,000 to 4,000 feet in the Dutcher, Cromwell and Wilcox sands.

ALDEN-Robert. The New York Times anounces with deep sorrow the passing of Robert Alden, associated with The Times since May 21, 1944. ALEXANDER-Ellen, survived by grand niece Ava Rado Harle and grand nephew George Haydu, Services Thursday, Oct. 25, 9:30 AM. at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.
The United States auto industry reported sales of 268,439 cars for Oct. 11-20, down, 15.7 per cent from 318,445 in the. same period a year ago.
Two holdup men walked into the lobby of the Playboy Theater on 57th Street near the Avenue of the Americas late last evening and demanded money from the manager, the police reported.
Eleven members of the New World of Islam were arrested on homicide charges or as material witnesses in the killing last Sept. 4 of James Shabazz, a Black Muslim leader.

Westfield and Nutley may be the two best high school football teams in the state, and since they will collide Saturday at Nutley, it would seem as if the rest of the schedule is just a routine supplement. "It's going to be a big one," Nutley's coach, Mario Cocchiola, said, caught up in the excitement his own kids are exhibiting.

Commercialism, once associated only with capitalism, has produced the current sports scandal in the Soviet Union. Never before have so many Soviet athletes in so many different sports traveled so extensively.

Two veteran pick-and-shovel men-John V. Lindsay and Dr. William J. Ronan -- broke ground yesterday for the downtown section of the Second Avenue subway while state officials were elaborating plans for a "breakthrough" in intercity rail service.

The Consolidated Edison Company proposes to increase its bill to a typical gas customer, who uses 800 cubic feet a month, from $3.85 to $4.59, a rise of 74 cents, or 19.2 per cent. The small commercial gas user would get a similar increase.

Marita Redondo of National City, Calif., and Julie Heldman, an American living in London, gained the women's final of a $75,000 international tennis tournament today. Miss Redondo, former United States junior champion, had the toughest time, eliminating Elly Appel of the Netherlands, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, while Miss Heldman romped through her semifinal against Glynis Coles of Britain, 6-0, 6-3.
Acting Attorney General Robert H. Bork made clear today his intention to take any necessary steps, including judicial action, to obtain evidence from the White House if it.
A bill to authoribe a Congressional watch - dog agency to audit the Federal Reserve System was blocked today from House consideration, probably killing it for the year.

Three of the four major candidates for'Mayor, facing what is widely regarded 'as a commanding lead by the fourth, Controller Abraham D. Beame, and fighting for public attention that has been focused on Washington and the Middle' East, tried to reach out yesterday with a joint news conference.

The past week's climactic events in the custody battle over secret White House tape recordings may have averted a dangerous constitutional deadlock between President Nixon and the Supreme Court, but they resolved only some of the complex and controversial legal issues involved.

WASHINGTO-A half-century ago, Owen J. Roberts was appointed-Special Prosecutor to investigate the Teapot Dome scandals, which had reached President Harding's Attorney General and other top members of his Administration.
Driving through the Egyptian countryside today, a correspondent could glimpse some of the contradictions that make the Egyptian scene so hard for a foreigner to understand.

Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, the Rutgers University president, announced yesterday that the university had received $27,751,646, a record, in gifts, bequests, grants and contracts during the 1972-73 fiscal year. This compared with $19,120,945 in 1971-72, he said. Dr. Bloustein said the bequests included $10-million from the estate of the late Charles L. Busch of Edgewater, the largest gift ever made to the state university.
Yvan Cournoyer scored two goals and had an assist to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 3-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Penguins onight.

Mrs. 1. wayne Rutter of Williamsville, N.Y., the first-round leader, posted an eight-over-par 80 today, but remained in front by a stroke after the second round of the North-South women's senior golf championship.
The retirement of James J. Rowley as director of the Secret Service, a position he has held since 1961, was announced today by George P. Shultz, Secretary of the Treasury.

The City Council Committee on Environmental Protection heard a good deal of testimony yesterday in favor of a bill that would require builders to install storm-drainage sewers in new construction. The measure is aimed at reducing street flooding, mainly in still-to-bedeveloped areas in Queens and on Staten Island.
Michel Tremblay, a 32-year-old warehouse worker, has begun wearing a blue and white campaign button that declares in French, "I am voting for truth."

The police are nothing a New York City teen-ager who, they say, used a friend's credit card and an estimated $200,000 in worthless checks to finance a round-the-world trip that may have cost a total of $500,000.

Elated that a long-sought sacred tribal carving has been found here after it mysteriously vanished six years ago, officials of the Cameroon Embassy in Washington set in motion yesterday diplomatic moves that they hope will result in the statue's return to the western African kingdom of Kom.
The president of the Argentine subsidiary of Standard Oil of Indiana has been kidnapped in Buenos Aires, police sources said here tonight.

The Federal Bureau of Investigation agreed out of court today to apologize and pay $1,000 to a former. University of Oregon student president whose F.B.I. file was given to a radio station news director.

Speculation centered today on a San Diego civic leader, Herbert Kunzel, as the probable new chairman of the Westgate-California Corporation, succeeding C Arnholt Smith, deposed head of the $190-million conglomerate he created 13 years ago.
Egypt accused Israel today of continuing to violate the cease-fire agreement and said Israeli troops had fired on Egyptian forces wherever they were found.

Wholesale tobacco. distributors here reached a new labor agreement yesterday with Local 805 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and they said the cost of the settlement would result in an increase of 2 cents a pack for cigarettes.
The state's second-highest court ruled today that municipal residents did not have the power to block local zoning amendments through a referendum.
The commodity spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials fell to 191.1 from 193.8 last week. The index compiled by tile Bureau of Labor Statistics stood at 124.6 on Oct. 24. 1972.
Engineers pressurized two fuel tanks on the Skylab 3 booster rocket today and successfully popped two buckled sections back into normal shape.
A State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed a $3-million suit brought by former Assemblyman Stanley, Harwood against the 1972 Republican campaign committee and others.

The House Ways and Means Committee approved today legislation to extend the statutory ceiling on the national debt and permit payment of up to 6 per cent interest on savings bonds. The bonds now pay 5 1/2 per cent annually if held to maturity.
There was deception, foul language, nudity, incest necrophilia and murder at the Music Box Theater last night. And that was just on stage. The play was Ira Levin's "Veronica's Room."

Opal V. Boynton, social work educator, who retired in 1967 as a consultant in group work administration and supervision for the Young Women's Chris. tian Association and settlement houses in the United States and Canada, died Wednesday in Toronto, where she lived.
A 22-year-old man was arrested yesterday as a suspect in the Tuesday night murder of Carol A. Hoffman in her East 29th Street apartment, the police reported.
Assistant Attorney General Henry E. Petersen and the Watergate special prosecution force asked United States District Court today to take custody of the task force's records.

The head of Puerto Rico's office in Washington has proposed that the commonwealth become a member or observer in a variety of international organizations and participate in United States delegations in certain conferences.
Charles C. Hay, the first president of Hockey Canada and retired president of Gulf -Oil Canada, Ltd., died yesterday after a short illness. He was 71 years old.
A bill pronllting me use ot lead-based paint in federally financed homes, on toys and on other items won final Congressional approval yesterday and went to President Nixon.

An emergency allocation of gasoline by Texaco, Inc., temporarily averted a crisis for fleet taxis, some 600 of which were forced off the streets here yesterday morning because of empty fuel tanks. After meeting with Texaco officials, fleet operators and state officials, Michael J. Lazar, chairman of the Taxi and Limousine Commission, announced a temporary restoration of supplies.

TEL AVIV, Oct. 25--A major political controversy has erupted here over Israel's state of readiness just before the Middle East war began and the Government's decision to accept a cease-fire last Monday.

The Public Service Electric Gas Company, the largest utility in 'New Jersey, today announced that it was preparing to convert some of its generating units to coal to enable it to cope with a potential fuel-oil shortage this winter,
A nervous Maria Callas was given an enthusiastic welcome when she returned to the stage here tonight in her first major concert in eight years.

President Nixon and his chief de'fense counsel, Charles Alan Wright, have not always displayed a similarity of views on the larger legal questions of the day. For example, each reviewed the book "Witness" by Whittaker Chambers in The Saturday Review of May 24, 1952. Their opinions were at opposite poles.
Metroliner service will be expanded by one round trip daily and one New York-to-Washington Sunday Metroliner run beginning this Sunday, the National Railroad Passenger Corporation announced today.
The two cellar clubs of the National Hockey League, the New York Islanders and the Minnesota North Stars, showed how evenly matched they were tonight by playing a 1-1 tie at Nassau Coliseum.

The city's Human Resources Administration yesterday canceled a $2-million contract with a Queens company to run an antipoverty program to train truck drivers after a report found that the program was poorly managed, had no accountability, used shoddy equipment, cost the city extra money and did not lead to good jobs.

Detectives who have sought for a week a motive for the pipe-bomb explosion at a Union Square bank now "strongly believe" that the bomber electronically set off the two highly sophisticated devices after failing in a scheme to extort $100,000 from the bank.
A Federal judge ruled today that the Tennessee Valley Authority may resume building the long controversial $69-million Tellico Dam project near Knoxville.

Crime and violence are "possibly worse" than last year in the city's junior high and elemlentary schools, but is down in the high schools, Eldridge Waith, chief administrator of the Board of Education's office of school safety told a City councill committee yesterday.
The new winter wheat was poking out of the drying ground in Pratt County this week, as thin and scraggly as whiskers on the cheek of a teen-aged boy.

History is open to interpretation, but Elliot Richardson appears to be the first Cabinet officer since Secretary of State William Jennings Bryan in the first Wilson Administration to have resigned on a matter of principle. Ironically enough, Mr. Richardson might well have been, instead, the first Cabinet nominee since Lewis Strauss in 1958 to have been refused confirmation by the Senate.
Commerce Secretary Preaeric B. Dent issued an "urgent appeal" to business today to conserve energy so that oil short ages do not cause factory shut downs and layoffs of workers.

The local fan has a right to feel frustrated about the fare in front of him for profootball Sunday. The Jets open their home season at Shea Stadium as underdogs to the Denver Broncos while the Giants are slight favorites in St. Louis.
Five American religious leaders have issued statements criticizing President Nixon's actions in the Watergate case in the last week.
The Security Council voted today to establish a United Nations emergency force to insure a cease-fire in the Middle East, using troops from smaller countries.

It's official. If you think the umpire is a bum, Justice George M. Carney of the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday, you can tell him so. Even if you're Joseph M. Cronin, president of the American League-as long as there is no malice intended.

Mayoral candidates paid homage to Brooklyn yesterday when there of them appeared at the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce where the emphasis was on programs for decentralizing the government away from Manhattan.

Dr. Maurice J. Dionne, chief of staff of the Regional Memorial Hospital, which he helped found here, died last night of a heart attack while playing chess in the community's recreation center. He was 69 years old.

In hopes of counteracting the ruinous political effect of President Nixon's miscalculation in firing Archibald Cox, Senate Republican leaders are now urging the President to name a new special prosecutor to take over the Watergate cases.
The New England Whalers outplayed the New York Golden Blades last night and posted an 8-3 victory before 3,721 fans in a World Hockey association game.

An offering of 200,000 common shares of the Missouri Public Service Company at $14.625 per share was made yesterday by Merrill Lynch. The company's common closed unchanged at 14 5/8 on the New York Stock Exchange.
President Nixon has signed legislation appropriating $9.92billion for operations of 10 Federal agencies, the White House said today.

Military installations in the state and nearby were on precautionary alert yesterday, according to Defense Department spokesmen, and although officers at the installations would not confirm the alert there were reports of unusual activity at many of them.

The indictment of Representative Frank J. Brasco on Tuesday came as a result of information given to the Justice Department by John A. Masiello, a Mafia captain who was involved in the case, according to Federal sources.
Controller Abraham D. Beame is so confident that he will win the mayoral election that he is forming a "recruiting" committee to seek out prospective top-level appointees for a Beame administration.

The expansion of Soviet airlift capacity, airborne forces and the Mediterranean squadron of the Black Sea fleet in the last five years has provided the Russians with means of rapid military intervention in the Middle East North Africa and the Indian subcontinent, should they have decided on such a course.
Tickets matching the number above win $50,000. Tickets matching the last five numbers win $5,000. Those matching the last four numbers win $500 and those matching the last three, $50.

Starting sometime next year, New Yorkers may be able to sleep more easily. The State Department of Environmental Conservation has proposed a set of rules for the prevention and control of noise pollution, which, if adopted, would limit the volume of sound produced in residential commercial and industrial areas.

Dow Finsterwald, the 1958 Professional Golfers' Association champion but now a part-time tourist, .scrambled for a six-underpar 65 and a share of the first-round lead today in the $135,000 Sahara invitation golf tournament.
A man allegedly tried to enter an IND subway station at Eighth Avenue and 116th Street without paying his fare was shot to death by a Transis Authority patrolman last night.

If Lord Macaulay had been in Washington during the last week he would never have written that "Your Constitution is all sail and no anchor." The Constitution not only demonstrated its holding power, but also its capacity to inspire men and women in high places and humble places to rush forward and tend the anchor chains.
