The Lions of Columbia and Trenton State are licking their claws for Rutgers and Jersey City State, respectively, especially the Lions at Trenton State, who know it's the time of the year when Jersey City State is the only undefeated collegiate team in the state.

Michael Tilson Thomas, the talking conductor, gave a Spectrum Concert on Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall. With the willing members of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra at his disposal, Mr. Thomas animadaverted on the theme of sound stretching.

The flow of oil from Middle East nations and their nearby allies has been cut an estimated four million barrels a day because of the war and related political moves, according to government and industry sources here.

Two men were charged with arson yesterday morning while town firemen put out several fires set in the rear of the First Memorial Presbyterian Church in Dover. Twenty-three-year-old Andres Kruizenga and Ernest August, 20, both of Dover, were arrested on charges that they had set fires that caused a quarter-million dollars in damage.
Seven weeks after charging that "nearly all" superfecta races at New York harness tracks were fixed, Federal investigators are still digging for evidence to prove it.
Cyrus S. Eaton, the 89year-old financier, is not going -to conduct a proxy contest so he can personally name a chairman of Chessie System, Inc., after all.
Rheingold, Europe's record money-winning horse, has been sold for $2.5-million. Rheingold will go to stud in Ireland.
The Nixon-Kissinger policy of negotiation instead of confrontation seemed to be still working today - against considerable odds.

Detectives who have sought for a week a motive for the pipe-bomb explosion at a Union Square bank now "strongly believe" that the bomber electronically set off the two highly sophisticated devices after failing in a scheme to extort $100,000 from the bank.

"Ringo," the new album by Ringo Starr, is big news in the pop world because it should finally establish the drummer-actor-comic as an independent star able to entertain and amuse as well as any of his former colleagues.

John R. Thompson, assistant to the president of Philip Morris International and its director of public relations, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 49 years old and lived, in Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y.

An official of a veterans organization said today that the White House had approached him for statements of support for President Nixon to be made after Mr. Nixon's news conference, scheduled for tonight but postponed.

An alert of airborne troops within the Soviet Union combined with a Soviet threat to send forces into the Middle East was cited by military officials today as the reason the United States placed its forces on a worldwide alert.
Although he may not choose to, Elliot L. Richardson can now attend all the dinner parties he wants to on the East Side of Manhattan.
New Jersey's candidates for Governor pledged today in a joint appearance before the State School Boards Association to overhaul the state's public school system.

Subway safety has become a matter of increasing concern recently, but the Transit Authority maintains that incidents such as last night's subway accident in the Bronx represent a statistical rarity in a 237-mile subway network that carries 3.8 million passengers on an average workday.

Barclays Bank, the big British bank that was turned down in May in its bid to take over the Long Island Trust Company, now aims to acquire the First Westchester National Bank, a $206-million bank with headquarters in New Rochelle.
Following is a transcript of Secretary of State Kissinger's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

ALBERT--William, beloved father of Richard Albert and Susan Vick, adored grandfather of Jeffrey Brain and Kim Ellen Albert and Jonathan and Linda Vick, dear brother of Charles and Sidney Albert, Helen Greenwald, Lilly Ellenkreig and Ruth Lipkind, Services Friday, 12:30 P.M. at Schwartz Brothers "Forest Park Chapels", Queens Blvd, at 76th Road, Forest Hills.

Jean-Philippe Carson, a cinematographer and executive of the Camera Company, was killed on Sunday, when a truck toppled on to his parked car at Culican in the Mexioan state of Sinaloa. He was 49 years old.

John Brodie, veteran San Francisco 49er quarterback, announced today he was retiring as an active player at the end of the current season. Brodie, 38 years old, told newsmen at the 49er training camp that he didn't feel his skills were diminishing, but that after 17 years he felt it was time to pursue interests in other areas.
Four persons who lived on a makeshift 35-foot houseboat at City Island were arrested yesterday and charged with looting pleasure boats of equipment and furnishings.
Some "significant" reductions in butter prices were forecast for next week for city consumers by the State Department of Agriculture. The prices had reached the highest retail peaks in seven years.
Frank A. Strom, board chairman of the Old Stone Bank in this city until March 30, died today at the Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital.
The Egyptian III Corps, estimated to number 15,000 to 30,000 men, remained trapped by the Israelis today, unable to acquire fresh supplies of water and food.

Dress designers once concentrated on designing dresses. If they were feeling adventurous, they perhaps tried a coat. Today, that's pretty simplistic. Everybody's designing everything, and on a global scale.

Mrs. Carolyn Spry, former president of the Woman's Club of Hastings-on-Hudson, N. Y., and a contributor to The New York Times daily crossword puzzles, died Wednesday at the New York Hospital. Her age was 67, and she lived at 415 East 52d Street.
Governor Rockefeller began a busy Republican fund-raising visit today with his full political entourage and a message that "Watergate is a tragedy of individuals-not the Republican party."

To the Editor: Bertrand Russell said shortly before his death: "No people anywhere in the world would accept being expelled en masse from their home country; how can anyone require the people of Palestine to accept a punishment which nobody else would tolerate?"

Brad Van Pelt, the New York Giants' No. 2 draft choice who has yet to play in a regular-season game because of a nagging groin injury, came out of today's skull session grinning-and with a fistful of new plays.
A Federal grand jury today indicted five men, including two alleged organized-crime figures, on charges of bilking thousands of small investors in a $1.5 million stock-fraud conspiracy.

The New York State Legislature, which is considering amendments to the state's obscenity laws in the wake of last June's United States Supreme Court ruling changing the criteria for obscenity determinations, opened the first of a series of joint hearings on the subject yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Board and its allies in the nation's private banking system see a threat to the much-prized independence of the nation's central bank in a bill that has emerged from the House Banking and Currency Committee.
A 21-year-old student at C..W. Post Center of Long Island University was found dead in his dormitory room here this atfernoon, the police said.
A group of demonstrators carrying banners and chanting slogans briefly took over Car. negie Hall last night just before the start of the Leningrad Sym. phony's program.
Willie McCovey, the National League's Most Valuable Player in 1969, and Ferguson Jenkins, the league's Cy Young Award winner in 1971, were the key figures in two three-man trades yesterday.
The Consolidated Edison Company has blocked the construction of a 1,000-unit residential and retail complex just south of the United Nations,. which had been approved by the state.

Mayoral candidates paid homage to Brooklyn yesterday with a joint appearance at the Brooklyn Chamber. of Commerce where the emphasis was on programs for decentralizing the government away from Manhattan.

Manufacturers and retailers of consumer products showed mixed results yesterday for third-quarter earnings. The Kraftco Corporation, for instance, had an 80.6 per cent rise .in the quarter's. net income, compared with yearearlier totals which included a $12.3-million extraordinary charge on plant closings.

The National Transportation Safety Board announced yes-' terday that it would investigate the macabre series of chain collisions on the fogshrouded New Jersey Turnpike Wednesday that left nine persons dead and more than 40 injured.
The New England Whalers outplayed the New York Golden Blades last night and posted an 8-3 victory before 3,721 fans in a World Hockey Association game.

Texaco, Inc., and the Atlantic Richfield. Company announced yesterday that earnings for the third quarter and first nine months of 1973 continued the trend of sharp gains for the nation's major oil companies.

More than 150 subway riders suffered smoke inhalation and other minor injuries and hundreds more were trapped in a dark smoky tunnel in the South Bronx for an hour or more last night after an IRT express train struck the rear of another that had been stalled by a fire;
Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, predicted tonight quick Senate passage of a bill establishing a new special prosecutor's office to handle the Watergate investigation.

A new principal, Mrs. Juana Dainis, took over at Public School 206 in East Harlem yesterday, despite a boycott by parents who kept virtually all children home from two schools For the fourth straight school day.

President Nixon's military alert radically changed the daily routine of life today for hundreds of Air Force personnel at Offutt Air Force Base here, the worldwide nerve center of the Strategic Air Command.
Frank Howard, one of the highest priced designated hitters in baseball, was given his unconditional release today by the Detroit Tigers.

The appointment of Eugene S. Haggerty as metropolitan region news editor and Allan R. Bruce as New York City editor for United Press International was announced yesterday by Thomas E. Cunningham, regional manager.

With net income in the third quarter and nine months rising to records for both periods on increases' of 9.2 per cent and 12.9 per cent respectively, directors of the Southern Railway yesterday voted to increase the regular quarterly dividend to 48 cents a share on the common stock from the 43 cents paid previously.
From the 5:02 commuter train to Stamford, Noroton Heights and Darien, Conn., to the Admiral Kidd Club in San Diego, President Nixon still has his supporters.
Profit taking by traders cut wheat futures prices by 10 cents a bushel for the December delivery yesterday. The decline came after a strong opening that followed Wednesday's sharp price increase.
Egypt accused Israel today of continuing to violate the cease-fire agreement and said Israeli troops had fired on Egyptian forces wherever they were found.

Six of Sunday's 12 National Football League games, including the clash between two unbeaten teams, the Los Angeles Rams and the Vikings at Minnesota were sold out yesterday, 72 hours before kickoff, and will be televised locally, the league said.
After an 18-race association, Secretariat will conclude his notable racing career on Sunday in Canada without Ron Turcotte in the irons.

The Board of Estimate yesterday opened the way for construction to begin Tuesday on Mitchell-Lama housing in the Northside section of Brooklyn for 30 families that lost their homes to permit the expansion of a factory.
In defiance of Government warnings, 65 Opposition candidates have withdrawn from the election scheduled next Sunday for a new National Assembly.

An aroused South Shore team defeated previously unbeaten Jefferson, 16-6, yesterday in a game that decided the title in the Public Schools Athletic Brooklyn Division II. South Shore, in its second season of varsity football, stifled Jefferson's powerful attack, which had rolled up 254 points in five straight victories.

Princeton will be a strong favorite to continue its monopoly in the seventh annual New Jersey intercollegiate cross-country championships Tuesday at Garret Mountain reservation. The United States Steel Corportion reported yesterday gains in sales and net income for the three and nine months ended Sept. 30. Shipments and sales set new highs for the first nine months.

Federal food stamp allotments for most four-person families will increase by $26 a month in January to help lowincome families cope with higher food prices, the Agriculture Department announced today.

The White House announced today that President Nixon would confer tomorrow with the Acting Foreign Minister of Egypt and on Thursday with Premier Golda Meir of Israel as part of an intensified effort to overcome cease-fire problems and clear the way for Arab-Israeli negotiations.
The United States today accaused North Victnam of shipping vast quantities of materiel and of sending large numbers of troops into South Vietnam in violation of the Jan 28 Paris peace agreements.

The House Commerce Committee overrode today Administration objections and added a $250-million labor-protection package to. legislation designed to salvage the bankrupt Northeast railroads. With only- one major provision remaining to be settled, the committee's chairman, Harley O.Staggers, Democrat of West Virginia, indicated, he expected the committee to report the bill out Wednesday.
A ring that reportedly conspired to steal and sell hundreds of thousands of dollars in stolen welfare checks was said to have been broken yesterday with the arrest of four men,

The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation voted unanimously today to defer action on Charles G. Rebozo's status as chief executive officer of the Key Biscayne Bank and Trust Company until completing an investigation in about three weeks.

The Toronto Maple Leafs aren't kidding around this season. Last year's National Hockey League's patsies whipped the Detroit Red Wings, 7-0, last night to move into a tie for second place in the East, a point behind the Boston Bruins.

Somewhere out there in the dazzling wordstorm of John Leonard's fourth novel, "Black Conceit," real characters grope about for a solution to the 1960's. One of them is Kenneth Coffin, the scion of a family so old and comfortably well off in New England history that the library of the family's ancestral home is decorated with the swords brought

A suburban Pittsburgh man, on his 43d birthday, suffered first and second degree burns yesterday in an explosion in his garage. Damage was estimated at $50,000 to his home, furnishings and two automobiles.

Caspar W. Weinberger, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told a conventions of American Indians here today that his department would not use Federal programs for Indians as a tool for exploiting natural resources on their reservations.
Great expectations fizzled yesterday at an auction sale as no bidders appeared for relics of Christopher Columbus contained in two crystal lockets.

Nobody-not the marketing geniuses, not the Government bureaucrats and not the strident consumerists-really knows consumers well enough to say that they are speaking for them, according to Harold M. Williams, dean of the Graduate School of Management of the University of California at Los Angeles.
Dr. Herman L. Frosch, a specialist in internal medicine, died at New York University Hospital on Monday. He was 78 years old and lived at 170 West End Avenue.

The word which, so recently, could scarcely be uttered without incredulity or shudder has blossomed into an active threat to the Presidency of Richard M. Nixon. The House Judiciary Committee has started a formal impeachment inquiry, voting its chairman, Representative Peter W. Rodino Jr., of New Jersey, full subpoena powers to gather evidence.
8-10 A.M., WNCN. Trumpet Concerto, Torelli; Three Sonatas, Cimarosa; Suite No. 2: Water Music, Handel; Nocturne for Strings, Dvorak; Piano Concerto No. 2, Beethoven.

Last February, Theodore Draper, a historian and writer, ordered a sofa and, love seat from W J Sloane's flagship store on Fifth Avenue for his new home in Princeton, N. J. Projected delivery: last June.
The city's firefighters warned yesterday of a possible strike or other action next Monday if a new contract has not been worked out by then.

Premier Kakuei Tanaka of Japan. and Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia agreed today that their Governments would negotiate a wide-ranging new treaty "to formalize, stabilize and broaden" their relations.,

A state appeals court ruled that municipal zoning authority did not include the power to limit the age of the persons who might live on land controlled by local zoning practice. The Appellate Division of Superior Court said: "All that a municipality may validly be concerned with in the exercise of its zoning power is the physical use of lands and structures thereon."
The Senate Watergate committee agreed this morning to try to wind up its publichearings by Thanksgiving.
After 81 years as one of the most widely known producers of men's wear, Botany Industries has gone bankrupt.
Bos Johnson, president of the 1,000-member RadioTelevision News Director's Association, said tonight that President Nixon was wrong to blame the mood of the nation on the TV networks.

Aaron Furman, the New York art dealer and present owner of the sacred African statue, the Afo-A-Kom, yesterday cabled the king of the tiny nation of Kom in Cameroon that he has decided to return the statue to its home.
The predominant quality of Gilda Muhlbauer's violin recital Monday night in Tully Hall was lyricism-warm, singing lines backed by a sweet tone that bathed everything she played in a delicious glow.
The Department of Justice accused the nation's trucking industry today of practicing discrimination against blacks and Spanish-Americans.

Egypt and Israel seem to be moving sensibly toward at least a limited prisoner exchange before the tempers of both sides are stretched any further on this emotional issue. Some Cairo spokesmen persist in attaching unrealistic conditions to any over-all exchange but the differences on what is obviously a humanitarian concern are being discussed jointly by Israeli and Egyptian representatives.

Prime Minister John Vorster is pushing ahead with the formulation of new laws to curb the South African press and has rejected a request to discuss the issue with the country's publishers' association, it was disclosed here today.

The police yesterday barred parents from entering Public School 37 in Jamaica, Queens, where they have conducted improvised instruction for kindergarten and first-grade pupils since classes started last month.
The Vancouver Canucks scored twice within a 38-second span in the third period tonight to overcome a two-goal deficit and gain a 3-3 tie with the Rangers.
Boston College, working to upgrade its football program, announced today it would play host to the University of Texas Longhorns in a season opening game next Sept. 14.
The United States Treasury borrowed $2-billion yesterday at higher interest rates than expected in a financing that wasn't snapped up with quite the verve that Wall Street had anticipated.

TITLE--"Negotiations on the Mutual Reduction of Forces and Armaments and Associated Measures in Central Europe," still referred to informally by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization as "M.B.F.R." or "mutual, balanced force reductions," as originally proposed by the alliance in June, 1968.

Doctors in some cities are "cavalierly" subjecting women, most of them poor and black, to surgical sterilization without explaining either potential hazards or algernate methods of birth control, the Health Research Group charged in a study released today.

Senator John G. Towers, Republican of Texas, a supporter of President Nixon's policies, said last night that the Watergate "trail" should be followed "wherever it leads--even into the Oval Office," The Associated Press reported.

An analysis of how 84 Swedish men and women want to die shows that two-thirds of the men and one-third of the women wanted to "die suddenly or unexpectedly," according to an unusual report by the chief internist at Sweden's oldest hospital.

Nixon Administration help to the dairy industry may appear suspicious because of dairymen's campaign contributions, but the decisions were taken on valid economic grounds, Agriculture Secretary Earl L. Butz said yesterday.

James C. Quinn, for more than three' decades secretarytreasurer of the Central Trades and Labor council of Greater New York, died Saturday in the Irvington Nursing Home in Newark. He was 85 years old and lived in Putnam Valley, N. Y.

J. Bennington Peers 3d, a regular contributor to the Harvard football program, characterized Dartmouth as "one of the most offensive herds of dullards ever to invadetany stadium."
Stan Smith opened the defense of his French indoor tennis championship today with an easy 6-3, 6-1 second-round victory over a fellow American, Jeff Borowiak.

A black militant who is appealing a conviction in St. Louis for a fatal assault on a policeman in a 1972 shootout was arrested in Brooklyn last night by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents and New York City police.

The White House charged today that the disclosure of President Nixon's' intervention in an antitrust case supported the Administration's contention that Archibald Cox had been running a partisan investigation for months before he was dismissed as special Watergate prosecutor.

Secretary of State Kissinger was quoted by a Congressional source today as having said he was "disgusted" with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the ground that its European members did not support United States policies in the Middle East crisis.

The City University of New York has picked Harold M. Proshansky, a professor of environmental, psychology with professional ties to the university dating to 1951, as president of the Graduate School and University Center.

A 41-year-old talent manager in the lock music industry who was convicted as a ringleader in a heroin smuggling conspiracy was sentenced today to 10 years in prison and fined $10,000 in Federal District court here.

President Nixon's contention last week that "every President since George Washington has tried to protect the confidentiality of Presidential conversations" is rebutted, at least in part, by a long-forgotten incident involving one of Washington's Cabinet officers.

Continued White House efforts to withhold Presidential papers and tape recordings would leave "a substantial number" of future prosecutions in the Watergate scandal in "jeopardy," the dismissed special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, contended today.
China has applied for membership of the International Monetary Fund, but the Fund's executive board has deferred a decision on the application, monetary sources said today.
Steve Reich's music has a way of getting under people's skin. Last winter in Carnegie Hall his "Four Organs" drove an otherwise respectable audience into a paroxysm of boos and catcalls.

With a verbal swipe at the "wise guys" and pollsters who have predicted his defeat in next week's gubernatorial election, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. told Monmouth

The House passed today and sent to the Senate a bill that would provide for continued education in the schools on the dangers of drugs and alcohol. The legislation would authorize $90-million in Federal aid for school and community programs over three years.

Top House leaders, protesting that they had not been officially notified, reacted coolly today to White House efforts to delay Congressional action on the issue of trade benefits for the Soviet Union.

The sporting world's Great Lover-Elect, Secretariat, makes his final New York appearance next Tuesday when he parades before an Election Day crowd after the third race at Aqueduct with Ron Turcotte in the saddle wearing the blue and white blocks of Meadow Stable.
Baseball, which ended its playing season a week ago, opened its paying season yesterday with the first of the winter's trophies: the Cy Young Award for the outstanding pitcher in the
the huge New Jersey sports complex, proposed by Sonny Werblin, was to be only a 10-minute drive from his warehouse. He was hoping the plans did not eventually include a golf course.

The White House charged today that the disclosure of President Nixon's intervention in an antitrust case supported the Administration's contention that Archibald Cox had been running a partisan investigation for months before he was dismissed as special Watergate prosecutor.
George P. Mitchell, former Deputy Police Commissioner of New York City, died at his home here yesterday. He was 81 years old.

The edgiest exchanges during an informal mayoral debate at The New York Times yesterday occurred between Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democrat who is thought to be far in the lead, and Assemblyman Albert H. Blumenthal, who ran fourth in the Democratic primary and is now the Liberal party candidate.

The Securities and Exchange Commission, in an unusual action, filed suit today against a major accounting firm, Peat, Marwick, Mitchell Co., as well as against the company whose allegedly false statements the accountants certified.

What brings corporations together in merger discussions? For Gulf Oil and the CNA Financial Corporation, two giants that dropped consolidation plans on Monday, the catalyst was the good will that existed between CNA's President, E. L. Nicholson, and Harold Hammer, who is executive vice president-finance for Gulf.

Nan T. Cuming, a retired nurse who was a former field representative of the Registered Nurses Guild, died yesterday in Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. She was 74 years old and lived at 208 East 88th Street.
Al Woodall returns as the Jets' starting quarterback Sunday and when he looks over the Miami defense, staring him in the face will be No. 84-Bill Stanfill.
The life sentence of Caril Ann Fugate, companion of Charles Starkweather, the 1958 Nebraska mass murderer, was commuted to a 30-to-50-years sentence today by the State Pardon Board.
The Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) today endorsed amnesty for draft evaders and elected the church's first woman moderator.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N. J.Maybe it isn't significant, but the Choate School, which has replaced its single-wing system with a winged-T, is enjoying a winning football season. Lawrenceville, which sticks to the single wing, is having a .500 campaign.

Aaron Furman, the New York art dealer and present owner of the sacred African statue, the Afo-A-Kom, yesterday cabled the king of the tiny nation of Kom in Cameroon that he has decided to return the statue to its home.

Montgomery Ward Co. today asked owners of 52,000 color television consoles or televisionstereo combinations sold in late 1969 to request inspection for a possible defect that could create an electrical shock hazard.
The United Automobile Workers began today the ratification of a new contract with the Ford Motor Company that contains some gains over the settlement with Chrysler.
Governor Rockefeller tonight denied that he was "moving to the right" to court favor with Republicans nationally.

Last Friday, President Nixon, in still another of his analyses of the "electronic media," complained that "I have never heard or seen such outrageous, vicious, distorted reporting in 27 years of public life.... When people are pounded night after night with that kind of frantic, hysterical reporting, it naturally shakes their confidence."

Governor Rockefeller tonight denied that he was "moving to he right" to court favor with republicans nationally. After arriving here to address Republican state dinner, the Governor was asked whether his toughened image on welare spending and other programs was evidence of a shift.
Copper and silver futures prices, weak in recent sessions, advanced quite sharply yesterday. One broker commented, "It's a war market again."
Al Woodall returns as the Jets' starting quarterback Sunday and when he looks over the Miami defense, staring him in the face will be No. 84-Bill Stanfill.
YONKERS, Oct. 30-Starlark Hanover, a filly who wanted to be a pacer, left no doubt at Yonkers Raceway tonight about why she's the nation's best 2-year-old trotter.
Queen Eliabeth II, with traditional pomp, opened a new session of Parliament .today and told the assembled peers and commoners what "my Government" intends to do in the next 12 months.

Connie Hawkins, the King of the Schoolyards who fought his way out of a Brooklyn ghetto to become a basketball millionaire, moved yesterday from Phoenix to Los Angeles in the National Basketball Association.

The judiciary committee of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York charged yesterday that 10 candidates for State Supreme Court judgeships had "violated the proprieties" in resigning from their Civil Court seats after receiving party nominations for the Supreme Court.

The Legal Aid Society, on behalf of three clients facing felony drug charges in State Supreme Court,. brought suit yesterday to prevent recently appointed Court of Claims judges from presiding over drug trials in Supreme Court.
The United States Embassy has asked the Chilean Government to investigate the violent deaths of two Americans in the wake of last month's military take-over here.

An American businessman complained after a frustrating day at the trade fair here: "The Chinese aren't going to make a significant impact on the American market until they change their policies on the question of labeling,

Brendan T. Byrne collected a crowd and picked up some votes during a lunch-hour walk through downtown Newark today.

In an unexpected move, William R. Roesch has resigned as chairman and president of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation to become president and chief executive officer of the Kaiser Industries Corporation. When Mr. Roesch leaves J. L. on Jan. 1, 1974, Roscoe G. Haynie will become chairman and chief executive and Thomas C. Graham will become president and chief operating officer.
Shareholders of the Fruehauf Corporation and the KelseyHayes Company approved yesterday in separate meetings a merger under which Kelsey would become a subsidiary of Fruehauf.

The Museum of Modern Art yesterday rejected an offer by its striking union of professional and administrative workers to go back to work tomorrow and to submit all disputed issues to a fact-finding panel.
Something calling itself the Greek Art Theater surfaced from the wine dark sea of Off Broadway last night at the Players Theater. It opened with Euripides's "Medea" in the Rex Warner translation.
The Unitarian Universalist Association has urged the House of Representatives to initiate impeachment procedures against President Nixon.

Henry H. Scudder, who retired in 1969 as chairman of the International Standard Electric Company, overseas manufacturing, research, licensing and sales subsidiary of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, died Monday at his home, 121 Bedford Road, Greenwich, Conn. He was 78 years old.
The Ford Motor Company said today it would go into the motor-home business, with production starting "early in 1975."
When the first chords of Berlioz's "Benvenuto Cellini" Overture sounded at Carnegie Hall on Monday night, older members of the audience turned and smiled at one another.
Boston College, working to upgrade its football program, announced today it would play host to the University of Texas Longhorns in a season opening game next Sept. 14.

If what their lawyers called the second Pentagon papers case, the authors and publisher of a forthcoming book about the Central Intelligence Agency filed suit in Federal Court yesterday to enjoin the Government from deleting roughly 10 per cent of the book's material and to halt all interference with its publication.
Thailand's new civilian Government ordered the seizure today of the fortunes of the three leaders who fled the country after the military regime was overthrown.
There was a time when no newspaper would have thought itself worthy of the name if it did not thunder at election time for or against a political candidate.

The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies has declared that the city's child-welfare system "in its structure and in its operation does result in religious and racial discrimination and inadequate care and service for a substantial number of children."
Governor Cahill will name a successor to Chief Justice Pierre P. Garen in time for consideration by the State Senate when it returns Nov. 12, aides to the Governor said today.

Despite two years of inflationary boom, there are still over four million people out of work. The jobless rate lingers at 4.8 per cent-well above the 4 per cent mark that was long considered a norm for reasonably full employment. It is remarkable that unemployment remains so high when over-all industrial capacity is under. heavy strain.
Irony, rather than humility, was Earl Weaver's reaction yesterday when he discovered he had been named the American League manager of the year by The Associated Press.
The stock market, saddled by a variety of uncertainties, buckled sharply yesterday to produce the biggest single decline since the start of the strong rally in mid-September.

In his private briefing of Congressional leaders on why he put the armed forces of the United States on worldwide alert the other day, President Nixon took a decidedly pessimistic view of the Soviet Union's objectives in the Middle East.

Declaring that New York City's child-welfare system produces "racial and religious discrimination and inadequate care for a substantial number of children," the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencis announced its support of a suit against the system's policy of placing children in institutions of their own religious background.

The Dutch Government, under pressure from an Arab ban on oil exports to the Netherlands, appealed today to other member countries of the European Common Market to share their oil supplies if necessary.

Look who's atop the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association: the Buffalo Braves. With a 105-103 victory over the Seattle Sonic at Buffalo last night, the Braves took a half-game lead over the idle Boston Celtics.

In the first formal report of a Congressional panel investigating the Watergate scandal, a House subcommittee said unanimously today that the Central Intelligence Agency had operated in a way that "had no support in reason or law."

An American antiwar activist has been forced out of his post as co-chairman of the American delegation at the World Peace Congress for having criticized the Soviet Union for its attempts to silence dissidents.

Secretary of State Kissinger was quoted by a Congressional source today as having said he was "disgusted" with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization on the ground that its European members did not support United States policies in the Middle East crisis.
Soviet leaders wept today over the grave of Marshal Semyon M. Budenny, Red Army hero of the Bolshevik Revolution and Civil War, who died Saturday at the age of 90.

Premier Robert Bourassa and his Liberal party today interpreted the landslide victory that they won in the provincial parliamentary elections yesterday as a repudiation of Quebec separatism. But others, noting that the separatists had gained too, took a different view.
Egypt today offered the release of Israeli prisoners of war on condition that Israeli troops withdraw to the cease-fire lines of Oct. 22.
President Nixon won his eighth consecutive veto battle of the year with Congress today as the Senate failed to override his veto of a bill authorizing funds for the United States Information Agency.

Flooded highways dried off, traffic slowly unsnarled itself and the high tides that had threatened shore communities returned to near normal yesterday as the metropolitan area shook off the effects of Monday's record 3.67-inch rainfall.
Ron Vander Kraats of Princeton led his team to victory today in the New Jersey State College and University cross-country championship.

The American representatives in 1974 world championship for the fifth straight year will be the Aces, captained by Ira Corn Jr. They scored a comfortable victory in the final playoffs here this afternoon by 90 international match points.

To the Editor: Marbury v. Madison (1803) is a case of unique interest to us today. In it the Supreme Court declared a law unconstitutional for the first time, thus establishing that Court's generally accepted function to rule on constitutionality.

United States officials said today that despite several suspicious signals, neither the United States nor Israel seriously believed at the start of October that the Arab countries were about to attack.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation announced yesterday the receipt of a contract valued at about $75-million for two 1.2-million-kilowatt nuclear turbine-generators.
Chile's military junta issued a 264-page report today in which it seeks to explain both here and abroad why it overthrew the Marxist coalition Government.

Contracts for new construction work throughout the nation will total $101-billion in 1974, or 2 per cent above this year's expected level, the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company announced yesterday.

A Soviet squadron of 20 ships, 10 of them modern and the rest auxiliaries, is operating in the Indian Ocean, according to the United States Navy. The United States force there is composed of two destroyers and a command ship- based on Bahrain in the Persian Gulf.

The Senate Finance Committee today confirmed the nomination of Helmut Sonnenfeldt as Under Secretary of the Treasury 168 days after it began hearings on the controversial White House appointment.

After offering two hours of testimony by nine witnesses, the prosecution rested ats case today against Lester Zygmaniak, a 23-year-old Monmouth County man who is charged with killing his brother with a shotgun in a local hospital last June.

President Nixon has nominated Morris Thompson of Juneau, Alaska, as Commissioner of Indian Affairs, Representative Don Young, Republican of Alaska, announced today.
The chief engineer of the New Jersey Highway Authority, Philip May, 53 years old, of Hamilton, pleaded guilty today to ,two counts of Federal income tax evasion.

The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit has overturned the trespassing conviction of five antiwar activists, ruling that military officers could not bar civilians from public areas of the Air Force Academy.

As two small boys and their mother watched in terror, a Brooklyn barber struggling with a holdup man, managed to wrest away a revolver and fired two shots that killed the intruder last night.

Today is the 87th birthday of President Chiang Kai-shek, and despite the strain in relations between his Nationalist Government and the United States in recent times, the Generalissimo had in hand a letter of congratulations from President Nixon.

Sakharov. They threatened his life if he ever again made a statement-as he had on Oct. 12--sympathetic to Israel. As a result of Dr. Sakharov's report of the incident, his friend, the Soviet writer Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn, wrote him this letter.

Look who's atop the Atlantic Division of the National Basketball Association: the Buffalo Braves. With a 105103 victory over the Seattle Sonics at Buffalo last night, the Braves took a half-game lead. over the idle Boston Celtics.

What the United States had envisioned as the Year of Europe, a period of imaginative updating and refurbishing of the NATO Alliance, capped with a new Atlantic Charter, has become instead the year in which Washington's relationship with its European partners has struck an all-time low.

The first offcial steps toward moving the Watergate tape recordings out of the White House vaults toward the grand jury were taken in Federal District Court today, and it looked like a long, slow journey.

A Wayne county court ordered the Detroit F deration of Teachers today to pay fines and damages that could far exceed $1-million for striking the school system here for six weeks.
The Boston School Committee prepared today to appeal to the Supreme Court a state court ruling ordering compliance with a Massachusetts law requiring racial balance in the city's public schools.
Rich Jones sparked a second-half rally and led the San Antonio Spurs to a 104-92 victory over the New York Nets in an American Basketball Association game tonight.
DURHAM, N.Y. -- Brooks Atkinson spent a good part of his life reviewing plays on deadline, and now he is spending another good part of his life away from all that.

United States officials said today that despite several suspicious signals, neither the United States nor Israel seriously believed at the start of October that the Arab countries were about to attack.

The Soviet Union blocked a move yesterday to ask Egypt, Syria and Israel to cooperate with the International Committee of the Red Cross on the matter of prisoners captured during the Middle East fighting.

Refunds are being offered to paid-up subscribers who failed to receive tickets to the series of film versions of famous Broadway and London plays being presented by the American Film Theater during the next eight months under the co-auspices of American Express Films, Inc., and the Ely Landau Organization, Inc.
Tomorrow's Miami Herald reports that Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, used an unreported $300,000 "booster" fund to defray office, travel and other expenses in 1971 and 1972.

Testifying before the Senate Finance Committee recently on his nomination as Under Secretary of the Treasury, Helmut Sonnenfeldt remarked with a tinge of sarcasm, "I may be one of the more investigated persons in this town."
The ancient issue of where the power should reside to control the nation's money and credit lies at the heart of a bill introduced by Representative Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas,

For its first major case since it was established last April, the National News Council will look into and appraise President Nixon's charges that certain news reporting by television networks had been "outrageous, vicious and distorted."

The annual convention of the New york State School Boards Association ended today, and the general feeling of many particpants was that while schools may not be as good as they should be, they are far better than their critics say they are.

Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today that only under a Threat of losing vital United States arms supplies had Israel permittedd relief convoys to reach 20,000 beleaguered Egyptian soldiers in Sinai.

Brilliant performances by Harvey Smith and Graham Fletcher paced the British Equestrian Team into a lead for the International Trophy at Madison Square Garden last night, where the National Horse Show opened an eight-day run.
The local National Alliance of Businessmen announced yesterday a "rejuvenation" of its program for hiring the disadvantage with new emphasis on veterans and ex-criminals.

The White House announced that President Nixon would confer today with the Acting Foreign Minister of Egypt, Ismail Fahmy, and tomorrow with Premier Golda Meir of Israel as part of an intensified effort to overcome cease-fire problems and clear the way for Arab-Israeli negotiations.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange tumbled yesterday in moderate trading. Some analysts attributed the drop to disappointment among investors over the failure of other banks to immediately follow the lead of the nation's two largest in reducing their prime rates.
The House Commerce Committee reported out today a $1.4-billion aid package structured to salvage tile bankrupt Northeastern railroads.

The Aces were not tested severely in the international playoff matches in Milwaukee this week. Their two victories, by 106 international match points in the semifinal and by 90 points in the final, reveal the extent to which they outclassed their opponents.

President Sadat's boastful belligerency and harsh rejection of direct peace talks with Israel at a press conference yesterday were in unfortunate contrast to the diplomatic initiative that was being pursued concurrently, with apparently serious and constructive purpose, by his new foreign minister in Washington.

Standard Oil Company of California, like most other major petroleum producers, turned in record profits for the third quarter with a 51 per cent gain over the similar three months last year, according to its report issued yesterday.
The price of raw farm products dropped 4 per cent in October, the Government said today, raising prospects of consumer relief at supermarket food counters later on.
The House passed and sent to the White House today a $185-million three-year authorization for Federal aid for emergency medical services. President Nixon vetoed a similar measure earlier this year.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged voter approval of the state's $3.5-billion transportation bond proposition as he sent the City Planning Commission a message calling for $900-mil-lion in capital projects within debt limit for 1973-74.

Over a one-month period in the fall of 1969, President Nixon made 21 separate requests to his top aides to take action to counter what the President saw as unfavorable news coverage, according to a memorandum made public tonight by Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, who is a member of the Senate Watergate committee, said today that the Justice Department was investigating allegations that builders had secretly contributed money to him and expected favors from the Federal Housing Administration in return.
With everyone else analyzing what's wrong with the New York Giants, Coach Alex Webster finally offered his theory today - a lack of aggressiveness and hustle.

France, smarting from what she sees as total Soviet-American disregard of Europe in the Middle East crisis, took the lead today in trying to restore Europe's world influence by tightening Common Market ties.
Julie: Artisans' Gallery, a newcomer to Madison Avenue, provides a showcase for the distinctive clothes, jewelry and home accessories created by a group of some 100 craftsmen.

The Suffolk County Board of Elections charged today that a concerted campaign was beings undertaken to "rig" the East Hampton Town elections by having summer residents of the wealthy resort community vote illegally by absentee ballot.
Once a year, owners of miniature dachshunds stage a roundup. This year it was at the Lehigh Valley show and of the 144 badger dogs entered at the Pennsylvania fixture, 110 were minis.

Plans to bring up a tax-reform proposal in the House of Representatives this week were apparently thwarted today by strategists in two key Congressional committees, some of whom conceded that they were acting under pressure from the oil industry and other businesses.

President Salvador Allende Gossens of Chile committed suicide by shooting himself with a submachine gun shortly after the armed forces attacked the presidential palace during the September 11 coup, according to an official medical report published here today.
An artificial earth satellite, Intercosmos 10, has been launched in. the Soviet Union under a joint program with other socialist countries to explore space, Tass reported today.
FREEHOLD, N. J., Oct. 31--"I am here to end your pain, George. Is it all right with you? He nodded, yes - the next thing I knew I had shot him."

While details supplied by the White House about the case of two conversations that were said to have been recorded, and now reportedly were not, do not directly conflict with what has been made public about the recordings, statements by Presidential aides have made no previous mention of tape troubles.
Gerald R. Ford will go before a Senate committee tomorrow for the opening round of questioning on his fitness to become Vice President of the United States.
Cambridge University has appointed Archibald Cox, recently dismissed by President Nixon as the special Watergate prosecutor, Pitt Professor of American History and Institutions.
The defending champion, Stan Smith of Sea Pines S. C., overcame mistakes to defeat Jaime Fillol of Chile, 6-3, 6-7, 6-2, and reach the quarterfinals of the French indoor tennis championships.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange rose early in the day but finished lower in slackened trading, continuing a downward trek as news that could be constructed as bullish remained lacking. Prices also fell in the over-the-counter market in slightly higher volume.

Officials here expressed "much happiness" today that a New York art dealer had agreed to return the most sacred statue of the people of Kom to the isolated mountaintop village from which it was taken seven years ago.

Senator Edmund S. Muskie's Presidential campaign manager testified today that Republican dirty tricks disrupted strategy, generated suspicion and animosity among Democratic Presidential candidates and demoralized Mr. Muskie's staff workers during the 1972 campaign.
Westchester Rockland Newspapers, a member of the Gannett chain, has decided to support none of the three candidates for Westchester Executive.

A gleaming, airliner-styled turbo train was turned loose on the Toonerville trackage of the Penn Central between New York and Albany today as a symbol of the kind of high-speed train t that could be running along the Hudson by 1976.

The combination of Frank Chapot, captain of the United States Equestrian Team, and a little white stallion named Good Twist led the international jumping field last night in winning the Frederick D. Mackay Memorial Challenge Trophy event for the second year in a row.

THE WIND SHIFTING WEST. By Shirley Ann Grau. 247 pages. Knopf. $6.95. In her second collection of short stories, Shirley Ann Grau shows an impressive range: her stories stretch from fairly good to pretty bad.
A child can join the Squirrel Club at the Glendale Savings and Loan Association with a $3 minimum deposit in a savings account.
Joseph N. Monty denied yesterday that he had ever taken money for performing favors for Avis Rent-A-Car Systems, Inc., while he was chief rackets investigator for the Queens District Attorney.
The Columbia - Presbyterian Medical Center has received a $5-million gift from the Commonwealth Fund toward its five-year, $133-million expansion program initiated earlier this year.
The television version of Theodore H. White's "The Making of the President--1972" has been completed but at the moment is without sponsor or network.

Rain in the Middle Western harvest areas dominated futures trading on the. Chicago Board of Trade yesterday and prices staged quite a sharp recover from the recent downturn, although they closed below their best levels of the session.

The Justice Department said today that it had no evidence that President Nixon's close friend, Charles G. Rebozo, had cashed stolen stock certificates. As a result, the department said, it has closed its investigation of the matter.

Mrs. Shirley Salem, president since 1964 of Salem Stores, a retail and mail-order distributor of lingerie, sportswear and hosiery, died of cancer Wednesday in Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. She was 54 years old and lived at 124 Onslow Place, Kew Gardens, Queens.
Richardson Thurston, board chairman of Polymer Industries, Inc., of Stamford, died yesterday at his home in Wilton. He was 49 years old.

Cultural institutions ought to be the last place for resort to the law of the jungle in resolving disputes between management and unionized professional employes. Submitting all unresolved issues to determination by impartial experts makes much more sense in such situations than waiting for one side or the other to crack under the strain of a prolonged strike.

The key child-care agencies are resigning from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies in protest over the federation's criticism of the city's child-welfare system as resulting in "religious and racial discrimination and inadequate care."
They still call the Saturday night dances "hops," and cannon search the bend in the Hudson River where the British navy once tried to enter.
Mary Simons, now editor in chief of Homelife magazine, has been appointed to fill a new position as a senior editor of The New York Times Magazine.

Striking workers at the Muscum of Modern Art received assurances last night of aid from other unions in their dispute.

A major breakthrough in the detection of anabolic steroids, the body-building drugs used by many of the leading sportsmen to improve their performances, has been made by a British research team.
The November issues of just about every magazine have a story pegged to the tenth anniversary of the death of John F. Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31--With the nation's oil supplies starting to tighten because of production cutbacks by Arab nations, Washington and the states begin tomorrow a joint "mandatory allocation" program intended to help the country to scrape through the winter without jeopardy to public health or grave damage to the economy and the education of children.
Mario Biaggi, Albert H. Blumenthal and John J. Marchi each indicated yesterday that he was still hopeful of being elected Mayor, despite polls showing that Controller Abraham D. Beame was far ahead.

A Navy enlisted man was killed yesterday when a 100-foot underwater demolition team's vessel rammed a minisubmarine in San Diego Harbor. The accident occurred as both boats returned to Coronado amphibious base from routine exercises with 40 other vessels.

New York City agreed yesterday to walve its Shea Stadium rental fee if the Public Schools Athletic League wanted to stage its football final there. However, the offer was reluctantly refused by the league, which earlier had been told it would cost $31,900 in deposits and fees to use the ballpark.
To the Editor: As the smoke settles over Washington, we must pause to ask what justice requires of this nation with respect to its President.
Hash marks, a group of women learned the other night at an East Side church, are not greasy spots on some careless cook's wall. They are the one-yard markers running the length of a football field.
The Exxon Corporation, the world's largest oil company, announced yesterday that it was resuming allocations of gasoline to all customer groups in its East and Gulf Coast markets, effective today.

The Public Service Commission today envisioned the possibility of shutting down schools, instituting curfews and cutting off heat in the New York City subways this winter as it ordered major utility companies to prepare emergency contingency plans within the next two weeks.

Senator William B. Saxbe, an Ohio.Republican with a reputation for outspokenness who is an occasional critic of President Nixon, said tonight he had been offered the post of Attorney General and had accepted.
Alizona, Inc., and Cutter Laboratories, Inc., announced jointly yesterday that they were negotiating for the possible acouisition of Cutter by Akzona.

President Anwar el-Sadat warned today that pressure from Egypt's army would force him to renew the war if Israeli forces have not withdrawn to the Oct. 22 cease-fire line by the time Secretary of State Kissinger visits here next week.

The surprise disclosure yesterday by Presidential counsel J. Fred Buzhardt that two of the nine subpoenaed Watergate tapes do not exist is the latest, and possibly the most serious, blow to both the investigation and to White House credibility.

Before the awed gaze of countless millions of television addicts, the remarkable O. J. Simpson of the Buffalo Bills gave a truly virtuoso performance against the Kansas City Chiefs on Monday night. He virtually had the electric scoreboard screaming. Near the end of the game it kept lighting up the sullen, rain-filled skies with alternate flashes of "Juice" and "1,000."

William M. Ramsey, who as director of radio advertising for the Procter Gamble Company, soap manufacturer, backed the daytime serial dramas that gave the country the phrase "soap opera," died here today in Jewish Hospital. He was 73 years old.

The financially troubled WestgateCalifornia Corporation today became a ward of the Federal District Court here when C. Arnholt Smith formally surrendered control of the $190-million conglomerate to a new board of directors selected by Judge Leland C. Nielsen.

Senate Judiciary Committee hearings on the dismissal of the former special Watergate prosecutor, Archibald Cox, fell into partisan bickering today as two Republicans tried to portray Mr. Cox and his staff as indiscreet Democrats out to get the President.
The only wild flock of the world's whooping cranes has begun its annual migration from the Canadian marshlands to the bird's winter nesting grounds on a remote coastal peninsula in southern Texas.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company said yesterday that it was facing far more serious shortages of natural gas than it had originally expected and that its 1.1 million customers in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island might be in for a rough winter.
"Don't be caught cold by the fuel shortage!" read a newspaper advertisement for a heater last Sunday.
Rick Martin scored three goals at close range to lead the Buffalo Sabres to a 3-2 victory over the California Golden Seals in a National Hockey League game last night in Buffalo.
Antiques, folk art, sophisticated porcelains and latter-day home appurtenances are companionably ensconced at Greenwich House in the settlement's annual antiques fair.

A New Jersey gravestone dealer was charged yesterday with preying on the "grief and despair" of bereaved families in a fraudulent inscription scheme that bilked "hundreds" of people in the metropolitan area.

Fifteen former presidents of the New York State Bar Association yesterday denounced as a "flagrant misrepresentation" the charge that "judges do not do a day's work" and criticized the man they identified as author of the charge, Jacob D. Fuchsberg, the Democratic nominee for chief judge.

The Maxwell House division of the General Foods Corporation announced yesterday that it would increase its wholesale prices for ground coffees and decaffeinated instant and freeze-dried coffees on Dec. 3.
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the third quarter and first nine months of 1973.

There are musicians whose talent is so obvious that their failings as performers can be a puzzle and even an irritation. Rita Bouboulidi, a Greek pianist who gave a recital at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, fell squarely in that class.

Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and the Daily News and The New York Times intensified their efforts yesterday to resolve their differences and avert a strike threatened for next Monday.

Syria charged Israeli today with repeated and continuing violations of the 1949 Geneva Convention on the protection of war victims and said she would not. submit lists of Israeli war prisoners until Israel carried out the convention in full.
A 12-year-old boy was killed last night in an elevator accident as a result of a friendly scuffle with a 22-year-old man who tried to prevent him from going on a trick-or-treat Halloween expedition.

Both of New Jersey's gubernatorial candidates .agree that only a huge infusion of Federal money can help resuscitate the state's moribund commuter railroads, but each has his own ideas about who should run them.

President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that almost one year of the "so-called cease-fire" had not ended the war in South Vietnam and that Communist forces were preparing for an offensive.

Justice Albert S. McGrove of Brooklyn Supreme Court has signed a temporary restraining order requiring the Exxon Corporation to continue its contractual delivery of diesel fuel to the Transit Authority,

Three stockholders who were customers of Weis Securities, Inc., filed a suit in Federal court here yesterday seeking damages for all those who failed to receive ful value for securities they had deposited with the financially troubled brokerage company before it closed down last May 24.
Firemen gained the upper hand today in fighting a fierce brush fire that drove hundreds of persons from canyon homes on the outskirts of Los Angeles.

Albert N. Connett, a former commander in the Naval Reserve, died here today at his home, His age was 87. Mr. Connett was liaison officer between the American and French ordinance departments during World War 1.
Donald M. Bermingham, a former editor of Life magazine and of the Time-Life News Service died in Glen Cove Hospital on Monday. He was 68 years old and lived here.

Among the welter of ideas put forth as finished dances on the Choreoconcerts program Tuesday evening at the New School, Stuart Hodes's "Transit Gloria" alone translated impulse into finished movement.
After four and a half years of study, a royal commission proposed steps today toward limited self-government for Scotland and Wales to counter rising nationalist discontent in both regions.

A parent-sponsored boycott took effect yesterday at Public School 37 in Jamaica, Queens, almost halving the normal attendance, with 358 out of 705 registered at the school at 179-37 137th Avenue attending classes.
The Palestinian resistance is favorably disposed toward taking part in a Middle East peace conference, along with Arab governments and Israel, reliable Palestinian sources said today.
A hijacked helicopter airlifted three Irish Republican Army men to freedom from a prison exercise yard here today. The escape was carried out at Mountjoy jail close to the city center.

The World Congress of Peace Forces, a Soviet experiment in winning broader support in the West for Moscow's version of detente, ended tonight without appearing to have won over many of the very people it had haped to enlist.

Agnew as Governor of Maryland in 1969, reported today that he had returned $53,950 in contributions for his 1974 re-election campaign to 40 consulting engineers and architects who are eligible to receive nonbid contracts from the state.

Arthur Ashe was told yesterday he could compete in the South African open tennis championships at Johannesburg next month.

WASHINGTON - President Nixon may be the most elaborately briefed President in our history on what the news media say-and he may be the most badly informed. This does not explain Mr. Nixon's profound animosity toward professional journalism. But it may illustrate how this feeling is reinforced.
A $10,000 personal check from former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew was received at the United States Attorney's office in Baltimore today to pay a fine imposed on Mr. Agnew for income tax evasion.

A Federal judge today banned the enforcement of a New Jersey law permitting the dropping of convicted welfare cheats from relief rolls.

Sanford I. Freedman, an assistant city corporation counsel for the last 10 years, has been offered a post with Loew's Corporation, and the city's Board of Ethics has ruled that there would be no conflict of interest if he took the job.

With the gubernatorial campaign in the home stretch and Brendan T. Byrne far ahead in the polls, the Domocratic nominee is nevertheless campaigning as if his political life depended upon it.

President Anwar el-Sadat warned today that pressure from Egypt's army would force him to renew the war if Israeli forces have not withdrawn to the Oct. 22 cease-fire line by the time Secretary of State Kissinger visits here next week.

Stock prices plummeted across a broad front yesterday for the second session in a row. This week's profit taking was set into motion by renewed uncertainties over the Watergate crisis--and its impact upon President Nixonas well as the uneasy road to a peace settlement in the wartorn Middle East.
Leaders of the American Indian Movement have begun ne gotiating with older, more established Indian organizations in hopes of forming a national coalition to press for Indian rights.

The Senate Commerce Committee approved yesterday a bill that would require the Secretary of Transportation to develop an "energy-efficient, low-polluting" automobile engine within four years, and would authorize $200-million in loan guarantees and $140-million in direct grants to get the job done.
Prices were down yesterday in the Government bond market as investors and dealers digested the two-part, $3.6-billion Treasury refinancing.

Charles O. Finley, the Oakland A's controversial owner, has been placed on indefinite probation by Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and warned of possible more drastic action for any further infractions, United Press International reported yesterday.
The manufacturers of men's ski jackets, parkas, leather coats and other heavy outerwear predict that these items will cost at least 10 per cent more next fall than they cost now.

Three race tracks in New Jersey and one in Florida were indicted today on charges of illegally contributing thousands of dollars to Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign and listing the contributions as legitimate busi ness expenses on corporate in come tax returns.

The scoreless tie Westfield and Nutley played last Saturday was costly for both teams. Westfield's bid for a state record of 41 straight victories ended at 36, although the Union County high school did extend its unbeaten string to 48. There have been two ties in that streak.
Saturday telecasts of Aqueduct's get-rich-quick triple probably will begin within two weeks, a spokesman for the New York Racing Association indicated yesterday.
The Soviet Union, apparently moving to smooth over public differences with Washington on the Middle East, today abruptly dropped its criticism of President Nixon's handling of the crisis last week.
A suspect who fled when a policeman sought to question him broke into a home on Valiant Drive this afternoon and held a housewife hostage for nearly an hour before he was talked into surrendering.
Several prosecutors said here yesterday that they were now attempting to extradite Robert L. Vesco on the basis of a new indictment charging the fugitive financier with fraud.

A 16-year-old youth from the Lower East Side who admitted killing a 70-year-old grocer during a holdup last May was put into an upstate experimental rehabilitation program near here that authorities abandoned as unworkable a month after it began.

Mickey Lolich's stolen World Series ring was recovered yesterday more than two years after a sneak thief took it from a locker room at the old Kansas City Municipal Stadium. Lolich received the ring for his participation in the Detroit Tigers' 1968 Series victory.

The United States, seeking a formula to overcome the ceasefire dispute between Egypt and Israel, has proposed that a special corridor be established between Cairo and the encircled Egyptian III Corps and policed by United Nations personnel.
The Pentagon today ended its worldwide military alert called last week and 350,000 servicemen returned to normal duties.

A rookie, Mike Green, and Byron Beck came off the bench in the fourth period to score 17 points between them and give the Denver Rockets a 107-103 victory over the New York Nets tonight at the Denver Auditorium.

A crash survey by state health inspectors of the 104 profit-making nursing homes here has found accumulations of dirt- and garbage, overcrowding, improper infection control or other "serious operating deficiencies" in nearly two-thirds of the facilities, according to a state health official.
A controversial plan to deliver food, water and medical supplies to a large force of surrounded Egyptian soldiers is moving at a snail's pace.

A Superior Court judge refused for a second time yesterday to unseat Newark City Councilman Louis M. Turco, who had pleaded guilty to Federal tax charges. Judge Irwin I. Kimmelman ruled Turco's guilty plea was not equivalent to a conviction, because the former Council President had not yet been sentenced.
The Massachusetts Legislature is now the only state legislature in the country still in session, and lenders say it might last until Christmas.

Three race tracks in New Jersey and one in Florida were indicted today on charges of illegally contributing thousands of dollars to Governor Cahill's 1969 campaign and listing the contributions as legitimate business expenses on corporate income .tax. returns.

A grandmother was turned back by security police at Boise Airport until she checked her slingshot in with her luggage. "It was an armed slingshot," said A. V. Cox, United Air Lines station manager, "and it falls into the category of unacceptable items not allowed aboard an aircraft."

Two gunmen broke into the East Side apartment of a musical booking agent yesterday, and while one kept the man's pregnant wife hostage, the other accompanied the agent across town to a bank, where the victim removed $11,000 from a safe-deposit box and gave it to the robber, the police reported.

An agreement between the New York Stock Exchange and the Pacific Exchange to merge clearing and depositors services is "very imminent," perhaps no more than a month or two away, James J. Needham, chairman of the Big Board, told a Houston audience yesterday.

The Public Service Commission today envisioned the possibility of shutting down schools, instituting curfews and cutting off heat in the New York City subways this winter as it ordered major utility companies to prepare emergency contingency plans within the next two weeks.

Dr. Paul Dudley White, the renowned leader in the fight against blood and heart diseases, died today at Massachusetts General Hospital at the age of 87. He had been hospitalized since Oct. 15; when he suffered a massive stroke.

Former Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy received an award for "meritorious service and the betterment of police and community relations" from the National Conference of Christians and Jews at a luncheon yesterday at Luchow's restaurant.

A gleaming, airliner-styled turbo train made the run between New York and Albany yesterday as a symbol of the kind of high speed train New Yorkers could have by 1976.

The United Automobile Workers has set a 10 A.M. strike dead line Nov 19 at the Genera Motors Corporation. The strike deadline was made public yesterday by Leonar Woodcock, U.A.W. president minutes after the union's National Ford Council, by a wide margin, recommended approval of a new contract with the Ford Motor Company. The National Broadcasting Company's chimes, an audio trademark since 1929, are being eliminated for a new, more modern sound.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 31. (AP)--The Senate Investigation subcommittee asked the Justice Department today to determine whether Federal laws were violated in the Nixon Administration's handling of the 1972 wheat sale to the Soviet Union.

The White House effort to turn Archibald Cox's indiscretion into a high crime and misdemeanor would be funny if it were not so ugly. The men who tapped their colleagues' telephones now lecture us on the sin of breaking confidences!
Air service over much of the nation is being reduced today as major airlines cut flight schedules because of the Federal mandatory fuel allocation program.
Fortyfive naval officers who tried to overthrow the Government and restore the exiled King Constantine last May were given dishonorable discharges today.
Walt Kelly's fellow cartoonists honored him yesterday as a "genius in his time" at a short memorial service sponsored by the National Cartoonists Society at the Lambs Club here.

With a smiling Mayor Lindsay standing by, Alitalia Airlines announced yesterday that it had decided after a long study to double its office space on, Fifth Avenue rather than quire h move out of the city.
A hijacked helicopter airlifted three Irish Republican Army men to freedom from a prison exercise yard here today. The escape was carried out at Mountjoy jail close to the city center.

Western delegates at the talks on troop reductions in Central Europe said today that they did not intend to propose cuts in air forces or nuclear weapons on either side. The Soviet Union's spokesman said both should be discussed.
Arthur Ashe was told yesterday he could compete in the South African open tennis championships at Johannesburg next month.
The Christian Chprch (Disciples of Christ) endorsed today the Equal Rights Amendment and called for increased participation of women in their own ranks.
The board of directors of the New York Philharmonic met last night to consider action in the five-week-old musicians' strike but adjourned apparently without arriving at a new position.

The progress of the amendments to the Landmarks Law has been about as stately as some of the landmarks themselves, but the proposed revisions coming before the City Council today would eliminate loopholes in the current law and strengthen it considerably.

Romans filled bathtubs and jugs today as they prepared to go without water supply for four days amid public controversy over whether the ordeal is really necessary.

Watergate investigators are looking into the possibility that the nation's largest milk marketing cooperative may have made illegal corporate contributions to both major parties in the last two Presidential elections.
Premier Golda Meir departed for Washington today, leaving behind an Israel divided over her Government's handling of the war and deeply concerned about the future.

Dr. Ernest Little, dean emeritus of the Rutgers University College of Pharmacy and the first president of the American Foundation for Pharmaceutical Education, died here yesterday at his home. He was 85 years old.

Basil L. Rowe, chief pilot for Pan American World Airways for 30 years until his retirement in 1956, died on Sunday at his home in Coral Gables. He was 77 years old. Mr. Rowe leaves a brother, Carl, and a sister, Mrs. Lewis White.

President Nixon asked Congress today to appropriate $1.5billion more as the United States contribution to the International Development Association, which funnels longterm, low-cost loans to the world's poor nations.
Book World, The Washington Post's Sunday book review supplement, will end after 10 years when it goes to press this week.

The Health Department has released the names of 61 more restaurants and food stores in the city accused of having violated the Health Code after their owners failed to correct infractions that persisted through two inspections.

A committee of social activists, writers and academicians calledd on college students today to fast at their family Thanksgiving tables as a "national rededication to the struggle against racism in the universities, in the White House and in their home towns."
A surge of dollar buying on the foreign-exchange market here went into its second day this morning, pushing the value of the Japanese yen to its lowest point since the currency crisis last winter.
The day last month that Rob Spicer made his first start as a New York Jet, the Jets were trounced by the Miami Dolphins, 31-3.
Representative Gerald R. Ford assured a Senate committee today that, as Vice President, he would attempt to be a "peacemaker" and a "calm communicator between the White House and Capitol Hill."
The state Republican party canceled today a fund-raising dinner with Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois because Watergate developments hurt sales of tickets for the $100a-plate affair.
Israel charged today that Egypt has broken the Middle East cease-fire for the second day in a row by attacking Israeli positions along the east bank of the Suez Canal.

The Southern Pacific Company's president, Benjamin F. Biaggini, complained yesterday that the huge system had lost an estimated $22-million of business so far this year because of the national shortage of railroad equipment as well as the fact that one of the severest winters in history had held down shipments from the S.P.'s territory of perishable farm products.

Ben Crenshaw, playing in his first tournament after receiving his approved player's card, scored a six-underpar 65 for the first-round lead today in the $125,000 San Antonio-Texas open golf tournament.

Rutgers University was urged today by its University Senate a faculty-student-administrative body, to start legal action against the State of New Jersey to stop alleged encroachments upon the university's statutory autonomy.
Sears, Roebuck Co. said yesterday it was trying to contact the owners of some 65,000 portable dishwashers about a possible safety hazard.
A' suspicious fire, the ninth in this exclusive island resort area in' the last three weeks, heavily damaged an unoccupied summer home early today.
In an effort to control boll weevils without heavy use of pesticides, agricultural scientists in Texas have developed a smaller, faster-growing cotton plant.

Meeting in Scottsdale, Ariz., the general managers of baseball teams in the National League have been disporting themselves in Marge Everett's swimming pool while their employers fret about Marge's fitness to join their lodge.

Secret Service agents testified today that more than 30 tape recordings of Presidential conversations had been removed from a safe by White House aides at the request of President Nixon, and that their return had never been recorded.
Judge William C. Sachtjen of Dane County Circuit Court today sentenced Karleton Lewis Armstrong to an "indeterminate" prison term not to exceed 23 years.

The Chrysler Corporation announced today its intention to raise car and truck prices an average of $63.25 to meet material and labor costs, including wage increases in its recently negotiated contract with the United Auto Workers.
The train From Bratislava on the Czech border arrived in Vienna's South Station today at 12:25, three minutes behind schedule.

William Steinberg, not as spry as he used to be but as expert and knowledgeable as ever, conducted the Pittsburgh Symphony on Wednesday night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Steinberg, who had been ill last year, has a chair on his podium and uses it until he forgets his doctor's advice.
Premier Golda Meir of Israel said after meeting for more than an hour with President Nixon that she was "reassured" of continued American support for Israel's security.
Stock prices continued to slide yesterday in a partial correction of the huge six-week advance that started rolling in mid-September.
Canada, the United States top source of foreign oil, announced tonight that she was increasing her export tax on crude oil by 375 per cent.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Three window inspectors were rescued without injury yesterday when their metal scaffold began to malfunction at the 16th floor of an incompleted building at 1144 Avenue of the Americas, on the corner of 42d Street. A 16th-century Florentine bowl-small, misshapen and no bigger than a cereal dish--was sold Thursday at Sotheby Parke Bernet for $180,000, setting two world auction records and bringing joy to the hearts of five nuns in the audience.
The nation's unemployment rate dropped to 4.5 per cent in October, the lowest level in three and a half years, the Government reported today.

Daniel C. Kremens, a con evicted killer of a policeman escaped today from Trenton State Prison. Kremens, 40, of Brooklyn was serving a life term fo the 1966 murder of a statetrooper, Anthony Lukis, on the New Jersey Turnpike near Bordentown.
