The American business school has long made important contributions to the training of the world's business leaders. Among them the Harvard Business School has enjoyed a reputation of pre-eminence, one that has led some observers, not entirely without malice, to describe it as the West Point of capitalism. "The Gospel According to the Harvard Business School," a new book by Peter Cohen, a recent graduate, provides a view of the school through a student's eyes.

Undefeated Riverdale had to rally today to beat Hackley, 19-8, for its seventh victory today. Damon Powell, the Riverdale fullback, gained 176 yards and scored a touchdown, his 10th of the season. Paul Meltzer, a Riverdale halfback, scored two touchdowns.

Stock prices plummeted last week as confusion and uncertainty gripped investors. The result was the biggest weekly decline in years for the Dow-Jones industrial average. Chile's military rulers have finally ordered an end to summary executions, though military courts are still inflicting death penalties. The junta has also transferred the last group of foreign prisoners from the Santiago stadium to the care of refugee agencies. These overdue actions in themselves will not advance national reconciliation very far, nor halt the storm of criticism from abroad of the junta's excesses.
KUWAIT, Nov. 4--The Arab oil embargo against supporters of Israel is more severe than was originally foreseen, and new supply cuts are impending, Arab oil ministers said here today.

What has long been contemplated as East-West negotiation for Mutual and Balanced Force Reductions (MBFR) in central Europe became reality last week under the name of the Vienna conference for "Mutual Reduction of Forces and Armaments and Associated Measures in Central Europe" (MURFAAMCE). This is one case in which diplomats' propensity for complexity of jargon is an accurate reflection of complexity of subject matter.

President Nixon stood fast today in the face of multiplying demands for his resignation. Gerald L. Warren, the White House deputy press secretary, reiterated firmly that Mr. Nixon had "absolutely no intention of resigning."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 4-For reasons going back centuries in Anglo-American legal history, we have an adversary system of justice in this country. The premise of that system is that truth is most likely to emerge, in a court of law, from an open clash of conflicting interests. It is not the only possible view; other cultures differ. But it is ours.

Martha Mitchell, one of the first public figures to call for President Nixon's resignation, predicted last night that he would have to quit and "will be out by April."

Sal Matera, champion of the Marshall Chess Club here, took a 1-to-O lead yesterday over George Kramer, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, in their four-game Emery Cup match being televised on consecutive weekends from Albany over the Eastern Educational Network.

When Mariner 10 reaches Mercury in five months, its television cameras are expected to return the first highresolution pictures for mapping more than half of the hitherto unexplored planet, a barren sun-baked body that may re semble the cratered moon.

PLAINFIELD, Vt. - The scarlet leaves of the maples and the yellow of the birches are nearly all down now, and in the wild forest surrounding Spruce Mountain the black bear are preparing their winter dens under uprooted trees or in hollow logs, where cubs will be born in late January or early February.

Civilian 'and military search teams flew over hundreds of miles of rugged wilderness today seeking the body of a man who had been sucked through a jetliner's shattered cabin window 39,000 feet above the ground.

A new census study of the nation's voting patterns reports that the percentage of Negroes who voted--already well below the percentage of whites voting --declined faster than the figure for whites in last year's Presidential election.
Some intelligent planning and taste have gone into "The Carroll O'Connor Special," a generally pleasant 90 minutes due tonight at 9:30 over the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Two people were slain in separate incidents Saturday night after becoming involved in traffic disputes. In Manhattan, at 51st Street near 10th Avenue, an 18-yearold girl from Scotch Plains, N.J., visiting the city with five friends, was shot and killed by a girl in another car after a minor collision.

In an action last week that reflects the growing public concern over the failure of auditors to protect the public, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit against a major accounting firm, Peat, Marwick, Mitchell and Company, as well as against the corportion whose allegedly false statements the accountants certified.

New Jersey's major candidates for Governor, carrying their battle for votes down to the wire, confronted each other yesterday in two televised appearances in which each reiterated his stands on such issues as the state income tax and legalized abortion.

Forty-eight voluntary hospitals and nursing homes stocked up on blood plasma and TV dinners yesterday in last-minute preparations for a strike of 30,000 technical, service and maintenance workers set for 6 A.M. this morning.
Mrs. Jane Gold Kurland, widow of Robert J. Kurland and daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert A. Gold of New York, was married here yesterday afternoon to Dr. paul Hans of Newton,
The Israeli Army radio said today that Syrian roops on the northern Golan heights front had killed Israeli prisoners of war.

Secretary of State Kissinger is scheduled to leave today on a round-the-world trip that will take him to Cairo for crucial talks on strengthening the Middle East cease-fire and to Peking for a long-planned review of international affairs with Chinese leaders. He will visit nine countries in 10 days. [Page 1, Column 4.]

Howard Hawks, Raoul Walsh and William Wellman have made in the last 50 years, from silents to talkies, from small screen to Cinemascope, almost 200 movies that form a rich library of American film history.
Each year, more and more ships from West Germany, Japan and other foreign countries dock at American ports to unload their cargoes of Volkswagens, Toyotas and other shiny new imported cars.
At Ricker College, a tiny liberal arts school two miles from the Canadian border, a student may be able to skip two of the usual four years because of reading he has done or experiences he has had.

AMHERST, Mass. -Vermont's kickoff went to Tim Berra 3 yards from the Massachusetts goal line, and as he snugged the ball against his red jersey his father grunted involuntarily. "He's got it!" Yogi Berra said, as if Tim's mother, Carmen, didn't know. Tim started fast. He is an abandoned runner, all threshing elbows and pumping knees. He burst past a cluster of white shirts, slanted right across the hash marks and kept going.

Four years ago Michael Patrick took his first riding lesson. Yesterday, the 18year-old youth, aboard Irish Coffee, at the National Horse Show, was named the winner of the championship trophy of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, more familiarly known as the Maclay class.
United States Attorney Herbert J. Stern has announced the creation of a Special Election Task Force to handle complaints of irregularities Tuesday's statewide election.
Although a new Mayor will be elected tomorrow, the present Mayor will demonstrate today that his own power is still considerable by naming five Civil Court judges. Four of them will be women.

In 1815 an army pay clerk made a $47.50 mistake, according to Ernest Shead, a retired schoolmaster. As he sees it, the Government owes him $172.5-million.

The people roller-skated, bicycled, strolled six abreast or trotted on horseback through the streets of their cities today. They rowed in their canals, held sitdown picnics in the middle of empty superhighways and went to soccer games in 19th century coaches drawn by mane-tossing steeds.
ROME, Nov. 4--The Communist party has come out against legalized abortion, angering Italy's fledgling women's movement and pleasing the Vatican.

Dr. Judah J. Shapiro, Zionist National Committee for Labor leader and educator, was elected yesterday president of the Israel at the close of the organizations's three-day golden jubilee convention at the New York Hilton Hotel.
Albert Henry Aronson, a retired division chief of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, died last night at George Washington University Hospital here. He was 69 years old.
As the first snows glaze the city streets, many Muscovites are searching for what has eluded so many New York City motorists-a parking place.
The sacred Afo-AKom is coming home and the man who deserves substantial credit for its return is Craig Kinzelman, a young American Peace Corps volunteer working here in the Cameroon grasslands.
Mike Laughton scored his second goal of the game late in the third period to give the New York Golden Blades a 4-3 World Hockey Association victory over the Vancouver Blazers today.

Mrs. Jane Miriam Silver, a nutritionist with the city's Human Resources Administration. was married here yesterday morning to Michael Eric Timm, who is with the New York law firm of Gold stein, Shames Hyde.

The City Opera introduced a new Gilda in Saturday night's performance of "Rigoletto"Cecilia Albanese, a soprano from Venezuela who has been singing fairly extensively in European opera houses in the last few years.
Ben Crenshaw, a rookie playing with the confidence of a seasoned pro, fashioned a four-under-par 67 and scored a two-stroke victory in the San AntonioTexas open golf tournament today.

France and Britain are sidestepping the issue of pooling oil with their European neighbors, including the Netherlands, even after that country has been deprived of two-thirds of her normal im. ports by an Arab boycott.

An off-duty policeman who had reportedly told his father "everything was down on him" shot and killed his wife, daughter, son and four upstairs neighbors before taking his own life this morning the police said.

The president of the American Psychiatric Association has returned from a visit to the Soviet Union, hopeful of achieving a freer international exchange of information on the uses and abuses of psychiatry.
When some of the current crop of students at a university branch here look back fondly on their college days, the only two days they'll have in mind are Saturdays and Sundays.

The chairman of a commission writing a new charter for Democrats said today that "blind loyalty" to political parties "is a thing of the past, and a good thing it is."
In the wake of the costliest war in Israel's history, the country is bracing for a prolonged period of severe economic austerity.

The Capital Bullets, paced by 25-point performances from Mike Riordan and Phil Chenier, won their fourth straight National Basketball Association' game . tonight, holding off the Phoenix Suns, 102-99, at the University of Maryland. It was the eighth loss in a row for Phoenix.
Prime Minister Gough Whitlam of Australia left Peking today after a five-day state visit that he hailed as a breakthrough in relations and the end of a generation of misunderstanding.

Two Houston lawyers may be rivals for President in 1976. Former Gov. John Connally, the convert to the Republican party, has been joined in the Presidential speculation by a Houston Democrat, Senator Lloyd M. Bentsen.
A 25-foot pleasure cruiser burned to the waterline yesterday nearly three miles off Reynold's Channel and East Rockaway Inlet between Long Beach and Far Rockaway.

The Rangers' longest victoryless streak in almost four years reached seven games tonight in a 4-1 loss to the Chicago Black Hawks.

The Da Capo Chamber Players, an ensemble that devotes its energies chiefly to contemporary music, appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Thursday night to play works by Morton Subotnick, Preston Trombly, Stefan Wolpe and Paul Hindemith.

Senator William E. Saxbe, whom President Nixon has nominated as Attorney General, has been quoted as advocating last summer the de struction of Watergate tapes "if they're incriminating," The Washington Post News Service reported today.

International efforts to make a Middle East cease-fire work have run up against repeated barriers of SovietAmerican disagreement. A pattern seems to have; emerged in which other nations stand aside waiting to see if the Soviet Union and the United States have reached an effecttive agreement on point after point; when none has appeared,

Four persons were killed today in two automobile accidents in Burlington County. The police said Helen McMullen, 24 years eold, of Philadelphia, and Jack Lynch, 29, of Rancocas Woods, were killed when the car they were riding in was struck by another car at Westfield and Bridgboro Roads in Moorestown.
A strike of Trans World Airlines stewards and stewardesses began at 12:01 A.M. today when negotiations on a new contract broke down in Washington at the expiration of a 30-day cooling-off period.

Secretary of State Kissinger leaves on a round-the-world trip tomorrow that will take him to Cairo for crucial talks on strengthening the Middle East cease-fire and to Peking for a long-planned review of the international scene with Chinese leaders.
They played another of those fieldgoal games in Atlanta Stadium today and it came out right for the home side at last.

Communistled insurgents today attacked a Government position five miles outside Phnom Penh, the military command said. But the command gave no details of the reported attack, on Prek Thon, northeast of here, and did not mention casualties.
Negotiators for the Newspaper Guild and The Daily News sought last night and early today to reach a contract agreement that would avert a strike threatened for today.
George Marshall, who will be 82 years old on Dec. 29, will return to acting after directing more than 400 films over the last 60 years. Mr. Marshall has been signed to appear in "Vrooder's Hooch,"
The Justice Department released today a report calling for tight new restrictions on the use of criminal information systems and intelligence files.

Big-band sounds from the swing era filled 52d Street on Friday evening. You could hear Jimmie Lunceford's "Ain't She Sweet" and Tommy Dorsey's "On the Sunny Side of the Street" at Roseland, where Sy Oliver, who wrote both arrangements, was leading his current band.

Forty-eight voluntary hospitals and nursing homes stocked up on blood plasma and TV dinners yesterday in last-minute preparations for a strike of 30,000 technical, service and maintenance workers set for 6 A.M. this morning.
The Fire Department, facing a threat by firemen to strike today, said yesterday that trucks would be operated with reduced crews and that, if necessary, civilians might be used to help lay hoses.

A man identified as 46-yearold Christopher Allan, a theatrical agent, was killed yesterday afternoon when he fell from his ninth-storyapartment at 116 East 66th Street, apparently while cleaning his windows, the police reported.
John M. Bickel, a retired vice president of the Carrier Corporation in New York, died here yesterday at Myrtle Beach Manor, a nursing home. He was 81 years old.
A parcel bomb planted outside a gas station in Lurgan, County Armagh, blew up today, causing exten sive damage but injuring no one, the police said.

The Mayor of Metter says she ran for office to repay the town's citizens for saving her life. Now Mrs. Catherine Robinson, the first woman Mayor in the town's history, is engaged in planning for a "new Metter" that she might not be alive to see.

BASKAS-Rose, beloved wife of the late Abraham, devoted mother of Anne Orben, Gertrude Edelstein Dr Morris, loving grandmother great-grandmother. Services Mon, 1 P.M. at Geo. T. Davis Funeral Home, 14 LeCount Place, New Rochelle.
A spokesman for the International Harvester Company said tonight that United Auto Workers members had ratified a threeyear contract and were expected to begin returning to work tomorrow.

Every year well over a million out-of-state cars pour into New York. What happens after next Feb. 1, when New York's nofault auto-insurance law goes into operation, if a New Yorker should be seriously injured in an accident involving an out-of-state car?

Two of the major mayoral candidates renewed yesterday their criticism of what they said were heavy real-estate contributions to the campaign of Controller Abraham D. Beame, the Democrat who is expected to be elected the 104th Mayor of New York City.

Anyone who thought the New York Giants had hit bottom last week and the week before was wrong. They plunged deeper into total ineffectiveness today while being almost ludicrously manhandled by the Oakland Raiders, 42-0.

New Jersey's major candidates for Governor, carrying their battle for votes down to the wire, confronted each other yesterday in two televised appearances in which each reiterated his stands on such issues as the state income tax and legalized abortion.
Defense Minister Moshe Dayan warned tonight that Egypt might resume hostilities in the Middle East and that she did not seem ready for what Israel regarded as a stable ceasefire.

In the City Council elections tomorrow, the republican party stands to regain seats lost to Liberals four years ago, when Mayor Lindsay headed the Liberal ticket, and to become once again a minority party that can hold a caucus in something larger than a telephone booth.

Erich Segal, the author of "Love Story," resigned from Yale University last June 30, according to a list released by the university over the weekend. Mr. Segal, an associate professor of classics, failed to gain tenure at Yale.

Hunter College's 1973-74 Saturday evening series got off to a lackluster start on the weekend with the first appearance here of the English Sinfonia, a chamber orchestra from Nottingham, England, led by Neville Dilkes.

In the City Council elections tomorrow, the Lepublican party stands to regain seats lost to Liberals four years ago, when Mayor Lindsay headed the Liberal ticket, and to become once again a minority party that can hold a caucus in something larger than a telephone booth.

Uncharacteristic Miami mistakes and an uncharacteristic second quarter for the Jets excited the Shea Stadium crowd of 57,591 prematurely yesterday. Then cooler heads and more talented arms and legs prevailed in the second half, and the Dolphins posted a predictable victory. 24-14.

Britten's "Old Clocks and Watches and Their Makers," by Cecil Clutton, G. H. Baillie and C. A. Gilbert, eighth edition, revised by Mr. Clutton (Dutton, $40). Collector's Guide to Antique Porcelain by Gordon A. Rust (Studio Book: Viking Press, $9.95). Copiously illustrated history.

Nancy McMullen, a doctoral candidate in experimental psychology at Columbia University, recently returned from a trip to Argentina with the United States women's field hockey team. Now, she's seriously engaging in a can.paign for the creation of greener and plusher pitches in this country.

After a day of seesawing prices, wheat futures ended as much as 20 cents a bushel higher, the daily trading limit, on the Chicago Board of Trade Early in the session prices were down as much as 10 cents.

The men of "La Casa Grande," the busiest firehouse in the city-at 169th Street and Intervale Avenue in the East Bronx-sat in their firehouse kitchen telling tales of dramatic fires and false alarms yesterday afternoon, waiting out the long hours of union negotiations in a mood of nervous jocularity.
Dr. Haim Ginott, noted child psychologist and author of "Between Parent and Child," died Sunday at Beekman Downtown Hospital. His age was 51, and he lived at 923 Fifth Avenue.
Vsevolod A. Kochetov, a writer who was long a conservative leader in Soviet literature, has died in Moscow, the Soviet press agency Tass reported yesterday. He was 61 years old.

The American Museum or Natural History will move its 3,000-work rare-book collection, consisting of books, manuscripts, letters, diaries, journals, maps and drawings, into its long-envisioned Rare Book Room next Tuesday.
The history examinations in South Vietnam's public schools contain no questions on the American role here, nothing about North Vietnam and no mention of the Vietcong.

All 40 patients in a ward of the Kings County Hospital psychiatric division were evacuated safely last night when a bedding fire sent dense, choking smoke rolling through the wing, hospital officials reported.

Women's service magazines love to help sell food and be sold near food. Both for economic reasons. Food and related products advertising is a very important category to Family Circle, Woman's Day, Good Housekeeping, The Ladies' Home Journal, McCall's and Redbook.
" We are tracking down every last barrel of oil that reached the United States," said Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, the Saudi Arabian Minister of Petroleum.

John Newcombe, suffering from a stomach disorder, defeated a fellow Australian, John Alexander, 6-3,. 4-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the first Australian indoor tennis championship today. The $50,000 tournament is restricted to men.

The British Equestrian Team, making its first appearance at the National Horse Show since 1968, won the Nations Cup last night and gained a leg on the Maj. Gen. Alfred G. Tuckerman Memorial Challenge Trophy before a crowd of 12,000 at Madison Square Garden.

The Senate passed a $21.3billion weapons procurement bill today. The measure now goes to President Nixon. The vote was 69 to 12. The compromise bill gives the Administration nearly everything it wanted in weapons-research and development authorization and military manpower levels.

Senator Peter H. Dominick, a conservative Republican of Colorado who has been a stanch supporter of President Nixon, called on the President today to make "a complete disclosure of all information" about the Watergate investigations.

Schlumberger Ltd., a major factor in worldwide oil-field services, reported yesterday the highest quarterly earnings in its history with a 31 percent increase over the third quarter of 1972. Revenues were up 14 per cent. Based on the ninemonth results, the company is expected to show record annual revenues and net income for 1973.

A favorable climate in Congress for three major items of maritime legislation was reported here yesterday by the chairman of the House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee, Representative Leonor K. Sullivan.
Premier Golda Meir returned from Washington today and reported to her Cabinet on her talks with President Nixon, Secretary of State Kissinger and other United States leaders.

AS the only one among the seven active New York major league teams over .500, the Knicks were feeling fairly content today, having returned from their first Western trip of the season with three victories in four games.

East Germany announced today that its fees for visits by Westerners would be doubled this month and sentenced to prison a West Berliner and two West Germans accused of having smuggled East Germans out of the country.
The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court decision permitting tax deduct tions for depreciation of equipment used by companies in doing their own construction. work.

At the city's Board of Elections yesterday, it was all over but the waiting. The last of the 6,900 voting machines were being taken to polling places, the absentee ballots were being bundled for delivery and the telephone lines to report machine breakdowns were being checked to see that they do not break down.

The Administration said today that the $2.2-billion in emergency military aid requested for Israel would be used to replace her combat losses and build up her forces to a greater strength than before the war.

The Forum at Lincoln Center, a 299-seat theater, was formally renamed the Mitzi I. Newhouse Theater last night. Mrs. Newhouse, the wife of Samuel I. Newhouse, newspaper publisher, donated $1-million last May to Joseph Papp's New York Shakespeare Festival.
The Senate passed a bill today to implement the international treaty designed to prevent or mitigate the effects of accidents at sea that might cause oil pollution.

Directors of the General Motors Corporation at their regular monthly meeting here yesterday, declared a yearend dividend of $2.35 per share payable Dec. 10 to stockholders of record Nov. 15. In the fourth quarter of 1972, G.M. paid a dividend of $1.65 a share.
Donald H. Segretti was sentenced today in United States District Court to six months in prison for his efforts to disrupt the 1972 Democratic Presidential primary in Florida.

The "brightest" Senator, according to a survey of Senate legislative assistants, is Jacob K. Javits, the New York Republican. The survey, conducted by Ralph Nader's Capitol Hill news service, polled the behind-thescenes senatorial aides who do much of the day-to-day support work all Senators depend upon.

The threat of the city's first firemen's strike this morning was the outgrowth of a new policy of militancy and a sense of frustration over the city's "unwillingness to bargain in good faith on a new contract," fire union sources said yesterday.

Attorneys for The Boston Globe have filed a civil complaint in United States District Court here against the Justice Department and Bureau of Prisons for being refused an interview with Clifford Irving, the author.

Thousands of followers of form will pay their final respects to Secretariat at Aqueduct this afternoon without having to think about win, place or show. The great golden chestnut colt is due to make the final appearance of his career in what amounts to a non-racing walk.
The Supreme Court today declined to review a lower court decision denying benefits from a jointly run newspaper-union trust fund to union member not employed by two participating New York newspapers.
Mayor Lindsay swore in five Civil Court judges yesterday to interim terms for assignment to the Foster Care Parts and Family Court.

A former high official of the Justice Department has disclosed that telephone wiretaps were placed on Nixon Administration officials and possibly newsmen who were not included in the previously reported 21-month effort that President Nixon has said was aimed at stopping leaks of classified information to the press.

The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that Wonder Bread, the largest selling white bread in the country, had been falsely advertised for the last decade as an extraordinary food that would cause children to grow dramatically.

New Jersey's campaign for Governor ended as it began today, on a bitter note-this one caused by a last-minute attempt by supporters of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate, to create an emotional abortion issue.

A few years ago the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association was faced with a major problem: crowd control at athletic events. Team buses were being stoned, windows broken, fights were breaking out in the stands and on parking lots. In northern Jersey some football games had to be canceled; a school was suspended.

The city's 10,900 firemen will strike this morning, the Uniformed Firefighters Association vowed yesterday, despite a State Supreme Court injunction and a court warning that a every striking fireman would.

An Israeli soldier has found the grave of his father who died while serving with the British Army in Egypt during World War II on the west bank of the Suez Canal. "We've been looking for my father's grave for 33 years," Itamar Weissbein told the Israeli Army radio tonight.

The Supreme Court voted 8 to 1 today to leave standing a decision upholding the right of a New Orleans hotel to refuse to serve women in its men's grill. The sole dissenter was Justice William O. Douglas, who would have taken the case for review.

John Newcombe, suffering from a stomach disorder, defeated a fellow Australian, John Alexander, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, in the opening round of the first Australian indoor tennis championship today. The $50,000 tournament is restricted to men.
Governor Cahill announced this evening that he would ask the Legislature next week to rescue the proposed financing of a New Jersey sports complex in the northern Hackensack Meadowlands.

A charge d'affaires has arrived in Peking to head -the Chilean diplomatic mission. The former Ambassador, Armando Uribe, left on Oct. 16 after being informed by the Chinese authorities that the military junta,-which took over Chile on Sept 11, had withdrawn his accreditation.

Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, once approved the use of a Houston foundation to launder money at the request of the Central Intelligence Agency, the foundation president said today.

The blue and white Israeli flag flew today from only five diplomatic missions in black Africa. Eighteen months ago there were 31. Only two of the 25 resident ambassadors remain on the African continent.

Dr. Cyril M. Levin, who retired recently as director radiology at Richmond Memorial Hospital and associate attending in radiology at Staten Island Hospital, died yesterday at his winter home in Long Boat Key, Fla.
Stock prices plummeted yesterday amid widening uncertainties over the political future of President Nixon and oil shortages induced by the Middle East conflict. Volume remained moderate.
The threat of an energy crisis in Britain deepened today as the Government reactivated a key committee to monitor petroleum supplies and moved another step closer to gasoline rationing.
The cost of building the nation's flying military command posts has increased $66-million in a year, despite eliminations of a computer system, Congressional auditors say.

Elizabeth Lindemann, a retired New York history and civics teacher, who for more than 25 years worked with the late Dr. Angelo Patri in pioneering liberal teaching at Junior High School 45, in the Bronx, died today at the John E. Andrus Memorial Home. Her age was 85.
The clamor for Richard Nixon's resignation is suddenly so deafening that it may drown out good sense and overwhelm due process. That clamor demands short-run therapy for a catastrophic illness.

Thirty-nine public schools in two Brooklyn-school districts closed yesterday to commemorate Black Solidarity Day in defiance of Board of Education directives that the districts be assessed for any loss in state aid because of the unauthorized closings.
The Senate Public Works Committee was given a pessimistic view by a major oil company today on the prospects for dealing promptly with a newly highlighted health hazard in controlling auto emissions.

The City Center Acting Company, New York's youngest, most peripatetic repertory theater, which grew out of the Drama Division of the Juilliard School, will make its Broadway debut in a special four-week season of four plays at the Billy Rose Theater from Dec. 18 through Jan. 12.

With the three commercial networks having discontinued their daily television pool of the Senate Watergate hearings, the National Public Affairs Center for Television in Washington has set up its own installation to resume coverage this week over the Public Broadcasting Service.
Strictly instrumental music has been at a premium these days at Lincoln Center, what with the New York Philharmonic on strike, but on the infraorchestral level superior concerts are still to be had.

Lester Zygmaniak, who shot his brother to death in a hospital bed where the brother lay paralyzed from the neck down after a motorcycle accident, was acquitted of murder today by a Superior Court jury on the ground that he was temporarily insane when he fired the fatal shot.
A group of South Korean intellectuals and religious leaders issued a statement today calling on the nation to "rise up and struggle" for the restoration of democracy.

The Senate Watergate committee is to hear testimony this week from a witness who is a key figure in a Justice Department investigation involving a committee member, Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida.

Leon Jaworski was sworn in today as the new Watergate special prosecutor and called his oath of office "more important, perhaps, than any I have taken in my lifetime."

Secretary of State Kissinger brought to the Arab world his effort to overcome Middle East cease-fire problems and to promote the start of full-scale peace negotiations. He received a military honor-guard welcome in Morocco. American officials accompanying Mr. Kissinger cautioned against any spectacular breakthroughs during his talks in Morocco and other Moslem countries he plans to visit. [Page 1, Column 7.]
John Halperin, a mortgage broker, died today at his home here. He was 69 years old.

The walkout yesterday by the Newspaper Guild at The Daily News is the latest chapter of a bitter history of newspaper labor relations in which citywide newspapers have been halted from publication eight times since 1950.

Marshal Boris P. Bugayev, the Soviet Minister of Civil Aviation, personally directed the successful foiling of an attempt to hijack a Soviet domestic airliner to Sweden last Friday, unofficial sources said today.

The Newspaper Guild struck The Daily News in a contract dispute yesterday, preventing publication of its Tuesday edi tions. The guild, meanwhile, reached a tentative two-year agreement with The New York Times a few hours after the start of the walkout at The News.

The Fire Department set up an emergency command post yesterday on the 12th floor of its headquarters at 110 Church Street, with 80 special telephones and a corridor of maps and charts to help officials maneuver what might be an undermanned, inexperienced fire crew, in the event of a strike today.

A Cambodian Government task force today recaptured the Mekong River town of Prek Luong, four miles north of Phnom Penh, and began moving on other rebel-held river front villages, according to reports from the field.
While Americans dwell on their troubles with insolent repairmen, Muscovites are savoring a horror story about the man who tried to get his outboard motor fixed.

8-10 A.M., WNCN. Concerto for Winds, Vivaldi; Piano Concerto No. 4; Scheizo, Litolff; Symphony No. 5; Boyce; Overture in Italian Style, Schubert: Danses d'Acanthe et Cephise, Rameau; The Return of Ulysses: Excerpts, Monteverdi.
After a 19-0 loss to the Kansas City Chiefs which reduced his team's record to 1-6-1, Harland Svare resigned as head coach of the San Diego Chargers yesterday and was replaced by Ron Waller.
Senator William B. Saxbe, the Attorney General-designate, denied today having advocated destruction of the White House Watergate tapes if they proved to be incriminating.

The Justice Department yesterday proopsed next Sept. 30 as a tentative trial date for its antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation presently in its pretrial stage in Federal District Court for the Southern District of New York. I.B.M. indicated the date might be several months too soon.
Marc Allegret, the film director, died at his home here Saturday. His age was 73.

" Roxanne" is really Risa Jaroslow, Stormy Mullis and Wendy Perron. It's a dance company, and it gave its premiere performance Friday evening at St. Clements Church. The dancers complement one another nicely, and the dances were tailored to show them to advantage.

Dr. Leon J. Taubenhaus, director of community health services at Beekman Downtown Hospital and a specialist in emergency medicine, died Sunday in La Paz, Mexico, where he had been on vacation. He was 61 years old and lived here.

Thousands of followers of form will pay their final respects to Secretariat at Aqueduct this afternoon without having to think about win, place or show. The great golden chestnut colt is due to make the final appearance of his career in what amounts to a non-racing
Arab oil states escalated today their "oil weapon" program of production cuts, with a new formula that seemed to require total embargoes on supplies to some more major consumers.
Officials of the State University said today that discussions were under way on alternatives to heat classrooms in the event of an energy shortage this winter.

The Eglevsky Ballet Company of Long Island did a very daring thing at Massapequa (L.I.) High School on Sunday. It staged Tchaikovsky's "The Sleeping Beauty," a ballet normally only produced by large and established companies.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and the over-thecounter market fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading. Some analysts attributed the drop to the increasing pressure being brought on President Nixon to resign.

A few days ago, former Gen. Alexander M. Haig Jr., his eyes red from lack of sleep and his face drawn with fatigue, observed that he had never known military combat to be as arduous as being President Nixon's right-hand man in recent weeks.

Israel's immediate goal in the diplomatic maneuvering in the Middle East is said to be to seek immediate return of Israeli prisoners and consolidation of the cease-fire under United Nations auspices, and then to delay all other issues until after the parliamentary election of Dec. 31.
Joseph Monty, former chief investigator for the Queens District Attorney, was found guilty late yesterday of receiving bribes-in the form of free cars-from the Avis Rent-a-Car System.

IN THE SINAI, east of Qantara, Egypt, Nov. 4Egyptian infantry, artillery and armored troops bolstered camouflaged positions in the desert here today, observing the cease-fire with Israeli forces but bracing for any resumption of war.

The Nixon Administration sought today to sidestep Israeli charges that Egyptians were massing forces for an attack and that Egypt and Southern Yemen were blockading Israelbound vessels at the entrance to the Red Sea.

Here are the 10 locations where Supreme Court Justices will he available to handle any disputes over voters' rights today from 7 A.M. in Manhattan, the Bronx and Queens, and from 6 A.M. in Brooklyn and Staten Island:

The executive commission of the European Economic Community, responding to this year's world protein shortage, has proposed that the nine-member Common Market subsidize soybean production in Europe and encourage other protein-rich crops.
Some 200 Livingston College students took over the dean's office here today and presented 43 demands, including several for the ouster of certain college officials.

Fred Saunders, who starred on the University of Southwestern Louisiana basketball team for the last two seasons, transferred to Syracuse University in September, hoping to play the 197374 season with the Orange.

The death of an Edison youth, shot in the back by a city policeman after a high-speed auto chase Saturday night, was being investigated by Middlesex County detectives. The police identified the youth as 18-year-old Gary Smerecki. They said he was shotgunned in the lower back by Patrolman Joseph Bingert, who has been "relieved of duty."

A State Public Service Commission staff report released yesterday attributed the massive power failure in the Jackson Heights section of Queens last Aug. 29 and 30 to the Consolidated Edison Company's "failure to monitor and operate the network successfully."
The Coast Guard says 387 barrels of cyanide are floating in the Gulf of Mexico, and probably are heading toward the Texas coast between Brownsville and the Sabine Pass on the Louisiana state line.

Today is Election Day, a legal holiday in New York. State and city offices will be closed, as will schools and colleges in the metropolitan area and most of the suburbs. Mail will be delivered, and Federal offices will be open, as will the stock exchanges.
To most people, it would appear the Jets' season already is over. To Earlie Thomas, though, the challenge of the season is just beginning.

A diplomatic dialogue that just two years ago was too bold and dramatic to be undertaken is now an active reality between the Israeli and Egyptian Governments through United States good offices. In 1971, diplomatic efforts centered on an American proposal to begin peace talks with Arab and Israeli delegations "in close proximity."

The Libyan authorities accused the Soviet Union today of aiding "the forces of Zionism" by letting Soviet Jews emigrate to Israel, but they praised the Austrian Government for having barred the use of Schonau Castle as a transit camp.

Architects rarely have the chance to design restaurants. There are a few architectdesigned eating places in New York -- among them, Gamal el Zoghby's Cleopatra, a splitlevel creation on upper Broadway, and Philip Johnson's Four Seasons, still a stunning piece of architecture after 15 years-but that honor roll is short indeed.
The White House has balked at meeting a request by Egil Krogh Jr. that he examine documents of the "plumbers" unit he directed at the time of the Ellsberg break-in in 1971, his attorney said today.

The Skylab 3 astronauts put in a final day of ground practice today on maneuvers to be used for docking with the eight-room space research laboratory that they expect to be working in for at least 60 days.
The nation's medical schools were warned today that the Nixon Administration may reduce, if not completely end, Federal aid for health manpower education next year.
The most extensive hospital strike in the city's history began yesterday, forcing the curtailment of medical and custodial care at 48 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area.
A major player snaKe-up will be the next order of business for the New York Giants as they battle the San Diego Chargers and Houston Oilers to avoid becoming the worst team in pro football.
The Washington Post resumed publishing on a normal schedule tonight following the settlement of a labor dispute that had kept it from printing all but supplemental sections over the weekend.
A race that began last January with10 fresh candidates for Mayor wound up last night with the four major-party survivors, weary and still talking, hours before the voting began.

Leonard Lisco, 43 years old of Fort Plain was being held in Montgomery County jail today on a murder charge in the slaying of his estranged wife. Sheriff's officers said Lisco's wife, Priscilla, 37, was shot to death with a .22 caliber rifle at his home.
Mrs. Emily Wissler Dess, who retired in 1970 after 27 years with The New York Times, died Friday of a heart attack at her home in Surfside. Her age was 65.

New Jersey's campaign for Governor ended as it began today, on a bitter note-this one caused by a last-minute attempt by supporters of Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the Republican candidate, to create an emotional abortion issue.

" Obviously there will be no strike," Leon J. Davis, president of Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Workers Union said on June 29, 1972, after arbitrators awarded his members a requested minimum 7.5 per cent pay rise plus other benefits for each of two years.

When Gene Frankel says "we brought the house down," he is referring with macabre humor to the destruction of his theater workshop and acting school in the collapse of the Broadway Central Hotel three months ago.

The Newspaper Guild struck The Daily News in a contract dispute yesterday, preventing publication of its Tuesday edi lions. The guild, meanwhile, reached a tentative two-year agreement with The New York Times a few hours after the start of the walkout at The News.

While the pickets marched and chanted outside on 77th Street yesterday, Edward Erskine slipped into a rumpled set of orderly's fatigues on the operating floor of Lenox Hill Hospital and began a day-long struggle with autoclaves and sterile pads.

New-car sales in the first month of the 1974 model year are down more than had been forecast by the United States auto industry. Auto-industry executives had forecast a modest decline, and they are not yet ready to say that it is turning into a slump.

it's really an quite improbable, this Transylvanian Ping-Pong champion who survived Hitler's Bergen-Belsen and now runs so many of New York's charitable events, but that's the way it is. Livia Sylva Weintraub just isn't your typical social butterfly.
Representative Frank J. Brasco pleaded not guilty yesterday to a Federal charge of conspiracy to receive bribes in return for assisting a truck cornpany controlled by a reputed Mafia member.

This has been a fall with little to cheer about for the New York fan: FOOTBALL Giants-After six straight preseason victories, they are 1-6-1 and only the Houston Oilers (1-7) have a worse record. Jets-Things have not been the same since Joe Namath's shoulder separation.
Banks and governmental offices will be closed in many states, including New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, today, Election Day, but in Wall Street it will be business as usual for stock trading,

South Vietnamese planes strafed and bombed North Vietnamese fromations yesterday around two Government militia outposts near the Cambodian border that, on Sunday were overwhelmed by tanks, the South Vietnamese command announced.
There is a pervading feeling among both Egyptian officials and ordinary citizens that hostilities will erupt again soon.
There are many thoughtful wildlife biologists and hunters who are far from convinced that the current move toward making the use of steel shot mandatory for waterfowling is a good thing.

Bobby G. Seale, the former Black Panther chairman who was shackled and gagged following violent outbursts during the 1969 Chicago Seven conspiracy trial, spoke softly and politely at contempt of court proceedings today and told the judge he had not intended to be "disrespectful to the court."

A gasoline additives fire roared 200 feet in the air from the middle of an Atlantic Richfield refinery here, but company officials said it was put under control today before there was any threat of a disaster.
A Liberian freighter carrying commercial explosives caught fire off the Washington Coast during the weekend but the blaze was brought sunder control without serious damage.

Lester Zygmaniak, who shot his brother to death in a hospital bed where the brother lay paralyzed from the neck down after a motorcycle accident, was ac- quitted of murder today by a Superior Court jury on the ground that he was temporarily insane when he fired the fatal shot.

A race that began last January with 10 fresh candidates for Mayor wound up last night with the four major-party survivors, weary and still talking, hours before the voting began.

Israel's delegate to the United Nations, Yosef Tekoah, accused Egypt and Syria of atrocities against Israeli prisoners of war yesterday as he joined Senator Jacob K. Javits, the four mayoral candidates and other speakers at a rally held to urge the prisoners' release.
Governor Cahill announced this evening that he would ask the Legislature next week to rescue the proposed financing of a New Jersey sports complex in the northern Hackensack Meadowlands.
National Guardsmen helped fight a fire this morning after they were ordered to duty following a "red flu" epidemic that stripped the Milwaukee Fire Department of about 30 per cent of its work force.

Yields on United States Treasury bills. rose in the Government's weekly competitive sales of these short-term securities. The average rate for three-month bills in this week's sale is 8.098 per cent up from 7.196 last week,

A Federal District Court in Dallas yesterday issued a verdict dismissing an antitrust complaint charging that New York Stock Exchange regulations were unfair to nearly 3,000 over-the-counter securities dealers who are not members of the Big Board.

Joseph C. Dey, golf's commissioner, announced today that he would retire on Feb. 28, 1974, when his five-year contract ends with the Tournament Players Division of the Professional Golfers' Association.

Forty-two survivors-including 30 Norwegians-were picked up in mid-Atlantic today after the 98,894-ton tanker Golar Patricia broke in two and sank after an explosion, according to radio messages received here.

Secretary of State Kissinger tonight brought to the Arab world his effort to overcome Middle East cease-fire problems and to promote the start of full-scale peace negotiations. He arrived in Morocco to a military honorguard welcome.

A gasoline additives fire roared 200 feet in the air from the middle of an Atlantic Richfield refinery here, but cornpany officials said it was put under control today before there was any threat of a disaster.
Doctors in 1,500 hospitals all over Italy started a three-day strike today, but later agreed to call it off pending new negotiations with hospital administrators.

Struck by its 5,000 cabin attendants, Trans World Airlines, one of the largest carriers in the world, yesterday canceled all of its 457 domestic and international flights, which serve more than 40,000 passengers daily.
The most extensive hospital strike in the city's history began yesterday, forcing the curtailment of medical and custodial care at 48 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes in the metropolitan area.
Over 70 of Los Angeles's leading citizens were on hand today to pay tribute, at a "Welcome Home Bob" luncheon, to an old friend who is moving back to his home town.

Edward W. Kilpatrick, Acting State Commissioner of Education, ruled today, that the results of the controversial statewide reading and mathematics tests given to public school pupils in the fourth and 12th grades last November were valid and should be made public.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it would raise prices by $2 to $12 a ton on various sheet and strip products, beginning Jan. 1.

Donald H. Segretti was sentenced today in United States District Court to six months in prison for his efforts to disrupt the 1972 Democratic Presidential primary in Florida.

Tourists are often confused by the discovery that Pennsylvania Dutch country is substantially populated by people of German origin. Bridge players know better, however. For them, Lancaster, Pa., is the home of the Swiss.
A 28- year-old drug addict detained in a state facility in Harlem and a suspect being held in a police station on East 21st Street both hanged themselves last night, the police reported.

The General Electric Company announced yesterday receipt of a contract for "over $45-million" for a domestic solid-state, high voltage direct current transmission installation by the Square Butte Electric Cooperative.

Reversed the disorderly conduct conviction of an Ohio man on the grounds that an ordinance prohibiting "noisy, boisterous, rude, insulting" conduct deprived him of his constitutional right to object to a policeman's attempt to arrest him. (No. 72-1366, Norwell V. Cincinnati).

Herbert Kunzel, a 65-yearold retired industrialist, has been elected president and chairman of the executive committee of the WestgateCalifornia Corporation, the financially troubled conglomerate. In the dual role,

The war in the Middle East and the Arab decision to impose an embargo on oil shipments to the United States, the Netherlands or any other country that provides support to Israel have given the NATO alliance its most severe internal shock since France withdrew from military integration in 1966.

The body of a 37-year-old man shot in the back of the head in gangland style was found in the rear of an automobile parked in front of a Bronx public school. The victim, identified as Albert Streppone of 2439 Morris Avenue, had been wrapped in an automobile seat cover and bound with wire.

The long cease-fire on the labor-management front ended painfully for New Yorkers yesterday. Strikes of hospital, newspaper and airline employes, coupled with a threatened total desertion of duty by unionized firemen, brought more dislocation than the city has experienced since President Nixon imposed wage-price controls in August, 1971.

Random killings of civilians by the police and armed forces have declined sharply in Santiago in the last month, a survey of 20 working-class communities in the capital shows. The Santiago area suffered a majority of the casualties in the weeks following the Sept. 11 coup that overthrew the Marxist Government of President Salvador Allende Gossens.
The Senate passed a bill today authorizing airlines, railroads and bus companies to offer reduced fares to persons 65 years old and over or 21 and younger and to the handicapped.

The "brightest" Senator, according to a survey of Senate legislative assistants, is Jacob K. Javits, the New York Republican. The survey, conducted by Ralph Nader's Capitol Hill news service, polled the behind-thescenes senatorial aides who do much of the day-to-day support work all Senators depend upon.

Magda Olivero at last seems to have found a niche in American operatic life with the Opera Theatre of New Jersey. This very special singer, who appeals to very specialized tastes, opened the company's 1973-74 four-opera series last night at Newark's Symphony Hall in the title role of Cilea's "Adriana Lecouvreur."

Randy Neumann, 24-year-old college student at Fairleigh Dickinson, scored a 10round decision over Paul Gorosito of Buenas Aires last night at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum.

A former Bolivian Cabinet minister in exile here was taken at gunpoint from his home a week ago and has disappeared. Today members of his family said they had' learned from high Chilean authorities and foreign diplomatic sources that he had been seized on orders of the Bolivian Government.

Of course, in hotels you had a species referred to as "lobby lizards," who would monopolize the seats and stare imperiously at other sitters as though the latter were intruders.

The Damon Corporation announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire United States Administrative Paramedical Services, Inc., of Los Angeles and its affiliates, and Aurora Clinical Laboratory of Aurora, Ill., for stock valued at $10.9-million.

It is sometimes possible to tell a lot about a young musician's progress simply by looking at his programs as they change through the years. When the young Soviet pianist Alexander Slobodyanik made his New York debut five years ago, a brilliant performance of Schumann's "Carnaval" caught one's fancy most, and certified him as a young man to pay attention to.

The Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and its subsidiary, the B. P. Oil Company, began allocations yesterday on gasoline supplies because of the embargo by oil-producing nations in the Middle East.

The Roman Catholic Church has offered Chile's military rulers "the same collaboration that the church had given in all matters of common welfare to the Marxist Government" of President Salvador Allende Gossens.

Senator Peter H. Dominick, a conservative Republican of Colorado who has been a stanch supporter of President Nixon, called on the President today to make "a complete disclosure of all information" about the Watergate investigations.

Weinberger, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, in a speech today at the formal opening of the 101st annual meeting of the American Public Health Association here, defended the Nixon Administration's policies of impoundment of funds and the reorganization of the Federal health system.

TEL AVIV, Nov. 6-Israel announced tonight that 1,854 Israeli soldiers were killed in the latest Middle East war. The total number of wounded was not given. It was announced only that about 1,800 wounded soldiers were still hospitalized.
Joanle Symons, a Democrat, easily defeated her Republican opponent, Lawrence Howard, for a vacancy in the State House of Representatives today.
A promised "giant step from the stone age to the space age" in voting procedures here stumbled in midstride when a computer developed difficulties in its counting of 7,500 ballots cast in this

Pepsico, Inc., which owns about 82 per cent of the outstanding stock of the Rheingold Corporation, proposed yesterday to acquire the remaining shares in a merger which would give Pepsico full ownership of the Rheingold beer operation.
LADIES FIRST It's Women's Lib, but not hortatory Women's Lib, that occupies the stage in this first show of the new Theater at Noon season in St Peter's Center, 16 East 56th Street (PL 34669).

A Harvard health economist charged today that the Nixon Administration's health budget was a political document that was intended to make health services a business enterprise, like "the popcorn and television industries."

Last July, Pete Squires, Manhattan College junior, started a training program in which he ran 200 miles a week. In the early fall, he reduced it to 150 miles. Yesterday, he won the most important race of his career.

Rose Mary Woods. President Nixon's personal secretary for more than 20 years, was summoned today to testify in the Federal court investigation into White House tape recordings and two missing conversations.
Seven Roman Catholic priests serving long terms for political offenses in a special prison tried to burn it down today in protest against their isolation from other political prisoners in Spain.

The combination of Rodney Jenkins and Idle Dice came into its own last night as the National Horse Show, celebrating its 90th year, ended an eight-day run at Madison Square Garden.
Former Gov. Mills Godwin, a conservative Republican, won a hard-fought race for Virginia's Governorship today, defeating Lieut. Gov. Henry Howell, an independent liberalpopulist.
On the first anniversary of Richard Nixon's spectacular re-election victory, this city Is still trying to analyze what it was in his character that brought about the greatest fall since Lucifer.

Ralph G. Caso, the incumbent Nassau County Executive, led the entire Republican slate of candidates on the county and town levels to victory by about a 2-to-1 margin on the basis of returns early this morning.

Whether pleading before the United Nations for the creation of an independent Jewish state, arguing in the Supreme Court against English-language literacy tests for Puerto Rican voters in New York or defending civil rights workers in a Mississippi courtroom, Paul O'Dwyer has rarely been without a cause.
Charles Alan Wright is back home in Texas after months of serving as President Nixon's chief legal strategist in the battle for control of the Watergate tapes.

As the Democratic party's nominee, Paul O'Dwyer won easily, as expected, in the balloting for City Council President. A citywide post with an independent and separate constituency from that of the Mayor, the City Council President chairs the open sessions of the city's representative body.

The New York Golden Blades' .frantic search . for money heightened yesterday. Lawyers sought a transfusion of cash while club officials met with. Madison Square Garden executives to see how the club could continue -in the world's most expensive arena.

The Charter New York Corportion, the $6.3-billion holding company that owns the Irving Trust Company, has lost out in its bid to acquire the First National Bank of Glen Head, a $56-million Long Island bank also sought by Arthur T. Roth.
The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it had begun notifying the owners of 31,394 motor homes built on Dodge chassis of a possible defect that could cause a loss of engine power.

Israel agreed today to permit an additional 50 truckloads of supplies to be delivered to the beleaguered Egyptian III Corps in an apparent effort to avoid a crisis over the resupply issue at the time of Secretary of State Kissinger's arrival in Cairo.

Democratic candidates won three out of six special legislative elections yesterday, picking up one Staten Island Assembly seat formerly held by a Republican and retaining one Brooklyn Assembly seat and an upstate State Senate seat.
Controller Abraham D. Beame, who began his public service as a part-time accounting teacher 44 years ago, was elected the city's 104th Mayor in a landslide victory yesterday.
Prices of Swedish-built Volv automobiles sold in the United States will be increased by $590 to $715 in the 1974 mode line, the Volvo of America Con portion said yesterday.

OAKLAND, Calif., Nov. 6--Dr. Marcus A. Foster, the Superintendent of Schools here, was shot and killed tonight and his deputy, was critically wounded when gunmen ambushed them as they emerged from the Board of Education building.
Richard Bach, author of the best-selling novel "Jonathan Livingston Seagull," has won a preliminary court order pending trial for extensive changes to be made in the film version of the novel.
It's been a long time since a great interior space was constructed in New York. Lately, architects seem to have been devoting more attention to removing great rooms than making them.

Brendan T. Byrne, the Democratic candidate, won an overwhelming victory in yesterday's gubernatorial election in New Jersey, defeating Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., the conservative Republican candidate who had sought to reconstitute President Nixon's silent majority.

A milk lobby official, denying accusations that an attorney fee was skimmed away for political payoffs, has charged that dairy farmers "have been victimized by the pervasive corruption" in the Nixon Administration.
Italians, like people elsewhere, worry a lot about violence, and when they do they usually say that there should be more carabinieri.

Since this is George Gershwin's anniversary season (he would have been 75 years old last September), there has been a celebratory flurry of Gershwin songs on records, headed by the two-disk set Bobby Short Is K-Ra-Zy for Gershwin" (Atlantic 2-608, $11.96).

Suffolk County Democrats appeared to be on their way tonight to the biggest gains in their party's history in this Republican-dominated county unprecedented strength in the County Legislature and control of as many as three of the10 town halls-all attributed to what they termed "the Watergate backlash."
The trucking industry poured more than $600,000 into the Nixon campaign last year while it was fighting a Government proposal that would have caused more competition in highway shipping.
Frank Navarro resigned as football coach at Columbia University yesterday after having struggled for six seasons to rebuild the Lions' fortunes.

Secretary General Waldheim has agreed to accept offers from the Soviet Union and the United States for each to provide 36 military observers for the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization in the Middle East, delegates said today.
Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said today that President Nixon should agree to drop all claims of executive privilege in the wide-ranging investigation of the Watergate scandals.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 6--Mrs. Cordelia Scaife May, one of the heirs to the Mellon family fortune, was married to Allegheny County District Attorney Robert W. Duggan on Aug. 29 at Zephyr Cove on the southeast shore of Lake Tahoe, Nev., it was disclosed today.

In electing Brendan T. Byrne Governor by an unprecedented majority, New Jersey has delivered an emphatic rebuff to the reactionary and divisive campaign waged by the Republican candidate, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr.

Labor and management, often at odds with each other, agreed today in their scorn of a Federal t plan to reduce automobile traffic in New Jersey by requiring employers to charge their employes high fees for using company parking lots.
Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, was arrested here this afternoon by the Royal Bahamian Police acting on a request from the United States for his extradition to face a fraud charge.
As though they don't have enough trouble, the New York Rangers, mired in a slump of seven games without a victory, must meet the brutal Boston Bruins tonight at Madison Square Garden.

TEL AVIV--Israeli-Arab wars in the Middle East seem to have a repetitive rhythm. The Arabs attack or provoke a war. Their armies are beaten on the battlefield. Israel finds herself an involuntary purchaser of additional real estate.
The total cut in oil production by Arab oil producers since the ArabIsraeli war began has already reached 28.5 per cent, or 5.83 million barrels a day, the Middle East Economic Survey reported.

Striking members of the Newspaper Guild prevented publication of The Daily News for the second day yesterday. The strikers are scheduled to vote today, however, on a new Management proposal submitted to the 1,400 members without any recommendation from the guild negotiators.

A representative of the American Broadcasting Company admitted that when the network buys major box-office hits from the motion picture studios it stipulates that the- films be withheld from all forms of pay television.

Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the severe inflation of 1973 "cannot responsibly be attributed" to excessive growth of the nation's money supply "or to public policies more generally."

George Crumb's "Makrokosmos," Volume 1 (1972), was given its New York premiere on Monday night, and it strengthened the composer's reputation as one of the most imaginative and mesmerizing creators around. The work was performed by David Burge, the University of Colorado pianist to whom it is dedicated, in his program in Carnegie Recital Hall.
The White House said today that President Nixon, far from yielding to demands that he resign, was planning a broad new initiative to restore his credibility in the Watergate case.

Vanderbilt and Joseph Weintraub won national acclaim.

Joseph Papp, William Shakespeare and their Festival arrived, officially, at the Vivian Beaumont Theater last night, to take their place as the resident theater company of Lincoln Center.

George Meany said today that the strike of flight attendants, which has grounded Trans World Airlines since Monday, "was forced upon the union by an employer who does not know that this is the 20th Century."

The Public Schools Athletic League football semifinals will go on as planned. Final appeals of rulings by the football commissioner were turned down yesterday by the Executive Committee of the High Schools Games Committee.

A bipartisan bill to head off the threatened collapse of rail service by restructuring railroads in the Northeast was approved by the House of Representatives today, 306 to 82. The legislation now Roes to the Senate.

A special committee of the board of directors of th American Stock Exchange, after two months of study, has concluded that the exchange's constitutional prohibition against dual trading - that conducted on both the Amex and another exchange - should be repealed.

Faced with oil shortages this winter that some experts believe could amount to as much as 21 per cent of normal consumption, President Nixon has finally acknowledged that the nation is headed into an energy gap that requires drastic Federal action.

American industry plans to invest a record $113.9-billion next year for new plant and equipment, or 14 per cent more than the estimated spending of $100.2-billion in 1973, according to McGraw-Hill's latest survey, which is to be released today.

BUFFALO-Almost two years after a grand jury began looking into the Attica prison uprising, 60 men who were inmates during the insurrection are awaiting 40 trials involving 1,300 charges. The jury continues to study the case, which lawyers for both sides say will take years to settle and will prove to be one of the most complex criminal proceedings in American legal history.

A 19-year-old Queens girl who was to have been married hands next month was found stabbed be to death yesterday afternoon in the high weeds of a vacant lot office about a block from her home near the northeastern edge Coun of Kennedy International Airport.

The probable pairings for two of the four major bowl games remain as they were a week ago. However, the sites have been switched. The Federal Government rested its case today in its antitrust suit against the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company on charges of price fixing in fleet-car sales.
A $1.4-million yacht belonging to the fugitive financier Robert L. Vesco must remain tied up at a Miami dock, a Federal judge here ruled yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

Two hundred tenants of a building that has been cited for 719 violations of state codes demonstrated in front of the North Bergen City Hall until officials agreed to give them temporary housing. According to a couple of American trainers, the United States will finish one, two, three in the $150,000 Washington D.C. International tomorrow and the six other horses in the race might just as well have remained in Europe. The American horses are Tentam, London Company and Big Soruce.

The restaurants reviewed here are rated four stars to none, based on the writer's judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

WALK TALK While most weekend walking tours are designed to reveal tucked away architectural beauty or to recall past grandeur, the one scheduled for 11 A.M out of St. Luke's Church, 308 West 46th Street, is in a way a battleground survey.

Kaufman Broad, Inc., the largest builder of private homes in the nation, was fined $50,000 in United States District Court today after pleading no contest to charges of conspiracy and the bribery of former village officials in suburban Hoffman Estates.
H. D. Armstrong, who retired in 1971 as treasurer of the Standard Oil Company of California, died yesterday at his home in Woodside. He was 66 years old.
The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced yesterday plans for building a new power plant in Western New York with a capacity of 1.1million kilowatts.

Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union, on strike since Monday against 48 hospitals and nursing homes here, is an aggressive, militant labor organization that was formed by Jewish drug clerks in Harlem and the Bronx at the outset of the Depression.

To the Editor: Prof. Stephen Zwerling's Oct. 23 letter concerning national service for young people between high school and college argues convincingly for the need to identify new, "more than symbolic" forms of service.

Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew, who became 55 years old today, has spent the last month sorting out the remnants of his aborted political career. Friends have found him in good spirits but say they have no idea what, if any, plans he has for his future.
Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. attacked the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy today as a "danger to the freedom of the press," and introduced legislation that would abolish the office.

Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell agreed today to consider the legality of the dismissal of Archibald Cox as special Watergate prosecutor and of the order temporarily abolishing his prosecution force.

United States officials today discounted reported differences between the United States and Europe on a new Atlantic charter and expressed irritation at publication of American draft proposals for a joint declaration.

The dispute' over the contract between the hospital workers union and 48 hospitals and nursing homes here; resulting in the current strike, illustrates many of the criticisms labor makes of the Federal Cost of Living Council.

The Israeli Government announced today that it had accepted "in principle" the American-sponsored cease-fire agreement with Egypt, but said it would seek further clarifications on the details from the United States.
A new urine test that reportedly can detect a heart attack moments after onset has been developed by a Hartford physician.
