With five good shows falling to this reporter's lot this week, the thing to do is to avoid implications of preference by taking them up geographically, from 57th Street to 86th.
France, whose 10 per cent inflation rate is becoming a big domestic political issue, asked her Common Market partners today to agree rapidly to emergency anti-inflation: measures.
The Soviet Union has completed the construction of a large industrial installation that converts petroleum into protein for animal feed, and ultimately into meat.

A 70-year-old widow, her son and a woman visitor were burned to death yesterday after they apparently were trapped in their small third-floor apartment in a brick building built in the early nineteen-hundreds in the Navy Yard section of Brooklyn.

FLORENCE, Italy - In 1447, a Florentine named Pietro da Lucha tried to get his taxes reduced. He wrote to the collector: "I have a house to live in, situated in Sancto Felice in Pizza.... I have nothing but debts and I am poor and I cannot do anything but dress flasks .."

Bob Leonard, the coach of the Indiana Pacers of the American Basketball Association, has been fined $1,000 and suspended for two days. The fine, announced by Commissioner Mike Storen, was the largest in the league's history.

The Continental Telephone Corporation, which operates the nation's third largest independent telephone system, achieved record revenues and operating earnings in the third quarter, the company. reported yesterday. Net income,

Montreal's reputed top leader of organized crime, two other Canadians, two Mexicans. and a New Yorker were indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on charges that they had conspired to import and distribute cocaine into the United States.

The State Environmental Commissioner, Henry L. Diamond, has been asked by Governor Rockefeller to join his National Commission on Critical Choices and is reported to be preparing to resign and become its director next month. :

A 43-year-old Housing Authority policeman was in critical conditions at Lincoln Hospital yesterday after having been beaten with baseball bats,the Housing Authority police said by a man and a teen-age couple in the South Bronx.

W. A. Boyle, the former president of the United Mine Workers who is accused of ordering the killing of Joseph A. Yablonski an anti-Boyle challenger in a 1969 union election campaign was formally ordered today to answer the murder charge in Pittsburgh on Nov. 21.

A leading insurance company told Congress today that the insurance industry could not quickly take over most of the functions of insuring business investment in less-developed countries now performed by the Government's Overseas Private Investment Corporation.
Stock prices plummeted yesterday in the biggest single-day decline since the massive market break known as Black Monday on May 28, 1962. Trading volume remained moderate at 17.32 million shares.

The Boston Celtics, sparked by Jo Jo White's 17-point third period, scored their fifth consecutive National Basketball Association victory, 122 to 107 tonight, and handed the Phoenix Suns their ninth straight loss.

The Secretary of Transportation Claude S. Brinegar, said yesterday that if the Arab oil embargo caused an energy shortfall in the United States of "as much as 15 per cent, we could well see a G.N.P. fall of 2 per cent."
Modernization of sections of the rustic Merritt Parkway in Fairfield County will proceed as planned, despite community opposition; the State Transportation Department said today.
The Labor party, which has been leading the governing Conservatives in the popularity polls, suffered a severe setback today in the final returns in four off-year elections.

Wiiiam Cardinal Conway, Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, said today that not enough was being done by authorities in Northern Ireland to combat what he described as "the campaign of slaughter and intimidation" against Catholics.

Barely three months after it received a $15.7-million rate increase, the Brooklyn Union Gas Company has asked the Public Service Commission for an increase of 22 per cent, or $39.8-million a year, including a temporary rate rise of $16.3million to take effect on Jan. 1.

THE NOTEBOOKS OF MARTHA GRAHAM. Introduction by Nancy Wilson Ross. 464 pages. Illustrated. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich $25. Like her best dance works, this first book by Martha Graham is a challenge to the mind and the eye.
There was an uncommon air of buoyancy around the State Capitol this week, considering that the Republican candidate for Governor lost on Tuesday.
Retail sales rose strongly in October after being steady in August and September, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Alameda County coroner's office said today that the bullets used in the ambush slaying of Marcus Foster, the school superintendent, on Tuesday contained cyanide.

The Guggenheim Museum, which set off a storm of con-. troversy with its decision last winter to add a tearoom and visitors lobby to the front of its building, designed by Frank Lloyd Wright, on Fifth Avenue, has altered its

The White House allegation that Walter Cronkite, news anchorman for the Columbia Broadcasting System, showed partiality to newsmakers who were unfriendly to the Administration has been rebutted in a background memorandum by Richard S. Salant, president of C.B.S. News.

Frank DeRosa, an offtrack bettor from Clifton, N.J., is looking forward to a busy afternoon at home today. We'll all stay home, me and my brother-in-laws," DeRosa said yesterday at the Times Square branch of the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

The Senate Interior Committee, pushing to finish work quickly on a bill giving President Nixon emergency powers to deal with the energy shortage, sidestepped action today on controversial regulatory provisions on natural gas and the environment.
The former Watergate special prosecutor, Archibald Cox, will return to Harvard University in January as Williston Professor of Law, it was announced yesterday by Harvard's president, Derek C. Bok.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Nov. 9--Launching crews uncovered more traces of corrosion on the Saturn rocket today and fell behind in their efforts to replace the eight cracked tail fins in time to get the Skylab 3 mission under way Thursday.

A lawyer, a carpenter and convict were found guilty ir Federal Court here yesterday as participants in a conspiracy that Federal authorities said was responsible for smuggling 600 kilograms of heroin, ?? more than 1,300 pound, into New York.

Andrew F. Brimmer, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he had concluded that the "fight against'inflation" must be pursued in the period ahead even if it means a relatively sluggish economy.

Senator William D. Hathaway, Democrat of Maine, urged Congress today to provide for a new national election if President Nixon should leave office before Vice President-designate Gerald R. Ford was sworn in as his successor.
New York University is trying to account for about $40,000 worth of equipment missing in its move from its former University Heights campus to its central facilities in Washington Square.
The Cost of Living Council has scheduled public hearings to determine if price Increases requested by the four automobile makers are justified.
Top officials of the Nixon Administration are seriously discussing the possibility of asking Congress to enact a large tax on gasoline as an alternative to rationing, informed sources said tonight.

Many' hundreds of businessmen bound 'for home after week of working in New York and other cities were turned away by airlines yesterday as the five-day-old strike by trans World Airlines employes and fuel shortages combined to hamper the nation's air transport system.

CAIRO, Nov. 9--Egypt stood firm tonight on her acceptance of an American Egyptian agreement on ceasefire arrangements on 'the Egyptian-Israeli front despite reports that the Israeli Government was seeking further assurances about it.

RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Nov. 9--Secretary of State Kissinger has been unable to obtain a relaxation of Saudi Arabia's oil embargo on the United States but he has reportedly convinced King Faisal of his sincerity in the search for peace in the Middle East.

Neighbors of 19-year-old April Fell, who was found murdered in a vacant lot near her home in Springfield Gardens, Queens, on Thursday, were saddened and embittered yesterday as they talked about her death--but not surprised.
More university students joined today in a spreading boycott of classes to protest Government policies. The boycotts now affect eight colleges in the Seoul area.

Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Ill., swept aside the challenge of Manuel Orantes of Spain today when he won a battle of left-handers, 6-2, 6-1, to gain the semifinals of the $75,000 Swedish open indoor tennis championship.
Livingston College sits on a former Army camp isolated from shopping centers, bars, movie houses and the rest of Rutgers University.
Frederick L. Knowles, a biochemist who had made important advances in malaria research, died yesterday. He was 74 years old.

A growing apprehension among New York policemen about the steadily increasing number of women police'officers here has prompted Commissioner Donald F. Cawley to call a private meeting of top commanders to discuss the role of women within the department.
The Cincinnati Reds traded Bobby Tolan, a discontented outfielder, and Dave Tomlin a pitcher, to the San Diego Padres today in exchange for Clay Kirby, a pitcher.

Miss Elizabeth Greer Raff, assistant director of riding at the Van Lennep Riding Center at Skidmore College, will be married next spring to Thomas Whitman Nace of Laconia, N. H., a civil engineer with Rist-Frost Associates of Glens Falls, N. Y.

One good quarter ot team basketball was enough to compensate for some continuing dreary play by the Knicks last night as they achieved a much desired victory, 10090, over the Cleveland Cavaliers, a perpetual victim, at Madison Sauare Garden.

G. Y. Dryansky, who is The Women's Wear Daily's man in Paris, has a keen eye for detail and a glittering style that serves him well in this impressionistic novel. About three dozen copiess of the novel "Slaughterhouse Five" were burned in Drake, N. D., this week, on orders of the local school board.

Executives of Hughes Airwest, a small regional airline little known beyond the enclave it serves in the Far West, decided recently that they were seeing so many Japanese faces on the company's planes that it was time to open a sales office in' Tokyo.

In weather more conducive to skiing than running, Gary Lindquist of Bellmore, L.I., completed an unbeaten crosscountry season today with a record breaking victory in the state intersectional crosscountry championships at the State University campus here.

Political attention in California shifted this week away from Gov. Ronald Reagan, whose tax limitation plan was soundly defeated in a special election, and into a fuzzy focus on next year's race for Governor.

Yale scored last on a trick play, a pass from a halfback to a quarterback, and defeated Pennsylvania today, 24-21, thus knocking Penn out of a tie for first place in the Ivy League, which Harvard and Dartmouth continued to share.

Roosevelt Leaks, the nation's rushing leader, ran for three touchdowns and Jay Arnold, a defensive back, intercepted two passes today as Texas scored a 42-6 victory over Baylor on the road to a sixth consecutive Southwest Conference title.

The stock market, which has swung wildly this autumn, made big news Friday when the Dow-Jones industrial average plunged 24.24 points to register its biggest single-day decline since the 1962 break. The industrial average, down nearly 27 points for the whole week, finished at 908.41. This followed the previous week's drop of nearly 52 points, which was the largest weekly setback in recent years.

Allan Miller, a nonwinner in two years on the professional golf tour, battled wind and cold for a 72 today and tied Gibby Gilbert for the third-round lead in the $500,000 World Open tournament.

PRICES--This is what is really happening in Madrid. The inflation is what is known as galloping, and visitors who may have been here last year will find most things up by at least 10 per cent. Inflation is so bad (1.6 per cent in August alone) that the Government finally froze prices until the end of the year for a lengthy list of goods and services, including restaurants.

Tibor Paul, Hungariian-born conductor, died today after a heart attack. He was 64 years old. Mr. Paul returned to Australia on Friday from South Africa, where he conducted in Johannesburg and Pretoria, to take up his fourth term as conductor of the West Australian Symphony Orchestra.

Jerome Zeffren and his family welcome the Sabbath every Friday evening by baking their own bread, lighting candles and blessing wine. They fast on Yom Kippur and have a special set of dishes for Passover. All four of them either know or are learning Hebrew.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 10-Venezuela, the second largest foreign supplier of oil and petroleum products to the United States and the largest to Canada, can do nothing to help the United States and other energy-consuming nations out of the supply difficulties brought on by Arab production cutbacks and embargoes. And there are some indications that even if the Venezuelans could increase oil production, they wouldn't.

Gibby Gilbert, who has led or shared the lead all the. way, clipped one stroke off par with a 70 and pulled away to a five-stroke lead today after four rounds of the $500,000 World open golf tournament.

With a ship tattoo on his right arm and an unlit cigarette in his mouth, a short, wiry man in blue jeans and a cotton T-shirt mopped his way, like a dirt-chasing dervish, into and out of patients' rooms and up and down corridors at University Hospital yesterday.
The South Americanchampionships being contested in Brazil this week will determine the representatives of that zone in the world team championship in Italy next May. Judging by past results,
Egypt and Israel today signed the sixpoint cease-fire agreement sponsored by the United States and immediately began direct discussions on carrying it out.

Compromise recommendations by an impasse panel for ending the contract dispute between the city and its firemen were handed yesterday to both sides, but the amounts by which the fire fighters' salaries will be increased were not made public.

The names of jurors who will choose winners of the 25th annual National Book Awards were announced yesterday by Roger L. Stevens, chairmen of the National Book Committee, Inc., which sponsors the awards.
Egypt and Israel were unable to agree in two bargaining ses sions on the first steps toward carrying out the cease-fire agreement they signed today.

Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, the spiritual leader of American Reform Judaism who died here Friday at the age of 71, was eulogized yesterday as the man who "rescued us as Reform Jews from becoming a transient sect in the Jewish movement in American life."
Secretary of the Interior Rogers C. B. Morton said today that "the odds are better than 5050" that the Federal Government would institute gasoline rationing "within the next two or three months."
The Redskins found their missing offense today and crushed the San Francisco 49ers, 33-9, as Bill Kilmer passed for 267 yards.

Deadlines for the mailing of Christmas cards and packages have been moved up by the Postal Service from one to two weeks because of possible airline flight cutbacks resulting from the energy shortage.

Engineers for the New Jersey Turnpike Authority have devised an electronic monitoring system designed to alert motorists to such traffic problems as congestion and crashes on the northern end of the heavily traveled expressway.

The resignations of Attorney General Richardson and Deputy Attorney General Ruckelshaus are important not only in themselves but also as a fundamental departure from the unwritten rules of American political behavior. It remains to be seen whether this departure also marks the beginning of a new constitutional tradition.
John Spoltore, the New Jersey Republican chairman, said today that he would soon convene a meeting of the state committee to start to "rebuild the party" in the wake of its Election Day defeats.

It's surprising what can be stuffed into a situation comedy. This evening's example is, not surprisingly, "Maude," which has Norman Lear as executive producer.

C. David Heymann, a doctor candidate at the State Univer sity of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., identified himself today as the researcher who is scheduled to receive the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation's secret files on Ezra Pound, the poet.

An estimate that the nation faces a daily shortage of 4 million to 6 million barrels of oil a day by midwinter led a scientist member of the House of Representatives to call here today for immediate rationing of petroleum, to be administered at first by state Governors.

Electrical power was cut off on BMT subway tracks at the Broadway and Canal Street station for 13 minutes last evening while firemen put out a minor electrical fire in the rear of a local, headed from Astoria, Queens, to Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn.
Glenn Beckert, whose string of four All-Star appearances at second base was snapped by injury this year, was traded by the Chicago Cubs today to the San Diego Padres for an outfielder, Jerry Morales.

It has long been evident that East Germany would cause more trouble for East-West detente and West Germany's Ostpolitik than any of the other Soviet allies in Europe. Even construction of the Berlin Wall in 1961, which cut off the flood of East German refugees to West Berlin, failed to dissolve the insecurity of East Germany's Communist leaders in any relationship with the prosperous, democratic Federal Republic.
James Abbe, pioneer photo journalist and reporter whose career spanned the era from wet plates and flash powder to color television, died yesterday at his home here. He was 91 years old.

Doubt can tear a man apart. It also can ravage a football team, For six straight weeks feelings of uncertainty kept gnawing with increasing intensity among the New York Giants They had begun to snap and snarl at each other. A week ago Bob Tucker offered the most cutting recrimination of all. "We're just a bunch of quitters," he said with a growl.

Officials of the West Side convention center corporation released a report yesterday on the environmental effects of the project that they said showed that traffic, noise and pollution generated by the $200-million complex would be within Fed eral standards.

The State Commerce Department reported yesterday that nearly four times as many new manufacturing projects started as closed or shrank since 1959, but a joint legislative committee also heard that the state had lost 300,000 manufacturing jobs in the period.

Among the actions taken by the Supreme Court today were the following: ABORTION Declined to review the Arkansas Supreme Court's ruling that the state's abortion statute was constitutional to the extent that it prohibits laymen from performing abortions. (No. 73355, May v. Arkansas).

A 39-year-old defendant critically wounded a woman and apparently shot himself in the head with a .22-caliber revolver in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday as the presiding judge ducked under the bench and screaming spectators scurried for cover in the crowded courtroom.

Too tall as a sofa, too low as a bed, too fat and too ugly to fit appealingly anywhere in the house-that was yesterday's sleep sofa. But all that has disappeared in the sleep sofa revotion of the last 10 years.
Seven bombs exploded in Roman Catholic areas of Belfast today, injuring at least 13 persons and destroying five bars. Those who had planted the bombs gave no warning of the explosions.

Mrs. Annette Perskin Goldman, Superintendent of Community School District 19 in the East New York area of Brooklyn, who recently led her district in a confrontation with the United States Office of Education, died today in North Shore Hospital after, an illness of nine weeks.

Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has been under investigation for nearly four months by the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, concerning alleged judicial misconduct involving improperly lenient sentences for criminal defendants, highly placed sources said yesterday.

"Wing-o, Wing-o" That was the only happy cry last Thursday night from Knick fans at Madison Square Garden. The following evening in Philadelphia even some 76er fans found themselves chanting, "Wing-o,. Wing-o." Back at the Garden Saturday night, Knick fans with little to cheer about an 8-7 won-lost record again resorted to, "Wing-o, Wing-o."

The Most Rev Thomas E. Gill, Roman Catholic Auxiliary Bishop of Seattle, who was credited with building Catholic Children's Services into the largest private child-care agency in this state, died yesterday in Washington. His age was 65.

When Richard Nixon and John B. Connally Jr. "discussed" the possibility that Mr. Nixon might nominate Mr. Connally to fill the Vice-Presidential vacancy, the two men never actually talked. Mr. Nixon spoke to his aide, General Haig, who talked to Mr. Connally, then carried the response back to Mr. Nixon; and so on.
Gasoline rationing may begin as early as Jan. 1, 1974, the President's energy adviser said here today.
Eight masked gunmen locked 12 employes of a Jamaica, warehouse into a security cage last night and drove off in three small trucks loaded with an estimated $300,000 worth of watches and watch parts.

Secretary of State Kissinger said that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East.

Gustave Loebel, who retired in 1967 as a vice president and director of the Continental Grain Company, one of the largest commodity-trading concerns, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at.400 East 56th Street.
New York's death penalty statute was permanently voided today when the Supreme Court refused to set aside last June's ruling by the New York Court of Appeals that the state law was unconstitutional.

The newly elected head of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations said yesterday that it would press on a political level to achieve a more prominent status for Reform Judaism in Israel's religious life.

This is an account of one of 3,500 complaints of sexual offenses that will be made in the city this year. It is based on interviews with each of the key participants; the conflicting statements and points of view are given, illustrating the ambiguities jurors are called on to resolve.
David Akeman, the television comedian, and his wife had $5,700 in cash hidden on them when they were murdered Saturday night in what was believed to be a burglary, a police source said today.

Finnish troops of the United Nations Emergency Force established two checkpoints on the Cairo-to-Suez road yesterday and held them in spite of a threat of attack by Israeli forces, highly placed sources reported.

Nathan's Famous, Inc., the 57-year-old restaurant chain, announced yesterday that it planned to open its first, West Coast unit next summer following a franchise agreement concluded with the American Fast Foods Corporation, of Los Angeles.
Thompson H. Mitchell, who retired in 1966 as president of RCA Global Communications, Inc., a subsidiary of RCA, died Sunday in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., where he had been living. He was 72 years old.

George Bradshaw, a writer whose short stories were often adapted for the screen, died Sunday night while riding in a taxi near his home at 68 East 86th Street. His age was 64.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-thecounter market fell sharply yesterday in moderate trading. Brokers noted that investors remained troubled by the uncertainties of the energy crisis and the attendant possibility of economic dislocations in the months ahead.

A prominent Brazilian law professor and former member of Congress has charged that his son was the victim of homicide while under detention and has asked for an investigation by the military police.

The nation's Roman Catholic bishops indicated today that they favored a broad interpretation of a Vatican demand that they stop the practice of delaying the first confession for children until several years after they receive first communion.

If there's one subject New Yorkers don't seem to be talking about it's Princess Anne's $240,000 wedding tomorrow in Westminster Abbey. The big event, to be held in the presence of millions of television watchers around the world, just isn't generating much excitement in New York.

Frank B. Rackley, who at the age of 33 in 1950 became president of the Jessop Steel Company here, died today in a hospital near his winter home in Orlando, Fla.

Harsher punishment of tax dodgers would deter other income tax cheaters, says Donald C. Alexander, Internal Revenue Commissioner.

Some 95 members of the strikebound New York Philharmonic Orchestra opened a tour of the Iberian peninsula tonight with the approval of the musicians union but under the cloud of a possible lawsuit by the Philharmonic's management.
The Securities and Exchange Commission is investgating the purchase by billion: aire industrialist Howard Hughes of Air West, a regional airline, The Los Angeles Times reported today.

Ralph G. Caso, the Nassau County Executive, released his proposed county budget for 1974.today, one that would result in an increase in the property tax rate of about 38 cents for each $100 of assessed valution for most taxpayers.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne today refused to support legislation that would have placed the state's moral commitment behind the financing of a major sports development in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

Allan A. Michie, a World War II correspondent and author of numerous books, died of a heart Attack yesterday at his home, 1,201 Parkway. He was 58 years old.
A nationwide increase in syphilis appears to be leveling off, the National Center for Disease Control has reported.

Ray D. Garrett Jr., chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, proposed today that the securities industry be exempted from the antitrust laws but backed down to a less sweeping position in the face of a critical response from Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., Democrat of New Jersey, chairman of the Senate Securities subcommittee.
Following is the text of President Nixon's statement issued by the White House today on the status of the evidence in the Watergate case:

Initially, the controversy over the Watergate tapes focused primarily on the question whether President Nixon would defy the courts. Now that Mr. Nixon has agreed to obey court orders to turn the tapes over to Chief District Judge John J. Sirica, the issue of Presidential defiance has given way, once again, to the question of Presidential credibility.
A kidnapped American oil executive was released unharmed yesterday and left for the United States shortly afterward, it was reported here.

A grocers' strike in protest against price curbs is spreading in France as shopkeepers, joined by the major trade unions, head for a new confrontation with the Government over its anti-inflation policies.

Secretary General Waldheim has sent one of his top aides to the Middle East to try to work out an exchange of war prisoners held by Syria and Israel, according to qualified sources here.

Eddie. Belmonte rode in only one race at Aqueduct yesterday and didn't do too well, finishing out of the money on an 11-to-1 shot. That sole outing for one of the top riders in the nation generated curiosity as to why Belmonte wasn't working more.

Four thousand students at South Korea's largest university for women held a rally today to demand a "genuine democratic system" in this country in the latest development in the spreading student protest against the Government.

The head of the Honest Ballot Association, George J. Abrams, disclosed to a Manhattar grand jury yesterday the resulte of the vote that preceded the five-and - a - half - hou strike last Tuesday by 10,90C city firemen.

Trans World Airlines, grounded since Nov. 5 by a strike of 5,000 flight attendants, and Local 550 of hte Transport Workers Union, said yesterday that they were meeting with officials of the National Mediation Board in Washington.

Assemblyman Calvin Williams was indicted yesterday by a State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn on charges of allegedly bribing the driver of a "gypsy" cab to drop charges of assault, robbery and auto theft against Mr. Williams's 21-year-old son.

President Nixon offered today to furnish Federal District Judge John J. Sirica with background information on two conversations sought by Watergate investigators that the secret White House recording system failed to record.

The New England Electrla System's offering of 1.3-million shares of common stock was won by a group of underwriters headed by the First Boston Corporation. The group bid $20.888 a share and will reoffer them at $22 a share. New England Electric closed yesterday at 22, unchanged, on the New York Stock Exchange.

In the strongest Government statement so far on the fuel crisis, a senior economic official warned today that the Arab oil cutbacks threatened, Japan with the "first serious blow" to its economy since World War II.
Negotiations failed yesterday to head off a threatened strike by dancers that would prevent the New York City Ballet from opening its 14-week fall-winter season tonight.
The Maryland State Bar Association began action today that could lead to the former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew's being barred from practising law anywhere in the United States.

Hospital workers returned to their jobs yesterday after voting to accept a wage settlement scaled down by the Federal Cost of Living Council, thus ending a week-long walkout that had crippled 48 hospitals and nursing homes in the area.
The Skylab 3 launching was postponed again today after technicians discovered more cracks in the eight-yearold Saturn 1-B rocket.

The dollar reached its highest level since midsummer on Western European money markets today with a continuing wave of buying orders indicating that its strong recovery this month had not yet reached its peak.

By WILLIAM N. WALLACE Eighty-five per cent of the National Football League's 1,300 players prefer playing on grass than on artificial turf. This was a claim made yesterday by the N.F.L. Players Association at its one-day conference in Washington presided over by an athlete with a leg in a cast.

The widening of the Garden State Parkway south to Asbury Park should be finished by next November. That would be a full year earlier than expected, according to John E. Gallagher, executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority, operating agency for the parkway.

Finnish troops of the United Nations Emergency Force established two checkpoints on the Cairo-to-Suez road yesterday and held them in spite of a threat of attack by Israeli forces, highly placed sources reported. They said fistfights broke out between Finns and Israelis in the process.
President Nixon has prepared an affidavit covering what he believes will clarify his relation to the Watergate scandal, The St. Louis PostDispatch said today.

It has been nearly seven years since American troops suddenly surrounded the prosperous village of Ben Suc, forced its residents into a barren make-shift camp 20 miles away and then burned, bombed and bulldozed the village out of existence.

President Tito of Yugoslavia flew to the Soviet Union today and began talks with Leonid I. Brezhnev Centering on the Middle East and dealing with the improving trend of their political and economic relations.

A student organization at Princeton announced today that Roy Innis, the director of the Congress of Racial Equality, and Dr. William B. Shockley, the Nobel laureate, had accepted an invitation to hold their controversial debate here next month.
Eighteen horses shipped from Idaho for slaughter last winter have been returned and may again roam freely in the high country near Howe.

The latest Department of Agriculture estimate that this year's production of feed grain would be less than expected resulted in considerable buying of corn and oats futures yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.
Negotiations failed yesterday to head off a threatened strike by dancers that would prevent the New York City Ballet from opening its 14-week fall-winter season tonight.

Leaon Jaworski, in his first major legal argument since taking office as Watergate prosecutor, said today that "not even the highest office in the land" has the authority to break the law in the name of national security.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne today refused to support legislation that would have placed the state's moral commitment behind the financing of a major sports development in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

Fifth Avenue and Rockefeller Center will be bereft of some of their holiday glitter this year because of the energy crisis, spokesmen for many of the major stores said yesterday, though they added that the area would not be less festive.
Two major bills to deal with the energy shortage cleared important hurdles in Congress today. The House approved 361 to 14, and sent to the Senate the Alaska pipeline bill.

The House Agriculture Committee approved unanimously today a bill to give Agriculture. Secretary Earl L. Butz power to approve use of DDT in emergency situations, such as when a forest is threatened by destructive insects.
An official said today that restrictions on fuel consumption inproduced here were intended largely as a gesture of solidarity with countries that were suffering because of Arab oil boycott.
H. Carl McCall, who resigned recently as chairman of the editorial page of The New York Amsterdam News in a dispute with the publisher over a political endorsement, has withdrawn his resignation.

Detectives were investigating yesterday a possible link between the killings of a numbers-rackets gambler found slain in Central Park Sunday and of another gambler found dead in his car in the Bronx a week ago.

O. K., so the New York Giants didn't quit against the Dallas Cowboys last Sunday But they didn't win either, sc where does that leave then with only five games left? Dc they really want the No. choice in the college draft?
Cambodian Government forces reportedly fought through the day today in an effort to dislodge insurgent troops who cut Phnom Penh's road to the sea yesterday.

Braniff International Airways Inc. and its board chairman pleaded guilty today to Federal charges of having made an. illegal $40,000 corporate cash contribution to President Nixon's 1972 re-election campaign.

Misunderstandings, lack of information and a basic divergence in perceptions of the nature of the Middle East 'crisis led to the recent sharp public rift between Europe and the United States, according to American and allied diplomats.
Egyptian and Israeli negotiators today failed for the second day to make progress toward agreeing on steps to carry out their cease-fire agreement, and their next session was put off until Wednesday.

PARAMUS-The rumor mills were circulating the story as to whether Dick DeTeresa had accidental or intentionally sidelined his roommate for the football season. After all, they were on opposite teams and DeTeresa's roommate was considered an outside threat, being described as "small but fast."

The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether a political candidate has a constitutional right to put his campaign advertisements on city buses that carry advertising for such products as soda pop and Perfume.

The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Essex International, Inc., manufacturers of electriccurrent carrying and controlling devices and related metal and plastic products.
The emphasis in the Jets' workouts this week will be on quarterbacks - offensive quarterbacks, defensive quarterbacks, backup quarterbacks, deactivated quarterbacks.

Leaders of the United Automobile Workers tried today to stem wide opposition, particularly among skilled trade workers, to a tentative national contract reached with the Ford Motor Company last. Oct. 26.

Savings banks in New York "are unlikely to again experience a steady and assured deposit inflow with an easy spread between rates on savings and rates on mortgages," according to Harry W. Albright Jr., the State. Superintendent of Banks.
Listlessly, almost aimlessly, and under what some said was "a dark cloud hanging over the party," defeated Republican legislators cast votes in the State Senate and Assembly today.

British playwrights-or at least many of them-seem interested nowadays in a kind of microscopic reality, virtually a documentary theater, probably borrowed from the cinema, that makes its points with a relentless insistence on time, place and minute detail.
A 17 per cent reduction in the nation's oil supply "will not really do any serious damage" to the economy next year, a Nixon Administration official said here yesterday.
Gov. Dolph Briscoe announced today that one of Japan's major textile concerns, the Daiwa Spinning Company, would build a large cotton spinning plant near Plainview, Tex., on the South Plains.
A Federal judge dismissed today a $4-million libel suit brought against The New York Times by Otto F. Otepka, a former employee of the State Department.

Israeli officials said tonight that unless a deadlock over control of the Cairo-Suez highway was resolved and Israeli prisoners promptly returned, Israel would have to reconsider the cease-fire agreement, including her pledge to permit the continuing supply of the Egyptian III Corps.

The Republican party established today what it hoped would be a policy voice independent of President Nixon just as the White House said it was beginning to win the counter-offensive against its Watergate critics.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East.

A 39-year-old defendant critically wounded a woman and apparently shot himself in the head with a .22-caliber revolver in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday as the presiding judge ducked under the bench and screaming spectators scurried for cover in the crowded courtroom.

Archibald Cox said last night that President Nixon, and not the courts, should be allowed to appoint a new Watergate prosecutor but that his independence should be guaranteed by Congressional statute.

It was an unusually lively opening for the Eastern States Antiques Fair, with the heaviest attendance in several editions of the show. Many of the visitors to the fairgrounds at the Westchester County Center weren't "just looking."
Two major bills, to deal with the energy shortage cleared important hurdles in Congress today.

The Columbia Broadcasting System has done away with its short-lived policy prohibiting its news correspondents from commenting on, or analyzing, Presidential addresses immediately after they are delivered.

In the strongest official denunciation of Soviet-American accords yet heard in Western Europe, France's Foreign Minister said today that the "brutal crises" in the Middle East confirmed his Government's doubts about the superpowers' capacities to keep peace.
Interest rates on Treasury bills-the securities the Goveminment sells when it borrows for a short period--soared yesterday, adding pressure to other rates throughout the money and capital markets.

In the strongest official denunciation of Soviet-American accords yet heard in Western Europe, France's Foreign Minister said today that the "brutal crises" in the Middle East confirmed his Government's doubts about the superpowers' capacities to keep peace.

Secretary of State Kissinger said today that the United States was considering a mutual security treaty with Israel as one of the possible ways of guaranteeing Israel's boundaries once a formal peace agreement has been achieved in the Middle East.
On Saturday night, the National Ballet's Carmen Mathe, took the lead in "Sleeping Beauty" at the City Center 55th Street Theater. She was ably partnered by Dennis Poole.

The House Ways and Means Committee has voted to increase Social Security benefits by 11 per cent next year--reversing its previous day's decision to boost benefits by 10 per cent. The extra amount split the difference between Republicans, who wanted a 10 per cent increase, and Democrats, who were going for 12.

Sam Fields patted the fender of his 1971 Cadillac while he gassed up- at the William F. Halsey .service area on the New Jersey Turnpike. "Speed limit doesn't bother me," he said. "I've got a regulator.

Norton Q. Sloan, president of the Distrigas Corporation of Boston, advised the Federal Power Commission that the recent shutdown of two liquefaction-lines in Algeria by Sonatrach, the Algerian national petroleum organization, had been found to have been caused by technical problems.

The Alaska Legislature has ordered a 50 per cent rise in petroleum production taxes on the oil-rich North Slope. The increase, raising the perbarrel tax to just under 27 cents, was about the level Gov. William A. Egan and oil companies agreed on during talks last year.

A student organization at Princeton announced today that Roy Innis, the director of the Congress of Racial Equality, and Dr. William B. Shockley, the Nobel laureate, had accepted an invitation to hold their controversial debate here next month.
Some suit combinations that appear childishly simple may have unexpected complexities in special circumstances. Textbooks for...
In the second quarter of the Buffalo Bills' game with the Baltimore Colts a few weeks ago,. 0. J. Simpson suddenly went to the end of the bench and sat there alone.

By the standards of Life, Look and dozens of other long-gone magazines of mass circulation, The New Leader has always ranked as a pygmy. But this estimable biweekly of news and opinion, celebrating its fiftieth birthday this week, never depended on numbers for either its usefulness or its influence.
President Nixon made a surprise appearance tonight at the 75th birthday party of Senator Wallace F. Bennett, Republican of Utah.

States and municipalities around the country continued yesterday to take actions to deal with the oil shortage. In Maryland, Gov. Marvin Mandel assumed unprecedented powers. Armed with emeragency legislation that was passed yesterday by the General Assembly in special session, the Governor said- he would quickly do the following:
Herbert V. Olson, a watercolorist, died yesterday in Fairfield. His age was 68. He lived at 6 Florian Court here.
Golfs richest tournament, the $500,000 World open, resumes tomorrow after a twoday intermission with Gibby Gilbert leading by five strokes. But the tournament's future was uncertain.

The Department of Health, Education and Welfare rejected today as "far short of being acceptable" the court-ordered racial desegregation plans for public college and university systems submitted by nine states.

Stock prices continued to fall yesterday as investors sought to assess the impact, of the energy crisis, including the future availability and price of gasoline that is so critical to many industries.
International business experts issued an appeal here yesterday for major energy consuming nations to seek joint solutions and avoid destructive competition for available supplies of oil and gas.
Secretary of State Kissinger publicly assured Chinese leaders last night that American policy toward Peking would remain constant "no matter what happens in the United States in the future."

Crucial talks are under way between the State Department of Higher Education and the New Jersey State Federation of Teachers that will determine whether the state college teachers' bargaining unit will decide Saturday whether to strike.
More than 200 rings and bracelets, including 48 wedding bands, that have been found on property of the Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in the last decade will go to the highest bidder tomorrow.

The Knicks just beat the best playground team in the National Basketball Association. The Seattle SuperSonics played like a bunch of talented kids in the schoolyard game as they lost, 104-102, last night at Madison Square Garden. Often the Seattle

Hire it is 1973, and Rick Derringer is reworking the "Tell Laura I Love Her" story, with no apparent sense of parody or satire, on his debut album, "All American Boy" (Blue Sky Records KZ 32481, $5.98).

Even before the Governor made public his latest transit dictum yesterday that the 35cent fare was dead in New York City, he was reliably reported to have cautioned Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame in a private chat' not to get locked into a hard "save the fare" posture.

The Suffolk County Executive, John V. N. Klein, said today that his administration would consider subsidizing private bus companies and, in some cases, taking over entire bus routes to strengthen and expand the public transportation system in the county.

United States District Judge Aubrey E.. Robinson found Northwest Airlines guilty today of practicing sex discrimination in its flight crews. The ruling could mean retroactive pay increases of up to $250 a month for 1,100 stewardesses.
The Moroccan office of phosphates said in Rabat yesterday that, beginning Jan. 1, the price of phosphate would be increased from its present level' of $15 a ton to $48.
Holy Cross College and Worcester Polytechnic Institute said today that they had established a cooperative program in which a student may earn two bachelor degrees in five years at the two schools.
Carlos Ward, a Sheepshead Bay junior, set a meet record yesterday while winning the Public Schools Athletic League individual cross-country title at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
After a re-examination of the trouble-plagued rocket, space agency officials decided today to continue with a countdown aimed at launching the Skylab 3 astronauts Friday morning.

To the spectators and opposition of Fairleigh Dickinson University's club hockey team, that 5-foot-10-inch center on the second line may look like just another stickman on Coach Dick Trimble's squad. But those familiar with the skating Knights are aware that John Pierce is a Franciscan priest.
Natale Marcone, president of the Italian-American Civil Rights League, pleaded guilty in Federal Court in Brooklyn to making a false statement in an application for a $6,000 bank loan.
A hearing on the extradition of Robert L. Vesco, the international financier facing Federal charges of fraud and conspiracy in New York, was snagged almost immediately today on the question,

Norton Simon, Inc., expects to increase earnings in its second fiscal year ending December by about 7.5 per cent from $18.9-million, or 48 cents a share, earned in the similar three months last year with sales up about 8.5 per cent from $378-million, David J. Mahoney, chairman and president, said following annual meeting of stockholders in the Commodore Hotel here yesterday.
A Washington Heights father was convicted yesterday of first-degree manslaughter in the rubber-hose beating death of his 16-year-old daughter. He contended he had a legal right to impose discipline.
Stephen H. Philbin, a senior partner in the law firm of Fish Neave, died yesterday at his summer home in Old Lyme, Conm He was 86 years old and lived at 141 East 72d Street.

Reports circulating today that the gubernatorial campaign debt incurred by Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. and his supporters could reach $300,000 inspired new discussion of the possibility of a protracted battle over Republican party leadership.

Francis, the pregnant white whale at the New York Aquarium, has resumed her normal appetite after a brief respiratory infection. Her white-cell blood count is down to normal and she looks happy and fatter.

About to perform for the gala opening of its 25th year, the New York City Ballet was shut down last night by the first strike of its dancers in the company's history. This is the fourth major strike against a cultural institution in the city this fall.

"This is worse than New York," proclaimed a weary Bob Foster in Johannesburg yesterday when a crowd of about 1,000 swarmed around the world light-heavyweight champion at the airport. Foster will make history Dec. 1 when he becomes the first professional black boxer to meet a white in South Africa.
Israeli forces today demonstrated that they retained control of the road leading to the city of Suez despite the two United Nations checkpoints that were set up yesterday.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market plunged again yesterday in stepped-up trading. The Amex index fell 0.98 to 102.16 as 656 Issues showed declines and only 208 rising.

An activist priest who said that America's Roman Catholic bishops were meeting here in an atmosphere of repression was arrested along with four other persons this afternoon for refusing to leave a downtown Washington hotel.

Passage of the Alaska pipeline bill is the triumph of scare propaganda and economic pressure over reasoned public policy. The bill tears a gaping hole in the National Environmental Policy Act by barring court review of the environmental impact statement filed by the Interior Department to justify the pipeline. A project that cannot withstand orderly judicial examination is suspect from the start.

Israeli forces demonstrated that they retained full control of the road leading to the city of Suez despite the two United Nations checkpoints that were set up Monday, Israeli soldiers with machine guns at the ready and standing shoulder to shoulder held back about 120 newsmen and cameramen who had come from Cario to the point on the Cairo-Suez road called Kilometer 101. [1:4.]

A pin-stripe-suited Englishman who allegedly swindled $170,000 from a Wall Street brokerage house through a girlfriend's account, was arrested here in a new guise-that of a bearded hippie, the police said yesterday.
The chairman of the State Select Committee on Crime said yesterday that New York judges had illegally freed defendants in at least 247 felony narcotic cases in the last few years.

One of the city's larger housing developments, Rochdale Village in Queens, will go cold and dark next week unless alternative fuel supplies can be found. "On the morning of the 22d, 5,860 families will be without electricity, heat and hot water,"

The need for strong measures -to combat the nation's energy crisis was a theme voiced by seemingly all of the 2,000 oil industry executives attending the annual meeting of the American Petroleum Institute

An executive of a South Kearny company was fined $20,000 and put on probation for two years for conspiring to bribe a tax agent to obtain favorable consideration for the company. Federal Judge Lloyd F. MacMahon suspended imposition of a two-year prison sentence on Joseph Scheinfeld, 48 years year old, of West Orange, president of S. Scheinfeld Sons of- South Kearny.

Although she can sleep later if she wants to, Stacy Morrison will get up at 9 o'clock this morning "so me and Kevin can have breakfast together." Then Kevin will stow his gear in the car for the drive from Rockaway, N. J., to the New York Golder Blades' practice rink in Newark.

The 48 voluntary hospitals and nursing homes struck last week by 30,000 hospital workers, are asking the state and Blue Cross to pay them more than $5.2-million they say they lost because of the work stoppage.

THREE ON BROADWAY, an anthology of American musical theater, with a special tribute to George Gershwin. Conceived and written by Ronald Rogers. Presented by Lucille Lortel, artistic director, the Matinee Series. At the Theater de Lys, 121 Christopher Street. WITH: Ronald Rogers, Jan McArt and Richard Otto.

The Senate Commerce Committee said yesterday that it would hold hearings tomorrow and on Friday on a bill that was passed last week in the House and which would restructure the Penn Central and six other bankrupt Eastern railroads.
New York City moved yesterday to bring back a football team to Yankee Stadium when it invited Robert Schmertz, a collector of sports franchises, to begin negotiations.

Two employes of the American Ship Building Company told Senate investigators today that their chief, George M. Steinbrenner 3d, had devised illegal schemes to contribute thousands of dollars in corporate funds to President Nixon's re-
A commuter group warned Gov. Thomas J. Meskill today that Fairfield County commuters faced a 70 per cent increase in fares on the Penn Central's New Haven line.

New York City's two franchised cable television systems, Sterling-Manhattan Cable and Teleprompter Manhattan Cable, have applied to the city for permission to raise their basic service rate to subscribers from $5 to $8 a month and the rental fee for the optional converter from $1 to $2 a month.

Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn has been indicted on a charge of lying under oath and seeking to obstruct a state investigation into judicial corruption, the special state prosecutor, Maurice H. Nadjari, announced yesterday.
Jeffrey P. Cohen, who was identified by the police as an assistant to Donald R. Manes, Borough President of Queens, was killed last night when his car. was hit by a tow truck.
Bruno Maderna, the Italian composer and conductor, died yesterday in a hospital at Darmstadt, West Germany, where he had lived for many years. He was 53 years old.

Fuel costs for each kilowatt hour of electricity have risen 20 per cent in New York City and Westchester, Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the Public Service Commission, said in a report made public by Governor Rockefeller yesterday,
A bill to raise the interest ceiling on mortgages to 9.5 per cent, if passed by the Legislature, could put state-chartered and federally chartered banks back on an equal footing in New Jersey.
The European heavyweight champion, Joe Bugner, scored a 10-round decision over Mac Foster of Fresno, Calif., in a dull fight at Wembley Empire Pool tonight.

The Government said today that a violent storm struck six coastal provinces over the weekend, killing at least 51 persons, forcing evacuation of at least 145,000 and flooding several cities with waters as deep as 10 feet.

In an unusually bitter struggle over a contract ratification, the United Automobile Workers union announced today that its skilled tradesmen had refused to ratify a tentative agreement negotiated with the Ford Motor Company.
Mrs. Mary P. Hooker, wife of Stewart Hooker, publisher of The Daily Racing Form, died here today of cancer at her home. Her age was 59.

Jimmy Connors of Belleville, Il1., became the first player to reach the quarterfinals of the $48,000 Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today by trouncing Gerald Battrick of Britian, 6-1, 6-3.. Ilie Nastase also won, as did Tom Okker.
The United States and six European countries have terminated the five-year-old agreement that barred them from transactions in gold in the free market.

A 32-year-old legal secretary who is in critical condition after being wounded in Mon day's shooting in Manhatta?? Criminal Court, was placed un der arrest yesterday. on a charge of possession of a dead ly weapon. She is in the in tensive-care unit of Beekman Downtown Hospital.
New York City's Congressional delegation today resolved to seek an "emergency meeting" with the Veterans Administration to ease the plight of the city's 350,000 Vietnam veterans.
Britain and Iceland formally ended their 15-month feud over fishing rights today with a twoyear pact cutting back the annual catch British trawlermen can take out of Iceland's claimed waters.

This may be the twilight of the floundering Federal wage-price control program, but New Yorkers would never guess it from the pivotal role the Cost of Living Council is playing in determining what happens to this city's vital services.
In an atmosphere of crisis, the Senate approved the Alaska pipeline bill today and sent it to President Nixon. The vote was 80 to 5, and there was only perfunctory debate.

New York needs the proposed new convention center. The competitive disadvantage of this city's present inadequate trade-show facilities is evident, as is the pressing need for employment opportunities -particularly for minorities -that the center would create. The project is in a sense a major defensive operation, to enable the city to keep and enlarge its trade-show business as critical support for its all-important tourist, hotel and service industries.
A wide variety of factors influenced commodity futures prices yesterday, pointing up the importance of viewing each commodity on an individual basis.

The most urgent need in the Watergate investigation is a special prosecutor chosen by the judicial branch of the Government and known to be totally independent of the Nixon Administration. Leon Jaworski, whom President Nixon has named as special prosecutor, takes office on the same terms and with no greater protection than his predecessor,
Members of the Newspaper Guild at The New York Times approved a new two-year contract yesterday by a vote of 704 to 246, it was announced by Bernard Stein, unit chairman.

Seventeen Greeks charged with rioting on Nov. 4 after a memorial service for the late Premier George Papandreou were set free tonight after a trial at which 11 defendants testified that they had been savagely beaten by the police.
The dollar's week-long rise on European markets was halted today after the Bank of England raised its minimum lending rate to a record 13 per cent from 11 1/4- per cent, pushing the pound upward.
A number of FM radio stations were off the air last night for up to two and a half hours because of a mechanical problem with an antenna at the Empire State Building.

Vice Adm. Morton L. Deyo, who commanded gun support groups at the Normandy and Southern France landings in 1944, died Saturday in Portsmouth Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at Hookes Cove, Kittery Point, Me.

The striking professional and administrative employes of the Museum of Modern Art have thrown up pickets in front of the 1 Beekman Place home of Mrs. John D. Rockefeller 3d, chairman of the museum's board of trustees.

Wellington Mara, the president of the New York Giants, said today he was still enthusiastic about moving his football team to northern New Jersey despite new demands, that the contract involving the Giants' commitment to move there be renegotiated.
James W. McCord Jr. appealed his conviction today for conspiracy, burglary and wiretapping in the Watergate breakin, and asked to be released until a Federal appellate court acts.

Earnings of the Beneficial Corporation fell 8 per cent in the third quarter, the company reported yesterday. This reflected a decline of 5.8 per cent in the finance division's earnings to $15-million from the year-earlier $16-million and:a decline of 19.5 per cent in the merchandise division's earnings to $2.6-million from $3.3-million.

Borrowing an idea from Governor Rockefeller, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill of Connecticut conducted an open meeting last night with the people of Meriden, the first in a series of planned com-. munity forums designed to bring the /government closer to the people.

The Knicks just beat the best playground team in the National Basketball Association. The Seattle SuperSonics played like a bunch of talented kids in the schoolyard game as they lost, 104-102, last night at Madison Square Gardenn.
The chairman of the two major stock exchanges differed today on aspects of a proposed national market system, although both basically supported legislation for such a system.
The Archbishop of Barcelona has openly intervened on the side of 113 opponents of the Spanish Government who were arrested Oct. 28 while meeting in a church building.
New York City's Congressional delegation .today resolved to seek an "emergency meeting" with the Veterans Administration to ease the plight of the city's 350,000 Vietnam veterans.
Four youths and seven young girls were arrested last night in the Bronx and charged with the kidnapping and sexual assault of two teen-aged girls.

A majority of Roman Catholics, Protestants and Jews favor abortion if the mother's health is endangered, in cases of rape or to prevent birth of a defective child, according to a survey conducted by The National Catholic Reporter.
In a week top-heavy with "specials," the most special began last night. It is "The Blue Knight," an adaptation of Joseph Wambaugh's bestselling novel.
Edward B. Redman, manager of the Dartmouth Club of New York from 1935 to his retirement in. 1957, died yesterday in the Hanover Convalescent Center. He was 88 years old.

The first great blow in Gary Cohen's young life came three years ago His mother died Of cancer. Five months ago, his 15-yearold sister, Janice, accidentally shot herself while handling a gun in the family weapons collection.

About to perform for the gala opening of its 25th year, the New York City Ballet was shut down last night by the first strike of its dancers in the company's history. This is the fourth major strike against a cultural institution in the city this fall.
Eleven leaders of organizations that oppose South Africa's policies of racial separation went on trial this week for refusing to testify before a secret Government investigating commission.

While trying to line up sup port for the Democratic nomination for Governor next year, Howard J. Samuels' is urging Democratic politicians .to work for an ethnically and geo. graphically balanced ticket.

Corporate bond prices fell slightly yesterday in quiet trading as the market turned its attention to several new offerings. The initial response to the outpouring of new issues in both the corporate and taxexempt markets was regarded as favorable.
Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he did not see any way to save the 35-cent transit fare here and that anyone who said it could be saved was "kidding the public."

President Nixon met for more than two hours tonight with 15 Republican Senators and apparently persuaded most of them that he intended to tell everything that he knew about Watergate and allied scandals.

WASHINGTON-The image of the lobbyist as a cigar smoker, a wisecracker, a glad-hander, a back-slapper and, above all, a man, is being challenged by the capitol's small but growing band of women lobbyists.
The Drug Enforcement Administration ordered strict Federal controls today on three commonly used barbiturates because of findings that they have high potential for addiction.

Representative Wilbur Mills, back in his office for the first time since undergoing back surgery in August, said yesterday that trade legislation, delayed at the personal request of President Nixon in Mr. Mills's absence, should not be postponed any later than the week of Nov. 26, when Congress returns from its Thanksgiving recess.

"We always have 'Hamlet' without the Prince of Denmark," said W. McNeil Lowry, a vice president of the Ford Foundation, after the guest of honor to whom he had just proposed a toast, seemed to vanish from a crowded party at the State Theater last night.
The city made public yesterlay the properties that were granted reductions of assessed valuations by the City Tax soul commission for this year.

Pro football scouts, who drooled over last. season's rich crop of. college seniors, are calling this year's harvest the leanest in a long time. "It's the worst year in my memory, and I pride myself on my memory," Gil Brandt, th the director of personnel for the Dallas Cowboys,

In an unusually bitter struggle over a contract ratification, the United Automobile Workers union announced today that its skilled tradesmen had refused to ratify a tentative agreement negotiated with the Ford Motor Company.
While trying to line up support for the Democratic nomination for Governor next year, Howard J. Samuels is urging Democratic politicians to work for an ethnically and geographically balanced ticket.

Inbal, Dance Theater of Israel is a watch-charm folk company, modest in size but with a warm humorous quality. One has the impression of seeing exotic children at play much of the time. The group began its season last night at the City' Center.

Jimmy- Connors of Belleville, I11., became the first player to reach the quarterfinals of the $48,000 Dewar Cup indoor tennis tournament today by trouncing Gerald Battrick of Boston, 6-1, 6-3. Mie Nastase also won, as did Tom Okker.

Bankers interviewed last night termed the decision by the United States and the other nations to end a five-year bar on gold sales in the market a logical one and suggested that it was prompted by the recent strength of the dollar in world currency markets.

Britain's deteriorating economic position forced the Government today to adopt a series of drastic measures to shore up her balance of payments, curtail the money supply and cope with labor disputes that threaten to cause widespread power blackouts.

Rivera appealed the decision to the National Transportation Safety Board and his license was suspended for 180 days.

In an atmosphere of crisis, the Senate approved the Alaska pipeline bill today and sent it to President Nixon. The vote was 80 to 5, and-there was only perfunctory debate.

The price of gold steadied today after yesterday's sharp plunge in European bullion markets. The dollar was stronger in foreign exchanges. Gold dropped more than $7 an ounce Wednesday on fears that governments would soon dump their massive holdings of the metal on the open market.

Mr. and Mrs. Cabell Calloway 3d have announced that their daughter, Miss Cabella Catherine Calloway, will be married at home here Dec. 16 to Andrew Langsam, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander E. Langsam of Stamford, Conn., and Natanya, Israel.

There was a strange silence over this town's central square yesterday and an unusual dimness at dusk. As a testimonial to Jefferson's determination to play its part in conserving energy, the bells in the Mahanay Memorial Carillon Tower no longer peal their hymns and patriotic music.

NEW BRUNSWICK-Problem drinking by people beyond the age of 55, which may affect as many as three million people in the United States, is the target of a new project at Rutgers University's Center of Alcohol Studies.

DETROIT-When Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Automobile Workers union, was asked at a press conference last week to evaluate the feelings of the skilled trades workers in the U.A,W. he replied: "I'm not a psychiatrist. I'm just a collective bargainer."
Union and industry official said today that striking United Mine Workers in Illinois were returning to their jobs in compliance with Federal court injunctions.

The use of $100-million or more from the New York City capital budget to subsidize private construction of low-income and moderate-income housing, reducing the cost to tenants by as much as 50 per cent, has been proposed by special task force commissioned by Controller-elect Harrison J. Goldin.
Nick Harbaruk scored one goal and assisted on two others tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 4-0 victory over the New York Islanders in a National Hockey League game.
The first of 28 transit-information signs at key bus stops in downtown Brooklyn and in shopping districts in Jamaica, Queens, will be installed by the end of the year, Mayor Lindsay said today.

Auto-racing officials are concerned that their sport may run out of gas, figuratively if not literally, during the fuel crisis.

Jo Jo White pumped in 30 points, 28 in the second half, to lead the Boston Celtics to a 123-110 National Basketball Association - victory over the Kansas City-Omaha Kings tonight.

Syosset, which has played second fiddle to Farmingdale in recent seasons, won the Nassau County North Shore Division I championship yesterday by stopping Hicksville, 16-0. Syosset's Kevin Mannix scored two touchdowns to take the county scoring title again, this time with a total of 20. touchdowns.
President George Papadopoulos imposed martial law today after a night of street clashes in Athens between the police and student and worker demonstrators.

Miss Sarah Graham Mann plans to be married here Dec. 30 to William F. Russell Jr., national sales manager of Peter Storm, Ltd., of Norwalk. Conn., makers of yachting apparel in the United States and Europe.
Paul Getty 2d tonight disclosed that he has offered to pay an undisclosed ransom to the kidnappers of his oldest son, Paul Getty 3d.
SHIP-Thanks to Vincent Panella of this Morris County community, the wild turkey is safe from extinction in both Morris and Warren Counties for some years to come.
PERTH AMBOY-An elderly couple in Perth Amboy and a church congregation in nearby Rahway were dislocated for weeks after underground pools of gasoline forced them to flee.

Given the emergence of Fred Astaire dance studios, Esther Williams swimming pool installations, Arlene Dahl beauty operations and Lassie kennels, perhaps it was inevitable the nation would have the Evel Knievel Electro-Cycle Service Centers of America, a 25-unit franchise chain in the Midwest.

BURR, by Gore Vidal. (Random House, $8.95.) An imagined biography cum autobiography of the conventional textbook villain; a wicked entertainment in which Mr. Vidal slyly upends American history. A CROWN OF FEATHERS, by Isaac Bashevis Singer. (Farrar, Straus Giroux, $8.95.) God crowds the world of these masterful short stories. with his busy divinity, strewing surprises at every turn.

LOS ANGELES The most extraordinary Hollywood bargain of the last few years was sealed recently over a tray of diet cherry cola, diet red apple, diet root beer, Tab, and one glass of diet chocolate soda.
PEMBERTON - Science teachers from throughout the state and the Delaware Valley will meet at Burlington County College on Dec. 8 for a conference on "New Directions in Science '74."

In the Noroton Presbyterian Church this afternoon, Miss Sandra Procter Young, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Young of Darien, became the bride of William Joseph Adams of Ardmore, Pa. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Adams of Waltham, Mass.

Rod Laver and Ken Rosewall, the aging but still agile tennis stars, overcame intense heat to beat Jan Kodes and Vladimir Zednik of Czechoslovakia, 6-4, 14-12, 7-9, 8-6, in doubles today, giving Australia a 2-1 lead in the Davis Cup semifinal.

Pierre Davis scored three touchdowns yesterday as he led Bayside to the Public Schools Athletic League title and helped prove a point. "We had heard all week about how strong and physical South Shore wa," Davis

The National Hockey League scoring leader, Phil Esposito, got his 20th goal of the season, a modern league record for 18 games, and the Boston goalie, Gilles Gilbert, posted his first shutout of the season tonight as the Bruins notched their fifth straight triumph, 8-0, over the Detroit Red Red Wings.

Mr. and Mrs. Daniel V. McCarthy have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine McCarthy, to Kevin Ecclesine, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Ecclesine of White Plains. A wedding in March is planned.
Officials of the State Game and Fish Department are convinced that Americans all over the country are more willing than ever to go to great lengths to "get away from it all."
Mrs. Miles Valentine's 6-yearold Chilean-bred jumper, Lucky Boy III, won the fourth running of the $50,000 Colonial Cup steeplechase at the Springdale Course today.

To the Editor: Regarding the article by Leonard S. Bernstein on "Becoming a Man Where Abraham Stood, David Sang, Solomon Judged" (Travel Section, Nov. 4), I feel compelled to comment. As a travel piece, the article on traveling to Israel for a bar mitzvah didn't nearly warrant the space it got, but that in itself wouldn't get me to bust my knuckles on the typewriter.

Fairfield Prep and Danbury emerged as conference champions yesterday in two Fairfield County playoff contests. Fairfield won the Metropolitan Bridgeport Interscholastic Athletic Conference title with a 21-6 victory over Warren Harding.
Connecticut gained a 7-7 tie with Rhode Island and won the Yankee Conference football championship today with Eric Torkelson, UConn fullback, setting two school records.
New York City and the nation's other urban centers may benefit from a reawakening-and a rebirth-in the wake of the energy crisis and gasoline restrictions, Federal and local officials said today.
Since the country is probably beyond shock by this time, there can be no harm in telling the truth at last about the first Thanksgiving Day.

Corporations are becoming less charitable these days. Although corporate giving increased between 1970 and 1972, corporate profits increased more, and the percentage of pretax income given away decreased to 0.73 per cent from 0.82 per cent. The Conference Board surveyed 443 companies, which gave $323-million to charity, or one-third of all corporate donations.
Soviet authorities have issued a veiled warning that they may lift the Soviet citizenship of Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident atomic physicist, especially if he tries to go abroad.

JAN TROELL'S "The Emigrants" was a fine film with some nagging flaws: the characters seemed too simple for the epic scope of the drama, and the movie as a whole did not supply the emotional impact that it promised.
The 12-year-old son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy had his right leg amputated today in an operation for cancer.
STONY BROOK, L. I.Last Sunday evening, 150 people enjoyed a gastronomic restoration of the Revolutionary War period. The event, a Colonial dinner, opened the bicentennial celebrations on Long Island.

Governor Rockefeller yesterday announced the appointment of 35 prominent figures in government, industry and education as members of the national study commission he has founded at President Nixon's request to anticipate the problems of the country's third century.

Conservative Judaism, born 60 years ago to strike a balance between Orthodoxy and Reform, ended its five-day biennial congregational convention in Klamesha Lake, N. Y., last week still convinced that the "soundest course is to oonserve what is valuable while changing that which requires change."

CAIRO. Eternal Egypt murmurs amidst the present and the future on the road from Cairo to Qantara. We hasten, beneath a brilliant sky and eucalyptus trees, along the length of the Sweet Water Canal, a Nile tributary flowing toward that territory in the Sinai which Egypt's army has wrested from the Israelis. We see peasants in white robes
THE late Jacques Lipchitz was a sculptor whose career perfectly matched his opportunities. In 1909, when he arrived in Paris from his native Lithuania, he was 18.
The United States Social Security Administration is to make a spot check of beneficiaries

St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Susan Handal, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham S. Handal of New York, to Philip Ward Warner, son of Mrs. John M. Warner of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and the late Mr. Warner.

SHOW biz is show biz and almost anything's good for a shtick, but some things are still sacred. No television comic has yet done a boffo impersonation of Cesar Chavez slipping on a grape peel.

Morris Sarnoff, a retired insurance man and corporate executive, died yesterday at Golden Isles Hospital here at the age of 79. Mr. Sarnoff, who operated his own insurance business, had been associated for more than 20 years with Lane
THE great jazz dream of a permanent performing organization giving an annual season of concerts-a dream that has been drifting through the jazz World ever since jazz began invading concert halls 30

TRENTON - New Jersey was a pioneer last week in President Nixon's program to curb energy consumption by reducing highway speeds and, although compliance was generally good, the acceptance of fuel conservation as an automatic result of slower driving was far from unanimous.

Miss Maggie Harvey Moss, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy I. Moss of New Rochelle, N. Y., was married here yesterday afternoon to Paul Hayes Tucker, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Duane Tucker Jr. of Pelham, N. Y.

New York is immortal. It is eternal regeneration, a love affair with the new. No more so than in Lower Manhattan, where it all began. Dutch New York isn't even a memory. Georgian New York is suggested by a few crumbling houses and stubborn ghosts. Greek Revival New York struggles for survival. Victorian New York is fair game for the bulldozer.

THERE is an item I rather like in the thoroughly untrustworthy program notes that Peter Cook and Dudley Moore have provided for the new entertainment called "Good Evening." HAUPPAUGE, L. I.-The Suffolk County administration was ordered by the County Legislature last week to select specific sites as parking lots for car pools.

The leasehold for the 23story Look Building at 488 Madison Avenue between 51st and 52d Streets has been exchanged by Charles Benenson, the head of Benenson Properties, Inc., for a number of properties owned by John D. MacArthur.
Measles, brought to a once remote section of the Amazon Jungle by a new and controversial highway, is killing members of a primitive Indian tribe, a Brazilian newspaper reported this week.
The Nixon Administration's program to provide funds and other aid to minority businessmen was turned in 1972 into the vehicle by which the President's re-election effort sought nonwhite support.
When it comes to the future of Times Square, Alex M. Parker is not given to understatement.
