On the night of Aug. 15, 1963, Eddie Lee Mays, a 34-year-old convicted murderer from Manhattan, was put to death by electrocution at the New York State prison at Ossining. He was the 614th person to lose his life in the Sing Sing electric chair since 1891.
Venezuela's Betulio Gonzales retained his World Boxing Council flyweight title today by stopping Alberto (Costenito) Morales of Mexico at 1 minute 40 seconds of 11th round.
TOMS RIVER - Vocational students at Toms River High School are going into the building business.
TENAFLY - In the protracted battle over the use of New Jersey's diminishing land resources, conservationists and housing proponents have frequently been the chief antagonists.
Steve Siegel, the topseeded player, and unseeded Ed Faulkner reached the final of the New Jersey state men's indoor tennis championship tonight.

At least six persons were injured today in a series of bomb attacks against bars owned and frequented by Roman Catholics. The police blamed Protestant extremists seeking to prevent any relaxation of tension between Northern Ireland's two feuding religious communities.

SPRINGFIELD--The statue of a Minuteman in front of the old First Presbyterian Church on Morris Avenue is just one reminder for the 18,000 residents of this Union County community that their town traces back to the Revolutionary War.
What is described as a "broadly expanded fair-advertising program for 1974" has been announced by the New Jersey Automobile Dealers Association.
Commack South, Suffolk's AA-I champion, used a bit of deception to record a 7-0 up-. set of previously unbeaten Harborfields yesterday in the AA conference championship game at Central Islip.

NEWARK - City officials are delaying "for a couple of months more" their submission to the state of a $1-million report on Newark'sovertaxed potable water sources. The report, promised to the state last February, was to have been ready on Oct. 15.
Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said yesterday that "little good would be served by the impeachment of President Nixon."

To the Editor: Anent C. D. B. Bryan's review of my novel "Servants and Their Masters," I grieve that so practiced a writer of fiction should come so close to grasping its intentions and yet miss them.

IT'S going to be a long winter of discontent for the airlines. As it begins, they face the unenviable task of informing passengers that while they have endured delays, "bumpings" and other inconveniences in the past they haven't really seen anything yet.

The stock market took a beating last week in very active trading, although a rally on Friday managed to reduce the size of the earlier losses. The main depressant on prices throughout most of the week was the energy crunch. Fears that the shortage of oil and energy supplies could reduce business spending plans for 1974 as well as profits weakened prices.
Archie Griffin rushed for a record 246 yards and Bruce Elia scored four touchdowns today to give topranked Ohio State a 55-13 victory over. Iowa.
Steve Davis scored twice on goal-line dives and Joe Washington added two touchdowns on short runs to pace Oklahoma to a 48-20 victory over Kansas today.

In 1970, in his annual "State of the State" message, Governor Rockefeller announced a bold new plan to stem the "growing wave of crime which threatens the nation and destroys the quality of life for our citizens."

A proposal to demolish the historic Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul and Apostle, its school, convent and rectory to save from bankruptcy the beloved "Cathedral of the West Side," and the Mother Church of the Panlist Fathers, will be discussed at a public hearing in the church auditorium on Dec. 2.

Richard J. Vizzini, the president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, has conceded that he lied when he reported his membership had voted "overwhelmingly" in secret ballots to endorse a strike.

The father of a 31-year-old American filmmaker and writer killed in Chile during the September coup believes that the handling of his son's case by United States officials in Santiago was "either a cover-up or an incredible apathetic bit of stupidity."
Ken Hodge got a goal and three assists tonight as the Boston Bruins whipped the Atlanta Flames, 5-2, in a National Hockey League game.

Joan Singer stared hard at the RPFIAYB she pulled out of the small purple bag lying on the table. She did not even watch as her opponent placed DATA on the board. "It's called a quickie," he said loudly.

Joe Namath, taking over with five minutes to play after a seven-game absence, rallied the Jets within a foot of the tying touchdown yesterday in Cincinnati, but time ran out at the goal line and the Bengals won, 20-14.

The decision of the United States and six European countries to terminate the March 1968 two-tier gold agreement, which barred governments from dealing in the private gold market, ends an arrangement relevant to an earlier period but ripe, as Chairman Burns of the Federal Reserve Board said, for "decent burial."
Republican Governors marked off this afternoon the outer limits of their forthcoming debates on President Nixon and Watergate.

The State Chamber of Commerce urged that the New Jersey Legislature quickly give the state's moral support to bonds to finance the Hackensack Meadowlands sports complex. Meanwhile, State Senator James. H. Wallwork, Republican of Essex, called for a special session of the Legislature on Nov. 26 to determine what steps were needed to insure construction of the complex.

To the Editor: It has become popular to issue regular assaults on the character of the President. A sampling of public opinion would indicate that he is probably guilty of sundry crimes against humanity.

The Roman Catholic Chapel of Our Lady of Lourdes in Queens Village, Queens, was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Ellen Catherine Kelly, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis Q. Kelly of Queens Village, to Gerald Miles Tierney Jr., son of Mrs. Tierney of Arlington, Va., and the late Dr. Tiernev.

Ken Hodge got a goal and three assists tonight as the Boston Bruins whipped the Atlanta Flames, 5-2, in a National Hockey League game.
Evans J. Liolin, a prominent layman of the Albanian Orthodox Church in this country, died here Friday. He was 76 years old and lived at 80-23 190th Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens.
Almost a month after the cease-fire ordered by the United Nations Security Council, the authorities and citizens of Cairo are maintaining a determined psychological mobilization.
There's a 400 sweater warming a number of chic shoulders this season and the Rive Gauche boutiques in the city are weeping with frustration that they aren't able to get anymore.
Rabbi Nathan Perilman, the recently retired rabbi of Temple Emanu-El, said yesterday that he believed that the Prophet Daniel provided words for reflection in the time of Watergate.

The signing of the TransAlaskan Pipeline Bill by President Nixon Friday ended a major battle in the four-year effort by the oil industry to tap the large reserves of Alaska's North Slope, but some uncertainties remain to cloud the future of the $4.5-billion project.

Richard J. Vizzini, the president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, has conceded that he lied when he reported his membership had voted "overwhelmingly" in secret ballots to endorse a strike.

It wasn't a day for tennis, but they played the final of the New York City public parks doubles championship yesterday at Central Park. Retaining their title in an uphill battle were Joe Cerrato and Biligere Kripanidhi of Brooklyn, who defeated Vern Morgan and Brian Squires of Manhattan, 4-6, 6-7, 6-2, 6-1, 6-1.

Miss Alice Sara Prince, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon M. Prince was married here this morning to B Smith Hopkins 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Hopkins Jr., of Urbana, 111. Mayor Donn Snyder of Westfield performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

In his Florida press conference last night President Nixon conveyed the impression of a man frustrated in his efforts to publish the facts of Watergate. "I wanted the evidence out," he said, expressing his "very great disappointment" at the non-existence of two tapes.

Like other regulatory bodies throughout the country, the State Board of Public Utility Commissioners is taking longer these days to decide rate cases. Some major decisions have taken as long as two years to reach.

In Old First Church (Congregational) here this afternoon, Miss Deborah Ann BozBeckian of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. M. A. BozBeckian of Springfield, became the bride of Dr. Vassilios Raptopoulos of Washington. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Demetrios Raptopbulos of Thessalonica, Greece.
Arab oil exporters made a conciliatory gesture to Western Europe today in announcing that petroleum supplies would not be cut back further to most European Common Market states.

Voters in this northeastern Illinois village of 3,500 overwhelmingly approved yesterday a proposal for construction of a giant amusement park, hotel and industrial park complex on 600 acres to be annexed by the village.
A Newburgh city patrolman was killed late last night during an hour-long shootout with an unidentified gunman, the police said

While Americans debate the propriety of expensive improvements on President Nixon's private homes, the Soviet press is exposing officials in the Georgian Republic for diverting public funds to build themselves fancy hunting lodges and forest hideaways.

ROME -- The Vatican's new Collection of Modern Religious Art will be open to the public in the next few days. The 55-room extension to the Vatican museums was inaugurated by Pope Paul VI on June 23. It contains about 600 works by 250 artists, most of them living.

Mrs. Estelle Karon Scheinman, widow of. Eli Scheinman and former woman's and society editor of The Long-Islander, a Huntington weekly, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Morris Robert Keen, a Huntington urologist.

Two longtime archenemies from the South Bronx -- one a proud and powerful self-made Puerto Rican militant, the other a shrewd, ambitious, committed Roman Catholic priest -- will be sitting together in the new City Council.

A Protestant guerrilla group in Northern Ireland called a six-week Christmas truce today. The Ulster Volunteer Force said that any member breaking the truce would face "severe physical punishment or execution."

Mrs. Doris Guttman Schulman of Scarsdale, widow of Dr. N. Jerome Schulman, a gynecologist, was married here this morning to Benjamin Franklin Lee, a widower who is president of the B. L. I. Development Corporation of Nanuet.

American and German cancer researchers working in a Texas hospital have discovered an experimental blood test that, two pilot studies indicate, apparently distinguishes cigarette smokers whose genes make them prone to lung cancer from those resistant to developing the malignant tumor.

Milton Musicus, the city's Municipal Services Administrator and chairman of the Mayor's Emergency Energy Committee, said yesterday that the city did not face a fuel crisis for the next few weeks but that the situation "looks pretty bleak" in the near future.
The pieces finally fell into place for the New York Giants today in a 24-13 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals that ended the Giants' puzzling seven-game losing streak.

Tom Hoover a former player for the New York Knicks basketball team and now a City Hall trouble-shooter in the city school system, was being held in $100,000 bail yesterday in a New Jersey jail on charges involving 1,580 pounds of marijuana with an estimated street value of $1.8-million.

France presented new suggestions for a declaration of Atlantic alliance principles last week, mentioning a "just sharing" of alliance costs and the need to remove the sources of economic conflict among the allies.
The setting of utility rates should be brought back under the Federal Government's Phase 4 controls, New York City's Consumer Affairs Commissioner, Betty Furness, said yesterday.
Two quiet young Americans met violent death in the troubled aftermath of the military coup d'etat here two months ago, and the reason is still unclear.
Scrambling to get back on schedule today the Skylab 3 astronauts sorted out and stowed thousands of items they will need for their three months aboard the orbiting space station.

"I feel excited," said Lee Bayrd, after his victory. "It was very elating to play people of this caliber." Mr. Bayrd, a 39-year-old writer from Los Angeles, was the winner yesterday of the first world championship Monopoly tournament, held at Grossinger's Hotel and Country Club in Libertv. N. Y.
The blueprint for a Central Park riding academy was unveiled yesterday by Richard M. Clurman, Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administrator.
This is the time of year when the singers, musicians, dancers and stagehands of Italy's 10 state-subsidized opera houses walk out of rehearsals and in a strident chorus ask for more money.

American and German cancer researchers working in a Texas hospital have discovered an experimental blood test that, two pilot studies indicate, apparently distinguishes cigarette smokers whose genes make them prone to lung cancer from those resistant to developing the malignant tumor.

Greek demonstrators defied the martial law imposed Saturday and clashed with police in scattered fights throughout the Athens area. Policemen fired handguns into the air and used tear gas to disperse hostile crowds. A few times during the morning and again in early afternoon, army tanks moved into trouble spots, but did not fire their guns. [1:5.]
When the boss wants to know how much money he should pay a new worker, if he does not already know, he simply picks up the telephone and asks someone who makes it hi business to know.
The United States Equestrian Team won the International Championship in a runaway last night at the closing session of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

The first public disclosure by the Federal Government of Medicare fees charged by doctors shows that Manhattanbased physicians usually charge more--sometimes much more-for an identical service than other practitioners in the metropolitan area.
Miss Devin Frisch and Eric Joseph Feldman were married here yesterday afternoon in the St. Regis-Sheraton by Rabbi Jacob Polish.
The dominant but divided Gaullist party ended its biennial convention here today with a clear endorsement of Jacques Chaban-Delmas, the former Premier, as its next candidate for President of France.

Norman C. Lee, a retired stockbroker who in 1939 became the first regular passenger to fly around the world using scheduled commercial plane service, died Saturday night in the Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived at 24 East 82d Street.

Sir Gerald Nabarro, a maverick Conservative Member of Parliament, who was long an effective goad to Conservative and Labor Administrations alike, died today at his home in Worcestershire. His age was 60, and he suffered a cerebral hemorrhage last week.

Large amounts of new Soviet weapons have been put into service by the Syrian armed forces, which are offeringWestern suppliers cash in advance for quick delivery of radar and other air-defense equipment.
A Bronx man who went out to buy a Sunday newspaper and some ice cream for his wife was stabbed to death Saturday night by three youths who tried to rob him, the police reported yesterday.
Joe Namath, whose storybook career has been punctuated with miracle-like achievements, tried to pull off another improbable feat today, but the clock and the Cincinnati defense wouldn't let him.

The fate of the Grand National, the prestigious steeplechase race first run in 1837 at the Aintree Race Course near Liverpool, is expected to be announced tomorrow. WASHINGTON--Perhaps some of us who have been in the eye of the Watergate storm can be forgiven if we look for a silver lining-if we suggest that out of the public turmoil and personal agony, there has emerged an historic opportunity for long-overdue political reform.
Philip A. Vogelman, a leader in the silk industry and a philanthropist, died yesterday at his home, 784 Park Avenue. He was 80 years old.
Mira Richard, the Mother of the Aurobindo religious movement in India, died of a heart attack last night in the coastal town of Pondicherry. She was 95 years old.

State Controller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday that the Transit Authority was wasting $8-million a year through inefficient maintenance and manning of its buses and subway token booths. Mr. Levitt asserted in a report that the agency required almost 50 per cent more workers and maintenance hours to service its buses than the average used by five private lines in the city.

Senator Edward M. Kennedy's--year old son, Edward Jr., making a satisfactory recovery after his right leg was amputated above the knee, received thousands of telephone messages today from people offering support and prayers.
Four language scholars from China received a glimpse today of how American students at Seton Hall University here were taught to speak, read and write Chinese.

Celebrating their locally designated "Love Thy Neighborhood Day," an interracial group of 200 Upper East Side residents--who have battled against demolition and relocation in their community--joined yesterday in a "Mass for the City of New York."

Loren Murchison, 76 years old, seldom talks about the 1920 Olympics in Antwerp, but he thinks about those days a lot. Not about the first gold medal he won as a relay sprinter, but about the World War I transport the team sailed on, how the athletes attempted to organize a boycott and how they got tricked.
Tom Riley's firsthalf goal today gave Madison College of Harrisburg, Va., a 1-0 victory over Maryland and a berth in the National College Athletic Association Division I regional soccer playoffs.

Jewish communities around the world must raise $2.25-billion to relieve Israel during the coming year of the burden of caring for her sick, aged and handicapped, according to a United States Jewish leader.

It is a beautiful theater -a nice place to be, and an unusually effective machine for drama. The place is the Abbey Theater on East 13th Street, the new home this season for the always enterprising CSC Repertory.

When the 26th Amendment to the Constitution extended Federal voting privileges to 18year-old citizens two years ago, Police Chief Thomas Ryan thought that this southwestern New Mexico mining community should make a similar age change in its regulations on the employment of law enforcement officers.

The sharp disagreements between the United States and its NATO allies that emerged during the Mideast war are now forcing into the open some of the more fundamental differences that threaten the Atlantic partnership.

Rod Laver and John Newcombe powered Australia into the final round of the Davis Cup tennis competition against the United States by winning their singles matches today from Czechoslovakia and completing a 4-1 semifinal victory.

When the game ended in drama and controversy, with the New York Jets a foot away from the touchdown that would have averted a 20-14 loss to the Cincinnati Bengals today, Joe Namath crouched in despair, his hands to his helmet.
Former Premier David BenGurion, 87 years old, entered a hospital today suffering from what his doctor described as a cerebral hemorrhage, which paralyzed his right side.
Miss Brenda Nora Starling, a pediatric social worker at the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn, was married yesterday at noon to Solomon Becker of Forest Hills, Queens,

Mrs. Marguerite Spiridovitch, widow of Gen. Alexander Spiridovitch who was chief of the bodyguard of Czar Nicholas of Russia in World War I, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. Sh was 78 years old and lived at 34 East 61st Street.

Governor Rockefeller, arriving here today for a two-day Republican Governors Conference, planned to, enlist the support of his fellow Governors for his National Commission on Critical Choices for America.

In a direct challenge to Government regulations controlling the protection and management of wild, freeroaming horses and burros, the New Mexico Livestock Board has notified Federal authorities that it claims ownership of "all of these animals in this state under the stray laws of New Mexico."
Two Senators and one of the nations's top bankers, taking sharp issue with President Nixon, said today that gasoline rationing was essential.
After two weeks of heavy flows of new offerings in the tax-exempt and corporate-bond markets, the holiday-shortened week ahead represents something of a breather for underwriters and dealers.

The conservative coalition government of New South Wales, Australia's most populous state, badly defeated Prime Minister Gough Whitlam's Labor party in an election yesterday. The defeat was considered a significant pointer to the declining national popularity of the Whitlam administration, now almost a year old.
Women will be able to get credit more easily in at least two banking institutions in the state as a result of agreements announced last week.

CHAPPAQUA, N. Y.-"In this town the only job the kids are allowed to do is take out the garbage," Martin Weiss commented as he sampled a steak dinner cooked by four of his five sons and smiled. Son Number 5 was serving the drinks.

While the World Hockey Association and the owners of the New York Golden Blades are apparently bargaining over who will have to pay Madison Square Garden $8,000 by tomorrow, the Blades' players yesterday kept their part of the bargain, which is playing and, in this case, winning.
Demonstrators defying the martial law imposed yesterday clashed with the police in scattered fights throughout the Athens area today.

A proposal to demolish the historic Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, its school, convent and rectory to save the parish from bankruptcy, will be discussed at a public hearing in the church auditorium on Dec. 2.
Bob McAdoo staked the Braves to an early lead tonight and his 43-point performance sealed the victory as Buffalo defeated the Capital Bullets. 112-101.
Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame is due back at his desk in the Controllr's office at 9 A.M. today, aides said yesterday, with two main items confronting him after his postelection vacation.

A powerful mixed foursome took the lead going into the final session of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss team championship at the New York Hilton here last night.

New York women are different from other women, and there are among them women who belong only to New York. They are a type, really , and they burn with what is supposed to be a gem-like flame, and they add to the gayety of the city and to the sexual tension as well..

The United States Court of Appeals said last week that it was all right for a radio station to be sold and the new owners to switch, over listener protests, from classical to rock music if another station in the areas presented "substantially" similar classical music.
Bankers, it seems, do not keep bankers' hours any more. More and more banks in the New York area are opening early, closing late and unlocking their doors on Saturdays.

Three Dartmouth College students were killed early today when a single-engine plane they had borrowed from the campus flying club for a flight to Schenectady, N.Y., crashed into 3800-foot Mount Equinox.

STANFORD, Calif.--China's position as an emergent nuclear power has increasingly influenced the calculations of the superpowers. It is becoming a silent partner at the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks.

The Secretary of the Interior, Rogers C. B. Morton, announced today that 147 tracts covering 817,000 acres in the Gulf of Mexico off Mississippi, Alabama and Florida would be offered in an oil and gas lease sale next month.

Forecasts of a huge expansion of air travel into and out of New York--predictions that have been used by Metropolitan Transportation Authority consultants to justify the need for a fourth jetport--may never be realized, the Regional Plan Association said yesterday.

Demonstrators defying Greece's dayold martial law clashed today with the police in scattered fights throughout the Athens area. Policemen fired handguns into the air and used tear gas to disperse hostile crowds.
Important changes are taking place in the thinking of international financial officials about reform of the monetary system.

Some Pennsylvania car dealers who donate autos for high school driver education courses got a shock this year when they were told they were evading state sales taxes.

Through the quiet Sunday afternoon, the alarm bells and buzzers that become part of a fireman's life in Brownsville periodically emptied the modest firehouse on Watkins Street that is home for Ladder Company 120 and Engine Company 231.
Pope Paul VI, speaking with a tone of optimism he has not expressed in some time, said today that he had witnessed an upsurge of vitality in the Roman Catholic Church.
Thailand is fashioning a new constitution that would decentralize the government and set the stage for a broad social welfare program designed to narrow the gap between rich and poor.

All-women groups are not unknown in rock 'n-'roll, but they generally confine themselves to the usual lineup of guitars and drums. Isis, a seven-piece unit, steps out of that particular rut by employing a gusty front line of trumpet, trombone and tenor saxophone (doubling flute) that gives a definite soul-rock feeling tn the band.
President Nixon was jeered as well as cheered in conservative cen:ral Georgia today as he joined in a 90th birthday tribute to former Representative Carl M. Vinson.
The Israeli Cabinet today ordered a judicial inquiry into the country's military preparedness for the latest Middle Eastern war.
Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan revolutionary leader who is at odds with most of his fellow Arab leaders, arrived in Belgrade today for hurriedly arranged talks with President Tito.
An Ohio bank has filed two $4-million lawsuits accusing a Los Angeles bank and an accounting firm of helping U. S. Financial, Inc., record millions of dollars in fictitious profits.
Arab oil exporters made a conciliatory gesture to Western Europe today in announcing that petroleum supplies would not be cut back further to most European Common Market states.
"Eddie! Eddie! Eddie!" the crowd yelled in admiration as Ed Giacomin skated off the ice of Madison Square Garden last night, surrounded by the rest of the New York Rangers.
Nearly two million Italians, representing about 5 per cent of the electorate vote today and tomorrow in local and regional elections in scattered parts of the country.

Armand Hammer, the 75-yearold president of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, signed an agreement with Poland yesterday to help build a metalfinishing plant that would have a S10-million annual output.

An agreement between West Germany and Czechoslovakia that would pave the way for the establishment of diplomatic relations between them has been withdrawn by the Czechoslovaks, apparently because of pressure from East Germany, according to Communist and Western sources.

A second Soviet aircraft carrier is being built at Nikolayev on the Black Sea, and United States and British intelligence sources report that the Russiahs plan to construct carriers of another, larger class as part of their expanding naval program.

A controversy over Dr. Grant Cooper, the University of Arkansas history professor who said in September that he was a Communist and that he taught his classes from that viewpoint, has intensified, with a group of legislators stepping up efforts for his immediate dismissal.
Talking flames, laser-beam light shows and electric-car rides drew curious onlookers to, Princeton University today for the wind-up of the school's two-day Art and Technology Fair.

Looking fit and talking like a man in quest of black votes, Gov. George C. Wallace was given a standing ovation and the key to this famed Negro college town when he came here today to discuss industry, jobs and education with members of the Southern Conference of Black Mayors.

To no ones surprise, the cost estimate for a renovated Yankee Stadium is soaring out of sight-now about $50million, compared with Mayor Lindsay's original proposition of half that amount. With even more urgency than when the idea was first raised, it is appropriate to ask whether this ego-trip for city boosters is really necessary.

Gaylord Ravenal stepped out of here over the weekend, though that isn't how the obituaries identified him. They used his square name, Lloyd Mangrum. Ravenal was what his companions on the professional golf circuit called him because his rakish good looks and meticulously trimmed mustache gave him a debonair jauntiness that they associated with the riverboat gambler in Edna Ferber's "Show Boat."

An organization claiming responsibility for the slaying of a school superintendent apparently has rescinded its so-called "shoot on sight warrant" for other educators.

Frank Sinatra's highly touted "return" after a two-year retirement made a winning hour last night over the National Broadcasting Company.

Auburn and Missouri did not brighten the day for Sun Bowl officials Saturday as these teams were upset before accepting formal invistationss to meet in the postseason game at El Paso, Tex., on Dec. 29.

It wasn't a day for tennis, but they played the final of the New York City public parks doubles championship yesterday at Central Park. The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's program Friday night in Tully Hall--repeated late yesterday afternoon--proved typically refreshing.

After nearly four weeks in North Vietnam and sections of South Vietnam that are controlled by the Vietcong, two American antiwar activists said here yesterday that full-scale war would likely break out if a coalition Government was not formed in Saigon.
The Carrier Corporation said yesterday that its domestic air conditioning divisions were planning price increases ranging from 3 to 4 per cent on unitary equipment.
Big is beautiful in this season's jewelry. Not big in terms of Elizabeth Taylor's over-$1-million Cartier diamond, which weighs 60.42 carats.
President Nixon slapped or patted a man on the face Saturday night, it was disclosed today, stirring a new controversy between. the White House and some segments of the press.
When Miss Diane B. stepped into the yellow-striped sales tent at Belmont Park yesterday, even the bargain-hunters winced.

The Saudi Arabian Government wants a "substantial revision" of its participation agreement with the Arabian American Oil Company to bring its ownership in the concern to more than 51 per cent immediately, according to news reports here today.
Although he never had to address Swedish hockey players when he was a member of the Ontario Parliament, Red Kelly apparently has learned the protocol.
Britain escalated her attack on the national energy crisis today with a Government directive that deliveries of all petroleum products be reduced by 10 per cent immediately.

Faced with a shortage of priests and an uncertainty among the public of just what a priest does, the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has launched a 13-week campaign that will place advertisements in newspapers and magazines throughout the 10-county diocesan area.

With Australia gripped by feverish excitement over the prospects of regaining the Davis Cup, the United States chose a tennis team headed by Stan Smith and Tom Gorman yesterday to defend the cup in the final at Cleveland Nov. 30.

A convicted murderer who had been attending college classes in a special study-release program was being held today on suspicion of beating and robbing the wife of the chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority.
Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ward of Detroit began turning off the lights last week when they brushed their teeth or talked on the telephone at night, to save electricity.

A 36year-old former mental patient who killed his parents four years ago was arrested as he sought readmission to a state hospital here last night. He was accused of having stabbed his aunt and uncle to death in Pennsylvania earlier in the day.
Lee Thayer, whose 59th or so mystery book, "Dusty Death," published in 1965, was probably the first detective story written by a nonagenarian, died Sunday in Coronado, Calif. She was 99 years old.

A series of legal changes intended to ease the flow of information to the public-including the passage of a strong Federal shield law to protect reporters and the removal of all Government control over television and radio programing-was urged today by a panel of 58 lawyers, journalists, scholars and other specialists.
Two more persons along central Florida's Gulf Coast reported paralytic symptoms of shellfish poisoning today after eating clams believed to be contaminated with a red tide algae.

This year's Goncourt Prize was awarded today to Jacques Chessex, the Swiss writer, for his novel "L'Ogre." France's most coveted literary award thus went for only the second time to a foreigner and for the first time to a Swiss.

The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted in August to reduce the rate of growth of the monetary "aggregates" even more than was suggested by staff analysts, it was disclosed today. The disclosure came in the summary of the August Open Market Committee meeting, publishing three months after the meeting.

Abruptly the curtain fell with a leaden clank just as the hero seemed about to pull off a final theatrical show-stopper.

Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said last night that he had been "badgered" and "needled" by reporters into lying about the results of a strike referendum that preceded his union's five - and - a - half - hour strike on Election Day.

In most states, the fiscal crunch of the sixties has been surmounted, in part because school-age population has leveled off, and with it the cost of education. Nationally, attention has swung from the Cold War and Vietnam to domestic problems, so that once again governors are looked upon-and see themselves--as possible Presidents.

The Salute to Ted Agnew Committee, which held a fund-raising event for former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew last year, pleaded guilty today to four counts of violating Maryland election laws.

Copper futures contracts for December delivery set a record yesterday on the Commodity Exchange. The surge in price was a followthrough on the action in the London metal market, which opens earlier than here because of the time differential.
Arthur J. Morris, the banker and financier who created the Morris Plan, which made consummer credit available to working people, died yesterday at Phelps Memorial Hospital, North Tarrytown.

The American Medical Association voiced concern yesterday about the competency and immaturity of a growing number of young doctors as a result of accelerated medical training programs.

A Brooklyn woman was struck on the head with a stick and robbed of $35 by two men on a subway train yesterday afternoon, and about 20 other passengers in the car watched and did nothing as she screamed, bled, and finally got off to seek help.
In an unusual legal coincidence, two apparently conflicting suits were filed yesterday in State Supreme Court involving the collapsed Broadway Central Hotel.

Clarkstown's new censorship committee put the question squarely to its constituency last week: shall we go on? The answer was: yes and no.

The Jerusalem Post, an English-language paper, today attacked Israel's policy on war information and called for a reorganization of her information services. It said that a dangerous "credibility gap" had developed in the country during the war that began Oct. 6.
The Campeau Corporation, an Ottawa real estate development company, increased yesterday its offer for shares of Markborough Properties, Ltd., another Canadian company, from $16 to $18.50 a share.

Dennis Smith is a fireman. He is also the author of the best-seller "Report From Engine Company 82," a book about firemen. And he is a union member who reluctantly obeyed his union's call to strike.

Stock prices had their sharpest drop in more than 11 years yesterday amid growing fears by investors that the widening energy crisis could cause a recession.

Black student leaders at the Staten Island Community College said yesterday that they would boycott a seminar tonight featuring Dr. William B. Shockley, the physicist and Nobel laureate who argues that, because of genetic factors, blacks are generally inferior to whites.
Randolph Township, charged in a suit with having exclusionary zoning laws, has filed a motion in Superior Court here to have 31 other Morris County municipalities named as thirdparty defendants.
George S. Raymond, a lawyer credited with writing I many of New York State's industrial codes, died today in Ramapo General Hospital. He was 74 years old.
Gerald R. Ford was variously pictured today as little more than "a messenger from the White House" and as another potentially great Harry S. Truman.

Mrs. Frances Proskauer Cohen, widow of the lawyer Paul P. a Cohen and daughter of the late Joseph M. Proskauer, who was a former justice of the State Supreme Court and chairman of the Crime Commission, died today at her home here. She was 68 years old.

The Pentagon said today that the United States had canceled the six-week-old military alert for the 60 ships of the Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean. Now that tensions in the Middle East have eased, many of the ships will be stopping at Mediterranean ports.

If there ever was any doubt about the kind of electricity Joe Namath can generate on the football field, consider this: in just 4 minutes and 40 seconds, he ignited more excitement and more controversy than the Jets had experienced in the first 595 minutes and 20 seconds of this season.

Thanksgiving monday auto travelers who save their gasoline by cruising at 50 miles an hour stand a better chance of surviving an accident than more speed-minded companions on the highways, a spokesman for the National afety Council said today.

South Vietnam said today that an American Quaker volunteer was aboard an Air Vietnam DC-3 with 23 people aboard that has been missing since Saturday on a flight from Saigon to the northern city of Quang Ngai.

Former Gov. Richard J. Hughes was confirmed by the State Senate yesterday as Chief Justice of the State Supreme Court. Mr. Hughes, who served as Governor from 1961 to 1969, was nominated to the $47,500-a-year post by Governor Cahill to succeed Pierre Garven, who died last month.
Two of the country's strongest mixed partnerships scored a striking victory in the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team Championship at the New York Hilton Hotel here during the weekend.

Msgr. Vincent O. Genova, pastor of Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn for 38 years, died yesterday of a heart attack at Lefferts General Hospital,Brooklyn. His age was 68.
Auto industry executives asked the Cost of Living Council today for a new round of price increases to help soften the impact of rising costs.
A 17-year-old girl and four male members of a gang known as the Savage Skulls were indicted yesterday in the kidnapping and rape of two teenaged sisters in the Bronx last week.

After a delayed opening, copper futures contracts for December delivery again soared the daily permissible limit of 3 cents a pound, setting another record price. It closed at the new high of $1.05 85/100 a pound, up from $1.02 85/100, on the Commoditv Exchanee.
A leading economic forecasting group estimated today that the energy shortage would cut only about 1 per cent from the total output of the American economy next year.

In the face of a refusal by members of the Teamsters Union to cross picket lines, the strike-bound Museum of Modern Art announced yesterday that it was postponing indefinitely the highly acclaimed Marcel Duchamp Retrospective, scheduled to open Dec. 5.

President Nixon's murky explanations of Watergate are models of candor and clarity by contrast with the televised self-defense offered by the head of the Uniformed Firefighters Association in presenting his reasons for falsely reporting the results of the union's strike vote.
Col. Muammar el-Qadlafi, the Libyan revolutionary ??eader, today depicted a virtual alliance between his country, which has great oil wealth, and Marxist Yugoslavia.
The Senate Finance Committee today approved a House-passed bill fixing a new $475.7-billion national debt limit through June 30, 1974.

Under the cold pallor of a November moon, eight tall ships awaited dawn in the snug, keyhole-shaped harbor, their jutting masts and angled rigging creaking softly, casting long, bobbing shadows on the low skyline of docks and warehouses.
When the 700 people expected to turn out for the Mount Carmel Guild's annual luncheon at the Robert Treat Hotel today turned out to be 900, nobody was much surprised.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame announced a major reorganization of the Mayor's office yesterday, including the elimination of 50 jobs on the Mayor's executive staff and the setting up of a more powerful Bureau of the Budget and three positions of Deputy Mayor with new responsibilities.
Mayor Lindsay's energy chief charged yesterday that a large Bronx oil company had used "double talk" when it said it would run out of fuel "in a few days."

The United States Postal Service has decided that there was no basis to complaints by a Manhattan businessman that mail carriers harassed him and scrawled ethnic epithets across his letters after he told of poor mail service in an article last Feb. 18 in The New York rimes.
John Scali, United States representative to the United Nations, underwent open heart surgery today at the Arizona Heart Institute.

After an 18-day visit that afforded rare access to Soviet political circles, a delegation of young American political leaders has concluded that the Soviet Union grooms its future political leadership as carefully as any large American corporation.
Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's political position has been substantially strengthened by defections at the state level among her principal opponents.

PARIS--Who said the french were no more playing a major role in international politics? It is they who contributed the most widely used term of the moment-and thus, the concept: detente. Detente was the first term of the trilogy used by de Gaulle as of 1963 to sum up his policy towards the East: "Detente-entente-cooperation."

H. I. Romnes, retired board chairman and chief executive officer of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company, died yesterday at Sarasota Memorial Hospital. He was 66 years old.

The Senate Finance Committee gave final approval today to a bill increasing Social Security benefits in two steps over the next seven months. A 7 per cent increase would he effective on enactment of the legislation and a 4 per cent increase next June.

GIDEON WELLES: Lincoln's Secretary of the Navy. By John Niven. 676 pages. Illustrated. Oxford University Press. $17.50. Among the thousands of books written about the Civil War and its principal and even minor participants, oddly only one up to now has been devoted to Gideon Welles, and that one, issued 30 years ago,

The cutback of Arab oil supplies, now running into its second month, is affecting the economies of European nations, and fears that it could trigger a recession next year are sending the stock markets of the Continent down about as sharply as in Wall Street.

Mrs. Ann Swinburne Ditchburn Munroe, a former comic opera star and for many years a director of G. Schirmer, Inc., died Saturday in Doctors Hospital. The widow of Charles A. Munroe, a financier, she was 87 years old and lived at Munroe House in Nassau, the Bahamas.
Asking a composer to talk about his music is not necessarily a guarantee of enlightenment--the old one about asking the centipede to describe how it walks is often much to the point.
Two Arab oil ministers will begin a tour of Western Europe, the United States and Japan next week to explain why the Arab oil embargo was imposed and how it may be lifted.

First came the announcement last week by Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that the United States and six European nations had agreed to end the two-tier gold system, which had prevented governments from buying or selling gold on the free market since 1968.

A number of Republican county chairmen, who hope to force a change in leadership of the New Jersey Republican party following heavy losses in the Nov. 6 election, met today to discuss rebuilding "along moderate lines."
A University of Pennsylvania anesthesiologist investigating the possible medical uses of marijuana has tentatively concluded that the drug is unsuited for a major role as a surgical anesthesia.
Gen. Aleksandr N. Komarovsky, the Soviet Union's military construction chief, died Monday in Moscow, the press agency Tass announced. He was 67 years old.
While large-scale fighting is spreading in other parts of the country, Communist units appear to be stepping up a program of selective violence in the Mekong Delta.

Bache Co., Inc., the nation's largest securities house, after Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., operated in the black in the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 after six months of deficit operations.
The Soviet Union has taken the firm position in private talks with he West that the Palestinians must be represented at any diddle East peace conference.
The Texas Railroad Commission said today it would continue virtually all Texas oil wells at 100 per cent production through December.

Arthur Ashe, the black American playing for the first time in this apartheid country scored a fifth-round victory today in the $100,000 South African open tennis tournament. He beat Sherwood Stewart of Baytown, Tex., 6-1, 6-7, 6-4.
The Government took a considerably more relaxed attitude today toward the bombing of the presidential palace than it did last March, when a similar incident occurred.

Steamship operating between the United States East and Gulf coast and Latin America will introduce special freight surcharges next month to offset the higher cost of fuel oil the ships use, it was announced yesterday.

Because the average guy is familiar with a sports personality and respects his (or her) talent doesn't mean he likes him (or her) or would trust his (or her) endorsement of a product, an almost completed national survey pointedly shows.

The Senate, in a unanimous-consent action, confirmed 38 executive appointments today that had been blocked in some cases for over a fortnight by disagreement over the nomination of Helmut Sonnenfeldt as Under Secretary of Treasury.

Chet Walker scored 6 of his game-high 30 points in the final two minutes tonight to lead Chicago to a 106-101 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers. It was The Bulls' 14th victory in the last 16 contests.
The Netherlands, unler an Arab oil embargo, forally told her partners in Europe today that she might have to restrict exports of natural gas to them unless oil moved freely within the Common Market.

A player who makes 12 tricks when he had only contracted for game often suffers from a guilt complex. Sometimes the slam was a good proposition and should have been reached, but just as often the slam was a lucky one that required good breaks or a helpful lead.
Jack Gordon, citing a case of nerves, stepped down today as coach of the Minnesota North Stars of the National Hockey League and was replaced by Parker MacDonald.

The military-backed Government has put down last week's student rebellion with tanks, mass arrests and courts-martial, but many Greeks predict that a radical youth movement is here to stay as a political force.

Leon Fokine, former ballet dancer and teacher, died Monday at his home, 181 Claremont Avenue. His age was 68. Mr. Fokine, the nephew of the late Michel Fokine, who was known as the "father of modern ballet," was a teacher in his later years at the Harkness School of Ballet here and accompanied the Harkness Ballet Company on its European tours. He retired in 1967.

Surgeons at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center here said yesterday that they were "very encouraged" by progress made in developing an experimental technique of giving selected patients an auxiliary liver.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame announced a major reorganization of the Mayor's office yesterday, including the elimination of 50 jobs on the Mayor's executive staff and the setting up of a more powerful Bureau of the Budget and three positions of Deputy Mayor with new responsibilities.

Nate Thurmond blocked a shot by Oscar Robertson with 35 seconds to play tonight, then sank a driving layup with 12 seconds remaining to preserve a 108105 triumph for the Golden State Warriors over the Milwaukee Bucks.
Eighty clinics are treating more than 1,300 out-patients a day at Bellevue Hospital's new glass-and-concrete skyscraper a little more than a week after its opening.

The weeks of waiting ana wondering ended for the New York Golden Blades' players and their-families yesterday when the World Hockey Association plucked the team out of Madison Square Garden and moved it to the more rustic, and less expensive, Cherry Hill Arena in New Jersey.

If the unemployment statistics are showing a sharp rise, football may be the reason. Several coaches lost their jobs yesterday, other departures seemed imminent, a few players quit and one coach neared retirement.

Eight leading American economists-including all four American Nobel laureates in economics-urged the American Government today to resist what they called "oil blackmail" in setting Middle East policy.
Television studio stagehands ended their three-week strike here against the three major networks today, accepting a contract providing for a 42 per cent pay raise over four years.
Edward G. Gibson, Skylab 3 astronaut-scientist, said today that lack of gravity in the eight-room space vehicle had disoriented the crew and even made tying shoelaces a chore.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation headed the list of the Defense Department's prime contractors for the fifth straight year in the 1973 fiscal year, ended last June, the Pentagon announced today.

Fifteen 25-pound turkeys--home-cooked in Lower East Side kitchens accustomed to kosher, "soul" and Puerto Rican cuisines-were served last night at the annual pre-Thanksgiving dinner at the Henry Street Settlement-Urban Life Center.
Amtrak has raised rail fares between Boston and New York to $11 from $9.90 and has also increased fares between other stops along the Boston-to-Washington corridor, officials said today.

Thanksgiving Day will be celebrated as customary tomorrow with family turkey dinners at home, special meals for inmates of government institutions, the needy and homeless, holiday exhibitions at museums and Macy's anuual balloon parade down Broadway. Banks, libraries, stock exchanges, department stores, post offices, public schools and other public buildings will be closed. Sunday parking rules will be in effect and alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules will be suspended.

With a sloppy performance that moved Coach Al Arbour to say, "We've got to start from scratch," the Islanders dropped their fourth straight game tonight, a 4-2 loss to the rejuvenated Toronto Maple Leafs.

The Soviet note that led to a precautionary alert of United States forces around the world on the night of Oct. 24 carried an implied threat rather than an actual threat of the dispatch of Soviet troops to the Suez war zone.

The Senate Rules Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of Gerald R. Ford as Vice President of the United States. The committee's action came nearly six weeks after the resignation of Vice President Spiro T. Agnew and the nomination of Mr. Ford as his successor.

A group of about 13 black and Hispanic students ended a 28hour sit-in at the Ramapo State College recreation building today after agreeing to Federal mediation of their demands, which included more financial aid and the dismissal of 10 faculty members they called "racist."

In 1969 Coach Bob Blackman took an undefeated Dartmouth team into Palmer Stadium to play Princeton in the season finale. The Tigers won, 35-7, and grabbed a share of the Ivy League championship with Dartmouth and Yale.

A 6-year-old boy was fatally attacked, apparently by two German shepherds, in a vacant lot here last night, the police reported today. The two dogs, who were found by the body, lunged at police officers and were shot to death.

Governor Rockefeller says he will announce whether he will seek re-election before the Jan. 9 opening of the Legislature so that the legislators will not be diverted by "confusion" over his intentions.
James A. Pattisonowner of the Vancouver Blaiers of the World Hockey Association, announced today that the club had been sold to Neonex International, Ltd.

Mrs. Isabel Avila Maurer, a former State Department information officer and wife of Leonard Maurer, a Washington printer and printmaker, died Friday in Washington Hospital Center. She was 72 years old.

The South Vietnamese Government raised gasoline prices about 32 cents a gallon today in an attempt to cut civilian energy consumption by 25 per cent within two months.

Eastern Freight Ways, Inc., announced yesterday that the A-P-A Truck Leasing Corporation had terminated its recently announced agreement to purchase Eastern's approximately 46 per cent stock interest in Associated Transport.
The Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity said today that the time had come for Arab nations to use oil sanctions against the white-dominated minority governments in southern Africa.
Czechoslovak players were in the spotlight today in the second round of the South Australian tennis championships. Jan Kodes, top-seeded, defeated Ties Roerke of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2;

An agreement has been reached, acceptable to North and South Korea, to avoid a vote for now on two rival resolutions dealing with the status of the United Nations military command in South Korea, diplomatic sources said today.
The Phillips Petroleum Company expects to spend 'over $400-million" on next year's capital expenditures, Robert Sears, vice president, told St. Louis security analysts yesterday.
Valeri Postoianov of the Soviet Union beat a countryman, Alexandr Kediarov, by a point today to win the gold medal in the running boar mixed runs event at the world moving target championships.
Four airlines that operate between London and the United States agreed yesterday to sizable cuts in service to help cope with the fuel shortage.
The Village Board of Gurnee unanimously approved last night the annexation of 600 acres of farmland that is scheduled to become a $40-million amusement park owned by the Marriott Corporation.
The New York Pro Musica Antiqua began its 20th-anniversary New York season Monday night with a concert in Tully Hall devoted to Elizabethan music on the theme of love.

The International Business Machines Corporation filed an appeal today of the $259.5-million damages a Federal judge ordered the company to pay the Telex Corporation for alleged monopolistic practices.

The Italian magistrate investigating the origins of a Greek vase sold to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for $1-million unofficially confirmed reports yesterday that an Italian high court had annulled an arrest warrant against the seller, Robert E. Hecht Jr.

Two rafts reached Australia yesterday after a 177-day voyage of more than 8,000 miles from Guayaquil, Ecuador. But a third raft in the adventure was abandoned by its crew when it began to break up in heavy seas about 45 miles off the New South Wales coast this morning.

The New York Stock Exchange, buffeted by a drop in volume, barely stayed in the black during the third quarter of 1973, Big Board figures disclosed yesterday. Net revenues-the exchange, a nonprofit organization, does not call it profit - stood at $161,300 for the quarter, down sharply from $3.9-million a year earlier. Gross revenues slipped to $22.3-million from $23.3-inillion in the year-earlier period.

Robert D. Bower, a vice president of the Union Carbide Corporation, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 51 years old and lived at 3 Huguenot Drive.

To the Editor: In a recent editorial you expressed support for fusion research as an alternate nuclear power development to the fast-breeder reactor because it is cheap, safe and nonpolluting. Your arguments for fusion power are naive and only serve to misinform a public already confused by the swirling controversy about the need to develop nuclear power in the United States.

The Consumer Price Index in the metropolitan area rose six-tenths of 1 per cent in October, primarily because of increases in the costs of housing and private transportation, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday.

George M. Feigin, a lawyer and past president of the Association of Private Camps, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived at 70-26 Fleet Street, Forest Hills, Queens.

After years of rising energy consumption, the major utilities in the metropolitan area are seeing the first tentative signs that the public may be responding to urgent requests to cut back the use of gas and electricity.

Lawyers for Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive United States financier, argued yesterday that politics and his $200,000 payment to President Nixon's re-election campaign were behind United States attempts to extradite Mr. Vesco on fraud charges.

However the public may remember John Fitzgerald Kennedy 10 years after his assassination, the scholars who will eventually fix his place in history are at loggerheads.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's decision to raise its dividend, announced yesterday, presented a ray of hope in a devastated stock market.

Greg Stremmel of Gateway took individual honors and St. Joseph's of Metuchen won the team title in the second annual New Jersey interscholastic all-group crosscountry championships at Bridgewater - Raritan. West High School.
Seven mail handlers have been accused of stealing $86,000 in travelers checks from a mail bag and going on a spending spree.
Two former principals of Charles Plohn Co., a brokerage firm, were acquitted Tuesday at 7 P.M. of having illegally pledged customers' securities for bank loans.

" I still have a sour taste in my mouth from what happened in Munich-the killings and the whole Olympic structure," Steve Prefontaine said yesterday after completing his college track eligibility at Oregon. The distance runner said he was far from ready to join the pros.

Miss Pamela Ann Stonesifer, daughter of Richard J. Stonesifer, president of Monmouth College in West Long. Branch, and Carl W. Hurley were married here this afternoon by the Rev. G. P. Mellick Belshaw at St. George's By The River Episcopal Church.

A Federal bankruptcy referee has scheduled a hearing Nov. 29 in Federal District Court here on a petition by D. H. Overmyer, Inc., an interstate warehouse and real-estate company, for an arrangement with creditors.

Some Thanksgiving that was. Mashed potatoes missing, gravy boat empty. His daughter carved the turkey after her husband had cooked it. Poor grandfather. Instead of a proper New England Thanksgiving, he got his fill of feminism.

The White House disclosed in court today that a portion of another Watergate conversation--this one between President Nixon and H. R. Haldeman three days after the Watergate burglary -- had not been recorded.

On a freshly painted black pedestal, beneath a single spotlight alone in an all-black room, the sacred statue Afo-A-Kom went on display for the general public today for the first time in its 100-year history.

John Riggins, who suffered a minor shoulder separation last Sunday, feels he'll be ready to play against Atlanta. So does John Ebersole (bad back), who could lose his middle linebacking job to Al Atkinson, returning after a seven-game absence with a pulled thigh muscle....

The Senate Judiciary Committee sent to the Senate floor today without recommendation two bills calling for the appointment of a special Watergate prosecutor. One bill provides for court appointment and the other for selection by the Attorney General.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame made the first two appointments of his new administration yesterday, and at the same time appeared to be drifting into a dispute with prominent blacks who supported him during his campaign.

The wife of Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, said today that secret-police interrogators had called her mentally ill and had threatened her with arrest and reprisals against her children during three Interrogation sessions over the last week.

Foreign Minister Michel Jobert called today for Western Europe to build up its own defenses against new danger of tactical nuclear and conventional attack, now that the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed to prevent nuclear war between themselves.

The Civil Aeronautics Board approved yesterday a 5 per cent increase in all domestic airline fares, effective Dec. 1. The airlines asked for the increase some months ago to compensate, they said, for a leveling off in the growth of passenger traffic and for increases in operating costs.
Banks, libraries, stock exchanges, department stores, post offices, public schools and other public buildings will be closed. There will be no regular mail deliveries.

New Yorkers began leaving the city by thousands yesterday for the Thanksgiving holiday weekend, and a great many appeared to be depending more on public transportation than in the past, perhaps because of the fuel shortage.
Harlem Prep, a nationally known school aimed at preparing disadvantaged blacks for college educations, is expected to be transferred to the jurisdiction of the city school system.

After their experience of the past quarter-century, New Yorkers will receive with appropriate skepticism the hopes for retaining the 35-cent transit fare that were voiced by Mayor-elect Beame and Governor Rockefeller following their initial meeting on the transit crisis this week.

A former oil company official who had been expected to tell Watergate investigators about political contributions by the petroleum industry has invoked the Fifth Amendment's protection against possible self-incrimination rather than testify.

A report on current labor negotiations in the arts. New York City Ballet Dancers struck 10 days ago over 14-week work guarantee in event of strike by musicians' union, currently in negotiations with management.
Bob Cousy, coach of the National Basketball Association Kansas City-Omaha Kings since 1969, said tonight he planned to submit his resignation, and hoped that it would be accepted immediately.

The nation's major securities and commodities markets will be closed today in observance of the Thanksgiving holiday. Banks, business and Government. offices will also be closed. Canadian and European markets will be open.
One man was killed in a twoalarm fire that burned out a two-story building housing a synagogue and yeshiva in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon.
The city's Health Services Administration has announced the names of 35 more restaurants and food stores that have violated the health code.
Randy Gallagher and his wife soon will embark on what they hope will be a long tour of the United States, financed by taking along a van full of pets.
When James Alfred Cavanaugh returned last night to the eight-room, shingled house in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn that has been his home since 1949, a double celebration was awaiting him.

The chief of the Greek armed forces outlawed and disbanded 28 student organizations today in the latest move to discourage a revival of the Greek student revolt.
The Rangers conducted a relaxed, easy-going hockey school for the California Golden Seals last night at Madison Square Garden, beating them, 3-0, without breathing very hard.

Louisiana officials and oil companies seeking to build an offshore "superport" are going ahead with their plans, even expanding them, despite the cutoff of Mideast oil to the United States.

The District Attorney's office and the police announced today a combined investigation into alleged payoffs to the police by Roman Catholic clergymen to ignore illegal gambling activities at certain churches.

President Nixon's popularity apparently is reviving in the South. The resurgence of his standing in this region, which has steadily been the source of his greatest strength, began even before his Southern tour last weekend.

Brendan T. Byrne, New Jersey's Governor-elect, outspent his Republican rival, Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., by almost 2 to 1 in the gubernatorial race that was decided in the Nov. 6 election.
