Former Vice President Spiro T. Agnew has been hired as a consultant for J. W. Industries, a newly-formed international trading concern, Frank Jameson, the company's co-founder said today.

Howard J. Samuels, a Democratic gubernatorial contender, charged yesterday that a shift in the primary from June to September would increase the cost of campaigning and give an "unfair advantage" to the incumbent Rockefeller administration.
The Nixon Administration was ordered by a Federal district judge here today to free from impoundment $380-million for the nation's grade and high schools.

Amid the final bustle of the football season, basketball has begun in the high schools. Most of the Public Schools Athletic League members got their seasons under way last week with some interdivision contests. League play begins the first week of December.
Harding L. Lawrence, chairman and chief executive officer of Braniff Airways, Inc., was among corporate insiders who were major sellers of their companies' stocks last month.
A Cook County coroner's jury ruled today that the death of Mrs. E. Howard Hunt Jr. and 44 other persons in a plane crash near Midway Airport last December was accidental.

Chief Federal Judge John J. Sirica announced today the names of a six-man "advisory panel of technical experts" selected by the Watergate prosecution force and the White House to "study the authenticity and integrity of the tapes that the White House has furnished to the court."
Misconceptions about the need for regularity of bowel habits are widespread, and there are hazards associated with dependence on some laxatives, according to a leading medical publication.

Allan Sherman, the rotund entertainer whose comical lyrics, set to well-known tunes, elevated him to swift international celebrity 11 years ago, died last night while entertaining friends at his home here. He was 48 years old.

A new Gallup survey indicates that a majority of the public supports a proposal that would require young men to give a year of national service in the military forces or such nonmilitary agencies as VISTA or the Peace Corps.
The Lambs, the theatrical club marking its centennial next year, will celebrate with a potpourri of scenes, sketches and songs from. major Broadway shows of the past.

Nicholas Ferraro, the recently elected District Attorney of Queens, announced yesterday that he had set up a panel to screen all candidates for the position of assistant district attorney, in an effort to restore public confidence to the office.
The Aluminum Company of America said yesterday that it was curtailing production of its Alumiframe residential construction system because of the tight metal situation.
Federal District Court Judge John Feikens declined yesterday to dismiss price-fixing conspiracy charges against the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company.
I was at the University of Chicago Law School, attending a conference. A student came into the room and made an announcement: There had been shooting in Dallas.
John Scali, United States representative to the United Nations, was reported making a good recovery today after undergoing open-heart surgery yesterday.
Improved income tax forms to make filing easier and faster have been announced by Internal Revenue Commissioner Donald C. Alexander.

The New York Court of Appeals granted permission today to the horse trainer, Howard (Buddy) Jacobson to sue the New York Racing Association for denying him stall space at major thorough. bred tracks in the state.
Russel Means, a leader of the American Indian movement, today threatened further Indian violence unless the Government resolved Indian treaty disputes quickly.

Beginning Monday afternoon, New Englanders will have to get by on a voltage reduction of 5 per cent for four hours a day. The cutback, the first fuelsaving measure of its kind in the country, was announced yesterday by Gov. Thomas J.
International oil companies have notified France that they will be forced next month to cut their deliveries here by 10 to 15 per cent because of the worldwide petroleum shortage.

Gerald R. Ford acknowledged today that the Justice Department provided him with "some leads" that he used three years ago in preparing his request for an inquiry into possible impeachment of Associate Justice William O. Douglas.
Johnny Majors has turned the University of Pittsburgh football team into a winner so quickly that opponents are restless and suspicious.

The president of New York University, Dr. James M. Hester, said yesterday that he was temporarily suspending efforts to evict three elderly women tenants of the Brittany Hotel, a university-owned student dormitory. Dr. Hester said the school was investigating the situation anew to detelrmine whether there might be a feasible way to enable the three to stay.

Joseph M. Cahill, chief of the special-projects division in the information division of the United States Military Academy, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in the West Point Army Hospital. He was 55 years old.

Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 and publishers of The Daily News, The New York Times and The New York Post have reached agreement on a new two-year contract, William J. Kennedy Jr., president of the local, announced yesterday.

After a decade of controversy and hundreds of millions of dollars of expense, Governor Rockefeller dedicated his grand pet project, the South Mall, as frigid winds whipped through the vast marbled tract today.

Commissioner Mike Storen upheld Tuesday a protest by the San Antonio Spurs, marking the first time in the seven-year history of the American Basketball Association that a decision has been made to replay any portion of a game. Storen ruled that the final 30 seconds of a game between the Spurs and the Indiana Pacers, played Nov. 14, be replayed.

The United Methodists' New York Conference has lost more than half of a $7-million investment fund used chiefly for pension payments, because of what are described as improper high-risk loans by the corporate treasurer.

Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, denied today that his union had made surreptitious donations to President Nixon's 1972 campaign and said that his predecessor, James R. Hoffa, was a "damn liar" if he said otherwise.

The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has awarded the first construction contract for the Alfred E. Driscoll Expressway despite challenges from environmental and civic groups. The authority awarded a $2.3-million contract to Robert P. Winzinger, Inc., of Hainesport for 2.3 miles of the road through Jackson Township, Dover and Lakewood in Ocean County.
The Massachusetts Supreme Judicial Court has upheld a lower court order that compels a Wall Street Journal reporter to disclose her news sources in connection with a libel suit.
The White House said today that President Nixon had no plans to release his 1970 and 1971 personal income tax returns in connection with his efforts to clear up Watergaterelated matters.
The stock market finally mastered a rally yesterday on Thanksgiving Eve, after having plunged earlier this week in its sharpest two-day break since October, 1929.

Since the Middle East war erupted six weeks ago, the stock market has taken one of its worst plunges since the Depression. Although the market rallied yesterday in turbulent trading, the Dow-Jones industrial average has fallen by over 125 points-13 per cent-since the weekend of Oct. 5, when Egypt and Syria launched their attack on Israel.
Miss Patti Robin Brody, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Brody of Scotch Plains, was married here this evening to Daniel Kenneth Lehrhoff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Lehrhoff of Short Hills.
A South Vietnamese division commander said today that the Saigon Government's forces would need American air support if the Communists staged a major offensive in the next few months.
Every four-year state-supported college in Virginia stands accused today of conspiring to deny equal rights to women employes, according to a suit filed by three former professors.
Patricia Montero, a young Mexican pianist with fleet fingers but no consistently satisfying idea of how to put them to use, gave a recital Tuesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
The new limitations on copper trading for December contracts ended yesterday the recent sharp rise in price on the Commodity Exchange here.
Maurice F. Strong, the executive director of the United Nations Environment Program declared today that the energy shortage required the development of a new "lowenergy life-style."

President Juan D. Per6n was placed under medical care today for what doctors described as a bronchial condition. But reliable sources said that the 78-year-old leader had suffered a light heart attack.
The visit here by Libya's leader, Col. Muammar elQaddafi, produced an agreement today providing crude oil for Yugoslavia, tankers for Libya and joint economic ventures.
The New Jersey Superior Court refused today to continue a tradition of releasing five reputed Mafia figures from jail so they could spend Thanksgiving with their families.

Milk prices will rise by 6 cents a gallon to a minimum of $1.30 on Dec. 1. The State Agriculture Department said dwindling supplies had caused the increase and warned of "severe" shortages if the higher price did not reduce the demand for milk.

In the evening during the autumn festival the palace shimmered-with thousands of tiny lights and the streets were crammed with soldiers and sword dancers and flower-bedecked elephants. The Maharaja, with diamonds in his ears, sat on his gold and emerald peacock throne to welcome the princes and nabobs of India.

The shot that claimed the life of John F. Kennedy shortly after noon in Dallas ten years ago today will be remembered for more than the murder of a charismatic and promising young President; it marked the beginning of the end of an era filled with the ebullient optimism and confidence identified throughout the world with the spirit of America.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today that his family did not want him to. run for President, but that did not necessarily mean he would not seek the nomination in 1976.

With very rare exceptions, men who have been convicted of a crime will no longer be denied in the pages of The New York Times that small, sometimes insignificant, usually taken-for-granted honorific -"Mr."
The Food and Drug Administration said today the Hormel Company of Austin, Minn., was recalling products ranging from chicken chow mein to salisbury steak because they may contain tainted mushrooms.

The police said today that the driver of an overcrowded bus speeding over twisting mountain roads was drunken and was to blame for the deaths of 15 persons, most of them children, when the vehicle plunged into a 150-foot ravine and split in half.

Secretary of State Kissinger asserted today that the United States would not alter its Middle East policies because of the Arab oil embargo and warned that countermeasures might have to be considered if the embargo continued "unreasonably and indefinitely."

Beginners have a tendency to lead unsupported aces and then look round for something else to do. They soon learn to save their aces in the hope of using them more effectively to capture the opponents' kings and queens.
A Presidential spokesman denied today that anyone at the White House was involved in reading a report that former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson had a drinking problem.
Connecticuts attorney General, Robert K. Killian, yesterday rejected three sections of the proposed state regulations governing abortion and sent them back to the State Public Health Council.

Secretary of State Kissinger asserted today that the United States would not alter its Middle East policies because of the Arab oil embargo and warned that countermeasures might have to be considered if the embargo continued "unreasonably and indefinitely."
Reforms reportedly under way in the Roman Catholic Church are to include an overhaul of the Vatican legal structure.
Marie - Frangoise Bucquet, the French pianist who is giving four Tully Hall recitals devoted to contemporary music, presented her second program Tuesday night, "The New Piano in Europe."

Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders today endorsed the concept of a state subsidy to help communities yams, hold down transit fares, but said they would await congressional action on aid to mass transit before making any moves.
Because of increased costs, the armed services have cut back every serviceman's serving of turkey this Thanksgiving by 30 per cent.

The exhibition of "Large Paintings" by Lee Krasner, currently installed in the spacious fourth-floor galleries of the Whitney Museum of American Art, is the first major museum survey of the artist's work to come to New York. (A retrospective was mounted in London as long ago as 1965.)
Big Bertha of the Baltimore Zoo's reptile house had a vicious hiss for the energy crisis yesterday when she was displaced by an otter.

For today's college students, the glitter of Camelot has been dulled by textbooks and time. Most were in elementary school when President Kennedy was killed. Many were in kindergarten when he was elected. Some were not even born when he first emerged as a Presidential possibility.

There was merriment at the New York Giants' news conference today. "What a difference a victory means after seven straight defeats," noted Leon M. Yablon, the owner of the Captain's Table restaurant, who has observed a deepening gloom each week as the coaches tried to explain what went wrong.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange in the month ended November 15 fell to 16,166,641 shares. This was a decrease of 748,904 shares from the total on Oct. 15 when it was 16,915,545 shares.
Robert Moul, an off-duty police-officer, stopped at the side of Saw Mill Creek here the other day and examined the footprints in the wet earth. "There were raccoons here yesterday," he said,

Israel today set up a five-man civilian commission headed by the President of the Supreme Court to investigate the state of the nation's preparedness for the war that began Oct. 6, the Government said. The members include two former armed forces chiefs of staff.
A Northern Ireland executive body in which Protestant and Roman Catholic parties will share power for the first time in this century was agreed on tonight.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame made the first two appointments of his new administration yesterday, and at the same time appeared to be drifting into a dispute with prominent blacks who supported him during his campaign.

STAY OF EXECUTION. A Sort of Memoir. By Stewart Alsop. 312 pages. Illustrated. Lippincott. $8.95. True, the opening pages of Stewart Alsop's "Stay of Execution" are not particularly inviting. In the brief Preface, we learn that what follows is the memoir of a man condemned to die of a rare form of cancer.

A lawyer for Robert Garrow, accused in an Adirondack camping murder, said today that the defendant had punctured his arm in the county jail here in a suicide attempt, although a state-police investigator, Richard Beckwith, said the incident did not look like a suicide attempt.
A Sayville attorney was fined $1,000 today for contempt of a grand jury investigating an alleged mob-directed loan-shark ring.

Just after the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday, there was a long wait until the photo-finish camera showed that Grand Impression had beaten Brilliant Sage by the narrowest of margins. When the official sign went up, a fan shouted at Johnny Campo, "Hey, Johnny. That's two for two."
What do you ask a man who crossed the United States in a balloon? What do clouds feel like? Can you see through pollution? Where do you go when you have to?

As Strindberg observed, there is "a multiplicity of motives in 'Miss Julie.'" There is also a complexity of characterization. Who seduces whom? It is the servant Jean, not Miss Julie, who is worried about pride and reputation (and the maid Kristin who is concerned with morality).
The rise in consumer prices continued in October at an exceptional rate for peacetime, even though food prices were essentially stable, the Labor Department reported today.
The Vietcong's Provisional Revolutionary Government has rejected South Vietnamese charges that it is preparing an offensive in violation of the Paris peace agreement.
Beginning Monday afternoon, New Englanders will have to get by on a voltage reduction of 5 per cent for four hours a day.
Twenty-eight provisional members of the Junior League of the City of New York were presented last night at the league's 25th . annual Debutante Ball in the Grand Ballroom at the Plaza. Mrs.

About 300 persons gathered in a cold wind at Kennedy Memorial Plaza today for 30 minutes of music and prayer to eulogize President John F. Kennedy one day ahead of the I0th anniversary of his assassination.
The Skylab 3 astronauts found mildew tonight on the ar-conditioned undergarments they will wear under their spacesuits, and the discovery threatened to delay a spacewalk planned for Thanksgiving Day.
The Soviet Union gave a new sign of uneasiness today over the trend toward increasing political cooperation in Western Europe.
HOLIDAY Thanksgiving. Someone in the kitchen, pots banging, getting ready for company and gourmand dining and the wish is that you and the rest of the family would go away until dinner is served.
The General Motors Corporation told the Cost of Living Council today that it would need less of a price increase for 1974 model cars than it had originally proposed.
However the public may remember John Fitzgerald Kennedy 10 years after his assassination, the scholars who will eventually fix his place in history are at loggerheads.
Gail Goodrich scored 30 points, 18 in the second half, to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 106-97 victory over the Capital Bullets in a National Basketball Association game tonight.
The United Auto Workers announced today that it. had reached tentative agreement with the Caterpillar Tractor Company on a new contract. Duane Greathouse, the union vice president,
When James Alfred Cavanaugh returned last night to the eight-room, shingled house in the Bergen Beach section of Brooklyn that has been in his home since 1949, a double celebration was awaiting him.

A plan to introduce Sunday. horse racing in New York next spring has been abandoned because of the energy crisis. In its request for 1974 dates, delivered yesterday the New York Racing Association made no mention of Sunday programs. The State Racing and Wagering Board is expected to approve a Feb. 25-Dec. 29 thoroughbred season for next year.
Three vice presidents-two octogenarians and one who is almost there-are retiring' at the end of this month from Jas. H. Oliphant Co., Inc.

Two men and two women on their way to a formal dinner in a single-engine plane crashed into a mountain here and survived through a night of swirling winds in five inches of snow by starting a fire using part of one woman's evening gown.

Madison Square Garden Corporation announced yesterday it would apply for a rehearing of an Illinois Supreme Court decision finding that the corporation's Illinois race track subsidiary must pay about $5.6-million in additional state privilege taxes for interest for the years 1966 through 1972.

Ralph Nader joined yesterday with a Boston-area professional group, the Union of Concerned Scientists, in an attack on President Nixon's proposed speed-up of nuclear power development to ease the energy crisis.
Four weeks after the cease-fire in the Middle East, Secretary General Waldheim fears a slackening of the momentum needed to get the Arabs and Israelis to the conference table.
Connecticut may get the wild turkeys it ordered from New York, but certainly not for this Thanksgiving and probably not until another winter has set in.

State officials in New Jersey and New York were busy banishing Cadillacs yesterday to conserve fuel. Leading off was New Jersey's Governor-elect, Brendan T. Byrne, who got rid of his limousine even before it was delivered.
Gulf Western Industries, Inc., announced yesterday a cash tender offer to buy up to 1 million common shares of the Madison Square Garden Corporation stock at $7 net a share.
Stock prices rallied yesterday in heavy trading after falling to a two-year low on Tuesday in the face of the widening energy crisis. Volume was 24.26 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

The irregular business pattern in retail merchandising was further demonstrated in earnings reports yesterday by Federated Department Stores, Inc., which showed a modest 3.8 per cent rise in third-quarter profits to $26,213,584 from $25,175,325, while the W. T. Grant Company suffered a large deficit.

Governor Rockefeller and Republican legislative leaders today endorsed the concept of a state subsidy to help communities hold down transit fares, but said they would await congressional action on aid to mass transit before making any moves.

The fallen leaves skitter in the November wind and the chickadees and the juncos swirl and flutter in the dooryard. Winter birds, they have come down from the woodlands and the hills, back to the dooryard feeders where they were welcomed last year.

FROGMORE, S. C. -- The Warren Commission said it all nine years ago: Lee Harvey Oswald killed President Kennedy and did it alone. The commission's report, the most completely documented story of a crime ever put together, has been challenged, but its mountain of positive evidence has never been refuted.
Japan formally urged Israel today to withdraw from Arab territories occupied during the 1967 war and warned obliquely that if Israel did not comply, Japan might break diplomatic relations.
Four international airlinestwo of them American-say they will cut down on their trans-Atlantic flights in order to save fuel. One official said that 68 round-trip flights a week would be eliminated.
An attorney representing Eric "Jomo" Thompson, accused of having slain two fellow inmates during the 1971 Attica prison riot, yesterday entered a plea of not guilty for his client.

Three Atlantic salmonstocking ponds on Connecticut's Farmington River in Barkhamsted will be constructed this fall and Winter as part of the continuing effort to restore this valuable food and game fish to the Connecticut River basin.

Four narcotics dealers who were convicted in Federal Court here yesterday were permitted to remain free on bail so they could spend Thanksgiving with their families, requiring 30 narcotics agents to give up part of their own holiday to keep them under surveillance.

Defense officials said today that the United States had intelligence information suggesting that the Soviet Union might have moved nuclear warheads into Egypt at the height of the Arab-Israeli war last month.

William Del Toro, chairman of the community advisory board of the Metropolitan Hospital Center, yesterday attacked a number of individuals and organizations connected with hospital patient service, including the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation.

Pearl Bailey was talking the other day about beans. 'She said she always fixed plenty, in case somebody dropped in, and so as to have some left over. "The food is better the next day," she said. "You know, there's a whole cookbook now on leftovers."

A 25-year-old woman who took fertility drugs gave birth to quintuplets prematurely yesterday, hospital officials said today. Officials at Tampere Central Hospital said that all five babies were alive but that chances of survival were not good because of the premature birth, in the 25th week of the pregnancy.

Today's scheduled hearing for W. A. Boyle, the former United Mine Workers president, in connection with a Federal conspiracy charge in the death of a union insurgent, Joseph A. Yablonski, has been postponed until next Wednesday.
In the vanguard of Macy's Thanksgiving Day Parade today will be a 102-piece marching ensemble in which probably the only discordant note will be that their dress pants don't match.

Pete Rose of the Cincinnati Reds, who triggered the fight with the Mets in Shea Stadium last month, was elected the most valuable player in the National League yesterday - and immediately triggered another fight.

Morris Bishop, the Cornell scholar, literary biographer and master of light verse, died Tuesday at Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N. Y., after a brief illness. He was 80 years old and lived in Cayuga Heights, an Ithaca suburb.

Egypt has was a ordered a new feasibility study for the Sumed pipeline, raising doubts whether the biggest project in years involving Americans in the Middle East will ever get under way, it was learned today.
The rise in consumer prices continued in October at an exceptional rate for peacetime, even though food prices were essentially stable, the Labor Department reported today.
During the Nets' recent nine-game losing streak the party line was that the talent was there and it was just a matter of time before they jelled.
The Treasury announced today an unexpected financing operation to raise $3-billion in cash, mainly as a result of the indirect effects of the strength of the dollar on the foreign-exchange markets.

Manuel Orantes, the topseeded player, was the victim of fast-rising Byron Bertram of South Africa in the first major upset of the $125,000 South African open tennis championships today. Arthur Ashe of the United States was a winner, gaining the quarterfinals.
Pete Mahovlich, who had tied the game in the second period, scored the winning goal in the final four seconds last night to lift Montreal to a 4-3 victory over the hapless Minnesota North Stars.
Miss Ann Howard Kopple, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Kopple of Rollingwood, Roslyn and Southold, was married here at noon today to Donald George DeWerd, son of George DeWerd of St. Thomas, V. I.,

Rebounding from two sessions of sharp drops, prices opened higher on the American Stock Exchange yesterday, dropped at midday, but then surged again to close higher for the session. A similar situation prevailed in the over-the-counter market.
The wife and daughter of a local Methodist minister were kidnapped at about 2A.M. today by three armed men apparently seeking the release of a bank robbery suspect.
Four visiting. American Congressmen advised Israelis today not to count on an American defense pact, a possibility raised last week by Secretary of State Kissinger.

At the other end of the wire was Jack Lang, the official hearer of good tidings from the Baseball Writers Association of America, and he could hear an exultant shout in the background.
The chairman of the Delaware River Port Authority of Pennsylvania and New Jersey proposed today that the agency's four big bridges across the Delaware be turned over to the Federal Government.

North and South Korea each claimed victory today when the General Assembly's Political Committee, without voting, ended a week-long debate on what should be done about the United Nations military command in South Korea.
The United States was the first of the big five powers today to agree to pay its share of the costs of the United Nations' new peace force for the Middle East.
Stock prices rallied yesterday in heavy trading after falling to a two-year low on Tuesday in the face of the widening energy crisis. Volume was 24.26 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

Directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to 77 cents a share-a 10 per cent increase over the previous rate of 70 cents. It is payable Jan. 2 to holders of record Nov. 29.
A bill requiring the licensing of television, radio and audioequipment repair dealers and their service managers was approved yesterday by the City Council's Consumer Affairs Committee.
North and South Korea appear likely to reopen the suspended Red Cross talks next month. These have been one of the two channels of dialogue between the two Koreas on ways to improve their relations.
New orders for durable goods rose strongly in October to a new record after declines in the two preceding months, the Commerce Department

The Swiss Government today announced a general ban on the private use of motor vehicles, planes and boats for the next three Sundays as a fuel-conservation measure.
Former President Lyndon B. Johnson gave the bulk of his papers to the United States without obtaining any tax advantage, according to the director of the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library.
Now in the bleak November of President Nixon's unhappiest year the nation is being reminded of another November and another President-John F. Kennedy, dead these 10 years.

President Nixon's popularity apparently is reviving in the South. The resurgence of his standing in this region, which has steadily been the source of his greatest strength, began even before his Southern tour last weekend. His visit to Florida, Georgia and Tennessee is expected to boost it further.

The International Business Machines Corporation denied yesterday that it had engaged in monopolistic practices as charged by California Computer Products, Inc., which is suing I.B.M. for $100-million in damages. The plaintiff said that I.B.M. had slashed prices for peripheral computing equipment.

Tony Alguero put on a show for 12,000 fans at Baker Field yesterday. The junior running back ran for 209 yards and three touchdowns as he led Cardinal Hayes to a 28-21 victory in the 31st meeting between the schools.

Members of the Kennedy family and hundreds of mourners and friends paid silent tribute to the slain Kennedy brothers at Arlington National Cemetery today on the 10th anniversary of President Kennedy's assassination.

President Fahri Koruturk asked Bulent Ecevit, leader of Turkey's largest political party, today to make another attempt to solve the nation's 39-day-old governmental crisis.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he was "ready, at a moment's notice, to call a special session to deal with the energy crisis and the 35cent fare, if it becomes necessary."

The Labor Government has introduted legislation barring discrimination on grounds of race or sex. The new law, if passed, would principally benefit Australian women and aborigines, who are refused service in some bars and who receive lower pay than white men doing the same work, among other inequalities.
Archbishop Stepinac concluded one of its finest seasons ever yesterday, defeating White Plains, 17-7. Stepinac finished with a 7-2 won-lost record and White Plains closed at 6-3,

A forum for the discussion of the courts and social change, said to be the first of its kind in the country, has been established at Hunter College with a $10,000 grant from the New York Foundation.

Egyptian and Israeli generals met in a sandstorm on the Cairo-Suez road as the two sides held their first formal session in eight days to grapple with the intricate details of disengaging their troops under the ceasefire agreement.

Tempered in their celebration of the nation's historic holiday of bounty by the international scarcity of fuel, by rising fuel costs, by domestic political taint and by the recollection of a Presidential assassination, Americans here and across the country observed Thanksgiving yesterday.

Miss Betty Anne Hyatt and and Anton Meisner, president of the Transworld Fur Corporation in New York, were married here at noon by Kingston Alderman at Large T. Robert Gallo at the home of the bride's brother, Kenneth E. Hyatt, assistant superintendent of the Kingston School System.
The Miami Dolphins, who had been annihilating those second-class teams back in the Eastern Division of the American Conference, stepped up in class today and won again.
A collection of the recordings, pictures and letters of W. C. Handy, "father of the blues," goes on exhibit Monday at the Rutgers University Institute of Jazz Studies here.

When he disembowels a quarterback he does so with professional detachment, yet he has a considerable capacity for indignation and no special reluctance about expressing it.

Saudi Arabian Oil Minister Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani threatened today to cut oil production by 80 per cent if the United States, Europe or Japan took measures to counter current Arab oil boycotts and reductions.
The Cleveland Cavaliers took the lead today with 3 minutes 38 seconds remaining in the third period on a dunk shot by Dwight Davis and beat the Houston Rockets, 104-96.
A woman's answer to the all-male McSorley's bar of yesteryear is open for business at the College of St. Elizabeth here.
A Middletown policeman who has been charged by a Rumson man with having searched his car illegally has filed a slander and defamation suit against him.

Eugene F. O'Connell's Chance Miltie beat an equally fast-closing Escaped by three-quarters of a length today and won the $26,625 Festival Handicap at the Atlantic City track.

A Vatican spokesman "categorically denied" today that the church was contemplating the abolition of the Sacred Roman Rota, the ecclesiastical supreme court best known for its role in the annulment of marriages.
Glen Sather scored with less than three minutes remaining in the game tonight to give the St. Louis Blues a 2-1 National Hockey League victory over the Minnesota North Stars.

The United States Government rested its case today in the extradition hearing of Robert L. Vesco, the New Jersey financier who has been in dicted with former Attorney General John N. Mitchell and others on charges of'obstructing justice.
The Washington defense handed Detroit its first shutout in 56 games today as the Redskins defeated the Lions, 20-0, in a National Football League game. Billy Kilmer threw two short touchdown passes.
Geoff Petrie scored 43 points today directing the Portland Trail Blazers to a 131-125 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics in a National Basketball Association game.
Cambodian Government forces have recaptured the position of Dei Dos near Kompong Chain, 50 miles northeast of here, the military command said today.
Federal officials have disclosed how they uncovered an illegal hunting trip business that killed rare game at such places as Yellowstone National Park.
President Nixon joined his family today at his Mary land mountaintop retreat for Thanksgiving dinner.
A Houston gasoline marketing company is planning to turn the clock back 75 years by delivering gasoline to motorists's homes, United Press International reports.

Elliot L. Richardson says that Alexander M. Haig Jr., President Nixon's chief of staff, told him he had unsuccessfully tried to dissuade the President from ordering Archibald Cox on Oct. 19 to stop all court actions to obtain White House tape recordings and related documents.

Mrs. Ehnore Hoelzel Dewart of Delray Beach, Fla., was married in the Princeton University Chapel today to Clement R. Hoopes, a 1929 graduate of Princeton and an author.

To 10-year-old Sarah Hilsman, morality has become a simple equation. South Vietnam and the Vietcong resumed their eightmonth-old negotiations here to day but reported no progress in their search for an agreement on internationally supervised electionns.

The National Jazz Ensemble's debut at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening developed into a superb concert, although it did not really focus on the primary objectives that Chuck Israels, the ensemble's founder and conductor, had envisioned.
The United States dollar moved strongly upward on world money markets today, touching a five-month high in Frankfurt and gaining ground nearly everywhere.

Kiichi Aichi, Japan's Minister of Finance and a familiar figure at recent international economic conferences, died tonight of pneumonia. He was 66 years old.

Jose Alfredo Jimenez, composer of more than 400 popular songs in Latin America, died today in a hospital here. He was 47 years old. He had been under treatment for a bleeding ulcer.

The long, hard road democratic Finland has had to pursue to obtain Moscow's acquiescence to new trade links with the nine-nation Common Market illustrates the kind of Soviet pressure known as "Finlandization." Right up to the final moment, when Finland's Parliament overwhelmingly ratified the agreement with the Nine providing for virtual free trade in industrial products, the Finnish Communists fought the move and, as the only opponents, voted as a bloc against it.

As the wake wore on last night, the mourners drifted into the back room at the Blandin Undertaking Company and talked about the funeral music.
President Nixon is not moving fast enough or far enough to meet the nation's energy problems, according to economists, businessmen and oil industrv experts.
Israeli teachers have been told to prepare their pupils for the "eventuality that some or most of the territories" captured in 1967 may, have to be given back to the Arabs.
Tom Williams scored a goal and an assist in the second period tonight to give the New England Whalers a 4-2 victory over the Jersey Knights in a World Hockey Association game.
Yields on United States Treasury bills fell in the Government's weekly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

The Brooklyn Museum, the seventh largest in the United States and one of the jewels in the city's cultural crown, is being split by factionalism so severe that, according to museum and city officials, its effectiveness as a museum of first rank is endangered.
Some years ago when 23-year-old Shelley Isaac was making plans for her future, she considered possible careers in teaching, acting and nursing. But she chose teaching, "because I wanted security."

Negotiations between Egypt and an American financial and engineering group for construction of the Suez-Mediterranean oil pipeline are proceeding normally in Cairo, according to sources involved in the talks.

New York City may be compelled to pay an unconscionably high price in polluted air to meet its energy and transportation needs unless an adequate sense of urgency is shown at all levels of government in instituting less noxious alternatives.

The odd couple of this Broadway season is, undoubtedly, Neil Simon and Anton Chekhov. For Simon it is an affair of the heart - he loves Chekhov. And the extent of his passion will be revealed tonight when "The Good Doctor," Simon's 10th play, opens at the O'Neill Theater.

The Health Department has cited 19 more restaurants and other food-handling businesses for health-code violations found upon a second inspection, and it warned that a third inspection could result in closing orders unless the violations were corrected.
Press-Denison Mines, Ltd., announced today an agreement for the sale of $800-million worth of uranium oxide to Tokyo Electric Power Company. Inc., of Japan.
Officials in the New. York metropolitan area pressed ahead yesterday with the task of coping with the developing energy crisis.

President Nixon's personal secretary testified today that through some "terrible mistake" she had pressed the wrong button on her tape recorder and thus caused an 18-minute "gap" in one of the subpoenaed Watergate tape recordings.

Intensive negotiations were held yesterday in an effort to end the seven-week strike by employes of the Museum of Modern Art, a walkout that has cut attendance and forced the cancellation of some exhibitions.

Barring some unexpected development, such as Bob Lee tripping over the 50-yard line and breaking his right arm, the Atlanta Falcons will wind up in pro football's playoffs and they'll take with them, according to Eddie Bell, "one of the most vicious secondaries in the league."
Dr. Clarence Prouty Shedd, a faculty member of the Yale Divinity School for 32 years who prepared scores of students for campus ministries, died Saturday at a nursing home here. He was 86 years old.
Lawyers for two London banks filed a class action suit in Federal District Court today challenging the sale of certain assets and liabilities of the United States National Bank of San Diego.
Egyptian and Israeli generals meeting in a United Nations tent at this checkpoint failed today to break the deadlock between the two countries on the issue of troop withdrawal.

In a game made necessary by a television commitment and made noteworthy only by Bruce Gossett's two field goals, the San Francisco 49ers defeated the Green Bay Packers, 20-6, at Candlestick Park tonight.

The Assembly passed a bill yesterday that would provide up to 45 extra days of thoroughbred horse racing in New Jersey next year. The measure was passed by a 45-9 vote and was sent to Gov. William T. Cahill.
A Harris poll released today indicated that 44 per cent of Americans believe that when the Watergate investigation is completed, President Nixon will be found to have violated the law.
Arab hijackers who seized a Dutch jumbo jet Sunday night while flying over the Middle East agreed here last night to release the

The Watergate scandals have totally discredited the traditional system of financing political campaigns from private sources. Briefcases stuffed with $100 bills, illegal corporate contributions "laundered" through foreign intermediaries, and secret slush funds used to finance espionage and buy the silence of witnesses have brought the nation's politics into alarming disrepute.
The First National Bank of Chicago, the 10th largest commercial bank in the United States, increased yesterday its prime, or base, lending rate from 91/2 per cent to 93/4 per cent, effective today.
A city police officer was arrested and suspended yesterday after he fired his pistol into the ground during an argument with a citizen in a parking lot.
A dissident Soviet mathematician held incommunicado for 14 months finally went on trial in absentia today and was ordered committed indefinitely to a mental hospital, dissident sources said.

Some of the more talented schoolboys ever to play in New Jersey emerged from the football season that finished last week. And now most of them must decide which college offer to accept, after taking into account all aspects of the football and financial aid programs, and maybe even the academic quality of the various campuses.
SEASON The first subscription season for a series by professional performers at the Riverside Church, 490 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street (749-7000, ext 128), gets under way at 8 tonight.
Jimmy Connors, playing at the peak of his game, upset Arthur Ashe, 6-4, 7-6, 6-3, today for the men's singles title in the South African tennis championships.

Rising food costs are already putting unusual pressure on the nation's fish and game resources. At least one state, Missouri, has reported a 100 per cent increase in poaching activities by deer hunters, presumably the direct result of the high cost of meat, and it seems will prove true in other areas.

The Interstate Commerce Commission began 10 hours of oral argument here today on the 10year-old plan by the Union Pacific Railroad to merge with the nearly bankrupt Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railroad.

Peter W. Eller, former president of the Thompson Starrett construction company and retired chariman of the board of governors of the Building Trades Employers' Association of the City of New York, died Friday in Montclair, N.J., where he lived. His age was 83.

Why don't we hear more about Richard Gresko? The 31year-old Canadian pianist's appearance Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall left no question but that both his talent and his level of artistic achievement are considerably above ordinary.

Just when the Nixon Administration was looking forward to winding up its increasingly unhappy excursion into wage-price controls, along comes the energy crisis-and the need for a host of new restraints on the free market.
A Federal safety expert estimated today that the cut in the highway speed limit would reduce traffic fatalities by one per cent, saving 5,000 lives next year if the controls remained in force.

Three teen-aged boys were being held yesterday on charges of breaking into Intermediate School 93, at First Avenue and 110th Street in East Harlem, and causing considerable damage, the police reported.

Representatives of 250 Educational Opportunity Fund students at Ramapo State College here say they will picket the 300-acre campus beginning early tomorrow morning and continue to picket until the administration
Israel accused Japan today of surrendering to Arab threats in calling for an Israeli withdrawal from all Arab areas occupied in the war of 1967.
Opinions about the lighting required for growing plants indoors are exceptionally diverse, but there is basic agreenient that ordinary fluorescent tubes are satisfactory for growing plants.

The Carolina Cougars, paced by Billy Cunningham, outscored the Kentucky Colonels 25-12 in the fourth period. and recorded a 94-82 American Basketball Association victory tonight. Kentucky held a 70:69 edge entering the fourth quarter.

President Nixon is going to make public the contents of his income tax returns later this week to clear up the controversy over his deductions "once and for all," Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, said tonight.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger called last night for a radical revision of American legal practice that could bar three-quarters or more of the 375,000 lawyers in the country from appearing in court at all.

Rarely, if ever, do animals kill for the pleasure of killing or for the pleasure of bedecking themselves with one another's pelts. Only men do that. Only men, the supposedly civilized breed, kill other sentient creatures in cruel and ingenious ways. Only men kill-not because they need the flesh for food or the fur pelts to keep them warm but for "fun" or to make pin money.

A retired superintendent in the Buffalo Streets Sanitation Deapartment has been acquitted on eight counts of a 19-count indictment charging conspiracy, grand larceny and filing false instruments. The jury was unable to agree on the remaining 11 counts.

Two major retailers reported record quarterly profits yesterday, while a third retailer reported a decline. Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's largest retailer of general merchandise, posted record sales along with its second earnings in the quarter ended Oct. 31, according to its report Yesterday from Chicago head!quarters.

Michigan's football coach, Bo Schembechler, today accused the Big Ten commissioner, Wayne Duke, of "influencing" the decision to send Ohio State to the Rose Bowl and invited him to explain to his team why it wasn't good enough.

An 11man trade mission, the first sent here by the Communist Government in China, discussed expanded trade with the Philippines in a series of meetings today with President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his top advisers.
The Medical Examiner's office said yesterday that the nude woman whose body was found near the La Tourette Golf Course on Staten Island on Sunday afternoon had been murdered.

Edith Mason, a lyric soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera and reigned as a favorite for many seasons at the Chicago Opera, died of a stroke yesterday in San Diego. She was 80 years old and the wife of William E. Ragland.
A United Auto Workers union leader said today that he had told workers that "next month's layoff may be just the beginning."

The House Appropriations Committee, in approving the defense budget today, imposed a fuel conservation measure on the Pentagon: No more new passenger cars or station wagons,
A rise in unemployment next year is almost universally predicted by private economic forecasters, but only partly because of the energy shortage.
The funeral of Dr. Arthur C. Logan, a prominent surgeon and civic leader who died Sunday in a fall, will be held Thursday at noon in Riverside Church, his family announced yesterday.

After years of controversy and months of debate, the House of Commons today passed a bill that will impose strict controls for the first time on a broad range of foreign investments in Canada.
Syracuse University yesterday named Frank Maloney, an assistant coach at the University of Michigan, to succeed Floyd (Ben) Schwartzwalder as the head football coach.
A Federal judge halted today the use of entrance and promotion examinations in the San Francisco Police Department on the ground they discriminate against minorities.

Norman D. Archer, a former assistant Queens district attorney whose Federal conviction on charges of accepting a bribe to quash a criminal case was overturned by the United States Court of Appeals last July, was indicted yesterday on similar charges by a special state grand jury.

Should an officer of a racially segregated Mississippi private school be licensed to operate that state's major television station?

From interviews with Harry S. Truman recorded ten years ago by Merle Miller and just now being published, the ringing story has emerged of how Mr. Truman put Gen. Douglas MacArthur in his place at their Wake Island meeting in 1950. But there may be more to this story than meets the eye.

Stock prices plummeted yesterday in their biggest one-day drop since the 1962 market break as the energy crisis raised fears of an economic slowdown next year. Volume was moderate at 19.83 million shares.
The new Office of Petroleum Allocation, which will administer and enforce the fuel conservation program, expects to employ about 5,500 people to do the job.

The House Appropriations Committee, cutting the defense budget by 3 per cent, voted today to slow down the Navy's Trident missile submarine program and to kill a new missile defense system being developed by the Army.

The call to vacations in Honolulu, Delhi or other far-flung places will no longer be answered by those patrons of Manhattan's East Side cafes who for the last three months could buy airlines tickets at half their face value.

The City University plans to open an experimental five-year "middle college" by combining the last three years of high school with two years at La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens, beginning next fall.

Soft drinks are a fun thing and the advertising for them reflects that fact. But a retail market in excess of $7billion is nothing to joke about and the people involved in marketing soda pop in all its wonderous forms reflect that fact. For them fun is serious.
Negotiators for about 34,000 electrical workers reached a tentative contract agreement with the General Motors Corporation today, averting a threatened strike.
" It's been a long, long day," said Coach Red Holzman of the Knicks yesterday just before leaving Madison Square Garden for his home in Cedarhurst, L. I.

Helping China develop a professional-caliber hockey team is the least Alan Eagleson can do. After all, he said yesterday in a telephone conversation from Toronto, it was the application of Chinese acupuncture that relieved his allergy last weekend.
All 400 inmates of Connecticut correctional facilities returned from their Thanksgiving furloughs, Deputy Correction Commissioner Dorin Polvani said today.

It was another bloody, inconclusive day on Route 4. Since Nov. 10, when insurgeut forces cut the road at Mohassang, a town southwest of Phnom Penh, Government troops have been trying to reopen it. Route 4 leads from the capital to the sea.
Four months ago, President George Papadopoulos went on television and told the Greek people that the 1967 coup that brought him to power had been "a model of success in the history of revolutions."
Laurence Harvey, the actor, died of cancer here at his home last night. He was 45 years old. Mr. Harvey, had undergone surgery and cobalt ray treatment in Los Angeles last May.

To the Editor: The shortsightedness of our national failure to support basic research is now becoming apparent with the growing realization that we lack the knowledge and tools with which to meet our energy needs.

The Board of Higher Education last night approved the first list of City University faculty members for full tenure under the recently adopted rules requiring special justification for granting tenure to teachers in departments where more than half the faculty are already tenured.
Former Associate Justice Charles Evans Whittaker of the United States Supreme Court died today in St. Luke's Hospital of a ruptured abdominal aneurism. He was 72 years old.
At 8 o'clock, the American Broadcasting Company network presents the first installment of "The American Heritage," a series of historical dramatizations labeled "Bicentennial-themed."
After years of controversy and months of debate, Canada's House of Commons passed a bill that will put strict controls for the first time on a broad range of foreign investments in Canada.

In an effort to save fuel, the electric power companies in New England today began a 5 per cent voltage reduction to their customers during four hours of peak demand.

A predominantly black group of residents of the United States Virgin Islands has bought a Virgin Islands has assumed control of a network-affiliated television station on St. Croix, making it the first major television station owned and operated by blacks on United States territory.
A Senate subcommittee has found "distressing evidence" of drug abuse among athletes, the committee announced today.

Not every British rock group can bring officials of the Hayden Planetarium downtown to an American concert debut at the Academy of Music, on 14th Street, as Hawkwind did on Sunday. The Planetarium presented a lecture on the Kohoutek comet: Hawkind introduced flashing lights, back projection film (basically on an Other Worlds theme), a dancer and nearly two hours of their "Space Ritual" suite.
That the Denver Broncos, so long a synonym for defeat, are a first-place team in.the third from last week of the season is the phenomenon of the year.

The energy crisis has begun to delay the movement of transcontinental mail, particularly between New York and Los Angeles, and the United States Postal Service is concerned that the disruptions may spread widely before Christmas.
The Ford Motor Company said today it was recalling 17,744 current-model Lincoln Continentals because of a possible short circuit from an improperly routed starter cable.

An "unusually large" increase of 2 per cent in the purchasing power of factory production workers in the New York-North Jersey area in September was reported yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, the Department of Labor's assistant regional director for labor statistics. The gain, the first in five months, reportedly made up for about half the loss in real net spendable earnings such workers had suffered since September a year ago.
A Feydeau farce is a Feydeau farce and "Chemin de Fer," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last night as the second entry in the New Phoenix repertory, is undoubtedly a Feydeau farce.

Two Federal agencies are developing preliminary answers to the question of whether they halted a narcotics investigation when it led to Robert L, Vesco, the controversial financier.
Military sources said today that Government aircraft flew 114 bombing sorties over two Communist airfields Friday - the heaviest raids since the ceasefire agreement last January.
About 150 teachers and parents of pupils demonstrated outside Public School 219 in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn yesterday in an appeal for increased police security.

The Brooklyn Museum, the seventh largest in the United States and one of the jewels in the city's cultural crown, is being split by factionalism so severe that, according to museum and city officials its effectiveness as a museum of first rank is endangered.

A group of 10 prominent blacks who hope to gain more influence with Abraham D. Beame's administration in issues affecting the black community called yesterday for a strengthening of the new post of Deputy Mayor for Community Affairs.

The gain, the first in five months, reportedly made up for about half the loss in real net spendable earnings such workers had suffered since September a year ago.
The conference of Arab heads of state opened today with spokesmen talking exultantly of the Arab "oil weapon" and its impact on the outside world, but adding notes of caution about its use.

Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany told President Pompidou tonight that the members of the European Economic Community must stick together and help one another face the oil crisis or all would suffer.
Students from four colleges and universities in Seoul demonstrated today against suppressive measures by President Park Chung Hee's Government.
Most of the 33,000 employes of the Caterpillar Tractor Company, which makes farm and other heavy equipment in Illinois and four other states, returned to work today after an 11-day strike.
The Chapel of St. James at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Pamela Howard to Clarkson Nott Potter.

The TV Broadcasters All Industry Committee, made up of 10 New York City area television stations, has urged the Federal Communications Commission to grant at "the earliest possible date" permits to relocate their antennas atop the World Trade Center.
Yasir Arafat and other guerrilla leaders have been told that the Soviet Union would continue to give the Palestinians "assistance and support," the official press agency Tass reported today.

Secretary of the Treasury George P. Shultz indicated today that the United States would welcome a decision by European countries to sell dollars from their monetary reserves if necessary to prevent the dollar's value in the foreignexchange markets from rising much above its present level.

Penn State, which completed a perfect season by beating Pittsburgh, 35-13, Saturday, was unanimously named last night as the Lambert Trophy winner. The trophy goes to the top major college football team in the East. It was the third consecutive year 'that Coach Joe Paterno's team had won the award and the 10th time since it was introduced in 1936.
Steel production for the week ended Nov. 24 rose by 1.8 per cent to 2,959,000 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

Plans were announced yesterday for converting 1,500 acres in Ocean County, N. J., into a $100-million "total entertainment center for the Eastern United States" that would be similar to, but smaller than, Disneyworld in Florida.

Jonathan Eldridge, a retired ITT World Communications executive who had operated the marine coastal station WSL near Southampton, L.I., known to Atlantic mariners as Amagansett Radio, died Saturday in Falmouth (Mass.) Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived in Chatham, Mass., his birthplace, after retiring in 1970.
The gasoline shortage is producing a run on New Jersey auto-parts stores for locking gas caps and siphons, a random survey indicated today.
Representative Gerald R. Ford affirmed his support of the State of Israel at a dinner tonight, while at the same time giving 3,000 Long Islanders a chance to view the Vice President-designate.

The renewed controversy over saccharin versus cyclamates gasts my flabber. We have a food industry that shoots sugar into our bread, cereals, sausages, hamburger, ketchup, salad dressings and canned goods of all kinds-and clamors for the right to shoot low-calorie sugar substitutes into our desserts.
The formation of the Newark Preservation and Landmark Committee, a group to save and promote the city's remaining historic buildings, was announced at Plume House, 407 Broad Street, today.

Gerald R. Ford encountered both support and opposition from Democratic liberals today as a House committee ended six days of hearings and the Senate opened debate on his nomination for Vice President.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange plunged yesterday in stepped-up trading after rising slightly on Friday. Prices in the over-the-counter market were also lower.
One of Edmonton's many oil executives was explaining a power struggle that has erupted between this rich Western province and the federal Government.
The nameplate of the Liberty ship Adolph S. Ochs, named after the late publisher of The New York Times, was presented yesterday to his daughter, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger.

By his own admission, the measures announced by President Nixon Sunday night to deal with a "major energy crisis" fall substantially short of what will be required to close the widening gap between this country's fuel needs and available supplies. The President estimated that shortages this winter could run as high as 17 per cent of normal demand.

All 22 people indicted in the Equity Funding Corporation of America conspiracy and fraud case pleaded not guilty here today before Federal District Court Judge Jesse W. Curtis. Among those pleading today were Stanley Goldblum, former chief executive of Equity Funding, and Fred Levin and Samuel B. Lowell, former executive vice presidents.

Edward N. Cole, president of the General Motors Corporation, plans to enter the air freight business when he retires next fall. Mr. Cole will reach G.M.'s mandatory retirement age of 65 in September, 1974.

Firemen using more than a dozen pieces of equpiment, including a fireboat, worked for more than an hour yesterday to control a smoky fire aboard a small British freighter docked at the North Marine Terminal at 39th Street and the East River.

The recent Philippines International Tournament, held in Quezon City, featured a hot three-way fight for first prize that saw Bent Larsen of Denmark pull away from Ljubomir Ljubojevic of Yugoslavia and Lubomir Kavalek of the United States to snatch a well-earned victory in the closing rounds.
John R. Fiorino, the Monmouth County Democratic chairman, formally notified Senate President Alfred N. Beadleston today of his opposition to the nomination of Evan W. Jahos for Superior Court judge.

No more Senate Watergate hearings are planned until after the first of next year. Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Watergate investigating committee, agreed today to postpone further hearings at an unannounced meeting with the committee's top staff members.

Services at the A. M. Runyon Son Funeral Home 900 Park Ave, Plainfield, N. J. on Wednesday, Nov. 28 at 11 A. M.

Syracuse University yesterday named Frank Maloney, an assistant coach at the University of Michigan, to succeed Floyd (Ben) Schwartzwalder as the head football coach.
All 400 inmates of Connecticut correctional facilities returned from their Thanksgiving furloughs, Deputy Correction Commissioner Dorin Polvani said today.
Albert H. DeSalvo, who became known as the "Boston Strangler," was found stabbed to death at Walpole State Prison this morning.
The First Women's Bank and Trust Company filed last Friday a notice of intention to organize a trust company, the New York State Banking Department's weekly bulletin disclosed yesterday.

The secret weekend meetings of top financial officials of the United States, Britain, France, West Germany and Japan brought a formal diplomatic protest today from Italy and generated disquiet in financial markets.
Herman N. Liberman Jr., who recently completed a seven-year walking tour of Manhattan, died last night at his home at 1010 Fifth Avenue after a brief illness. He was 62 years old.
The new military rulers of Greece moved to consolidate their power today by purging from the armed forces high-ranking officers who supported the ousted President, George Papadopoulos.

Fears that the energy crisis might result in a 1974 recession, sent stock. prices tumbling yesterday. in the biggest singleday break since May 28, 1962, following a confrontation between President Kennedy and the steel industry.

The average rent for a family of four on welfare in private housing in the city shot up 14.3 per cent in the last year to $126.08 a month as of last September - double the rate of rise for all families.
The conference of Arab heads of state opened today with spokesmen talking exultantly of the Arab "oil weapon" and its impact on the outside world, but adding notes of caution about its use.

The humane thing to do in this season of football desolation in our village is to cast one's glance in another direction. There is no way of pretending that the indignities being heaped on the Giants and the Jets are not happening, but it would be an act of kindness to glance elsewhere.
The Rockland County Medical Examiner said today there were indications to support both suicide and murder theories to the death of James Pagano, 20year-old son of an alleged Mafia member.

A 23-year-old man with a record of arrests for burglary and larceny was found shot to death yesterday by the police who beseiged a Long Island department store with shotguns and tear gas after two of their colleagues were wounded.

A woman whose body was found near the Northern State Parkway in Woodbury, L.I., last Monday was identified by the Nassau County police today as Mrs. Frances Goldberg, 33 years old, of 18-43 215th Street, Bayside, Queens.
The entire Bolivian Cabinet offered its resignation today after President Hugo Banzer Suarez had announced that he would not run in Presidential elections he has called for next year.

The Petrol-Lewis Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to buy all of the oil and gas properties of certain subsidiaries of the White Shield Corporation for approximately $11-million in cash.
Three Arab hijackers aboard a KLM Dutch jumbo jet freed all 247 passengers and eight stewardesses today, took an airline official as a volunteer hostage and left...
In his second energy broadcast in 18 days, President Nixon sought last night to reassure the American people that things wouldn't be so bad.

Most service station operators throughout the country are expected to lock up their gasoline pumps on Sundays, although some say that the closings will mean 10 to 30 per cent less money in their cash registers.

Thomas D. Durrance, who retired in 1971 as director of we, employee and public relations for Texaco Europe, Ltd., in Brussels, died of leukemia yesterday in a hospital near Le Fleix, France. He was 56 years old.
Chris Evert, playing from the baseline, blunted Evonne Goolagong's attacking game and won the women's singles title in the South African open tennis championships today, 6-3, 6-3.

With nearly all gasoline stations expected to close this Sunday, sales of gasoline containers are booming. But in many areas the storage of more than a few gallons of gasoline without a special permit violates either state or city laws.

They hung a plaque for Eugene O'Neill on Broadway yesterday, and they hung it exactly one block from where they were supposed to do it. They did it in rain and drizzle, and while they did, people stopped and stared.

Minority group organizations--Hispanic, Oriental and American Indian, as well as black-have been exerting pressure on television stations in various parts of the country to ban from the air, or substantially edit, hundreds of motion pictures that they consider racially offensive.

TWO CONCERTS OF RECENT MUSIC BY NED ROREM. At Alice Tully Hail. Sunday, Nov. 25: Day Music (7971), Last Poems of Wallace Stevens (1972), War Scenes (1969), Gloria (1970), Monday, Nov. 26: Night music (1972), Ariel (1971), Trio (1959), Bertha, a one-act opera (1968).

Israeli postal authorities discovered three letter bombs mailed from Switzerland today, and the Swiss authorities announced that they intercepted five bound for Israel yesterday. All were discovered before they exploded.
Olympic Refineries, Inc., a company recently created by the Greek shipping magnate Aristotle Onassis, plans to build a major oil refinery in New Hampshire, Gov. Meldrim Thomson Jr. announced today.

A 27-year-old former city welfare investigator arrested by Bronx authorities last July as the mastermind of a $15million-a-year narcotics ring pleaded not guilty yesterday to new Federal drug charges lodged against him in Brooklyn.

President Nguyen Van Thieu has nudged 15,000 South Vietnamese bureaucrats out of their offices into a "revolutionary" retraining program where white-collar workers are learning to wear black pajamas, to box with their feet and, presumably, to cut red tape.

November volume showed improvement over the October level at R. H. Macy Co.'s 68 stores around the country but did not indicate recovery "of any high level of consumer optimism," Donald B. Smiley, chairman, said at the annual meeting here yesterday.

Jay N. Whipple, a past president of the Investment Bankers Association of America and a governor of the New York Stock Exchange, died yesterday in Lake Forest Hospital after a stroke. He was 76 years old and lived in Lake Forest.

Secretary of State Kissinger may make another trip to the Middle East in two weeks to discuss the prospects for the expected Arab-Israeli peace Conference with key countries in the area, Administration officials said today.
This is the third in a serles of articles by correspondents of The New York Times on changing Arab attitudes.
Chancellor Willy Brandt and President Pompidou today concluded their third meeting of the year by agreeing that the countries of Western Europe should get together to discuss defense problems.

The Senate Watergate committee has issued a subpoena for 1,001 hundred-dollar bills that President Nixon's friend Charles G. Rebozo accepted from aides of Howard Hughes arid reportedly kept in a safe deposit box for three years, according to a committee lawyer.

The summer of 1973 may well be remembered in tourist circles as the summer of the flip-flop, when the mass movement of Americans flocking abroad for vacations reversed itself and a new immigration of European and other foreign businessmen came flooding into New York.

Secretary of State Kissinger says that the main hope of easing the Middle East oil embargo lies in "progress" toward an Arab-Israeli peace agreement, but the chances are that it will be the middle of the winter before any substantial progress can be made.

The stock market has turn bled as though it were forecasting a major recession or even a depression. But the economists have kept their cool, forecasting nothing worse than slower growth in the national economy.

Stock prices continued to decline yesterday in what some Wall Streeters - shrouded in gloom-have tagged "the energy-crisis bear market." But the setback was modest when compared to Monday's drastic drop that wiped away 29 points on the Dow-Jones industrials in the worst break since 1962.
The United States Air Force flew 22,300 tons of military equipment, ammunition spare parts and medical supplies to Israel from Oct. 13 to Nov. 14.
President Nixon said today that evidence indicated the nation was "now on the way to winning the battle" against narcotics and drug abuse.

Harry B. Helmsley, one of the nation's biggest real estate developers, and his wife, Leona, were stabbed by an intruder in their Palm Beach, Fla., penthouse early Sunday morning, Mr. Helmsley said last night.

They hung a plaque for Eugene O'Neill on Broadway yesterday, and they hung it exactly one block from where they were supposed to do it. They did it in rain and drizzle, and while they did, people stopped and stared.

Arthur Conte, former director of France's state-owned radio and television system, was barred last night from appearing on French television screens where he was to have talked about his memoirs of his one-year tenure.
In the third week of its "operation tl candor," the White House finds itself mired, once again in contradictory stories and growing incredulity.

The formalization last month of the February devaluation of the dollar had the effect of increasing the dollar value of United States monetary reserves by more than $1.4-billion, the Treasury disclosed today. For example, the dollar value of the nation's gold stock rose to $11.65-billion in October from $10.49-billion in September.

Six masked Basque separatists armed with submachine guns held more than 100 persons inside a suburban yacht club last night, doused the floor with gasoline and set the building afire, police officials said today.
Delta Air Lines yesterday, announced a major expansion of operations and said it would add 300 reservation and clerical workers to its work force between now and mid-1974.
About 500 university students clashed with 200 clubswinging riot policemen here today as several anti Government demonstrations were held in various parts of the capital.

Japan and the Philippines have been exempted from the next scheduled reduction of 5 per cent in exports of Arab petroleum, the secretary of the Arab League, Mahmoud Riad, announced here tonight after a session of the Arab summit conference here.

A former Nixon Administration official has testified that Henry A. Kissinger precluded his access to sensitive national security information three days before the official's telephone was tapped under a secret program that President Nixon has defended as necessary to halt leaks of such information.

The head of the Government agency that inspects national banks testified today that he had tried to stop the Securities and Exchange Commission from taking legal action against the bank controlled by President Nixon's
Flight controllers indefinitely postponed further maneuvers of Skylab 3 today because of an unexplained high consumption of the thruster gas that stabilizes the space laboratory.
Tornadoes and torrential rain swept across Tennessee, Alabama and northern Mississippi yesterday, killing three persons and injuring more than 100 others.
The House voted today to put the nation on year-round daylight saving time for the first time since World War II in a move to conserve energy. The tally was 311 to 88.

Tom Bradley, the Mayor of Los Angeles and a graduate of the University of California, Los Angeles; said yesterday he would root for Southern California, U.C.L.A.'s crosstown rival, in the Rose Bowl game against Ohio State.

The United States Steel Corportion said late yesterday that it was seeking price increases of "about 6 1/2 per cent" on a long list of items. The giant steelmaker said that under Phase 4 regulations it had filed notice of its proposed price increases with the Internal Revenue Service.

The Environmental Protection Agency recommended today that legal limits on emissions of nitrogen oxides from automobiles be raised to a level five times that decreed by Congress for vehicles produced after 1976.

Twelve senior members of the staff of the Brooklyn Museum last night told the institution's 35-member governing committee that they supported the administration of their controversial director, Duncan F. Cameron.

Bargaining talks continued into the night as negotiators for the New York Philharmonic and Local 802 of the Americar Federation of Musicians sought yesterday to arrive at a con tract agreement that could be presented for a vote tonight by the orchestra's 106 striking musicians.

What is a cherry orchard without its cherries, or a Neil Simon without his New York? The answer was to be found last night at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, where Mr. Simon's play, "The Good Doctor," had its first performance.
The RCA Corporation announced yesterday its entry into the manufacture of private telephone exchange equipment with a new system that uses large-scale integrated circuits.

Adrian P. Burke, the senior associate judge on New York State's highest court, was appointed yesterday by Mayorelect Abraham D. Beame to be New York City's corporation counsel, one of the handful of top jobs in his administration.
The Vietcong today boycotted a meeting with South Vietnamese military negotiators in protest against what they charged was the bombing of a Communistcontrolled town on Friday.
United Air Lines said yesterday that it was laying off almost 1,000 employes, including 300 pilots, because of flight backs resulting from jet-fuel shortages.

ACLI International, Inc., a large commodity-trading concern specializing in cocoa, rubber, sugar, coffee and shrimp, announced today an expansion of its commodity-futures services business through its subsidiary, ACLI International Commodity Services, Inc.

Improperly refrigerated custard prepared by a Lisbon catering concern caused an acute illness that struck 247 passengers on three trans-Atlantic flights, according to the National Center for Disease Control. The illness, staphylococcal food poisoning, Oct. 10
Mayor Lindsay dedicated four new police stations yesterday in what, in effect, was his summation of enormous change in police work that has taken place during his eight years.

The city's Parking Violations Bureau will put into effect today a plan through which holders of millions of dollars worth of unpaid parking tickets will be hit where the bureau hopes it hurts-in their credit ratings.
A leading Jewish scientist who was denied permission to emigrate to Israel has challenged the Soviet Union's assertion that its emigration policy is an internal matter.

President Nixon signed into law today the Emergency Petroleum Allocation Act of 1973, a bill his Administration had opposed for many months. The bill requires the President to establish within 30 days supply-management,
A five-man commission today began investigating the causes of Israel's severe setbacks on the Syrian and Egyptian fronts during the first days of the latest war.

Four city marshals have lost their jobs and a process server his license as a result of an investigation into the "sewer service" of eviction papers and other legal documents, Investigation Commissioner Nicholas Scoppetta announced yesterday.

The presiding judge of the Essex County Court today ordered the rents in the Stella Wright public housing project reduced by 80 per cent because of multiple abuses and said that if they could not be corrected the huge development should be demolished.

Long before Richard Nicolls laid out America's first formal race course on Long Island, the practice of sticking a needle into a horse was frowned upon by the better element of livery stable society. We live in an era of change, however. Today reputable men of science are using needles on horses for purposes that the stuffiest steward of The Jockey Club would applaud.

Heavy selling of soybean futures continued yesterday, dropping prices the 20-cents-abushel limit in all positions on the Chicago Board of Trade. Soybean meal prices also dedined the daily limit. The meal is a high protein cattle feed.
