Fernando Valenti has long been identified with the harpsicord sonatas of Domenico Scarlatti. He made a heroic stab at recording them complete for Westminster in the nineteen-fifties,
Despite the security hazards of big-payoff exotic wagers, Roosevelt Raceway and the Offtrack Betting Corporation hope to introduce a new gimmick next month.

Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, gave assurances today that his office "is vigorously pursuing" an investigation into allegations of wrongdoing, including possible '"improper" White House influence, in "the I.T.T. matter.
The constitutionality of New York State's civil obscenity statute was upheld yesterday in a unanimous opinion of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

The Medical Examiner's office here is controversially involved in a New Jersey murder case, The New York Times has learned, because it severed the head of a woman who was believed to have drowned in the East River, buried her body in potter's field and discovered only by chance a week later that the head contained a bulet hole.

Another neighborhood is being lost in New Yorkthe Yorkville area around East 86th Street, The rapid erosion of the quality and character of one of the city's more interesting ethnic sections that has always served a strong neighborhood life is cause for citywide as well as local concern.
Delta Air Lines yesterday, announced a major expansion of operations and said it would add 300 reservation' and clerical workers to its work force between now and mid-1974.
More allegations of criminal violations, mismanagement and White House pressure were made today at the opening session of public Congressional hearings on the Small Business Administration.
The Food and Drug Administration warned today that two health food products made with parts of apricot pits contain a poison that could kill adults and children.

Richard J. Vizzini, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, said yesterday that he and the union's executive board had received what he described as "an overwhelming vote of confidence" at a special meeting of firemen at Manhattan Center.

The Alvin Ailey City Center Dance Theater's threeweek season got off to a flying start last night with the kind of spectacular production usually associated with a company such as the New York City Opera rather than a modern-dance group.

DETROIT-The trouble with cars, to adapt the old saying, is that you can't live with them or without them. We in Detroit are told that we produce, an extravagant luxury that can no longer be tolerated. We are admonished, on the other hand, not to push up the price of one of life's necessities.
Mrs. Flora Tansy Conrad, widow of Charles W. Conrad, who had been president of Conrad Young, Inc., an engineering consultant firm, died today at Phillips House in Boston. Her age was 83.

Japan and the Philippines have been exempted from the next scheduled reduction of 5 per cent in exports of Arab petroleum, the secretary of the Arab League, Mahmoud Riad, announced here tonight after a session of the Arab summit conference here.
The Senate interior Committee approved today a $20billion research and development program designed to Ni make the United States selfsufficient in energy over the Next 10 years.

The Senate approved today legislation that would revolutionize the financing of campaigns for the Presidency and Congress by requiring that public funds, rather than private donations, pay for all elections to these offices.
The Belgian Government, in what appeared to be a reaction to pressure from Arab oil cutbacks, called today for Israel to withdraw from all territories occupied in the 1967 war.

All but two of the Englewood General Hospital's 38 resident doctors and internes were subpoenaed by their own attorney today to appear in a case in which the group is attempting to gain recognition as a collective-bargaining unit for the institution's medical staff.
A spokesman for the Pittsburgh Steelers disclosed today that No. 2 quarterback, Terry Hanratty, played -the last five weeks with two broken ribs.
" I don't know what they did with the furniture, but I'm sure that whatever's there will be adequate. I'll take the pieces as they are. I'm not much on furniture-my emphasis is on work."

During its four years, the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, under Woodie King's direction, has introduced a number of provocative new plays and playwrights. Because of its record of accomplishment, this valuable company should be allowed an occasional offnight,
Leonid I. Brezhney and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi expressed their resolve today to solidify the links between the Soviet Union and India.
Ellsworth Bunker, now an Ambassador at Large, began a week of conferences today with Panamanian leaders on the possibility of a new Panama Canal treaty.

A copy of the tape recording of President Nixon's June 20, 1972, conversation with H. R. Haldeman-the conversation in which Mr. Nixon ordered "public renations" actions to be taken in the wake of the Watergate fo break-in three 'days earlierwas played in Federal District Court here today.

Are there any goals left this year for Jack Nicklaus? The big fellow took a swing with his driver to cut a ribbon that marked the official opening of a golf hotel here today, and then answered the question.

The Frick Collection has abandoned its plan for eventual construction of a wing to the east of its museum site at Fifth Avenue and 70th Street, and instead will create a permanent garden and terrace on the space earmarked for the wing.
The Philadelphia Freedoms of World Team Tennis signed a three-year lease today with the Spectrum.

The state's major County Executives were enlisted yesterday in Governor Rockefeller's drive to reverse Nixon Administration opposition to subsidizing local transit fares.

Spokesmen for the nation's major contractors, after meeting with steel-company executives today, warned that a large shortfall in structural steel anticipated for next year would cause economic havoc in the construction industry.
The Dutch jumbo jet that was hijacked by Arabs over Iraq Sunday night landed early today in this Persian Gulf sheikdom, its sixth stop so far.
Denying any wrongdoing, Senator Edward J. Gurney, Republican of Florida, said today that he would fight allegations that he benefitted from a slush fund raised by Florida home in builders.
The Senate approved today, 92 to 3, the nomination of Gerald Rudolph Ford of Michigan as the 40th Vice President of the United States.

In a new step toward the elimination of most price and wage controls, the Cost of Living Council granted an exemption today to producers of cement, a key material in construction and industrial expansion.

United States foreign trade registered another large surplus in October as exports continued to boom, the Commerce Department reported today. The surplus of exports over Imports last month was $527.1million, less than in September but otherwise a far better trade performance than was typical in recent years.

Operations of Litton Industries, Inc., for the first fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31 resulted in a 16 per cent increase in earnings on a sales gain of 5.9 per cent, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

An Eastern Airlines DC-9, unable to stop after landing at the Akron-Canton Airport, ran off the end of a runway and crashed last night. At least 24 persons were reported injured. In Chattanooga, a Delta Airlines DC-9 jet with 77 persons aboard, attempting an instrument landing in a thunderstorm, crashed, broke apart and caught fire. Nine persons were injured.

John Kennedy, president of Stereotypers Local No. 1, announced yesterday that his union had reached tentative agreements with The Daily News and The New York Times, but was still without a settlement with The New York Post.

Mrs. Kathryn Young Brewer, a former art teacher and the wife of George E. Brewer, director of Standards and Purchase for New York State, died Saturday at the Mary McClellan Hospital here. She was 71 years old and lived in Albany.

Higher quarterly profits were reported yesterday by three retailers-the F. W. Woolworth Company, the Allied Stores Corporation and Hughes Hatcher, Inc. Two others, J. W. Mays, Inc., and Bond Industries, Inc., reported declines.

Minority group organizations - Hispanic, Oriental and American Indian, as well as black -have been exerting pressure on television stations in various parts of the country to ban from the air, or substantially edit, hundreds of motion pictures that they consider racially offensive.

Benny Goodman, the "king of swing" during the nineteen-thirties and forties, came to New York City yesterday to preview a biographical exhibit and visit with some former musical cronies at the New York Jazz Museum.

CHATTANOOGA-At 1:35 P.M. last Saturday, 25 minutes before game time, fewer than a dozen people were on the sidewalk outside the University of Tennessee at Chattanooga football stadium and a friend of the school was trying to give away a fistfull of tickets. There was no traffic on Vine Street, no one hawking pennants or programs and no one was in line at the only ticket window.

Dr. Robert Branner, professor of art history and archeology at Columbia University and an authority on French Gothic architecture, sculpture and manuscript painting, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of complications following heart surgery.

The new Greek leadership, moving to generate public support, today began releasing students and others jailed in the demonstrations and riots against President George Papadopoulos before his ouster on Sunday.

Somewhere between the Mesozoic Era and outer space, the American Museum of Natural History is putting up a sign of the times-a decorated Christmas tree that relies more on the power of creativity than it does on electrical energy. For six weeks now, Alice Gray of the museum staff has been leading nearly 100 volunteers (a few at a time) in the Japanese art of origami, or paper folding.

Although it tries occasionally, television is rarely shocking. The American Broadcasting Company accomplished that feat on Monday evening with an A.B.C. News Close-Up called "Fire!" The shocks were delivered on two entirely different levels.

The Hudson's Bay Company said yesterday it had received commitments that would permit it to purchase at $19 a share more than 50 per cent of all the outstanding shares of Markborough Properties, Ltd., of Toronto and shares issuable under purchase warrants.
House-Senate Conterees agreed today on a home-rule bill for Washington, D.C., that would set aside a national capital enclave hut give the rest of the city substantial local government.

The New Jersey Turnpike, the first high-speed toll road in the country to reduce its speed limit to 50 miles an hour as a fuel conservation measure on Nov. 8, increased it today to 55 miles an hour. Its previous maximum speed limit had been 60 miles an hour.

BOSTON-There is, sadly, no more Boston Evening Transcript. Nor is there a Boston Advertiser, American, Daily News, Daily Times, Herald, Herald-Traveler, Journal, Pilot, Post. Record, Record-American, Traveller or Sunday Courier.

Mayor - elect Abraham D. Beame will announce today the appointments of David Dinkins, who was the first black president of the Board of Elections, and Judah Gribetz, former Buildings Commissioner under Mayor Robert F. Wagner as Deputy Mayors in the newly organized administration.

The presiding judge of the EssexCounty Court today ordered the rents in the Stella Wright public housing project reduced by 80 per cent because of multiple abuses and said that if they could not be corrected the huge development should be demolished.

The Atomic Energy Commission announced today that it wanted to relax and eventually remove restrictions on uranium enrichment, the process which converts natural uranium into material that can be used as nuclear energy fuel.

Last week, in the wake of largescale student demonstrations against his Government, President George Papadopoulos slept in a bed set up in his, offices in the heavily guarded old palace in the center of Athens.
A Federal judge demanded an explanation yesterday of how and why newsmen were allowed to accompany Federal and local agents in a massive roundup of suspected major narcotics dealers last spring.
The state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner agreed yesterday to permit the Consolidated Edison Company to burn coal in two of its generating plants here.
The former Protestant Prime Minister, Brian Faulkner, today announced the names of the five members of the Unionist party who will join him in the new coalition government of Northern Ireland.

Tom Riker and Wilt Chamberlain are coming back to New York tonight. Riker will try to lend a helping hand to the Knicks, who are battered by injuries, and Chamberlain will be making his New York area coaching debut when his San Diego Conquistadors of the American Basketball Association meet the Nets on Long Island.
Three robbers who invaded an East Side apartment early yesterday seriously wounded a 56-year-old man and escaped with an undetermined amount of money and some clothing.
A repairman here is asking the Federal Cost of Living Council to investigate the 30 per cent salary increase the Legislature has approved for Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne.
A spokesman for the Pittsburgh Steelers disclosed today that No. 2 quarterback, Terry Hanratty, played the last five weeks with two broken ribs.

The criticism leveled by the White House against special prosecutor Leon Jaworski for allegedly leaking to the press information unfavorable to the President's cause conjures up visions of the fate that befell Archibald Cox. Viewed against the background of Mr. Cox's dismissal, the complaint by deputy Presidential press secretary Gerald L. Warren contains unmistakable suggestions of intimidation.
Bobby Schmautz notched his ninth goal of the season tonight to give the Vancouver Canucks a 2-2 tie with the St. Louis Blues.
RIYADH, Saudi ArabiaSheik Ahmed Zaki al-Yamani, Saudi Arabia's Minister of Petroleum, admits unabashedly in Arab company that he likes Americans, among whom he has studied and worked for many years.

Chesterfield Smith, president of the American Bar Association, said today that Richard Nixon's "continued right to the Presidency" should be decided through a Congressional impeachment investigation as the only legal forum that could resolve deep national doubt about his guilt or innocence.
The General Motors Council of the United Automobile Workers voted overwhelming approval tonight for a tentative national contract covering 415,000 employes.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange fell again yesterday as volume dropped slightly. Prices also fell in the overthe-counter market in steppedup trading.
The Navy's controversial Project Sanguine, a billion-dollar underground radio transmitting system for sending messages to missile submarines, has received still another setback.

She had won the New Jersey State championship sixtimes, the New Jersey State Women's Golf Association championship 11 times and the Metropolitan women's title five times.
Joseph J. Sisco, the State Department's top official on Mideast affairs, is expected to leave the Government soon to accept a college presidency, a well-placed Administration official said today.

Motorists who run out of gasoline on the weekend got encouraging words, with qualifications, today from the American Automobile Association. "We will tow people who run out of gas to a safe place," said Lamar Phillips, local manager of the A.A.A. office.

Un happy partisans of the University of Michigan took the Big Ten Conference to Federal Court today in an effort to overturn the conference's decision to send Ohio State to the Rose Bowl instead of Michigan.

The Mobil Oil Corporation announced yesterday it was "mothballing" its 47,000-barrel-a-day refinery in East Chicago, Ind. The action was one of the first signs that the Arab oil embargo of the United States was beginning to affect operations of American oil companies.
Pravda came up with a new wrinkle in the energy crisis today: The Soviet Union is losing 10 million tons of badly needed coal every year because wind is blowing it out of open railroad cars.

Trading was quiet and prices mixed yesterday in the corporate and tax-exempt bond markets as dealers and investors began assessing several new offerings. The Government market was ahead in early trading but did not close at its best levels.

The Dec. 4 issue of Saturday Review/World out today is printed half on its regular coated stock and half on uncoated textbook stock. In a box inside, Norman Cousins, the editor, apologizes for the two-tone look and asks his many loyal readers to help him find a new reliable source of paper.
Overlooked in the hullabaloo surrounding Joe Namath's return last Sunday was the return of Al Atkinson, the New York Jets' middle linebacker.

Mrs. Irene Lawler Crimmins, wife of James Kershaw Crimmins, a senior partner in the law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside Wolff, died yesterday in Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived on Vineyard Lane in Greenwich.

John Barry Ryan 3d, a partner in Kuhn, Loeb, the investment banking firm, arrived here Sunday and headed for the Plaza Athenee Hotel. As the car approached the Avenue Montaigne, he noticed a larger than usual cluster of gendarmes.
The rubber-bridge player, unlike his tournament counterpart, feels joy and gloom according to the strength or weakness of his hand.

Last week, in the wake of largescale student demonstrations against his Government, President George Papadopoulos slept in a bed set up in his offices in the heavily guarded old palace in the center of Athens.

The Medical Examiner's office here is controversially involved in a New Jersey murder case, The New York Times has learned, because it severed the head of a woman who was believed to have drowned in the East River, buried her body in potter's field and discovered only by chance a week later that the head contained a bulet hole.
United Air Lines said yesterday that it was laying off almost 1,000 employes, including 300 pilots, because of flight cutbacks resulting from jet-fuel shortages.

GENERAL Beyond the Best Interests of the Child by Joseph Goldstein, Anna Freud and Albert J. Solnit (Free Press, $7.95; paperbound, $1.95). A review of the child placement laws. Encounter with Anthropology by Robin Fox (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $8.95).
Despite the security hazards of big-payoff exotic wagers, Roosevelt Raceway and the Offtrack Betting Corporation hope to introduce a new gimmick next month.

The state's Environmental Conservation Commissioner agreed yesterday to permit the Consolidated Edison Company to burn coal in two of its generating plants here. The decision-which also relaxes sulphur requirements for fuel oil burned in the citybrings the state into direct

Conceding that it may be asking too much of the football players it recruits, the United States Military Academy indicated today it was planning to change future schedules to make them more "realistic."
The Defense Department, faced with an inability to buy sufficient oil from American producers, has taken the first step in commandeering oil supplies for the armed services.

The New Jersey Turnpike, the first high-speed toll road in the country to reduce its speed limit to 50 miles an hour as a fuel conservation measure on Nov. 8, increased it today to 55 miles an hour. Its previous maximum speed limit had been 60 miles an hour.

The Milwaukee Bucks withstood 16 straight points by the Buffalo Braves in the second half tonight and got some clutch plays by Lucius Allen in the final minute for a 115-110 National Basketball Association victory.

The separation of his parents and ultimate divorce as seen through the eyes of a child are projected with intelligence and restraint in today's "Afterschool "Special," for youngsters, at 4:30 over the American Broadcasting Company TV network.

The Lindsay administration's last two major building projects cleared the final hurdle yesterday when the City Council approved funds for the renovation of Yankee Stadium and the start of construction of the West Side convention center.

To the Editor: There is a natural economic (as distinct from political) response to the Middle East oil restrictions. The freemarket price of oil, which restricts demand to the available supply, is the appropriate price for every user to pay. Anyone who pays less will use more, forcing others to use less even though they need it more.

The White House said yesterday that it had never sought to limit an investigation of a $300,000 heroin smuggling operation after Federal investigators were told by an informant that Robert L. Vesco was to have provided the firancing.
The Senate approved today, 92 to 3, the nomination of Gerald Rudolph Ford of Michigan as the 40th Vice President of United States.

Governor Rockefeller heaped praise on Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame at a formal banquet last night and then went jovially on to mangle a prepared speech with wisecracks and asides that brought guffaws from the 1,000 business and civic leaders in his audience.
An American missionary of the Roman Catholic Maryknoll order, who has worked among Filipino peasants, was charged today with acts against the martial-law Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos.
" There are times when I wish we had black drapes--on all 87,200 windows," Richard Ehmann, operations manager of the World Trade Center, said wryly yesterday.

Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Dayan has raised a. serious challenge to efforts to promote a negotiated Middle East peace settlement with his renewed call for retention of substantial portions of the occupied Arab territories.

Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne announced here tonight that he and the New York Football Giants had reached complete agreement on the club's planned move to a new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands.
The United States Steel Corportion said late yesterday that it was seeking price increases of "about 6 1/2 per cent" on a long list of items.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has won conditional approval to build a $40-million office complex on 200 acres in Bedminster Township for the national headquarters of its Long Lines Division. The Planning Board of the township, which is in Somerset County, voted to approve the complex pending compliance with 14 conditions. A spokesman for A.T. said it had agreed to an conditions.
Christmas-giving does not have to be a trauma or a crass commercial venture. It can fulfill the human desire to give without making the giving an orgy of useless or earth-destroying things.
A local hospital and a surgeon who admitted performing at least 37 unnecessary back operations were ordered today to pay a former patient now dying of cancer $3.7-million in damages.

The strike blanket that has shrouded New York City's cultural scene this fall shows signs of lifting. Musicians at the New York Philharmonic, away from Avery Fisher Hall for two months, are scheduled to vote tonight on a modified contract offer that may well represent the last chance to salvage their shattered concert season.

ACLI International, Inc., a large commodity-trading concern specializing in cocoa, rubber, sugar, coffee and shrimp, announced today an expansion of its commodity-futures services business through its subsidiary.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame will announce today the appointments of David Dinkins, who was the first black president of the Board of Elections, and Judah Gribetz, former Buildings Commissioner under Mayor Robert F. Wagner, as Deputy Mayors in the newly organized administration.
What are contemporary Hurngarian composers doing? The Budapest Symphony Orchestra, playing in Carnegie Hall on Monday night; provided a partial answer in Andras Szollosy's "Musica per orchestra."

The M. W. Kellogg Company, a division of Pullman, Inc., announced in Houston yesterday that it had received five contracts from China for the construction of large-scale ammonia plants valued at a total of $130-million.

Dick Cavett has accepted the take-it- or- leave- it offer from the American Broadcasting Company for a reduced schedule of broadcasts next year. His new one-year contract calls for 26 programs, or one every other week.

The city's Parking Violations Bureau will put into effect today a plan through which holders of millions of dollars worth of unpaid parking tickets will be hit where the bureau hopes it hurts--in their credit ratings.
Bolivia's principal political party announced today that it had decided to withdraw from the military-led coalition Cabinet, which President Hugo Banzer Suarez shuffled last night.
The House voted today to put the nation on year-round daylight saving time for the first time since World War II in a move to conserve energy. The tally was 311 to 88.

LONDON - During a visit to the Chinese People's Republic, I started my columns by recalling the advice of Father Teilhard de Chardin to a Shanghai friend: "Write about China before you have been there too long; later you would break your pen."

Four novels worth your attention: Small may be the literary pretensions of Pete Hamill's "The Gift" (83 pages; Random House; $4.95) and small its physical dimensions (it's really more a short story than a novel); but except for its slightly flabby ending, its impact on our feelings is large. The time is Christmas, 1952;
Campaign committees that helped Abraham D. Beame raise funds for the Nov. 6 mayoral election reported yesterday a surplus of $45,000 for the closing days of the race.

William B. Dale, the United States executive director of the International Monetary Fund, has been named to a five-year term as deputy managing director of the fund. His appointment was announced yesterday by H. Johannes Witteveen of the Netherlands, who has been managing director since September.

The audience pelted Maria Callas with flowers when she made her London "comeback," after an eight-year absence, in Royal Festival Hall. Many in the crowd of 3,000 swept toward the stage like teen-agers at a rock concert, once the two-hour performance was over, and they tried to grab her and they blew kisses at the 50-year-old sonrano.

Former Attorney General Elliot L. Richardson said tonight that he had made it clear to White House officials on two occasions that he would be forced to resign. if they went through with efforts to dismiss Archibald Cox.

LONDON - During a visit to the Chinese People's Republic, I started my columns by recalling the advice of Father Teilhard de Chardin to a Shanghai friend: "Write about China before you have been there too long; later you would break your pen."

Four novels worth your attention: Small may be the literary pretensions of Pete Hamill's "The Gift" (83 pages; Random House; $4.95) and small its physical dimensions (it's really more a short story than a novel); but except for its slightly flabby ending, its impact on our feelings is large. The time is Christmas, 1952;
The White House indicated today that the Presidential yacht Sequoia would be temoprarily mothballed to conserve fuel, but that President Nixon would continue to travel "when it's necessary."

The Food and Drug Administration claimed today a major achievement in reducing human exposures to cancer-causing substances called aflatoxins that sometimes contaminate peanuts and some other food products.

At least a dozen members of the champion Miami Dolphins would jump to the proposed World Football League if it got off the ground and could pay higher salaries, according to Doug Swift, the Dolphin linebacker. "A dozen to 15 if they had the money," said Swift.

Spokesmen for the nation's major contractors, after meeting with steel-company executives today, warned that a large shortfall in structural steel anticipated for next year would cause economic havoc in the construction industry.

Perseverance paid off handsomely for the New York Islanders tonight. Refusing to sit on a one-goal lead with a period to play against Atlanta, the New Yorkers kept the pressure on, scored two more goals and put out the Flames, 4-2, at Nassau Coliseum.
The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended Nov. 20:

Sandra Genter and Judith Schmukler presented a pleasantly easygoing evening of new dances for themselves and seven other dancers, all women, at the Cubiculo on Tuesday night. Even the few moments of obligatory angst seemed good-humored.
Prices of many basic commodities rose sharply yesterday because commodity traders were influenced by the rising stock prices reflected by the Dow-Jones industrial average.

Mrs. Mary Axelson Cropper was being sought by the police today for questioning about the death of her 82-year-old mother, Mrs. Mary McDougal Axelson, a playwright and artist, who was beaten in a hospital room.

Major R. Owens, the city's Commissioner of Community Development, yesterday demanded Federal and other investigations of what he called "corruption and conflicts of interest" in the Brownsville local school and antipoverty programs and of the use of teachers union funds.

A Gallup survey released yesterday found that 51 per cent of those persons interviewed believe that unidentified flying objects, sometimes called "flying saucers," are real and not just a figment of the imagination or cases of hallucination.
With the energy outlook appearing grimmer by the day school officials around the nation are striving with increasing urgency to conserve energy and to keep the schools open.

The October war has changed the military and political landscape of the Middle East. Some of the most important changes, in the Egyptian view, occurred in the relations among Arab nations and among Arab leaders.

The tape recorder that President Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, has testified she used to transcribe a conversation of June 20, 1972, between the President and his former chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman, has built-in protections against inadvertent erasures.
Extensive promotions in the top management ranks of The New York Times Company, effestive immediately, were approved by the board of directors and announced yesterday.

LUNCH BREAK The new show at Theater at Noon, the midday series at St. Peter's Center, 16 East 56th Street (753-4669), is called "A Day in the Port Authority." It's a comedy by Gloria Gonzalez, performed by Ann Hodapp and Tony Lang, and has nothing much to do with the big bistate agency except that it is set in its bus terminal.
The Democrats plan to hold their 1974 miniconvention in Kansas City, Mo., and a formal decision is expected within two weeks, party sources said today.
Flash thrusts in the dawn hours yesterday in the city and Nassau and Suffolk Counties resulted in the serving of 90 known gamblers with "massive tax bills."

Superior Court Judge George B. Gelman today approved a settlement that calls for an election to decide whether a group of 27 internes and residents can represent Englewood General Hospital's in-house medical staff as a collectivebargaining unit.
The Houston Rockets beat the Knicks, 114-106, . last night in a game of strange happenings at Madison Square Garden.
Adam Trepel, who at one time owned 27 florist shops in Brooklyn and Manhattan, died Tuesday at his home, 1 St Paul's Court, Brooklyn. He was 90 years old and had retired 20 years ago.

Mayor Lindsay ordered an inquiry yesterday into the unusual circumstances surrounding the severing of a dead woman's head by the Medical Examiner's office before a bullet hole was accidentally found in the head.

United States Magistrate Jerome D. Schwitzer of Interlaken, whose career as a Federal legal official spanned more than 20 years, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his chambers here. He was 65 years old.
House Democratic leaders announced today that legislation for the reform of private pension programs would not be brought to the floor until January.

The tape recorder that President Nixon's personal secretary, Rose Mary Woods, has testified she used to transcribe a conversation of June 20, 1972, between the President and his former chief of staff, H. R. Haldeman, has built-in protections against inadvertent erasures.

The home of an assistant special Watergate prosecutor, Jill Volner, was burglarized yesterday, but both the Police Department and the office of the special prosecutor, Leon Jaworski, said today that the robbery was routine.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not make such a report available this week.

Corporate bond prices were mixed again yesterday in quiet trading. Attention still was focused on several large new offerings. Tax-exempt issues were down slightly and the Government market was mixed in advance of the Treasury's auction of tax-anticipation notes.

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame officially named David N. Dinkins yesterday as a Deputy Mayor, an appointment seen by prominent black figures as one of the most significant movements by blacks into the upper echelons of municipal power in this city's history.
The new Greek leadership told the nation tonight that it would rule indefinitely by decree until it felt that the people were prepared for elections.

Impeachment is at dne and the same time a political and a legal process. The Constitution specifies the legal grounds, however vaguely, as "treason, bribery or other high crimes and misdemeanors." It also recognizes the political nature of the process by designating Congress as the special court to institute and adjudge the impeachment proceedings.

Government officials are stepping up efforts to generate electricity from garbage as oil supplies dwindle, but the first power from garbage is not expected to flow here for at least two and a half years.
A group calling itself the Broward County Marijuana Dealers Association pitched in yesterday to help a bank here raise funds to pay for a child's heart operation.

The America-Israel Cultural Foundation, a strong supporter of the arts in Israel and of cultural interaction between the two countries, presented the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra in a benefit concert at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night.

The British Broadcasting Corporation's five-part dramatization of Emile Zola's "Nana," considered too sexually explicit for networking on the Public Broadcasting Service, has been purchased on pooled funds by four public television stations, including New York's WNETTV/Channel 13.
President Nixon proposed es today, in a special message to Congress, that 12 areas embracing more than a million acres be added to the National Wilderness Preservation System.

Flamenco guitar playing is in its rococo phase, and Paco de Lucia stands out as one of the more accomplished practitioners of this declining art. Like other recently fledged virtuosos, he specializes in solo recitals (the older flamenco guitarist was part of an ensemble of dancers and singers and only played solos as occasional relief so the others could catch their breaths).
According to Earl L. Butz, Secretary of Agriculture, news about Watergate "will be less than a paragraph-a mere footnote-in the pages of history."
Supreme Court justice William O. Douglas said last night that the current energy crisis had been caused by powerful corporate lobbies.

Dr. Leonard Tushnet, a writer who was a physician, died at his home here today at the age of 65. Dr. Tushnet produced "To Die With Honor," "The Uses of Adversity" and "The Medicine Men." Of the last-named, a reviewer in The New York Times Book Review commented: "He has written what

An original provision of the Constitution bars any member of the House or Senate from appointment to a Federal office "which shall have been created, or the emoluments whereof shall have been increased" during the member's term.

The management of Chessie System, Inc., which owns the Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio Railroads, said yesterday it had "flatly reject ed" an offer of "certain individuals" who had indicated their interest in acquiring control of the $2.5-billion holding company.

Senator Hubert H. Humphrey of Minnesota has been asked to tell under oath whether he received a $50,000 political contribution from Howard R. Hughes in 1968, allegedly delivered by a former Hughes aide, Robert A. Maheu.
At the United States Open in 1946 in Pittsburgh, an unknown woodpusher appreached the late Herman Steiner between rounds and asked to be taught how to play a variation of the Two Knights' Defense.
An undercover man for the Government has alleged that loan officers from many of the country's leading banks are involved in stolen-stock schemes.
The tiny unmanned spacecraft Pioneer 10 today began to plumb the mysteries of the giant planet Jupiter as it appeared to report back a magnetic field of a shape never seen on earth.

As the pro football season nears its end, evidence is accumulating that abolition of the television blackout of sold-out home games has proved a mixed blessing for showing of those it was intended to help: showing of the home viewers.

American League baseball officials are studying ways the nation's energy shortage may affect airline travel by clubs and the scheduling of night games. Bob Holbrook, executive assistant to Joe Cronin, American League president, said today, "What we have to do is plan now and prepare the options."

The 420,000- hourly employes of the General Motors Corporation began voting today on a new three-year contract as union leaders predicted major layoffs in the coming year because of slumping sales of large model cars.
The Government of Argentinal denied today published reports that it had granted a permanent resident visa to Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive United States financier.
People may be more dietconscious every day, but furniture seems to be getting fatter. At least Angelo Donghia's is.
Makers of decorative Christmas lights said yesterday that they were threatened with extinction because of President Nixon's proposed ban on outdoor Christmas lighting.
The Administration is moving toward rationing of gasoline, although no formal decision to take such a step has so far been made, energy planners in two Federal agencies said today.
One of President Nixon's attorneys testified in Federal District Court here today that there were a "number" of blank sections lasting several minutes each on subpoenaed White House tape recordings.

Lucille Rose, the city's Commissioner of Employment, applauded the New York Telephone Company yesterday for being the first private enterprise to take graduates of the city's new Work Relief Employment Project on its regular staff.

Mrs. Sylvia Eastman Welch, widow of Prof. Roy Dickinson Welch who organized the music department at Princeton University, died Saturday in a Princeton, N.J., nursing home. She was 80 years old and had a summer home at Eastville on Martha's Vineyard.
Rodney Dangerfield, the comedian, is always griping that "I don't get no respect." In much the same spirit, the small investor is always complaining that nobody loves him.

The Metropolitan Opera's severe financial crisis has forced it to plan for a sharp reduction of its New York seasons, to cancel the fourweek June Festival of 1975 and to work toward cutting the company's annual employment contracts from a full 52 weeks to between 40 and 44 weeks.
He straightened up after clearing the doorway from his plane ramp at La Guardia Airport yesterday, and as he walked into the bright light of the terminal people stopped and just stared. Up.

An investigator for a House subcommittee dealing with small-business matters has testified during public hearings in Washington that the "White House tried to get the SmallBusiness Administration to burn its files" on Dr. Thomas W. Matthew.

In a gym on West 61st Street, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar became famous as Lew Alcindor. As a star at Power Memorial Academy, he developed into one of the most sought-after high school basketball players. Now, almost a decade later, the good players still go to Power.

ROBERT FROST ON WRITING. By Elaine Barry. 188 pages. Rutgers University Press. $7.50. I find Robert Frost's statements about poetry fully as poetic as his poems. In fact, I feel that some of them are even more poetic. This is not to be taken as a disparaging of the poems.

An undercover agent has told Senate investigators that, despite White House denials, he made "perhaps 10 or 15" telephone calls to the White House last July in an effort to alert staffers there to the halting of a narcotics investigation after it led to Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier.

S. William Green, regional administrator of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development, today vigorously attacked a court order reducing rents in the Stella Wright housing project here by 80 per cent and suggesting that the project be razed if multiple housing violations could not be corrected.

Dr. Joan P. Giles, research associate professor of pediatrics at the New York University School of Medicine, died yesterday of cancer at the Presbyterian Hospital. She was 54 years old and lived at 134 Brightwood Avenue, Westfield, N. J., with her husband, Frederick Giles, an engineer.
Harry Ferleger, retired executive director of the board of the Philadelphia Civic Center and Museum, which he served from 1955 to 1972, died today in Hahneman Hospital. He was 60 years old.
LUNCH BREAK The new show at Theater at Noon, the midday series at St. Peter's Center, 16 East 56th Street (753-4669), is called "A Day in the Port Authority."

Hayes Redmon, a former assistant press secretary to President Johnson, died here yesterday. He was 42 years old. After serving with the Johnson Administration, Mr. Redmon was an assistant to Dr. Edwin H. Land, head of the Polaroid Corporation.

Continuing resistance to desegregation has led to the suspensions or expulsion of "extraordinarily large and disproportionate numbers" of blacks from Southern schools, two civil rights groups charged today.

The economy next year will be in a no-growth position or a recession, depending on the severity of fuel cuts, E. F. Andrews, chairman of the business-survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Management, Inc., said yesterday.
Three Palestinian gunmen yesterday surrendered the Dutch jumbo jet they hijacked over Iraq Sunday night and in return for safe-conduct guarantees freed the last 11 hostages they were holding.
Investors staged the greatest gold rush today since the dollar crisis last July, bidding the metal up nearly $10 an ounce to $101 in London and Zurich and forcing a new record for gold coins here.
The Cities Service Company, one of the country's major oil companies, announced yesterday that it would move its corporate headquarters from the city to Tulsa, Okla., next summer.

Al Bumbry, a 26-year-old Vietnam veteran who had a .337 batting average, hit seven home runs and drove in 34 runs for the Baltimore Orioles, yesterday was named the American League's rookie of the year. He received 131/2

North Korea said today that it would agree under certain conditions to a South Korean proposal to resume next month the suspended Red Cross talks for family reunions. But the conditions were termed unacceptable by South Korea.

She takes the floor of the House of Representatives less often these days, and when she does, her words flow more slowly and more softly. She works more quietly in committees, introduces fewer amendments and takes an unaccustomed back seat in some important legislative battles.

These have been distracting days for Gabe Paul, president of the New York Yankees. He's been having considerable difficulty in getting work done because he has kept staring at his telephone in hypnotic fascination The only phone call that could break the spell would be one from Joe Cronin, the president of the American League.
Food prices in the city last week rose 1.3 per cent above the previous week's for the largest increase since mid-August, when the Federal freeze on most meat prices was lifted.

It was a family occasior Tuesday night in Tully Hall Yehudi Wyner performed his own piano compositions and those of his father, Lazal Weiner, while Susan Daven ny Wyner (Yehudi's wife) sang a sampling of songs by botl father and son. Finally, as ar encore, Mr. Weiner took over a' the keyboard to accompany hi! daughter-in-law.

The history of Hollywood film-making is studded with examples of bad taste and shoddy exploitation of popular stereotypes. The motion picture industry, in virtually every era, turned out too many films which chased after box-office profits by catering to the lowest common denominator of the audience.

The former head of the Philadelphia regional office of the Small Business Administration declared before a House subcommittee today that he would not be "the fall guy" for loan activities in the agency's Richmond office that are under scrutiny.
James F. Burns Jr., senior vice president of Harris Upham Co., investment brokers, died Monday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home, 1339 York Avenue, His age was 71, and he lived at 29 East 64th Street.

A report to be issued next month by the National Commission on the Reform of Secondary Education will urge that the nation's high schools make their curriculums and attendance requirements more flexible.

Legislation containing the state's 'moral pledge" to back the bonds needed to finance the $280-million sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands is expected to pass the State Senate tomorrow, legislative leaders said today.
Following are the results of the $3 - billion tax-anticipation bills offered by the United States Treasury in a competitive sale today:

An agreement in principle was announced yesterday for the sale of the assets of the music-publishing companies of Metromedia, Inc., to The New York Times Music Corporation, a subsidiary of The New York Times Company.

Bill Russell and K. C. Jones don't get no respect. A few weeks ago Russell, the new coach of the Seattle SuperSonics, returned for the first time to Boston Garden where he had for so long been a star as a player and player-coach. The Celtics walloped his club.

A strike of 225 hospital workers at the Helene Fuld Memorial Hospital here is now in its 10th. week, and shows no sign of being resolved, according to hospital and union spokesmen.
Morris H. Klein, a retired sales and manufacturing executive of Sandoz Colors and Chemical Company in Hanover, N.J., died of a heart attack today in a hospital here. He was 76 years old.

Chile said today she would ask the Soviet Union to pay $200,000 for not sending its soccer team here' for a World Cup elimination game. The Russians refused in protest against the over throw of the Marxist Allende regime.
The traditional Christmas tree at Rockefeller Plaza will be lighted on Dec. 6 - but with what has been described as a minimum amount of electricity.

Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident atomic physicist, posed a new challenge to Soviet authorities today by asserting that he objected to further interrogations of his wife and took "entire responsibility" for her refusal to appear.
A new Government board is needed to preserve the capital markets, the chairman of the Securities Industry Association said here today.

The State Commission of Investigation called yesterday for immediate remedial action to "reshape and revitalize" the Police Department in Albany, where charges of alleged corruption and ineffective leadership were aired at recent hearings.

If Jay H. Reichbach, director of the North American Wilderness Survival School, has his way, youngsters interested in hunting or fishing will learn how to live in the woods without need of rifles or rods.

Stepping out ahead of a large field of candidates, Homer D. Babbidge of New Haven, former president of the University of Connecticut, announced tonight that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor at the party's convention in June.

A 26-story faculty-apartment building for Rockefeller University will rise between 62d and 63d Streets on York Avenue, adding a 16th building to the university's 15-acre campus along the East River. Construction on the $9.3million edifice will begin immediately and will be completed by June, 1975.

What's the state of the Atlantic alliance, now that the reality of a Mideast war has called all the rhetorical bluffs?

A Long Island automobile salesman said that he told a Federal grand jury yesterday that an Internal Revenue Service agent had asked him testify falsely against Justice Dominic S. Rinaldi of the State Supreme Court, who is under indictment.

The Brazilian domination of South American bridge continues, and seems likely to continue. Earlier this month in Rio de Janeiro, six young Brazilians captured the South American title for the seventh straight year, and did so in convincing style.

George Auerbach, a stage and film writer and producer who was currently a consultant to the American Broadcasting Company, died of a heart attack in Exeter (N. H.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Kittery Point, Me.
The first nuclear power plant in Yugoslavia will be built by Westinghouse Electric Corporation, it was announced today.

Striking musicians last night ratified a new three-year contract with the New York Philharmonic Society, ending a 10-week walkout that had compelled the orchestra to cancel all performances since Sept. 25.

Pete Mahovlich and Guy Lapointe scored twice apiece for Montreal during its fivegoal opening period tonight to help the Canadiens celebrate Frank Mahovlich Night with a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Kings.

The egg has fallen on hard times, primarily the victim of anticholesterol admonitions that this year will help to push annual egg consumption in this country below 300 per person for the first time since 1935.
The Senate approved today a bill designed to remove a con stitutional barrier to the nomination of, Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio to be Attorney General.
" Catholics," a 90-minute production being presented on the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight at 9, is Brian Moore's television adaptation of his own highly acclaimed novella.

With the easy part of their schedule out of the way, the New York Giants started today to get down to the business of dealing with the three tough opponents remaining: Washington, Los Angeles and Minnesota, in that order. All three are leading their divisions and are playoff-bound.
International showed that leader, Mike Mansfield, today urged an expansion of rail passenger service to help alleviate transportation problems created by the energy shortage.
Fred S. Weitzner, a lawyer long active in the real estate field and a past president of the Building Industry league, died yesterday at his home, 215 East. 68th Street. He was 71 years old.
Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton gave his approval today for initial experimental development of the Federal Government's vast oil shale deposits in the Western states.

Insulation has ranked high as a way to save on home heating costs and on fuel expenditures, yet more than two-thirds of the 45 million homes in the United States do not have proper insulation, according to George J. Haufler, executive vice president of the Certain-teed Products Corporation, a company that sells insulation material.
The Belgian National Bank raised its discount rate today from 7 to 7.75 percent, effective tomorrow. The bank said it was raising only its basic rate, leaving other rates unchanged.
Richard G. Kleindienst has been ordered by a Federal judge to testify in the trial, of seven persons accused of smuggling eight ounces of LSD into San Diego County.

Robert J. McKim, former board chairman of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, died on Tuesday in St. Luke's Hospital, apparently following a coronary occlusion. He was 78 years old and lived in Lake Wales, Fla.
Heavy Mayonnaise, a colt who had been in claiming races only recently, is now regarded as one of the foremost campaigners among 2year-olds as a result of winning the Remsen at Aqueduct yesterday.

Diplomats reported today that the nine member countries of the European Common Market were secretly drafting a "European identity paper" to be issued as a declaration next month at a meeting of heads of governments.

Noble Wejover is rated as the 5-2 favorite in tonight's $15,000 Bridgeport Trot. The 4-year-old was assigned the outside post in a field of six yesterday, by the racing secretary, Ed Parker. In his last start, Noble Wejover left from the No. 8 slot and breezed to a comfortable 21/2 length victory.

An examiner for the State to Department of Motor Vehicles as here was indicted yesterday on sla charges of having fraudulently approved forged applications for drivers' licenses by ineligible convicts or persons with physical defects.

A New York dentist has for mulated a hypothesis he thinks could explain why some people brush their teeth regularly and still have gum diseases, while others are irregular about brushing but do not develop such disorders.

Federal. authorities investigating possible widespread corruption in Bergen County announced yesterday the indictment of former Mayor Eugene J. Santoli of Woodcliff Lake on charges that he had extorted $22,000. Mr. Santoli, 46 years old, who was Mayor of the affluent borough from 1966 to 1970, was charged with shaking down two contractors on a major borough sewer system project and extorting $10,000 from an engineering concern retained by the borough,
A former Brazilian state Congressman who is a son of American missionaries was arrested here in early September and has since disappeared.

The United States and the Soviet Union have reportedly agreed that the Arab-Israeli peace negotiations should begin next month without the participation of Palestinian representatives. According to a well-informed diplomat in Washington, only Israel, Egypt, Syria and Jordan have been invited to the conference by the two big powers,

The New York State Education Commissioner has directed the city's Board of Education immediately to place all students diagnosed as handicapped in public school classes or private schools under contract with the board.

Between appointments yesterday, David Norman Dinkins, the newly appointed Deputy Mayor for Planning, paused in his hectic schedule to settle into a phone booth, remove his jacket and spend nearly an hour on the telephone returning business calls and making appointments.
Mikhaill A. Suslov, the Communist party's chief ideologist, is touring Lithuania in an official show of Soviet solidarity with the sometimes troublesome Baltic republic.
International showed that leader, Mike Mansiield, today urged an expansion of rail passenger service to help alleviate transportation problems created by the energy shortage.
Ray J. Marini, who heads the state office responsible for warning drivers about speeding and other vehicle violations, was found guilty today of speeding on the Jersey Turnpike last month.
Three men were killed last night as guerrillas believed to be members of the illegal Irish Republican Army blocked 90 roads and rail lines in all of Northern Ireland's six counties.

The Boothe Computer Corporation, the financially troubled computer leasing concern, whose proposed acquisition by a subsidiary of the Flying Tiger Corporation was mutually terminated on Monday, reduced its loss in the three and nine months ended Sept. 30.

The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy showed a slight upturn in October, based on preliminary figures, after a large drop in September, the Commerce Department reported today.

New Jersey's Governor-elect, Brendan T. Byrne, met this afternoon with Gov. Milton J. Shapp to explore the possibility of working out a system of tax reciprocity for individuals living in either state and being taxed on earnings in the other.

Following, in unofficial translation from the French, is the text of tile declaration by the meeting of Aral heads of state that concluded here today: The kings and chiefs of Arab states met in the Algiers Palace of Nations Nov. 26-28, 1973, at the suggestion of Mohammed Anwar el-Sadat, President of the Egyptian Arab Republic, and Hafez elAssad, President of the Syrian Arab Republic.
A tentative agreement was reached late yesterday that was expected to end the 10week-old musicians' strike that had forced the New York Philharmonic to cancel all its performances since Sept. 25.
President Nixon plans to release information about his personal finances that will lay to rest misconceptions and allegations of unethical conduct, the White House said today.
There are two aspects of Mike Adamle's physical appearance that are at once striking and repeatedly prompt two questions: q From football fans in general: Aren't you too small to play pro football?
One of President Nixon's attorneys testified in Federal District Court here today that there were a "number" of blank sections lasting several minutes each on subpoenaed White House tape recordings.

A group of parents of patients in state mental institutions met yesterday with representatives of business and city and state governments to ask support for a plan for the care and rehabilitation of patients once they are discharged.
The Japanese Government reacted cau tiously today to an Arab reprieve on 5 per cent cut in oil deliveries that had been scheduled for December.
Westchester County's first Democratic County Executive, Mayor Alfred P. Del Bello of Yonkers, reached next door today to fill the No. 2 post of executive officer in his new administration.

Profits of three retail merchandisers declined in the third fiscal quarter and nine months ended Oct. 31, according to their reports issued yesterday. They were the McCrory Corporation, the Zayre Corporation and L. S. Good Co.

The conflicting orders issued by state and city environmental authorities on what fuel Consolidated Edison can and cannot burn in the energy crisis threaten to push New York City into a blackout by bureaucracy. The city's Environmental Protection Administration has prohibited Con Ed from converting to coal, the dirtiest of fuels, but it has authorized the utility to burn oil with sulphur content as high as 3 per cent, ten times the old maximum.

To the Editor: The great majority of our people seem convinced on the facts to date that President Nixon has been guilty of serious misdeeds. Rightly, they believe that he is not above the law and should be made to answer for them.

Some people, before buying a dog, carefully research the various breeds. If they decide on one, they go to a dog show where they can see the animal and speak to the owners. With others, it's chance. Mrs. Ben Nolan Dale

The Bahamian Government announced plans today to nationalize the islands' three casinos by January, 1976. Deputy Prime Minister Arthur D. Hanna said in Parliament that after January, 1976, all casinos would "be wholly owned and controlled by the Government."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28--The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed that Arab-Israeli peace negotiations should begin next month without the participation of Palestinian representatives, a well-informed diplomat said today.

Jack Nicklaus, back on the pro tour after a sevenweek absence, tied for 22d place today as Grier Jones and Larry Wise led the openround of the $150,000 Walt Disney World golf classic with 67's. five under par.
The maritime industry expressed confidence here yesterday that it would be able to maintain adequate services despite reduced fuel allocations.
Leaders of the House and Senate apparently reached agreement today to reduce dramatically the scope of the campaignfinancing bill that was passed by the Senate yesterday.

A Soviet official said tonight that the talks here between Leonid I. Brezhnev and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi would lead to a "qualitatively new and positive advancement of relations between India and the Soviet Union."
An autopsy completed today disclosed that a 21-year-old C. W. Post College student from Westchester County died in his dormitory room in Greenvale from an overdose of drugs.
The Interior Department has disclosed plans to nearly double acreage in the national park system by carving out 10 new parks in Alaska.

Carter Group, Inc., announced yesterday it anticipated making a merger proposal to its 51 per cent-owned subsidiary, the Utilities Industries Corporation, under which each shareholder of Utilities Industries would receive $35 a share in cash.

The California Supreme Court adopted today a redistricting plan that may increase the Democratic majority in the United States House of Representatives and is expected to put many state legislative incumbents out of office.

The Metropolitan Opera's severe financial crisis has forced to plan for a sharp reduction of its New York seasons, to cancel the fourweek June Festival of 1975 and to work toward cutting the company's annual employment contracts from a full 52 weeks to between 40 and 44 weeks.

The city's Board of Education voted last night to take over Harlem Prep as of Feb. 1. It also agreed to settle out of court a series of suits by teachers dismissed in the early nineteen-fifties during investigations into Communist influences
The trial of W. A. Boyle former president of the United Mine Workers who has been charged with conspiracy in the murder of Joseph A. Yablonski, a union insurgent, has been set for Feb. 25.

After more than a century of erosion, the food scene in America is a dreary moonscape. Yet there is life, for an outpouring of books about food shows that many Americans know that something delicious is missing from their lives.

In a room where body heat and sweaters provided the warmth, and only 4 of 55 overhead lighting fixtures--along with eight windows cleared of their drapes - provided the light, a group of building owners and managers yesterday began to learn how to save electricity and steam to counter the energy crisis.
Heavy Mayonnaise, a colt who had been in claiming races only recently, is now regarded as one of the foremost campaigners among 2year-olds as a result of winning the Remsen at Aqueduct yesterday.
A judge, jury, defendant, lawyers and court officers spent half an hour in a two-car subway train re-enacting the slaying of a porter.
Many New Yorkers donned light clothing yesterday as warm, muggy weather-which the National Weather Service attributed to conditions that usually prevail in July-moved into the area.

Another letter bomb, the fourth in two days, was intercepted here today without causing any damage, a police spokesman said.
Daimler Benz became today the third West German automobile manufacturer to announce short-time shifts in some of its commercial-vehicle plants because of fewer orders.

Negotiators for the New York City Ballet said last night that they would recommend to their directors cancellation of the entire 14-week fall season if they did not have a new contract with their union musicians by next Thursday.
The Nigerian Government has accepted a record offer of $16.40 a barrel for its oil, informed sources said today. The offer was understood to have been made by a number of oil companies.

Lillian Reis, the former showgirl, has been released on $2,500 bond after ending her battle against extradition to Philadelphia to face charges of firearms violations, loan sharking and handling stolen property.
Other major steel producers almost certainly will follow the United States Steel Corporation in seeking higher prices for a long list of items, steel industry sources said yesterday.

Carter Group, Inc., announced yesterday it anticipated making a merger proposal to its 51 per cent-owned subsidiary, the Utilities Industries Corporation, under which each shareholder of Utilities Industries would receive $35 a share in cash.
Stock prices rose sharply esterday in what Wall Street analysts called a technical rebound-in the absence of any compelling news developments -after the huge sell-off of the last five weeks.

While much of the central United States is expected to have a mild winter, helping to conserve scarce fuel, the prospects for the Eastern Seaboard are a toss-up, according to a long-range forecast made public yesterday by the National Weather Service.

About 1,500 workers, representing a half dozen unions, demonstrated in front of Concord Fabrics, Inc., 1411 Broadway, near 40th Street, yesterday charging that the company had dismissed about 80 employes at its North Bergen, N. J., warehouse and transferred the operations to the South.

The Civil Aeronautics Board warned- the public yesterday to expect difficult traveling conditions during the Christmas holidays because of the growing number of flight cancellations caused by jet fuel shortages.

A man and a woman were arrested in their homes in the Ozone Park section of Queens last night and charged with bottling hundreds of tiny bottles of ersatz Chanel No. 5 perfume, apparently to be sold during the Christmas season, the police said.

The two-day drop in prices on the American Stock Exchange was halted yesterday by a spirited afternoon rally that enabled them to close considerably higher. Prices in the overthe-counter market were also up.

It flashed suddenly and brilliantly onto the nation's television screens six months ago, but now the Senate Watergate Committee is fading from sight like a comet on an awesome yet brief circuit across the light sky.
A plan to set aside ample radio frequencies for emergency medical service networks all over the country was made public today by the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy.

The governing committee of the Brooklyn Museum has set Dec. 11 for what could be the ultimate confrontation between the museum's controversial director, Duncan F. Cameron and the group of critical for mer staff members who contend that he has been a divisive force at the institution.

The Senate approved today an amendment to a pending Social Security bill that would expand benefits under the Medicare program to include payment for prescription drugs that are needed for chronic illnesses by persons who are not hospitalized. The Medicare program

Anti-Government demonstrations by South Korean university students continued for the third day today with nearly 5,000 students participating in six protests here. The largest action took place at Ewha Women's University in the western section of this capital, where 4,000 students demonstrated for five and a half hours on a street outside the school gate.

The country music industry was shaken today by the second slaying of an entertainer in less than a month. James P. Widener, 55 years old, rhythm guitarist for Hank Snow's band, and a California woman were found shot to death in an alley late yesterday.

The State Education Commissioner, in what one local school official called "a historic decision," has directed the Board of Education immediately to place all students with diagnosed handicaps in appropriate public school classes or private schools at public expense.

PRINCETON, N. J.-Prompted to look back, it now seems to me splendid how the strict rationing in wartime Britain cleared the streets. The only traffic people in a small town saw was a bus or a taxi, a van or two, a doctor's or a farmer's car, a dispatch rider's motor bicycle or an odd convoy of lorries.

The city's Environmental Protection Administration said yesterday that it had received private assurances from the Federal Government that when emergency national fuel-allocation priorities were established, New York would be one of the first cities to get any available low-sulphur fuels and would be one of the last to be asked to burn coal for energy.
Faced with the possibility of a Government-enforced blackout, the billboard operators of America are being asked by their industry association voluntarily to cut energy use by 25 per cent.

In the first action in Congress to ease the impact of legislation limiting automobile emissions, the Senate Public Works Committee voted today to delay from 1976 to 1977 the starting date for meeting the most severe antipollution standards.

In one of the more anticlimactic events of the diplomatic season, the United Nations General Assembly has wisely deferred for yet another year any change in the old Korean armistice arrangements. This month's debate on the issue, the first in three years, turned into a perfunctory affair instead of the anticipated Communistled assault on the continuing presence of a United Nations Command in South Korea and its garrison of 40,000 United States troops.

The days pass and although President Juan D. Peron was supposed to be back at Government House, he remained at his suburban mansion, dressed in his dark satin bathrobe recuperating from what has officially been described as a "bronchial condition."

Mayor-elect Abraham D. Became officially named David N. Dinkins yesterday as a Deputy Mayor, an appointment seen by prominent black figures as one of the most significant movements by blacks into the upper echelons of municipal power in this city's history.

Paul S. Mirabito, executive vice president of the Burroughs Corporation, has been named president of the business-machine company. He succeeds Ray W. Macdonald, who was appointed to the vacant post of chairman and continues as chief executive officer.
When snow covers the ground and the bare bones of trees are stark against leaden skies, there is much pleasure to be had in attractin song birds about the house with one or more feedina stations.
The Administration is moving toward rationing of gasoline, although no formal decision to take such a step has so far been made, energy planners in two Federal agencies said today.

The 16th annual Christmas bazaar that opens here tomorrow is, like the town, observing the edict against the decorative lighting that, for as long as most people here can remember, has been a hallmark of the holiday season.

Administration officials say they are uncertain about the political future of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian chief of state, as a result of recent maneuvering within the Cambodian insurgent movement opposed to the Government of President Lon Ncl.

The Soviet press published its first direct criticism of France today for having derided collaboration between Washington and Moscow and for having advocated tighter coordination in Western Euorope on political and defense policies.

A group of students staged a brief demonstration in the administration building at Ramapo College here today to seek mediation of their request for more financial assistance, student employment and other improvements.
The House approved today a compromise overhaul of Federal manpower programs, ending a long battle with the Nixon Administration over the legislation.

The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed that ArabIsraeli peace negotiations should begin next month without the participation of Palestinian representatives, a wellinformed diplomat said today.
A fire raged out of control in a crowded department store today, and the police reported that 40 persons had been killed and 28 had been injured.

The war has not gone away, but Phnom Penh is enjoying-if that is the word-a brief respite from the tension of recent months. No one expects it to last much longer; everyone expects another offensive by the Communist-led insurgents in a few weeks.

The purchase of the San Diego Padres by a group headed by Mrs. Marjorie (Marji) Lindheimer Everett will be voted on next Thurs day by the National League club owners at their annual winter meetings in Houston.
The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged Canadian Javelin, Ltd., the embattled minerals development company, and its two principal officers with stock fraud.

The Egyptian-Israeli military talks being held on the Cairo-Suez road broke down in disagreement today, and no date for a new meeting was set. Each side said it had no new proposals to make and could not accept the proposals made previously by the other side, according to authoritative sources.
The commoditty spot market price index of foodstuff and industrial materials rose to 195.9 from 194.1 last week. The index compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics stood it 122.9 on Nov. 28, 1972.

The 785-foot Norwegian tanker Iddi, the world's largest when it was built eight years ago but soon superseded by a succession of supertankers, discharged 429,388 barrels here yesterday of low-sulphur oil, one of the largest such cargoes ever to reach the United States.

George Linden, who retired as a New York Times linotype operator in 1961 after 40 years of service, died Tuesday at the Jewish Memorial Hospital. His age was 83, and he lived at 598 West 191st Street.

Nine tape machines that were used for recording President Nixon's White House conversations have been surrendered to Chief District Judge John J. Sirica's court, at the request of the special Watergate prosecutor's staff.
The Justice Department has turned over to the office of Leon Jaworski, the special Watergate prosecutor, documents on milk industry contributions to President Nixon's re-election campaign.

With some of its most prominent members pointing toward New York and shouting, "We're No. I," the State Senate voted overwhelmingly here this evening to put the state's moral credit behind the financing of a new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands.
The New York Post and New York Stereotypers Union No. 1 reached agreement last night on contract terms, according to Sidney Orenstein, labor relations counsel to The Post.

The late Elmer Layden, when he was commissioner of the National Football League, didn't consider it worth an answer when asked what he thought of an embryo called the All-America Conference. "Let them get a football first," he said. Inside five years the newcomers had several footballs and some of Layden's employers had lost their shirts. The N.F.L. hollered uncle.

The Boise Cascade Corporalion announced yesterday a $ 1.1-billion capital expenditure program to be carried out over a period of five years. The program will also utilize $100million of carryover expenditures from previous years.

E. Howard Hunt Jr., one of seven men convicted in the Watergate burglary and bugging, has been transferred from a Federal detention center in the Washington area to the Federal prison camp in Allenwood, Pa., a spokesman for the United States Marshal Service said today.

The White House bitterly attacked the staff of the special Watergate prosecutor today, charging that it has displayed an "ingrained suspicion and visceral dislike for this President and this Administration."
Battle lines were being drawn yesterday for a renewal of one of the critical battles in baseball-over the future of the controversial 10th man, the designated hitter.
Workers virtually shut down the Caribbean island of Grenada today in a general strike to protest tactics of Premier Eric Gairy. The strike was called by several unions and professional organizations,
Randel Plastics, Inc., of Long Island City used to have 95 persons on its payroll. Last week there were only 48.
West German officials are fearful of a major recession next year if the current oil crisis intensifies, and say the signs of a downturn are already becoming apparent.
The Philadelphia Flyers, also known as "The Broad Street Bullies," rallied in the closing minutes of the third period tonight to tie the New York Rangers, 2-2.

Despite a hint that the White House is prepared to modify its long-standing opposition to Federal transit operating subsidies, Governor Rockefeller and Mayorelect Beame face an uphill battle in Washington today in their bid to win Federal assistance to save the 35-cent subway fare.

An eleventh-hour reluctance to commit at least nine years of their young lives to the military turned a number of good football players away from Army in recent years-players who might have contributed to a better 1973 Army season than the dismal 0-9 won-lost record so far.

Burt Smith, the athletic director at Michigan State University, told M.S.U. fans at a football dinner Wednesday night that he had voted to send Ohio State to the Rose Bowl because, "it was my opinion that Ohio State best met the definition of the "most representative team."
Three South Africans shared the lead today in the South African open golf tournament as Tom Weiskopf of the United States moved up to fourth place.

One day after saying he was "tired of guys sounding off about who's playing and who's not playing," Alex Webster, the New York Giants' coach, suspended Charlie Evans, his unhappy fullback, indefinitely for "conduct detrimental to the club."

The commanding officer of the Police Department's 107th Precinct, in the Fresh Meadows section of Queens, has been relieved of his command and transferred because of official dissatisfaction over the growth of crime in the area.
President Nixon's former appointments secretary, Dwight L. Chapin, was indicted today on four counts of perjury in the Watergate scandals.

Fire and smoke stampeded thousands of panicky shoppers in a department store here today and the police said more than 100 were killed and 100 injured in the worst such blaze in Japan's history. Casualties were expected to mount.

The head of the Richmond office of the Small Business Administration told a House subcommittee today how he incurred almost $500,000 in financial obligations, much of it with banks doing business with his office during the time his office has been accused of possible questionable loan activities.
The body of the pilot of a light plane was recovered from its wreckage on Moose Mountain today about a half mile from the 1968 crash site of a jet that took 32 lives.
Fewer than 100 persons have called the National Broadcasting Company to ask about the New York television blackout of the JetsBaltimore Colts game at Shea Stadium on Sunday.

Civil rights organizations said today they were intent on blocking the Sugar Bowl on New Year's Eve, possibly with sit-ins or other disruptive actions, unless its sponsors desegregated their organization. The president of the New Orleans Mid-Winter Sports Association, sponsor of the Sugar Bowl, said he had no immediate comment on the threat.

It is becoming increasingly apparent that if viruses do cause cancer in people, the culprits are not unusual viruses that infect only some people. Rather, leading researchers believe, they are extremely common viruses that infect many, if not most, people, but only rarely result in cancer.
