Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame and Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne of New Jersey met here yesterday and agreed that Mr. Beame should be permitted to name one of the members of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The Federal Reserve may have initiated a vigorous expansion of the nation's credit supply, spurred by energy shortages that have made an economic downturn more likely next year.
Leoid I. Brezhnev, on the eve of is departure for Moscow, called tonight for "a thorough nd comprehensive discussion" f an Asian collective security lan.

An Administration official expressed cautious optimism today that a convention establishing a global 12-mile territrial sea limit would emerge from a United Nations conference next summer that 148 nations are expected to attend.
A school for emotionally disturbed boys, on the first four floors of a new luxury apartment building on the Upper East Side, was dedicated to Robert F. Kennedy yesterday.
Israeli forces remained on full alert on all fronts today, and Israeli officials expressed deep concern about the possibility of a renewal of fighting.

Black Oak Arkansas's investment of a year ago is having an unexpected payoff. The Black Oak members, one of the hardest working and most-traveled rock bands, bought a Greyhound bus and converted it into a home for themselves, deciding to make all their concerts by road and in as much comfort as possible.

Former Attorney. General Richard G. Kleindienst testified today that he had signed a paper authorizing a wiretap in an LSD case.

Brig. Gen. Hugh Llewelyn Glyn Hughes, a physician whose British Second Army liberated the notorious Bergen-Belsen Nazi death camp in World ban War II, died Sunday in London at the age of 81, according to word received here yesterday.

Since the start of the Arab oil embargo against the Netherlands a month ago, the Socialist-led Dutch Government has managed to keep the support of the proIsrael Dutch public while gently moving toward the demands of the Arab oil producers.

The New Jersey college basketball coaches met today for the first time this season. They didn't have much to say because their teams haven't played yet, except for Wynn Phillips of Union, who has a 1-0 won-lost record. Some haven't settled on their starters, others already have problems.

Herbert Stein, Chairman, of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, forecast today that unemployment would approach 6 per cent next year-but not exceed that figure-partly because of the fuel shortage
The British Government has announced a five-year program to modernize the nationalized railway system, mainly at the expense of urban road building.

Pioneer 10, the first spacecraft to navigate the outer solar system, hurtled deep into the magnetic field of Jupiter tonight and found the field's reach to be greater than expected, its strength 40 times that of the earth's magnetic field and its direction south instead of north.

Jacques Offenbach, the hero of the boulevards, "the Mozart of the Champs-Elysdes," composed exactly 100 operettas and one serious opera. It is, of course, the serious opera that the Metropolitan Opera is staging, in a new production. And the production is built around Joan Sutherland, who will be singing the four female roles in "The Tales of Hoffmann."

Government scientists announced today the first identifiction of the virus that causes infectious hepatitis, one of the most important known infectious diseases for which the causative agent has eluded science.

An elderly man jumped from the middle deck of a Staten Island ferryboat yesterday and disappeared, the police reported. They said the man, who appeared to be about 60, jumped from the ferryboat, the Herbert H. Lehman, shortly after it left the St. George terminal, bound for Manhattan. Two crewmen said they saw him jump shortly before 5 P.M.

A state commission set up by Governor Rockefeller presented yesterday what it called a major new proposal to give tax relief to apartment tenants-and the commission was immediately accused by a State Senate leader of offering the public "rewarmed hash."
J. Fred Buzhardt, Jr. conceded today that the official White House explanation of the 18minute gap in a Watergate tape recording was not a certainty but instead. "just a possibility."

The Egyptian-Israeli military talks on troop disengagement broke down in disagreement, and the two sides exchanged heavy machine-gun and mortar fire less than two miles from the conference site on the Suez-Cairo road. No new talks were scheduled.

There's very little that John Chapman wants, only $10-million or so. The Canadian harness driver, who performed at Yonkers last night, is leaving for California this morning to drive Delmonica Hanover in the American Trotting Classic at Hollywood Park tonight,

Rabbi Isaac J. Asseo, who had led the Sephardic Center of the Mapleton section of Brooklyn, 2143 65th Street, since 1961, died, apparently of a heart attack, in Maimonides Hospital on Tuesday. He was 78 years old and lived at the synagogue.

Dr. Thomas W. Matthew yesterday said he had no knowledge of alleged attempts by the Whit House to get the Small Business Administration to "burn its files" on him.
Because of the oil situation, the United States faces a critical shortage of penicillin, cortisone and other vital drugs, an industry spokesman said yesterday.

The top financial officials of the United States, France, Britain, West Germany and Japan holed up last weekend in a chateau south of Tours in the Loire Valley for secret talks on monetary matters. Precisely what they decided-if anything-remains a secret, although Secretary of the Treasury Shultz has disclosed that their discussions ranged over long-term reform of the world monetary system, the energy crisis and the dollar's recovery in value on foreign exchange markets.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that despite reports of a breakdown in the ArabIsraeli military talks, he was still hopeful that a Middle East peace conference would begin next month.

Reports that military talks between Israel and Egypt had collapsed handed the stock market a mild setback yesterday in a seesaw session. Gold issues continued to perform as the market's strongest group.

The three Arab guerrillas who hijacked a Dutch jumbo jet and spent 68 hours in search of sanctuary in the Middle East and the eastern Mediterranean were reported still in this Persian Gulf sheikdom today.
It's advisable to telephone theaters for schedules and prices before going to the show. Most, if not all, theaters accept Theater Development Fund vouchers.
The British Petroleum Company, Ltd., reported yesterday that its earnings in the third quarter rose by 483 per cent to $204-million, a record.
George Sperry Hier Zahm, president of Bantam U.S. Toys, Inc., of New York City and Port Chester, died here yesterday in the United Hospital. His age was 64, and he lived in Larchmont.
Andrei D. Sakharov, the dissident Soviet physicist, disclosed today that he had begun his application procedure to go to the united States to accept a teaching offer at Princeton University.
The State Senate today gave final legislative approval to a bill permitting conventional home mortgage interest rates to be raised from the current limit of 8 per cent to as high as 9 1/2 per cent.
A convicted Watergate burglar, Frank Sturgis, was found guilty today on Federal charges of conspiracy and transportation of stolen automobiles to Mexico in 1968.

John N. Nassikas, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission, said today that the nation's consumption and production of electric power must be cut by an average of 10 per cent, and perhaps more in regions like the Northeast where the oil shortage threatens to be most acute.
A special legislative corn mission has reached bipartisan agreement for a substantial overhaul of the state laws governing political campaign financing.

New York enthusiasts have have three opportunities annually to compete in major tournaments in Manhattan. The third of them is the Winter Regional of the Greater New York Bridge Association beginning today at the New York Hilton.

A pothole cost the city $150,000 yesterday in the settlement of a damage suit in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. James A. Williams, 41 years old, of Brooklyn, who sustained neck fractures and internal injuries when his rented car struck the depression on Covert Street, had sued the city for $500,000.

Willie Long and Warren Jabali combined to score 50 points. and sparked a second-half surge that carried the Denver Rockets past the Indiana Pacers, 127-111, in an American Basketball Association game tonight.

LONDON-How one thinks about the situation in the Middle East-and particularly the Arab oil embargo-largely depends on one's point of vantage. The Arabs justify the embargo as a reasonable response to our hostile action in airlifting military supplies to their enemy during recent hostilities.
Melvin Laird said today that he planned to resign as President Nixon's chief domestic adviser after Representative Gerald R. Ford got final Congressional approval and assumed the VicePresidency.
The Rev. Dr. G. Adolph Zeltner, a retired Episcopal minister, died Wednesday at the Good Samaritan Hospital here. He was 77 years old and lived at 22 Forest Drive.
Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame yesterday named Stanley M. Friedman, 37-year-old associate counsel to the City Council's majority leader, as his legislative representative in Albany.
John Dabney Penick, a Wall Street investment banker for 45 years, died yesterday at his home, 275 Bradford Avenue. He was 66 years old and lived also in Watch Hill, R.I.

The State Department has been examining whether President Nixon could legally order a resumption of United States bombing in Indochina should North Vietnam begin a major offensive in violation of the Vietnam cease-fire agreement.

Mayor- elect Abraham D. Beame and Governor-elect Brendan T. Byrne of New Jersey met here yesterday and agreed that Mr. Beame should be permitted to name one of the members of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
The rise in prices of stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange and in the over-thecounter market that took place on Wednesday proved shortlived. Prices fell on both marts yesterday.
Occasionally, when a brokerage firm focuses on some narrow area of investment activity, it throws light on a broader aspect of the stock market.

The Soviet press today accused Bobby Fischer, the 30-year-old world chess champion, of reneging on a promise of a rematch with the man he dethroned, Boris Spassky, and charged that the American grandmaster was motivated only by "money, money and money."

Fred Apostoli, who formally won the world middleweight boxing title in November, 1938, after defeating two other champions in the same class in controversial fights earlier that same year, died after a heart attack in his office today. He was 59 years old.

The state announced graduated increases in payments for foster-child care. "The increases for the first time take into consideration the accelerating costs of maintenance as the child's age increases," said Frederick A. Schenck, director of the Division of Youth and Family Services.
Anna Pavlova, by Oleg Kerensky (Dutton, $6.95). A biography of the ballerina. Colette: The Difficulty of Loving, a biography by Margaret Crosland (Bobbs-Merrill, $8.95).

PAPERWORK The Archives of American Art is a bureau of the Smithsonian Institution. It stocks documents for use by academicians and writers doing research into original records, personal letters, sketchbooks and other documents of American artists, critics, collectors, dealers, museums, anyone or thing with involvement in art in America.

Bayreuth is not the only place where opera is given as though darkness covers the face of the earth. The new production of Offenbach's "Tales of Hoffmann," unveiled last night at the Metropolitan Opera, is a curiously moody setting.

Teresa Brewer, making her first appearance in New York in 15 years, is surrounded by a remarkable array of diversions at the Rainbow Grill. There is Bobby Hackett, giving her lovely backing with his cornet on a couple of old ballads.

A $110,000 health-screening unit consisting of a fully equipped medical van was turned over to the Timothy Still Memorial Health Center today along with a check for $20,000 from the Warner-Lambert Company.

The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed today a rule change to clarify financial obligations of brokers and dealers.

The Federal Communications Commission yesterday voted to ease regulations that, since 1971, have restricted the three television networks to three hours each night in the prime viewing hours of 7 to 11 P.M.

Alvin Ailey is in trouble. One would not know it from the way his company is dancing and one would certainly not know it from the enthusiastic audiences that are crowding City Center's 55th Street Theater.
Tom Hamilton, athletic director and baseball coach at St Edward's University in Austin, lied today at Tyler Medical center. He was 48 years old and had suffered a cerebral ??emorrhage last Friday.

The burning of a baby's plastic crib was demonstrated Wednesday night on Channel 13's program "The 51st State," even though an Indiana judge had barred the American Broadcasting Company from showing a similar demonstration on a network documentary broadcast nationwide Monday night.
Three men were arrested tonight after a shootoutt with police officers searching for the killer of a country and western musician in Nashville.

Pioneer 10, the first spacecraft to navigate the outer solar system, hurtled deep into the magnetic field of Jupiter tonight and found the field's reach to be greater than expected, its strength 40 times that of the earth's magnetic field and its direction south instead of north.

One day after saying he was "tired of guys sounding off about who's playing and who's not playing," Alex Webster, the New York Giants' coach, suspended Charlie Evans, his unhappy fullback, indefinitely for "conduct detrimental to the club."

Burt Smith, the athletic director at Michigan State University, told M.S.U. fans at a football dinner Wednesday night that he had voted to send Ohio State to the Rose Bowl because, "it was my opinion that Ohio State best met the definition of the "most representative team."

The shells, coming out of nowhere in particular and crashing into humble wood and thatch homes on the edge of town, had their effect. Today hundreds of people piled into buses and Peugeot 404 station-wagon taxis with their pigs, chickens and sewing machines and headed for the safety of Phnom Penh, 22 miles to the east on Route 4.
Saudi Arabia and Algeria, two of the largest Arab oil producers, assured Britain today of continuing petroleum supplies but indicated that further price increases would be imposed worldwide.
Israeli forces remained on full alert on all fronts today, and Israeli officials expressed deep concern about the possibility of a renewal of fighting.

Lee B. Morey, a former the senior partner in the Manhattan law firm of Chadbourne, Parke, Whiteside Wolff, died Wednesday in Tucson, Ariz. He was 80 years old.

Ten reputed members of an organized - crime gang were charged today with five murders and 100 robberies in an indictment that reported such bizarre details of the underworld as gunmen toasting themselves with champagne after a killing and deploying "crash cars" to head off pursuing policemen.
More than 100,000 fish, mostly carp, have died of an unknown pollutant in a 15-mile stretch of the Millstone River in Somerset and Middlesex Counties in the past three weeks.

Frederick Andresen, president of Ski Industries America, warned yesterday that the proposed mandatory Sunday closing of gasoline stations could endanger three-quarters of a million jobs and $2-billion worth of business.

George Welsh, the Navy coach, remembers how George Welsh, the Navy player, felt during the long twoweek drag of preparation prior to the annual Army-Navy football game. He does not want boredom to upset his 1973 Midshipmen.

With some of its most prominent members pointing toward New York and shouting, "We're No. 1," the State Senate voted overwhelmingly here this evening to put the state's moral credit behind the financing of a new sports complex in the Hackensack Meadowlands.

Abraham D. Beame, the quiet and methodical 67-year-old Mayor-elect, has invited 4,000 people to what will be one of the largest inaugural fetes in the city's history-at the Metropolitan Opera House-on Jan. 1, the day he is sworn in as the city's 105th Mayor.

Government scientists announced today the first identification of the virus that causes infectious hepatitis, one of the most important known infectious diseases for which the causative agent has eluded science.

Despite the existence of services aimed at encouraging relief recipients to become selfsufficient, a new city research report said yesterday that the longer people were on welfare the more they depended on it.

The new military rulers of Greece were criticized publicly by two political leaders today for the announcement of plans last night to govern indefinitely by decree until the people were considered ready for elections.

Clifford Irving was ordered paroled from the two-and-ahalf-year prison sentence he is serving for the Howard R. Hughes "auto - biography" hoax, but he won't be released until next Valentine's Day. Feb. 14.
William F. Raskob, former secretary of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., died Tuesday in St. Francis Hospital. He was 90 years old.
President Nixon's former appointments secretary, Dwight L. Chapin, was indicted today on four counts of perjury in the Watergate scandals.
Corporate bond prices registered gains in early afternoon trading yesterday but several issues closed below their best levels of the session.
The two-tiered market in copper futures continued yesterday. The nearby delivery months showed sharp rises, while the distant contracts declined in price on the Commodity Exchange.

Mrs. George A. Culp, the former Jean Fay, associated with the Urban Coalition of New York for the last five years, died in the New York Hospital yesterday. She was 49 years old and lived at 185 West End Avenue.

The director of the Office of Foreign Direct Investments, Robert H. Enslow, said today that the foreign direct investment regulations were being amended to ease year-end compliance problems. He added that the earnings allowable by United States companies would be revised to authorize 60 per cent of the greater of 1972 or 1973 foreign affiliate earnings.

An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation was recovering in a hospital here yesterday after chasing three men who had broken his jaw, capturing two of them and holding them at gunpoint until the police came to his assistance.

The American expatriate who sold a 2,500-year-old Greek vase to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York for about $1-million last year, Robert E. Hecht Jr., has so far stayed out of Italy, although he no longer risks arrest if he returns here.
Secretary of State Kissinger said today that despite reports of a breakdown in the ArabIsraeli military talks, he was still hopeful that a Middle East peace conference would begin next month.

Stutzmann Son Funeral Home, 2000 Hillside Ave. (1/2 ml. east of New Hyde Park Rd.). New Hyde Park, L.P. Service Monday 1;15 P.M. Visiting Sunday 2-5 P.M., 7-10 P.M.

Richard J. Lighthall, who retired in 1963 as a trust officer in the corporate-trust departmeant of the Chemical Bank in New York, died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home today. He was 75 years old and had lived in Sharon and Darien. Conn.
A seven-week strike against the Museum of Modern Art ended yesterday when its professional and administrative workers voted to accept a new 29-month contract.
Leaders of labor unions at Aqueduct, Roosevelt Raceway and Yonkers Raceway met yesterday to formulate plans for job-security negotiations with the Offtrack Betting Corporation.

Consumer buying of apparel, home furnishings and related goods picked up during November, providing retailers with higher gains over the year-earlier month than they had in October, reports from several national leading retail chains indicated yesterday.

Williard M. Bright has been named president and chief operating officer of the Curtiss-Wright Corporation, effective Feb. 1, 1974, and a director, as of yesterday. As president, he will succeed T. Roland Berner, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

President Nixon declined today to meet tomorrow with Governor Rockefeller, Mayor-elect Abraham D. Beame and Nassau County Executive Ralph G. Caso, who are coming here to seek Federal funds to save New York City's 35-cent fare.

A major highway funds scandal is threatening the political future of George C. Wallace at a time when the twotime Governor is fast regaining his health and is reportedly preparing to plunge once again into state and national electioneering.
Because of the oil situation, the United States faces a critical shortage of penicillin, cortisone and other vital drugs, an industry spokesman said yesterday.
The indoor soccer tournament scheduled at Madison Square Garden for tomorrow morning was postponed yesterday until Dec. 22 because of technical difficulties in setting up the arena.

The restaurants reviewed here each Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the author's subjective judgment of quality in relation to the price of meals and the quality of comparable establishments. Roughly, one star may be translated as fair, two stars as good, three as excellent and four as superb.

Americans are preparing for their first Sunday without gasoline stations by planning to fill up today and tomorrow and by buying locks for gas caps to thwart thieves-but otherwise, apparently, without any great change of plans.
Led by Jack Norris, Edmonton goalie, who posted his 10th victory of the season, the Oilers scored a 3-2 victory over the Jersey Knights in a World Hockey Association game tonight.

In 1716 the residents of this city outbid all the other towns in Connecticut for the privilege of having Yale University locate here. But ever since, many of them have been unable to shake the terrible feeling that it was all a mistake and that invitation had turned into imposition.

An intensive recruiting drive supervised directly by Mayor Lindsay's office and focusing on black and Puerto Rican neighborhoods has produced more than 100,000 applicants, the biggest roster for a Civil Service test in city history.

The funeral of Dr. Arthur Courtney Logan filled Riverside Church to the balconies yesterday with friends and associates, the powerful and the ordinary, in tribute to the surgeon and civic activist who was regarded as one of the most influential black men in the city.

The House Judiciary Committee approved the nomination of Gerald R. Ford as Vice President today by a vote of 29 to 8, with one vote of present. Some of the Democrats who voted for confirmation expressed concern over Mr. Ford's conservative voting record, particularly on such issues as civil rights.
Faced with a growing threat of unemployment arising from the energy shortage, the economic authorities of Europe are toning down the measures they were planning to use in the fight against inflation.

Boston's Mayor, Kevin H. White, announced yesterday that, after a two-year study by the Boston Consumers Coun.cil, the city had decided, for an indefinite period, not to issue cable-television franchises.
It will be Stan Smith versus. John Newcombe, and Tom Gorman against Rod Laver tomorrow afternoon in the opening two singles matches of the Davis Cup final between the United States and Australia.
The pro football offering on television for Sunday is a double-header beginning with the Giants at Washington, Channel 2, 1 P.M., and followed by Cleveland at Kansas City, Channel 4, 4 P.M.

Appropriations of capital to expand plant and equipment by the nation's 1,000 largest manufacturers have been increased to a record $11.08-billion in the third quarter, The Conference Board reported yesterday.

The Egyptian-Israeli military talks being held on the Cairo-Suez road broke down in disagreement today, and no date for a new meeting was set. Each side said it had no new proposals to make and could not accept the proposals made previously by the other side, according to authoritative sources.

The National Transportation Safety Board called on aviation authorities yesterday to alert all airlines to "unsafe conditions," including possible improper loading of dangerous chemicals, that could have led to the crash of a cargo jet in Boston on Nov. 3.
Fewer than 100 persons have called the National Broadcasting Company to ask about the New York television blackout of the JetsBaltimore Colts game at Shea Stadium on Sunday.

The Ford Motor Company's subsidiary here has moved about 25 American executives and their families back to the United States in the last two days after receiving guerrilla threats against them, according to company officials and other reliable sources.

A senior Soviet space official disclosed plans today for more Soviet manned space flights--individual Soyuz missions and link-ups of the Soyuz with the Salyut orbital platform--before the joint Soviet-American space mission in 1975.

The White House has told Federal investigators that the life of a foreign intelligence agent inside the Soviet Union would be endangered if a stillsecret "plumbers" operation were disclosed, informed sources said today.

James D. Carroll announced his retirement yesterday. He is the first deputy controller, and people at City Hall have been saying ever since the election that he would be the next Deputy Mayor.

Four teenagers were arrested in Brooklyn last night as part of what the police said was a gang of youths that had been responsible for more than 30 burglaries, fire-bombings and other incidents of vandalism in religious institutions over the last several months in the Sheephead Bay and Gravesend neighborhoods.

Marshal Tito, who will be 82 years old next May 25, opened the door today to the possibility that he might step down as President of Yugoslavia if his physical and mental abilities fell below the level required for the position.

The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it planned to shut down briefly two of the three Chrysler plants where full-size cars are assembled, and that the third plant would be converted to the production of compact cars.
The San Francisco Giants' rightfielder, Bobby Bonds, was arrested early today and charged with interfering with policemen who were trying to give his brother a speeding ticket, Belmont police said.
In ending their 10-week strike Wednesday by ratifying a new three-year contract, The New York Philhannonic musicians fell short of one of their stated major goals, but gained on other fronts.

In a major shift spurred by the energy crisis, Transportation Secretary Claude S. Brinegar said today that the Nixon Administration was moving toward a broader look at mass transit that would include the use of Federal funds for operating subsidies.
A happy group of professional and administrative staff employes walked together into the Museum of Modern Art yesterday morning, bringing to an end a seven-week strike against the museum.

Congressional efforts to finance Presidential elections with public funds rather than large private contributions bogged down today in a parliamentary squabble and the threat of a oneman filibuster in the Senate.

The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations. in the third of a series of statements calling for President Nixon's impeachment, said yesterday that removal proceedings were warranted because Mr. Nixon has "consistently deceived the American people" regarding watergate and related matters.

A 20-year-old student from Hampton Bays, L. I., caught two alleged car thieves yesterday afternoon inside John Jay College of Criminal Justice in mid-Manhattan, where he is studying full-time to become a Suffolk County policeman.

President Nixon's chief of staff, Alexander M. Haig Jr., will testify in Federal Court next week about the circumstances surrounding the discovery of the 18-minute "gap" on one of the subpoenaed Watergate tape recordings.

The Bronx Zoo reported yesterday that it would have to increase admission fees unless government and other funds could be obtained to offset a S600,000 deficit. Its general director, William G. Conway, would not estimate how much of an increase would be necessary, but he emphasized that even if the fees were doubled it would not be enough to make up the losses.

Tom Weiskopf of the United States shot a three-under-par 67 today and was tied for first place with Vince Baker of South Africa with a 206 total after the third round of the South African Professional Golfers' Association tournament. Two strokes behind were two South Africans, Gary Player and Hugh Baiocchi. At 209 was Bobby Verwey of South Africa, followed by Noel Hunt of Britain at 210. Baiocchi shot a course-record 65 today.

The Ford Motor Company joined the General Motor Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation today in announcing layoffs because of parts shortages and a slump in bigcar sales induced by the energy crisis.

Charles O. Finley, owner of the Oakland A's said today he would take Commissioner Bowie Kuhn to court to fight Kuhn's fines of $7,000 and tile probation imposed on Finley as a result of his actions during the World Series.
The number of major cities with "substantial unemployment" of 6 per cent or more declined by one in November to 33 when Waterbury, Conn., was removed from the list, the Labor Department said today.

Harlem's newest "place of peace" and "ray of hope," the $1.6-million James Varick Community Center of the Mother A.M.E. Zion Church, was dedicated yesterday in the presence of four bishops, a score of civic leaders and more than 600 Harlem residents.

John Mahaffey retained the lead in the $150,000 Walt Disney World golf classic with a 54-hole total of 206 today, but Jack Nicklaus was in a challenging group of five trailing the 25year-old Texan by two strokes in second place.
A battalion of Cambodian Government troops was badly bloodied today when it fought its way out of an important, encircled garrison 12 miles east of Phnom Penh.

The Cost of Living Council suspended temporarily today proposed new price increases on 1974 model automobiles. The council said in a statement that it needed more time to review price proposals, which were considered at a public hearing last week.

A "minor to moderate" earthquake was felt in four states early today, hut there were no reports of injury or major damage.

At a time when the securities business is worried about its unprofitability and the absence of individual investors, the Securities Industry Association has selected as its new president the head of a profitable regional concern that does most of its volume with individuals.

The Small Business Administration investigator who audited four businesses headed by Dr. Thomas W. Matthew testified today that one of his superiors in the agency "suggested" that he destroy his 84-page report on the Matthew enterprises and that he refused.

Dr. James A. Var Allen, discoverer of the earth's radiation belts, reported today that data from the Pioneer 10 spacecraft indicated that radiation surrounding Jupiter extended out farther than had been predicted in belts considerably different than earth's.

James W. McCord Jr., sentenced to one-to-five years in prison for his part in the break-in at the Democratic National Committee office, on June 17, 1972, says that the penalties meted out to him and the other Watergate conspirators were "fair and just."

A 34-year-old woman, whose husband and three children are living in Jamaica in the British West Indies, was found yesterday raped and beaten unconscious on the roof of 1710 Carroll Street the six-story building where she lived in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn.
A cheering audience saluted Beverly Sills during and after her performance Wednesday night as the grief-stricken Elvira in the local debut of Bellini's "I Puritani" at the Los Angeles Music Center.

Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that to achieve fuel savings ordered by the Nixon Administration, it would end its shuttle services connecting Newark with Boston and Washington, effective Jan. 7. In addition, it will drop its shuttle service to Montreal, which operates from La Guardia Airport.

Current fuel shortages would not interfere with the United States' ability to make an immediate military response, if necessary, in an international crisis, according to Arthur I. Mendolia, Assistant Secretary of Defense for installations and Logistics.
Three major city and state job programs for welfare recipients here were described yesterday as inadequate to help the 174,000 relief clients the city believes are potentially Employable.
State Insurance Commissioner John Ryan said today that he planned to open hearings next week into the possibility of freezing 1974 auto insurance rates in Massachusetts at their 1973 level.

Benjamin Britten's three "church parables"-he asks that they not he described as operas-constilute a major effort to meld two ancient theatrical traditions: the Japanese No-drama and the medieval Christian mystery or miracle play.

At least three of the nation's leading oil companies disclosed yesterday that they were raising gasoline prices this morning, when motorists are expected to be stocking up in advance of anticipated widespread closing of service stations throughout the country.

Policemen using water cannons and clubs broke up a street demonstration today by relatives of Israeli war prisoners and missing soldiers. The protesters, carrying placards and shouting, had demanded a meeting with Prime Minister Golda Meir.

It's a long stretch from the Kraushaar Galleries, 1055 Madison Avenue at 80th Street, to Acts of Art at 15 Charles Street, near Seventh Avenue South in Greenwich Village. But if you can make it, both galleries have rewarding collage exhibitions, Fred Laros's at Kraushaar and James Denmark's at Acts of Art.

Assets of private pension funds in 1972 rose about 18 per cent above the 1971 level, it was indicated yesterday in the annual summary of the pension-fund management survey conducted by Standard Poor's/InterCapital, Inc.

Motorists planning to travel during the weekend should have a clear idea of how far they plan to travel, the range of their cars on a tank of gasoline and how they will handle emergency breakdowns, highway officials warned yesterday.

The police said yesterday that a 33-year-old man had shot and killed an acquaintance during an early-morning argument, put the body in a wooden crate, and then put the crate, covered with garbage, in front of the building where he lived, to be picked up by sanitationmen.
A Federal judge acquitted Charles Pfizer Co., the American Cyanamid Company and the Bristol-Myers Company yesterday of conspiracy and of monopolizing the market for broad-spectrum antibiotics.
Word is quietly spreading from the special Watergate prosecutor's office that if the White House hated Archibald Cox, it will detest Leon Jaworski.

An escaped convict from Norfolk state prison was shot to death today by an offduty patrolman after he held a family hostage for 26 hours, the police said.

Secretary of Defense James R. Schlesinger said today that the Administration would propose development of a new series of strategic weapons as insurance against the possible failure by the United States and the Soviet Union to agree to further limitation of their nuclear arsenals.

The State Board of Public Utilities Commissioners has approved the $4.9-million sale of 207 acres of land in the Port Reading area of Woodbridge by the Port Reading Railroad Company to Public Service Electric Gas Company. Although the township is opposed to the sale, the P.U.C. said the transaction would help pay off debts of the bankrupt Reading Railroad, the parent company.

James G. Vermillion, retired master of St. George's School, died today at his home in Middletown. He was 73 years old.

Unishops, Inc., a chain store organization with a volume of more than $200-million annually, filed a petition yesterday for an arrangement with its creditors under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

Congressional efforts to finance Presidential elections with public funds rather than large private contributions bogged down tonight in a parliamentary squabble and the threat of a one-man fiibuster in the Senate.

Tom Weiskopf of the United States shot a three-under-par 67 today and was tied for first place with Vince Baker of South Africa with a 206 total after the third round of the South African Professional Golfers' Association tournament. After a weak opening, soybean future prices on the Chicago Board of Trade rallied yesterday. The movement came mostly on the news of a shortage of hexane, which is used as a solvent in the crushing process that reduces the beans to oil and high-protein meal.

In the exhibition of recent sculpture by William King that opened this week at the Terry Dintenfass Gallery, 18 East 67th Street, we are offered a multitude of miniature grotesques. There are 14 bronzes and 34 ceramics, all quite small and all devoted to figures or heads.

Comet Kohoutek's approaching rendezvous with planet earth during the Christmas holidays is causing no particular alarm. In 1910, people all over the world fell into states of anxiety or outright panic as they nervously awaited the arrival of Halley's comet.

Sliding steadily from the opening bell, prices on the American Stock Exchange closed sharply lower yesterday in slightly higher trading. Prices also fell in the over-thecounter market in slackened trading.
Charles S. Kee, "mayor" of Chinatown and former assistant city housing commissioner, was sentenced to six months in jail yesterday for his role in shaking down a provisional city employe.
Adolfo Ruiz Cortines, President of Mexico from 1952 to 1958, died here today of a heart attack at the age of 82.
The major leagues modified their rule against the spitball today in an effort to encourage enforcement of it. They put the issue up to the umpires' judgment.

Patients who have kidney transplants in small American hospitals are twice as likely to die as those who have the same operation at larger medical centers, according to a report published yesterday in the Journal of the American Medical Association.

Victor Yoran made his New York debut Sunday night at Carnegie Recital Hall but he had played here before. Mr. Yoran first attracted attention a couple of years ago as a Russian Jew who was playing here to attract attention to his efforts to persuade the Soviet authorities to let his family join him in Israel.

A lineman will never again win the Heisman Trophy, according to Leon Hart, the Notre Dame end and team captain in 1949 who was the second and last lineman to win this annual award as "the outstanding intercollegiate football player in the United States."

The United States said today that it expected Egypt and Israel to resume military talks on troop disengagement later this week, leading to a full-scale Middle East peace conference in Geneva on Dec. 18.

The tournament trend in recent years has been toward youth, but the veterans make their presence felt from time to time. The Winter Regional Swiss Team Championship, played Sunday at the New York Hilton Hotel, was won by the oldest team in the event.

PARIS--An encyclopedia that makes people uncomfortable? That doesn't pretend to know it all? That raises many more questions than it answers? That is what the guiding forces behind "The Encyclopedia of the Future" want to accomplish.

The volume of help-wanted ads increased in October, signaling a further dip in the unemployment rate, according to the Conference Board. The seasonally adjusted help-wanted advertising index stood at 122 in October (1967 equals 100), 2 points above September's reading and 13 points ahead of its year-earlier level, the private research organization reported. The index measures the volume of classified advertising in 52 major newspapers. Its movements often precede actual changes in the unemployment picture.

President Nixon's troubles with newsmen are negligible compared with what Zeus had to endure. Some idea of the Olympian's difficulties with the media may be gleaned from a fragment of an ancient press briefing, the text of which is reprinted here in its entirety.
